Julie says.  .  too hoppy she gives a 2.7. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Brown color with a ample tan head. Aroma is malty. Taste is malty sweet with a subtle hop finish.

At Bir&Fud pub in Rome-Italy, on tap. Pours dark brown (almost black) with reddish texture and a decent and compact ivory head. Nose is definitely sweet: cappuccino, chocolate, warm milk. The mouth mirrors practically the aroma with a predominant presence of dark chocolate.
caramel, nuts, roasty, resin, leather, alcohol, licorice, bread, clove, red, brown, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, creamy, lively, average carbonation,

355ml bottle. Pours a deep ruby chestnut, verging on black, with a large light beige head, which lasts very well and leaves good lacing. Sweet treacle and toffee notes mix with nutty malt and floral and spice hops to create the aroma. Strong grapefruit and floral hops up front are tempered by treacle sweetness, which builds into the mid-palate, where it plays nicely off savoury, nutty malt. Treacle sweetness and mild floral hops combine in the finish. A very nice brown ale, with a good balance of sweetness and hoppiness.

Bottle to glass. Pours a very dark brown with minimal head. Aroma is very malty, with hints of raisin. Mouth is very smooth and moderately thick. Taste is sweet, malty, and very well balanced. A great brown.
Bottle. Clear brown pour with a light frothy tan head. Lots of burnt malts, brown sugar, caramel, some exotic fruits, raisins and biscuits.

Bottle. Pours a deep chocolate, almost black with a thin brown head. Aroma of molasses and caramel. Taste has a good brown sugar or molasses tsar with a typical IPA finish. Good diversion from your typical IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle. Hazy dark burgundy with a foamy tan head. Flavors are molasses, maple syrup, cocoa powder, caramel and roasted malts with nutty and herbal notes. Medium body, soft carbonation, sticky texture.

Pours dark brown with a massive head.
Nose shows chocolate, toasty and nutty malt with a bit of brown sugar and treacle too. Some soft spicy hops.
Similar flavours, mainly focusing on the nutty and toasty malt. Again theres note all that much in terms of hops, just some spicy and earthy notes. A fairly aggressive bitterness though.
Nice creamy carbonation.
12 ounce bottle. Pours reddish brown with a nice beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruit, and grass. Taste is malt, caramel, fruit, spice, chocolate, and grass. Superb.

Dark brown pour with dark tank head. Strong roasted malt aroma, some chocolate aroma as well. Flavor is caramel malt, some chocolate malt too. Finish is hoppy bitter and roasted malt. As the finish fades there is a lingering roasted malt flavor. Nice beer all around.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddy brown with a tan head. Slightly nutty, toasty, caramel aroma. Medium body, medium carbonation. Lots of toffee, hazelnut, lemon, pine, coke, light dark fruit, wood... Too much toffee going on for me, still tasty though.
Really dark brown to black, off white small head, aroma of caramel and molasses, flavours of caramel, malts and spice, creamy body finishing with a mild bitter aftertaste, very good brown ale

Solid. Aroma of caramel, wine, maybe a bit of cinnamon. Tastes the same with a light sour aftertaste that isnt overwhelming. The cinnamon taste lingers. Could do without the sour but overall a great showing.

DATE REVIEWED: August 8, 2014... GLASSWARE: Barley Creek pint... OCCASION: Watching Return of the King with a worthy beer... APPEARANCE: Wow--allows a look through its body only when held to light--glass is black as a Wraith; the head is two-fingered, off-white and thick.. AROMA: wonderfully balanced: hoppy and citric, with raisin and plum, yet toasted with biscuit... the malts predominate, with a hint of roasted nuts and caramel--intense and robust ... PALATE: thick, creamy, and rather soft in ts carbonation--that classic cola mouth feel; slightly bitter at its end ... TASTE: the aroma sets this beers flavor, as dense, blanketed hops give way to unsweetened chocolate and toasted rye bread--a wondrously stout yet drinkable brown, that only hints at the alcohol it wields... OVERALL: what a drink with which to welcome crisp fall nights--strong, stern and warming, yet balanced, complex and highly drinkable...another victory for Sam and the guys at DFH...
Very nice brown ale. Hop heavy but still has a nice dose of roast. Pours mahogany with mocha head and lacing. Medium bitter finish with a light note of dark chocolate. Bottle thanks to the roommate.

This is a beer that has such a hoppy front with the most flavor on the back. The malt character, the roastyness and all the sweet caramel and smooth flavor just really makes this a favorite of mine. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Brown pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of caramel, bready yeast, spicy and brown sugar. Flavor is quite bitter, spicy and with a decent body. Well balanced. More like a Belgian Dubbel.

Draft. Aroma is a danker hop with some dry chocolate malt. Appearance is a darker brown, with some tan lacing. Taste is a darker brown ale that ends with lots of dank hops at the end. Palate is dark and hoppy. Overall, a good beer. Will buy again and again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
355 ml bottle. Pours a deep brown colour with generous tan head. Aroma is molasses, coffee, roasted malts, caramel. Taste is molasses, caramel, malts. Creamy. Pretty good.
Nice deep brown clear poor with lasting fluffy white head. Aroma of roast and mollases. Taste is bitter sweet with the mollases coming through strongly. Enjoyable beer.

Bottle, 10C. Clear deep brown with a beige head that laces well. Aroma is malty and spicy with some figs and sultanas. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation. Fairly sweet with enough bitterness that it doesnt seem that rich. Chocolate, sticky breadcrusts, light spices. Wholesome and harmonious.
Pours a dark brown with a foamy, long-lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet brown sugar and caramel. Flavor is caramel malts with a little bit of bitter hops. Quite good.
Draft. Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are brown sugar, caramel, and pine.

At cellar temperature and into a snifter. Had no idea what to expect of style so a cool temperature seemed apt. Deepest, darkest brown and opaque with a fine, tight bead and a thin pad of sandy cream atop. Big waft of cocoa and rpasted carob dominates the nose with minor licks of tangerine, cola and root beer, burnt toast and burnt, savoury raisins. Creamy mouthfeel, velvety even. Rounded, sumptuous body with a smooth finish. Chocolate malts dominate here as the nose. A tannic, dark berry note in back gives it a fruity element and then it is all dusty cocoa powder, carob and chocolate icecream in the finish. Light rust and blood, a higher, heated alcohol kick and plenty of wood and peanut husks in the aftertaste give it complexity. This is a nice brew. More Brown ale than Scotch ale and by no means showing any inkling of IPA. Great drinking though! (12fl.Oz, Bottled on 05/07/14, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)

12 fl. oz. bottle. Pours a dark red brown with a very thin, short lived, light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate and liquorice. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, brown sugar, dark chocolate and liquorice with a bitter, hoppy finish. Full body with a creamy, oily texture and soft carbonation.
Agree with the malty and hoppy taste. Didn't get much nose. Nice beer. Smooth on the palate.
Favorite Dogfish Head so far. Easier to drink than an IPA but still packs a ton of (slightly sweet) flavor.

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale has a very thick, crackly-sounding, beige head, a dark brown (with lighter, ruby-brown highlights), and heavy lacing left behind. The aroma is of sweet, dark bread crust, nuts, and malt. Taste is of a noticeable charred roastiness, sweet brown bread crust, some nut, licorice, and dark-roasted malt. Bitterness is there, and it increases. Mouthfeel is medium, and Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale finishes semi-dry, not very alcoholic, and easy drinking. RJT
Brown pour from a 12oz bottle. Slight white head. Roasted malt and slight coffee nose. Big malty beer with some big hops. Quite nice!

Now this. This my friends is a brown ale. For me, it is right there with Bells which I think is about as good a brown ale as it comes.
A deep rubby brown beer with a thick creamy tan head that lingers through my tasting process.
Smells of sweet carmalized roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.
Rich roasted, burnt malt taste, sweet. Coffee essence follows and chocolate brings up the rear.
No distinct flavor in the hops.
This is a full body beer with some alcohol warming on finish.
This is an excellent fall beer that compliments both English styles very well and the autumn season itself.
Drink well my friends
Dog fish head India brown ale from rome. Dark red brown ale, decent off white head. Liquorice and earthy on the nose. Taste is surprisingly sweet with a mild bitterness.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance: slight khaki brown head, dark brown color/ black, clear, light lacing, film persists. Aroma: roast coffee, bourbon, chocolate, molasses, floral, light fruit, grass, Palate: medium full body, average carbonation, light bitter lasting finish, oily texture. Taste: sweet malt to light fruit sweetness that lasts a bit, then into a subtle bitterness that build to mild bitterness. Overall, very smooth, very drinkable, unique and surprisingly simple.
Bottle at the hotel in Key Wes, FL. Dark brown body with a medium offwhite head. Hops, caramel, nuts, malt, burnt sugar. Soft carbonation. Delicious "IBA"
355ml bottle from Archive Beer Boutique. Rating from April 2013. Sweetness in the aroma is contrasted by some bitterness in the flavour. Well brewed malty brown ale with a boozy finish.

355ml bottle from Saveur Biere


Colour like a coca cola with a light brown head. Malty aroma with some chocolate. Malty sweet flavour with chocolate, raisins and cocoa. Nice!

Aromas of caramel, raw maple, milk chocolate, earthy hops, coffee. Clear, dark ruby-brown with a fully lasting beige head. Off-dry, maltiness upfront, savory, earthy nutty flavors, finishes with well-balanced hops. Medium bodied, with cleansing carbonation.

Dark body, thin tan head. Very sweet aroma with raisins and molasses. Mouthfeel is really smooth. Taste is a bit hollow and theres not much else besides a slightly bitter IPA aftertaste. Its very drinkable though but probably better paired with some food. By itself its a bit of a letdown for me.
Tap at brewery. Copper pour with a white head. Citrus, caramel, deal berries, grapefruit a and pine. A nice balance of sweetness, roast, fruitiness and ipa bitterness. A very nice beer

Bottle from saveur-biere.com. Dark copper to brown body, with a big, creamy, beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate, nuts, caramel, roast, dark berries, citrus, some pine. Taste with about the same aromas, great balance between roasty, sweet, fruity and bitter citric notes and very smooth! Mouthfeel is medium to full, creamy, with a medium carbonation and it finishes roasty, bitter, with dark malt and citric hop notes. Tasty! A really unique brown ale, that also resembles a Black IPA a bit, because of the greatly balanced roast and citrus notes. Very smooth to drink.

One of my favs. Aroma is brown sugar, pine, and dark fruits. Pours deep mahogany with a nice thick small head. Taste is nice and dark with roast nuts, brown sugar, sweet pine resin, and a nice bitter dark fruits. A truly nice ale.
Dark brown in color with a mahogany head. Delicious caramel and chocolate on the nose. Great beer that could be drank again and again.
Bottle. Color brown color with average white head. Aroma malty, roasted, caramel, licorice. Flavor sweet and bitter, caramel, coffee.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2016 Tap initially (rerated 01/15 from a 10/15 bottle). Pours a dark brown with a nice creamy head. Aroma is sugar, dark fruits (raisins maybe?) malts, and some hops. Flavor is a nice malty roasted sweet flavor with lots of coffee and some hops too. Flavor is hoppy but definitely pronounced maltiness Creamy kind of like a nitro beer. Awesome awesome balance. Really good, this. Similar to a black ipa. DFH does well here.

Reviewed from notes. 
Ive had this in pint glasses and a couple times in tulips. Its always the same. 
The appearance was a nice dark brown color with a decent one finger white foamy head that dissipates within about a minute and left some light semi - thick lacing in its wake. 
The smell was awesome as it had a super nice allocation of the Scottish peat - like smokey/roasty malts to the engraving bittersweet citrus hops to delightfully entice my nose to partake in more whiffs to get some light roasty caramel nuttiness about it.
The taste replicates the smell pretty much exactly the same.
On the palate, this one sits about a medium. The carbonation seems appropriately made for the style and shows a decent smoothness about it.
Overall, what an absolutely amazing beer - three styles in one and well done. Makes me want to move back East.
Bottle. Pours dark brown. Nose is powdered chocolate and coffee. Taste is chocolate and bitter coffee.

I am a big fan of dogfish and they always seem to come out with good stuff! This is complex but still easy to drink!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pour. The bottle reviewed has a good 6 months on it, so not exactly fresh. However, the malty scotch ale notes really shine through here. Muted hops, as to be expected, but the roasted backbone is very enjoyable. Coffee and english toffee undertones with a definite sugary feel. Has a caramel note to the aroma. This is a complex, easy drinking yet eminently powerful brown ale. So much going on in here yet nothing is muddled. Would love to try this against a fresh bottle to see how the hopper element sits here but I can say that with 6 months of aging this is a delicious beer.
Malty. Caramel, toffee and chocolate flavors blended with brown sugar and spice. Notes of dark fruits, ginger root and cinnamon. Good carbonation.
Great ale. Flavor is a nice malty roast. Aroma is light. Smooth on the palate with a light aftertaste.

A swell dark leathery murk with an off white head came out of the tap. A dry earthy and smokey chocolate, like raw cocoa nibs accounts for a lot of nose and taste. Everything about this beer is brown. Brown sugar, mud, burnt brownies, cigars. The kind of brown you want to take downtown and pound while making clown sounds. Loved it.
Pours a dark cola color. Thin off-white head that goes away quickly. Aroma is malty and sugary Flavor is all over the map...malty, roasty, sugary, molasses and a nice bitter balance.

From BA review on 2-5-12 - 
Poured from bottle into pint glass.

Appearance  Pours a deep-brown color. Upon pouring there is a billowy tan head which forms which slowly fades over time to produce some nice lacing and a very thin persistent foam film on the top of the brew.

Smell  A huge caramel aroma meets the nose. While overwhelming at first, it gives away a bit, revealing aromas of roasty malt and a bit of nuttiness and some alcohol.

Taste  A semi-sweet malt flavor first hits, which seems to sweeten over time giving way to a very caramely flavor and some brown sugar. A roasted malt flavor with nice toasted nut and a little bit of of coffee flavors round out the taste, leaving a rather satisfying taste in the mouth.

Mouthfeel  The thicker body suits this beer quite nice. Mixed with the slightly linger carbonation it allows the brew to linger on the tongue; creating a very nice mouthfeel. 

Overall  This is one very nice beer. While not the most potent, the sweet maltiness mixed with the thicker mouthfeel and roasty flavor make this a great brew to sit and sip slowly over a relaxing evening.
Bottle - Nutty flavor, malt and a little bit of hops on this one. Kind of a woody taste as well. While it does have a high alcohol content, it doesn't taste of alcohol.

Bottle to tumbler. Pours deep red. Two finger head, nice lacing. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, black barley. Tastes nice bitter, with sweetness in the back. Full body, moderate carbonation, slightly creamy. Finishes candied sugar, more coffee and chocolate followed by nice long bitterness.
Awesome stuff!

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 Bottle (12 oz): comes in six packs. Very nice brown ale that is a regular in my frig.

Smokey taste with a slight scotch finish.

6/21/14: Dropped the rating slightly after a few more.  The smokey taste is sometimes almost burnt.  Coffee taste also present.

Flaske, 355 ml. Mahognybrun. Maltet næse. Sødlig opvaskevand. Letristet malt. Brød. Chocolade. Ikke dårlig eller ublanceret, men vil alt for meget på een gang - ofte et problem med Dogfish Head. Kedelig prog-øl.

Excellent brew. Has a sweet, malty aroma with a slight hint of hops. Great color brown that is as clear as brown can get. The flavor slowly creeps across your toungue and leaves a light bitter finish.

Draft at Belmont Station. While I despise the IPA label being reassigned to any hoppy beer from red to brown, I am willing to forgive Dogfish Head both due to their brewing excellence and the fact that despite the pale in IPA it historically most likely resembled the blood-red brown of this beer, Carmel-colored with thick head and dark lace. Alcohol, dark berries, and earthy hops in the nose, thick and slightly-cloying mouthfeel with rich malt, alcohol esters, and back-tongue bitterness in the middle, and eatery-fruity malt and satisfying bitterness at the end, finishing in malt rather than citrus or astringent. Excellent example of a historical IPA, regardless of label.
Brown in color. Aroma of hops and roasted malt. Interesting mix. Taste is fruity and caramel. Slightely bitter aftertaste
Dark with slight head. Sweet aroma. Reminds me of a coffee stout. Not quite a true scotch ale, but not bad.

Bottle shared at the daje reaches 2000 ratings session
Pours dark brown with a big tanned head. Smell of caramel, burnt sugar, some dusty hops and dark malts. Medium sweet, burnt sugar and caramel, some spices and hints of dark fruits. Moderate bitter finish. A very nice take on the brown ale style

Americans, they have revitalized so many beers over the years, youre forgiven if you forget to mention the Brown Ale in all the "confusion". A lovely brown with a brown sugar type malt, meeting loads of hops, this is so well balanced and clever, it scares me away from ever daring to try brewing myself. If I had made this, Id named it after that most amazing of bands, Rolling Stones masterpiece, Brown Sugar.

Pours a clear, but very dark garnet brown with a full rocky light tan head. Aroma is coffee and bitter chocolate. Taste is big but well balanced, with sweet caramel malt, coffee, chocolate, molasses and a nice hoppiness that is not too bitter. Good effort.

Brown color with a little bit of foam. Aromas of malt, burned caramel and hazelnut. Taste of caramel, hazelnut, malt and hop bitterness. Couleur brune avec un peu de mousse. Arômes de malt, caramel brûlé et noisette. Saveurs de caramel, noisette, malt et amertume de houblon.
Nice hoppy aroma. Dark roasty malt and caramel flavors. The big hop flavors work perfectly with the dark malts. Really great beer.
Interesting brew, hints of alcohol on the nose, some kind of residual sweetness, lively carbonation, nice head, enjoyable brew....like

On tap at dogfish head Smooth easy drinking brown.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Kihoskh shared with esp0r and edvard, april 26th 2014. Dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma of burned malt, fruity hops, chocolate. Taste is light roasted with thick caramelized malt, flowery oand fruity hops, and quite high bitterness.

Bottle from Sugaya. It pours a rich ruby brown that looks somewhat stout like in the glass butappearance wise Id say is closer to a Belgian dark ale like a Rochefort 8 or 10. The nose is soft chocolate & toffee with a citrusy hop presence - pretty good. The beer has a medium body & a somewhat syrupy mouthfeel. The taste is quite good, roasty, cacao paste, figs, bitter coffee grinds & playing with these malt flavors are some candy sweetness & citrusy hops. Pretty good but Belgians do it better.

This dark chocolate colored beer pours a thick tan head that lingers. It has a nutty aroma with a hint of burnt sugar. The taste is reminiscent of the same and with the rich malted barley and high IBU from the dry hops it is nutty, sweet, and bitter all at once. The alcohol is high enough that it really becomes prominent as the beer comes to room temperature, so drink this one quickly.

Clear medium rubyish brown. Large frothy creamy tan head, partly lasting. Aroma is quite malty. Burnt roasty malty. Molasses. Nutty. Chocolate. Caramel. Coffee. Flavor is dusty cocoa mostly. Earthy hops. Medium body. Dry. Medium creamy. Lightly acidic. Mild bitterness. Roasty dry finish. Complex and still easy drinking. Puts the typical brown ale to shame.

Sweet malt, chocolate, dark roast, dark fruit, roasty aroma. Caramel, some hops. 
Medium body, roast, chocolate, caramel, molasses, hops, a slight bitter finish.
Pours brown with a dark brown head. Aroma is chocolate, nutty, and caramel. Flavor is bitter with a nice nutty chocolate finish. Great brown.

pours cola brown with a medium tan head. aroma is malty and bready. Taste is full rich malty caramel. definite coffee notes. slight bitterness and hop presence on the finish. nice fading linger. Really good beer!

Pint glass, brown with a finger tan head. Smells like molasses, caramel, and brown sugar. Tastes like roast nuts, molasses, and nice caramel malt. Oily, medium mouthfeel. Pretty tasty!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Another winner from Dogfish Head. Dark brown in color. The hops play off nicely with the caramel. Not over hopped.
quasi scura nocciola buona schiuma discreta persistenza leggera uva buona secchezza note tostate discreto amaro alcol piuttosto nascosto

Shared bottles over the course of month during a beer march madness bracket style tournament held by Louisville Dads Beer Club, this style buster came in 3rd of 32 beers with its hoppy aroma, beautiful color, vanilla molasses tobacco vanilla tastes and pleasant finish...as this was a secret competition, we were surprised when this was in the final 4! Well deserved...

Bottle. Impressive overall. Hoppy aroma. Dark brown color. Very nice balance of hops and caramel. Similar to Samuel Adams Boston Ale, but with more pronounced hop flavors. Slightly bitter finish. Very drinkable; belies its relatively high ABV.
Wow, very surprised. When they say cross between brown and scotch ale, they mean it. nice caramel, sweetness, alcohol, medium roast malts. A delight to drink.
sweet nuts aroma,brown, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, nice nuts light bitter finish.

Dark brown coloured. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Malty aroma, roasted bread and faint nutty notes. Flavor starts sweet, hazel-nuts, moderate bitter finish. Creamy texture, a bit astringent.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2014 12oz bottle poured into DFH signature glass. Pours a dark brown, small head that slowly disappeared, Lots of tiny bubbles rising to the top. Great aroma whatever it is, and that what ever it is is how it tastes. Its a little too cold right now but I remember drinking this on the 4th of July before the left Wisconsin for a few years ago, and I remember the taste of nuts jumped out and was delicious. Im hoping to relive that flavor again, Not thick or thin ale, does that make it a tweener? Overall this seems like a beer you always have on hand as a go to beer when you need it, Really good.

355 ml bottle from Tanakaya @ Mejiro. Pours dark brown with a thin beige layer of foam. Aroma is quite soft with subdued milky roast and some lenient hops. Feels surprisingly fresh actually. Taste feels hoppy, not so bitter but flavourful, mixed with roasted malts and molasses. Chocolate and nuts. Quite smooth mouthfeel, ending up in a long and dry aftertaste with a lingering roast. Nice beer, could actually drink quite a lot of it and not get tired of it.
Nice brown color, with a light tan head. Taste of light molasses and caramel, but totally overshadowed by the floral and citrusy hops. Also a little thin on the palate. Not a bad beer, but not great.
Bottle. Garnet with a beige head. Deep, chocolaty malt aromas. Smooth, malty and a bit tart with a chocolate finish.
Draught at eataly, Rome. Very hoppy brown ale. Licorice and honey at nose. Cream head, persistent. Dark brown color. Molasses in mouth at first, followed and balanced by a hoppy and bitter end.
Served on-tap, this pours a dark brown color with a slight beige head. The taste is malty like you would expect brown a brown ale but has a nice bitter bite to it.

From 355 ml bottle. Pours a clear but deep mahogany brown with some reddish highlights at the edges and a fluffy off-white head. Aromas of caramel, leather, raisins, plums, tobacco and cocoa. Taste starts out with raisins and apple, before a rich roast bitterness in the mid-palate. Caramel, malt, smoke and chocolate at the end. Dry finish with some fruit and spice in the aftertaste. A brown ale thats a cut above. Great stuff.
Bière un peu trop foncé et un peu trop caramélisée a mon goût. Selon la description sur la bouteille, je mattendais a une bière plus houblonnée. Pas mauvais, mais aurait pu être mieux

Poured from bottle into glass at The Cellar. Served a bit too cold, but pours a rich brown, minimal head that is just off-white. Aroma is soft and malty, caramel, toast, and a touch of hops. Taste is malty with a touch of bitterness. Some caramel, biscuit, and toast.

From YNWA bottleshop, Dk.
Bottled, 150214.
Borwn with beige head. Aroma of malt and bread. Flavor with caramel and some dried fruit.

3/1/14. 
With Michelle. 
Single bottle. 
At my parents' house. 
I really like the actual taste of this beer but I wouldn't want to drink more than one due to the uniqueness of the overall experience. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is everything a full bodied brown ale should be. Nice sweet roasty taste with a roasty but clean finish. Heavy mouthfeel and nice dark color. Almost Perfect.
Very nice toasty brew very well balanced. Toast and hoppyness make this a nice go to beer.
Bottle. Very nice dark Brown Body with tan head. Aroma is slightly roasted malts caramel coffee. Taste is caramel cocoa and some malts. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Very nice one.
Dunkelbraunes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch nach Kaffee, Karamell. Geschmack sehr röstmalzig, Kaffee, leicht bitterer Abgang.

Btl pours clear dark reddish brown,with a tan pillowy head. Lingers forever leaving wicked lace on glass. Smells of roasted malt,molasses,raisins,earthy spices,a hint of brown sugar,piney hops with a faint wisp of alcohol.Tastes of sweet caramel malt,latte, chocolate covered raisins,coffee,a little booze and a mild citrus flavor.Medium body, smooth creamy texture, nice,soft carbonation, mild hop bitterness and dry finish. Fantastic brown ale with complex flavors that keep your tongue busy. This is not an average brown. A unique and interesting take on the style, the different malts and sugar meld perfectly with the hops producing a highly drinkable beverage. I like browns and this is one of my favorites.
(Bottle 22 /02-2014) Low beige head, dark brown color, caramel aroma, soft co2, fit body, rather smooth taste. Bottled 06/08/13.

This beer is not my cup of beer (??!!??) ; however, I can still tell that it is a quality brew and those that like this style will love it. Its very aromatic (I didnt realize it had an ABV of 7.2 but I guess thats a selling point), and highly reminiscent of an IPA (I hate IPAs so that explains my skewed rating for which I apologize). Still it has a nice medium body, aspects of coffee and chocolate, and (because it is IPA-like) becomes bitter almost immediately. That intensifies and continues throughout the sip. I think 50 IBUs is 100% higher than my cut-off. Enjoy pale ale drinkers !

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2014 Bottle. At THE Hotel. Sweet roasted malts and brown sugar on the nose. Sweet throughout with some bitter notes in the long dry finish: medium mouth with slightly soft carbonation. Interesting twist on the traditional brown.

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Clear dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dark fruit and chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 050214
Bottle, 7.2%. Dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, chocolate, little nut and hop. Flavour is malt, caramel, nuts, chocolare, medium sweet, hop and a little bitter.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, coffee, little hops. Flavor is malty, chocolate, caramel, little dark fruit, little hops. Medium body, lively carbonation. 050214
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, nuts, roast malt, bitter hops, little flowers and has a bitter finish.
Draft. Sugar and slight hop in the nose. Bitter burnt sugar and a bit of hop bitterness is most prevalent to me . Not bad.

Pen & Paper Log (Feb 2011)

Aroma - is sweet, full of raisin, caramel, dark malts, and roast.
Appearance - The body is dark brown with minimal head
Taste - the taste is very rich with caramel malt at the same time its hoppy. Rich sugar is also prominent. Alcohol is also evident
Palate - the body is medium to heavy, the texture sticky, the carbonation soft, the finish is full of alcohol and sweetness but also bitterness.

Too strange to me. Kind of like a Scotch Ale or a Doppelbock, both styles Im not a big fan of.

12oz bottle bottled 09/27/13
Pours a deep bronze body, slight clarity, holds a beige head.
Quite a pungent aroma; treacle, dark brown sugar, wholemeal bread dough, roast malt huskiness, chocolate, touch of espresso even.
Full bodied yet much leaner than abv would suggest. Reasonably lively carbonation.
Palate continues with dry burnt caramel notes, husky chocolate malt graininess, bit of spiciness (rye?), hint of hop citrus. Moderate bitterness to finish, lingering husky maltiness.
Pretty tasty malty ale. Really dont realise how strong it is until the bottle is finished..
Looks like a porter. Nice head that dissipates to a ring around the glass. Nutty, syrup malts, slight bitter hop on the nose. Kinda tastes like a sweet porter to me. A pretty good beer.

Clear brown pour. Chocolate coffee and nut aroma, with a bit of hops too. Taste is coffee and nut, with bitter and very dry hop finish. Gets better as it warms, a bit sweeter too, making it more scotch ale-like. Solid.

Opaque cola red-black with barely any head or lacing. Smells of raisin, nuts, coffee, burnt malt, a little sour. Taste is same as aroma plus hoppiness, which is nice. Ends on sharp dry note. Body had a little bit of slickness but still crisp. Good brown ale. Definitely wouldn't mind having again but wouldn't rush out to get it either.
Pours a foamy deep reddish brown with a thin lasting head, malt aroma with a hint of nut. Coffee and burnt caramel flavor on the back of the palette, I really like it.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Dark red amber. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma, Burned plastic notes. Moderate bitter harsh not pleasent flavor. Moderate bitter average finish. Oily palate. Big disapointment.
Smooth and very pleasant to taste, it lacks a bit of power, a peak somewhere during the sip or right afterwards. Perfect body, right appearance.

Bottle from Gendarmenmarkt Berlin. Brown, coarsely foam, with an almost black, ember color.

Bitter chocolate, burned malts, toffee, almost stoutlike aromas. 

Malty beginning, hints of sweet toffee soon overwhelmed by a more breadish taste of malt going along with a sligthly sweetened chocolate. Hoppy bitterness brings in even more complexity, goes well along with the upcoming coffee flavor. Kicks in late, gives the malt aromas much time to develop. Bitterness adds a floral taste to the beer, which pairs up well with the malty body which dominates throughout.
Coffee aftertaste is very present, staying long on the tongue. Surprisingly it isnt very bitter, but leaving a smooth dry mouthfeel.
This is a very interesting and enjoyable beer, reminds me somehow of the "Schumacher 1838er", while being a little more aggressive on the hops.
This is about as good as a brown ale gets in my opinion, complexity along with a smooth delivery great scent and looks its part as a brown ale, I have a feeling I will drink this a few more times :)

Opened the bottle and the smell of it bursts with caramelized sugar and malt. Tastes sweet but malted and balanced with a crisp hop bite in the front but mid and finish go down smooth like a brown ale. Caramel finish doesnt last long but it is easy drinkin

355 ml. bottle. Dark brown colour with an uneven, bubbly, tanned head. Sweet and fruity aroma with caramel, toast, resin, grass, citrus, faint liquorice and coffee. Taste is sweet. Medium body with a creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes roasted with a heavy malt presence. An interesting fusion of styles.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2014 I really like Brown Ales and IPAs, so I thought, "This should be good". Not sure what to think now I am drinking it. Some sweet, charred, hops and other aromas I cannot place. Poured nice, dark with very little off white head. Starts crisp, slightly sweet, charred malt, smoke and ends with a charred, bitter hop, heavy taste. I do like it
Dark brown body, medium sized light tan head, spotty lacing. Roast, raisin, caramel, nuts, earthy hops, a bit metallic. Medium bodied, carbonation is a bit rough, lingering finish.
Looks like just another brown ale but packs a nice hop punch to balance the sweet and malt notes.

Pours dark brown with a thinner khaki head that settles to a ring and leaves some spotty lace. Nose involves nutty chocolate, perfumey herbal hops, some woodsy notes, refreshing floral notes. Quite sweet, fairly bitter. Medium body, fair action, a touch oily, a bit creamy, with a lingering bitter finish. A nice brew, crisp, plenty flavorful yet drinkable.

Pretty good, almost a porter with its roastiness and coffee aroma but also very typically hopped in true DFH style. I don't usually drink browns but I enjoyed this one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Two finger thick brown head black beer. Smell is sweet and metallic. Taste is bitter molasses and espresso. Mouthfeel is smooth with medium carbonation. Overall good but maybe not for me.
Bottle at cafe tu tu tango, orlando. Clear dark reddsih brown color, smooth beige head. Aroma is roasty, caramel, honey, some coffee. Nice balanced body, roasty, sweet, caramels, suryp. Excellent.

A nice smokey flavored brown ale from dogfish head. Very bitter an has a nice coffee flavor. Pours a dark brown. Had this at Mott Gaels 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Soapy aroma. Clear brownish pour with a tannish head. Nutty taste. Effervescent mouth feel.
Bottle. Poured medium brown with thin beige film. Light med carb med bod. Light hop aroma. Nutty malty resin taste. Bleh.

Brown in color, roasty and hoppy aroma. This beer is full of flavor, caramel and malt and a hops. A very good brown ale, on the hoppier side but not bitter. Medium to light body. Very drinkable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown beer with a two-finger beige head that slowly subsides into a thin surface film. Subtle, but pleasant nose of salted nuts, light brown sugar, and a touch of sour yeast. Flavor is much bolder than the aroma with a rich nutty malt explosion up front followed by roasted coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, and leather, which then finishes with a light bitterness that lingers on the palette. This is a flavorful beer with much of the flavors I look for in a brown ale, although it lacks the bit of sweetness that would put it over the top. Still, something I would definitely drink again.
Drank straight from bottle..nice aroma of nuts, brown sugar..tasted dry but with some bitterness..not bad, but probably wouldnt buy again.
12oz bottle at Stark's. Pours a reddy brown color with a bit of head. Full malt flavor and a large hoppiness.
Pours a dark black with brown head. Has a faint aroma of light malt and some coffee. Taste is a mix of apices, malt, coffee and chocolate with some espresso aftertaste.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a clear dark brown with a red hue and a light brown head, some lacing in the glass, aroma has quite a bit of sweetness on the front end with a little bit of a hop kick, flavor has a nutty and caramel front end with a sweet finish of chocolate, the coffee comes through as well, quite a bit going on, nice mouthfeel, not bad.

Bottled 12/07/2010

A: Pours out a ruddy brown with a single finger of tan head. This falls to form a sheet of the same over an ale with excellent clarity where light penetrates. Spotty lacing.

S: cocoa, soil, hazelnuts, roast malts. There is a hint of astringency on the nose. Fairly earthy in general as a beer.

T: Nice and roasted coffee and cocoa tones on a malty base layer. Plenty of dusty, woody flavors. I really like the flavor on this one. Finish is long and strong in the coffee flavors.

M: Medium to thin with lo carb. Wish there was a little more body here. Finish is dry on mouth watering.

O: Good beer. I can see why so many people have reviewed this beer so well. Although Im not a big brown ale fan, I feel strongly I will pick this up again.

Serving type: bottle

07-07-2011

On tap @ Battle N Rum, NYC. Clear but deep dark brown in the glass and it has a nice light lacing beige dense top. Really nice chocolaty sweet aroma with burned cocoa, chocolate paper, soft grass and a swift of vanilla ice cream. Not bad at all. Really round, somewhat sweet and really tasty flavors. Its soft oily on the mouthfeel and just below average on the carbonation. Sweet chocolate, sweet cocoa, some faint instant coffee hints and a little bit of that vanilla. Nice stuff. 11.06.2013

12oz beer. What a classic beer. Unfiltered deep brown body. Big rich brown malt, sugary and bold. This is maybe the quintessential American Brown Ale. Robust and big, quality ingredients shine. Malty and restrained like a big Scotch Ale, but hoppy enough to be something different. Ahead of its time. Well done.

Pours a very dark but clear brown with a brown head. Aroma is malt, caramel, roastiness, licorice with some hints of chocolate and coffee. Taste is high sweet leading to a sweet and hoppy and roasty finish. Great brown.

Hmmm. Tried again to rate for the first time, was one of my very first craft beers. Poured from 12oz bottle, a little light gets through showing the reddish brown color. Half finger of foam. Did not care for the aroma...it has a roasty note that I cant quite place. The beer starts like a winter seasonal or porter, but thins out and finishes with a hint of cherry. Easy to drink, but not at the top of my list.

Love the deep red tone & clear pour. Very complex in both smell & taste. Very caramelized flavors. Easy to pick out the ginger & molasses tones of the flavor. Super excited to have it DogFish Head back in WI!!
Very dark reddish color. Malty hop caramel smell. Bitter taste. Little citrusy on the back end. Malted caramel on the front. This is my first Dogfish Head. So far good.

Dark brown, cola coloured pour with a thin light tan head. Brown sugar, coffee and roasted malt on the nose. Taste is roasty, burnt sugar, coffee and chocolate, with nice bitterness cutting through all that at the end.
Hands down this is my favorite brown ale. Tastes great and even goes well with buttered popcorn and a movie.

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a decent beige white head that diminishes quickly leaving only a little lace. Aroma is caramel and molasses. Medium sweet and lightly bitter. Average to light carbonation, light body, thin texture and a smooth balanced finish. Quite nice.
Dark brown pour with a red background color. Tan head that quickly faded. Roasted malts with a coffee background. Taste reminds me of drinking a light porter. Very easy drinker, great beer.

Dark brown body with beige thick creamy head. Aroma is roasted malts, cacao, vanilla, grass. Palate is soft, little oily and full.bodied. Carbonation is soft and mouthful. Taste has distinct roasty malty taste, with cacao, chocolate and and fruity hops twinkling in there in between. Finish has a milky coffee like consistency. Very interesting ale, and has many flavors that you wouldnt expect in one ale. Enjoyable.

Poured a very dark brown colour, nearly like porter except it has a red tint when back lit. Light beige head is one- to two-finger thick and foamy. Retains poorly with curtain lacing. Carbonation low to moderate with small bubbles. Aroma strongly of coffee with a trace of subtle sweet caramel. Taste initially of sweet sugary caramel followed by roasted grain - taste not follow aroma. Medium body. Finished a bit sweet followed by coffee bitterness. Grows on you as you taste more of it. Very nice.

Nice mild choclatey malting with a good effervescence. Some high fruit notes that go into a mild hoppiness mixed with burnt notes.

Dark brown, almost black pour with thin beige head and lots of dense, creamy lacing. Creamy mouthfeel, average to low carbonation, clean finish. Nose is ferrous, chocolate, molasses, and smooth roasted malts, very smooth. Very smooth balanced flavor: roasted malts, woodsy bonfire and chocolate, licorice and floral hops. Nice brown ale.
Good beer, hops come through well, I get flavors of coffee and chocolate. medium light body, well done.
Nice, dark brown color. Slight hop aroma, but a nice malty flavor. Molasses, raisiny, maybe some darker sugar.
Exceptionally delicious. Probably the best Brown Ale I have ever had, and Ive had a few.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown to black color with a thin light brown head. Aroma is full of roasted malts and nutty characteristics. Flavor is about the same, with lots of toasted malts and light nutty sweetness. Medium in body with a lingering nutty toastiness. Phenomenal brown!
Nice beer. Looks good, appearance is ok and nice flavours. Good balance and mouthfeel.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear dark crimson with a two finger beige head. Strong coffee notes on the nose, with molasses, resinous hops, and a faint smell of caramel. The taste also reflects the coffee notes, light cocoa, and molasses up front, with a nice whack of roasted malt in the middle with a plentiful dose of resinous hops, and light citrus notes. Fantastic stuff.

Dark brew with no head. Smells of roasted malts, alcohol, and freshly dug dirt. Taste is kinda smokey, coffee, earth, bitter, dry, herbal. Too much going on with this to be really enjoyable. Its like a brown ale gone wrong. That is why I normally dont waste my money on the overpriced Dogfish but this was a sampler that had been marked down so figured why not. Well now I remember why not to buy Dogfish odd mixes..

Malty and hoppy. Boring. 
 
 B.

FROM NOTES; July 1, 12
Poured into a snazzy DFH pint. 

A: Not much of a hop profile on the nose, but an interesting combination of dark malts and dark fruits. Some coffee notes with a Lilliputian bitter cocoa note. 
A: Pours a crisp dark brown with a tan head that fades into some nice lacing. 
T: This beer is very complex. There are chocolate notes, but it is not a sweet beer. Its a bitter beer, but not over-whelming due to the progression of the hop profile. The finish is a malty/creamy finish. 
P: Very creamy with just a bit of hops for this smooth, medium bodied beer.
O: A fantastic brown, its complexity keeps the palette guessing while maintaining a nice balance throughout. No one taste dominates another too harshly but tumbles in some sort of complementary way that makes this a beer worth having.

A: Strong malt note followed by a hop note. 
A: looks good. pour is a little thin. Head is creamy light tan. In the glass it looks thin dark brown. 
T: Hits with some medium hop flavor which builds into the middle. Finish is malty with a hint of chocolate. Very nice. Flavors clash a little in the front but develop well. Unique. A little thin. 
P: A little clash of flavors at the start. Body is light and thin. Finish is good. 

Overall this is a solid beer and it is decently unique. Fun play between hops and malt. Drinks almost like a pale ale but has a chocolate finish.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a large, lacing head. Aroma of slightly roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily text. nd soft carb. An excellent brown.

Bottle. Thanks to the mother-in-law. Pours deep brown chestnut with a large, creamy, beige head. Aroma has caramel, toasted, citrus, hazelnuts, apricot. Medium carbonation, nice dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has nice caramel, chocolate, hazelnuts. Loads of good citrussy bitterness. Very well balanced.

12 oz. bottle. It pours a nice dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is pretty intense with pleasant toasty malts, a little coffee and cocoa and mild notes of raisin in the background. The flavor is really intense with a rich dark fruity thing up frontraisins, plum and then it settles in to a more roasted malt profile with coffee and tobacco. Lots of tobacco in the finish. This was way different than I expected. Im not getting a whole lot of hops in this one. To me, its more of a cross between a strong Scotch Ale and an Imperial Brown Ale. Unique beer and pretty tasty.

Like most India Ales, this is overbalanced by the hops. The caramelized malt is well done, but the aftertaste leaves a sticky taste, not very pleasant. Good color and aroma, but the taste is somewhat cloying.

Chestnut coloured with a deep red tinge, medium brownish head. Aroma: Nuts, caramel, melanoids, toffee and biscuit. full bodied and fizzy with refreshing flavors of red fruits with a hoppy finish and a good bitterness and balanced sweetness.

Caramelized, roasted malts, toasted bread and nuts. Dark red brown, clear w beige head. Same as in aroma. Dried dark fruits. Not any aroma hops as Id expected, but a nice dark brown tending to a porter.
Aroma: Caramel. liqurice, coffee, nuts. The beer has a flavour which is burned. The palate is thick and creamy

With Generous amounts of caramel, liqourice and roasted nuts this bery dark brown ale could just as will qualify as a porter.

Great and very balanced brown ale. Caramel, chocolate and smoky notes. The aftertaste is long and delightful.
En Brown ale der balancerer meget tæt på grænsen af en porter. Fortrinlige brændte noter i duften og en dejlig kompleks smag, hvor også bitterhumlen træder frem.

@ Ölprovning i Klippan 18/10. Tycker doften är ganska tunn, men det finns karamell där. Även smaken är lite tunn, det man hittar mest är karamellmalt och brunt socker, vilket gör den för söt för min smak. Tycker inte alls den är så välhumlad som man skriver att den ska vara.
Caramel aroma, rich molasses and hops, frothy brown head, gorgeous deep brown color. This is a fantastic brown ale.
An expansive brew. If you cant decide between another IPA or another porter/stout - try one of these. Its a refreshing difference.

Bottle from Kihoskh, Copenhagen. Clear deep amber beer with a nice beige head. Malty caramel and chocolate aroma, cocoa powder, vanilla notes, roasted, toffee, hop notes. Hoppy roasted flavor, caramel, chocolate, cream notes, grassy hops, floral, cocoa powder, some licorice. Full bodied snd really tasty.
Bottle @ Kihoskh, Copenhagen. Pours dark brown with a small creamy head. Roast, caramel, fruit and a hoppy finish. Chewy malty - nuts and caramel. Tasty!

Oh wow. I know a LOT of people appreciate this brew, but boy is it not to my liking. It has a boozy, caramel/maple candy thing going on that Im just not digging. Sorry, Dogfish, not buying this one again.

Sample @ GABF 13. Pours a dark brown beer with a small, off white head on top. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, toffee. Flavour is quite bitter and roasted. Very dry mouthfeel. Medium long, sweet aftertaste. Very dry finish as well. Nice brew.
Flaske> Brunrd klar oel med et taetsiddende skumhoved. Duften er karamelmalt med en diskret surhed og en del humle. Smagen er behagelig typisk amerikansk humlet brown ale. Rigtig god og solid oel.
Doftar något. Bra brown. Length of toast. För besk för mig dock. På SBWF 2013

Pours coca cola brown with low off white head

Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is rye bread, honey, cloves, cane sugar. Taste is honey, cane sugar, caramel, rye bread, cloves.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a very dark brown with off white head. Aroma is a pretty robust caramel and some notes of chocolate. At first taste you are hit with a pretty sweet caramel taste. Then you start to get some bitterness but not overpowering. I didn't get much hops aroma but they are definitely there. It's very balanced. Medium bodied. I really like this brown ale. This beer is really different, the color is great and the taste outstanding! I have always been a fan of brown ale but this puts the others to shame. Although it tastes sort of like a cross-over type beer because of its relation to IPA and others, I find the creativity used here to be wonderful. And as always 7.1% gets the bonus points. Enjoy!
I love this beer. Not over the top with hops like the IPAs. Wonderful caramel/, coffee flavor that finishes without bitterness on the palate.

Pours a deep brown color with a light tan head that never seems to disappear. Smells of roasted caramel, sweet and sugary. It tastes slightly like chocolate with an earthy base to it, Im guessing from all the hops. As with any hoppy beer, the flavor hangs around for awhile giving you a nice long taste. Not a bad beer, actually well crafted, just not one of my favorites.

Pours a beautiful chocolate color. Aroma of brown sugar, coffee, chocolate, nuts and hop fragrances. Tastes sweet with creamy caramel and maple syrup malt tones, and bitter bite from grassy hops. Palate is silky, medium bodied.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 12 oz Bottle. The beer pours to an almost black color with a medium dark tan head. The aroma has a strong coffee caramel smell to it. The taste has a heavy taste to it with a strong malt backbone. Overall a very interesting brown ale.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark chestnut color. The head is a two finger mocha shade. It has a wonderfully soft texture, and as it fades away, leaves behind plenty of lacing on the glass.

S: I dont really pick up a ton of hops...at first. Theres a pleasant wave of brown sugar, nuts, and chocolate at first. Hops build up as it unravels in the glass, revealing both piny and herbal qualities. Maybe even a touch of mint. I must say, the hops are VERY well integrated within the maltier aspects of the aroma.

T: Aye...this is a bit of a letdown next to the nose. Subdued hops open this up - providing notes of grapefruit, mint, and pine - and roll all the way to the back end, being propped up by caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and faint chocolate. This malt backbone builds up on the finish, slowly but gradually. My problem here is that it seems like a cross between a boring IPA and a boring brown ale - it hybridizes the two styles well enough, but comes off blandly. When people rag on balanced brews, this is exactly what theyd rag on. Actually, come to think of it, since its too sweet, that would make it imbalanced...

M: It finishes rather sweet, and unfortunately, the hops dont really dry it out as much as Id like. Even worse, it lacks the creaminess I like out of most sweetish brews. For that reason, its hard to drink. On the plus side, theres no remote hint of harshness in the feel.

O: Its not a bad beer. Nor is it interesting, complex, or subtly executed. Basically this is just another average brown ale, only with a hint of hops. I say its well worth a try for those who like this style, but I wont be back for this one.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby-brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of heavy liquorice, brown sugar, caramel, roasted malts and a hint of dark chocolate. flavour is mostly the same, grainy roasted malts, chocolate and bread crusts, slightly acrid, with a hint of alcohol and paint thinner in the light-bitter finish. medium to heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

Good one. Aromas of roasted malts with a hops floral essence in the background. Pours a chocolate brown with an off-white head. Palate has average weight and is a little creamy. Average carbonation. Good blend of flavors and falls in line with the description of a brown ale with an IPA twist. Bitterness is just enough to not distract and leave it as a roasted and malty brown ale.

Pours brown ruby with a foamy light tan head. Aroma is an unusual mix of cocoa-coffee and hops. Taste is caramel and coffee malt with a hoppy undercurrent. Finish is dry with both sweetness and bitterness. More complex than your average brown ale but I am ambivalent about the hop-touch. Still, a quality beer that I enjoyed.

Bottle sample at tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Pours deep brown with a small beige head. Aroma - caramel, licorice, roasted malts, floral notes. Taste - sweetish, dried fruits, dark chocolate, medium bitterness, alcohol is well hidden. Medium-bodied, smooth on palate. Nice.
This is a very hoppy brown ale. The combo of malt and hippiness just doesn't work for me. I like hops. And I like brown ales. But the mix here seems off.
Bottle. Dark brown oily pour. Malt chocolate coffee aroma and flavor. Has a nice mouth feel to it. Very solid brown.

Bottle. Second beer from this brewery and again I am not surprised to find it lives up to expectations. Pours a slick black body with a thin brown head, malty & mocha aroma, grainy choco taste upfront developing to a sugary and caramel finish and coffee like taste on the back of the tongue. Very tasty, didnt know what to expect with this beer but as a brown ale I find it very interesting with its porter/stout feeling to it. This was the second of two bottles of Dogfish Head I could get in the UK, a great beer to finish on! Very grateful to have gotten them, looking forward to try some more when I get stateside!

Bottle. Deeeep black pour with a coffee colored head. Burnt sugar, coffee, earthy hops, slight pine, and chocolate scents are wafting in my nostrils. This thing is smooth! Caramel, smooth roasty malts, lingering hops, and a full finish make this a delight. Bring on some more

Cola brown with a thick, light tan head.
Barley malt, nutty aroma.
Taste is mild coffee, caramel malt.
Chocolate...
Creamy, smooth.....a little spice.
Excellent..

Nice balance of sweet and bitter at the beginning. Tastes of coffee, molasses, toasted caramel, nice and rich. Medium body with soft carbonation. Finishes with a dark chocolate bitterness that fades nice. Extreme brown ale that is outstanding.

Appearance: opaque brown color with tan head which is extremely dense, the head stays intact
Aroma: Carmel, coffee
Taste: Carmel, coffee, vanilla, complex

Overall: this reminds me of a stout, it is refreshing and the flavors balance well, it is very different what I expected but am pleasantly surprised

Had a pint on tap at Alexandrias. Solid, if a little on the malty side for me. Very nice acidic lift, refreshing. Nice hop presence.

Appearance: has a very deep amber color that makes it almost opaque except when held up to bright light, looks clear though, pours with a very big tan head that settles into a pretty dense head

Dark brown, mild lacing. Malty chocolate aroma and maybe some dark fruit. Taste like a chocolate covered raisan. Very good start to finish. Complex multiple layers off goodness. Very good.

Pours a veey dark brown with a light tan head that disipates leaving little lacing. Aroma very similar to a stout with malt roasted barley notes. Flavors of the roasted malt, very similar to a scotch ale. Leaves a roasted malt/barley flavor on the tounge. An excellent entey from a great brewer.
Mild malt body. Opaque dark chocolate color. Coffee notes. Mild hoppiness. Brown sugar?

Tap. Murky brown with a toasted malt flavor. Medium bitterness with a mild aftertaste. Tasted a little burned. Ok, but not great.

Surprise! Its a deep brown color with a small, but noticeable amount of lacing in the head. Nose is lightly roasted, sweet maltiness. Definitely some brown sugar in there. Some hoppiness in the nose, but not of the three cs variety or as much of them if there are. Taste is way more roasty than I had imagined. Good balance of bitterness with the malty toast. The brown sugar is very apparent, but not too sweet. Flavor lingers long after. Not sure if I am fond of this style in general, but on paper it has all the characteristics I would like.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 18.06.2013, tap @ Blind Tiger Ale House NY:
Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly roasted, dark malts, puffed rice, coffee, chocolate, burnt caramel, unripe banana, grass. Taste is roasted dark malts, coffee, hops, burnt caramel, grass, puffed rice, pine needles. Longlasting bitterness, dry mouthfeel. Fair enough, not a favorite.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with a nice tan head and pretty good lacing. Looks a lot like a porter. Smell is malt, sugar, caramel, roasted nuts and hops. Flavor is intense roastiness, honey, sweet caramel that fades into a pleasant hop after bite. The flavors hide the above average ABV very well. Wasnt too big of a brown ale fan until I tasted this one and the Palo Santo. Definitely widened my palate for brown ales considerably. These guys really put out phenomenal beer.

Pour is very dark brown with tan head with the odor of chocolate and roasted malts. Taste has the same notes with with citrus and a slight espresso note. Very tasty brew and the 7.2% is a nice bonus also.
Pours a dark brown. White head with nice lacing. aromas of toast, chocolate, coffee, toasted nuts. Coffee and roasted malt flavours. Sweetness too. Chocolate notes. Very nice.

Nice and dark. Liked it very much, will buy again
Review: http://youtu.be/0G3YvoLNea8

On draught at Rogue Ales Public House SF. Dark brown color. Aroma of bourbon, dark chocolate, and plum. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and raisins. Really full mouthfeel and lingering roasted malt and alcohol finish.

Near-black pour with a thick cappuccino foam on top. Chocolate is my takeaway from the aroma, but the gf immediately says "soy sauce!". First impressions on drinking are definitely stout, with lots of chocolate and coffee notes. The aftertaste includes quite a bit of vaporized alcohol, which can be a plus or minus depending on your context. Thick, smooth mouthfeel, again like a nice dark porter. Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. A little old, I had it about six months from the brewing date printed on the bottle, which may be why my particular impressions of the beer dont include much hops.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a touch of red, tan head. Smells very chocolatey, roasty, coffee. Tastes rich, coffee, nutty, bitter, really smooth, easy, full flavor, quite good.
Dark brown, with robust foamy off-white head. Aroma of malts, hint of citrus and nuts. Really good flavor, making this very drinkable and enjoyable. Taste is more sweet than bitter.

Dark brown and ruby, with a thin off white tan head.
Cinnamon,aniseed burnt sugar are all found in the aroma. Very complex nose.
Good strong malt back bone, brown sugar, dough, but a strong aniseed, burnt malt, caramel and a great hop resin mix this brown all up.
A wonderful hop bitterness finish the beer off, a nice tartness and malt roast leave you wanting more.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very nice balance between caramelization smell and the hops. They blend into a well-characterized smell. A nice 2-finger head formed when poured from the bottle. As I drank it, nice lacing formed on the sides. A much darker brown ale then usual. Wonderful toffee, followed by hops, provide the initial mellow taste. There is a soft alcohol warmth felt. A little bit heaver then many brown ales, but excellent overall. Up to the last drink, foam was present. One of the best browns to date.
Creamy espresso head. A light coffee the roasted caramely aroma. Silky body light carbonated. Sweet caramel flavor. Not as bitter as I expected. Roasted finish. Great rich but balanced beer.

Appearance has a dark ruby brown color supporting a nice head leaving fair lace. smell of roasted malts with an aroma I cant put my finger on. Taste is very clean for a brown ale having the roastiness of the malt and a hop bite in the end. Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation. Personnally Im not much into brown ales, but this is a good one.
Dark brown, big tan foamy head, decent lacing. Sweet toasted and chocolate aroma. Toasted, malty, chocolate, coffee, molasses, modestly sweet and light hoppy bitter finish. Real nice. Recommended.

I find this beer to very well balanced and that for me is its main draw. It starts out with some malt, transistions into some earthiness and then finishes with hops. It is like a more complex version of the breckles brown from Anchor. There are few beers that I do not get tired of before the 6 pack is finished and this one keeps me coming back for more. Also I have found that this beer has one of the biggest changes from being served in a pint glass, belgian glass, or out of the bottle.
Love the complexity and the nice simple finish on this beer.  One of my ball time favorites.  Nothing stands out to much.  Some times I wish it was more hoppy, but its all in the balance.
bottle. Brown with one finger head. Excellent hoppiness with all the rich malt that youd expect from a brown. Great.

Bottle at Coopers in Chicago. Its been a while. Pours a deep, dark brown color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is roasty, hoppy, pine. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, nutty, caramel, roasty, toast, bitter pine hops, with a clean, nutty finish. A beer ahead of its time it would appear. Very nice.

On-tap in the Rogue Pub on Union St San Fransisco: 3rd Feb 2013.

Thought it looked like a Stout, dark brown with a good foaming head.

Malty molasses hit the nose and mouth, this has a sweet front: plenty of malty flavours as you dig into the brew. I got coffee and dark chocolate along with some dried candid fruit notes.

Good body thickness and feel to the beer, a pleasant and easy to drink brew.

Nuts, coffee, chocolate, and a little funk in the aroma that breathed off after a minute.  Bittersweet flavor, with coffee, brown sugar, and some nutty roast.  Hoppy, bitter finish.  Good, but not great--I was a little disappointed given the rating.

Pours cola brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is heavy molasses and light coffee. Taste is very smooth but not overbearing molasses up front transforming into a creamy latte mid palate and hopp bitterness that faintly comes through in the finish. Alcohol portrays itself sweetly. Truly complex brown.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2013 Bottle. Pours a dark, dark brown. Nice tan head with low retention and lacing. Smells of mocha, espresso, raisins, toffee, malt. Tastes of espresso, mocha, slight raisin or fig, medium malt. Low carbonation, subtle crisp. Weak creamy finish. Nice twist on a brown ale.
Probably the best brown ale Ive had so far. Great copper color, thick head after pour. Very sweet & refreshing! 3rd place on my ballot at Beer Night IV on 6/7/13.

Gorgeous dark brown body accompanied by a thick cappuccino froth. The nose is surprisingly light, considering the bold coffee and chicory notes to the hearty flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle, pours a dark cola brown color with tan head.  Aroma of caramel and toffee.  Taste is sweet, dark caramel, brown sugar, toffee and slight raisin.  A very good brown ale.
Good brown ale that is both malty and hoppy without being overly sweet. Easy o session this brown ale.

Malty, roasted aroma, with a sense of hop floral scent. Pours a nice brown with a diminishing White head. Smells of caramel, and brown sugar. Starts with roasted malt, moves to a sweet amber malt taste. Finishes with a bitter dry hop finish.  Nice mouth feel for a brown ale. Complex yet simple. Nicely done brown ale.

Pours medium brown with frothy brown head. Aroma of malty caramel sweetness with a bit of roasted sweetness laced with bitter citrus. Taste is a great balance of malty sweetness balanced with sweet malt. Overall an amazing brown ale
Beautiful reddish brown with off white head. Aroma is raisin and brown sugar. Tastes the same with a mild bitter finish.  Nice beer.

Bouteille 12 oz. Achetée au Half Time (Poughkeepsie). Robe dun brun cuivrée. Riche arôme de malt rôti, de noix, de caramel, de vanille et de chocolat. Le goût suit. Proposition fort intéressante, de beaucoup supérieure à la moyenne des Brown ales.
Malto, tostato e un stupefacente amaro equilibrato e mai stancante. Meglio delle aspettative, già alte a dir la verità!!
Uma cerveja dos deuses, equilibrio entre caramelo, chocolate e café, drinkbillity espetacular, recomendo !
Dark brown.  Very thin head.  Tastes like a new castle with balls.  Smells nutty.  Brown sugar.
My overall favorite in cooler seasons. This beer is tough to beat, by itself or with the right food pairings. The perfect blend of sweet maltiness with a nice hop bite.

Deep amber with foamy Lacy lasting tan head; aroma is sweet and reminiscient of something that is a very fond memory but innappropriate to mention here; Flava is of smoked cheddar with a slightly tart citrus finish; crisp and lightish but not watery.

02-MAY-2013, bottle @appartment in Rome, from Eataly. 
Dark, almost clear with lasting tan head. 
Roasted aroma with coffee, brown sugar, plum. Taste even better than aroma. Long roasted finish, creamy, medium carbonation. Moderate bitterness. 
Really nice brown ale.

A - Pours a very dark brown with red edges and a khaki head that sinks down to form a nice collar and some fizzy islands.

S - Some coffee and hints of chocolate, toasted malt, alcohol, green hops.

T - Sweet coffee notes, rich dark roasted malts, raw brown sugar, cherries, and berry fruit. It has a very clean earthiness about it. Fresh tasting hops round this one up with a clean and flavorful bitter finish.

M - Excellent. Full bodied, thick and creamy.

Everything seems to be in its perfect place here. This is really well done. The hops are just enough to bring the awesome malt profile together.

12-16-2010
12 oz bottle pours deep dark brown with light tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Brown sugar and raisin taste.

Spent the weekend in Delaware at the brewery and the restaurant. Tried everything that was currently available, this one is always a good stand by

Pours a deep chestnut color with a creamy off white head.  Aroma of coffee notes, taste is crisp and clean with a dry malty middle with a brown sugar tinge and finished with a touch of raisins and dry sweetness.  A very interesting brown.

Biege head in colour medium soft carbonation darkest of brown pour more like cola aromas rich malts caramel chocolate dark fruit sharp notes earthy notes the flavours oily taste rich caramel and chocolate fruity taste stonefruit citrus earthyness sugary notes a sweet ale the finish likeable ale best aftertastes fruity mix really lingers sweet malts lots of earthyness sweet aftertastes nice ale

aroma of carmelized sugar and chocolate. on the darker side of the browns closer to black. taste of heavenly chocolate and caramel. a little on the high side of carbonation for me but good nonetheless

UPDATED: APR 19, 2013 Caramel sweet malt and bitter hops aroma. Caramel brown with a thick lingering light tan head.  Medium bodied. Toffee sweetness with a hoppy finish. Not bad. A little hoppier than I expected.

Solid opaque brown with a generaous tan head that left a nice solid film and left very nice lace. Floral hops aromas peek up above a wonderful unsweetened chocolate and coffee foundation. Dark fruits and burnt sugar add some complexity to the nose. Carmelized sugars and roasted malts are featured in the flavor profile, accompanied by a bittersweet chocolate, leafy hops bitterness, berries, gentle spices, and warming alcohol. Medium body, lightly carbonated, creamy mouthfeel, and a long dark chocolate finish. Didnt expect this to be so good.

This is the best beer Ive ever had, hands down. Its perfect in every single way, from the aroma to the deep, rich color, to the hint of caramelized sugar on finish. Its a beer lovers heaven in a bottle.

this is wonderful, loving dogfish head. sweet caramels and coffees are most notable over the well balanced hops. that coffee lingers for a long time, dries right up like a bitter espresso shot. excellent.
Pours a sweet brown ale with hop aroma to pleasure the nostrils. Complex layered flavours make it a good tasting event.
Rich style with chocolate undertones.  Nicely balanced and coats the mouth with goodness.

12oz bottle from steve
Weird ipa stout but good very good

This beer had a pleasant aroma. The taste was better than I anticipated. It was not bitter, but smooth. Overall an enjoyable experience.
Bottle right now.  Pours brown with a creamy head.  Smell has hints of roasted goodness.  Taste pretty much the same.  Great beer!
Bottle. Tasting session at Leftys. From notes. Ruby color. Very sweet caramel aroma. A sensual tour of sweet to bitter, with a ton of tingle. Slightly oldish, and a bit oxidized.

Bottle from Total Wine in Redondo Beach.  Dark brown pour.  Long lasting thick tan head.  Aroma is coffee grounds and dried dark fruits.  Flavor is a nice mix of caramel sweetness, tobacco, alcohol that complements the flavor, and coffee.  The body is a medium thickness and the level of carbonation is medium.
Firkin at Real Ale. Pours a deep brown with some beige head and lace. Molasses, ginger, decent amount of hops.  Well balanced with malt and hops.
Picked up a bottle of this on business travel to California.  Very interesting hybrid here of the Brown and IPA - uniqueness points.
12oz bottle. Pours deep brown with small amount of tan head. Aroma of caramel malts, brown sugar, floral hops, and a light nuttiness. Taste is caramel and toffee, roasted malt, and floral hops.
Disappointed in this beer. Very sweet without much bitterness to balance it out. At the point of being cloying

Appearance: Pours a dark, deep brown color with a small, tan head. The lacings pretty good at the beginning.

Smell: Smells like youd expect it to after its been in a bottle for so long. Mild malt notes, but a sour, vinegar-like trunk smell is there as well. Not an overpowering smell... quite muted. I would certainly expect a fresh batch to smell a lot more pleasant.

Taste/feel: Tastes about as good as a 17 month old beer should be able to. Its drinkable, has a very nice and deep malty/coffee aftertaste. The hops seem to be almost completely gone in the taste and aroma, and it just drinks like a heavy brown ale ... almost like a porter or a stout with the super rich aftertaste. The feels pretty decent. Low carbonation and somewhat creamy. Not bad.

Overall, hard to accurately score this one due to the sheer age of this beer. Regardless of its age, it tastes better than a lot of beers do fresh. Id definitely try this again either on tap or out of a fresher bottle.

In the middle on this one. 

No aroma
Looks great with a very thick head. 
A slightly dusty bitter finish. 

Very good not great

Bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of various fruits, caramel, spice, and some licorice.  Taste is sweet and spicy up front, with caramel and a little chocolate.  Hoppy bitterness only creeps up after a while.  Sticky mouthfeel.  A nice brown ale, but Im not getting as much hoppiness as I was expecting.
From bottle. Pours a deep brown color and small head. Aroma was sweet bread, brown sugar and coffee. Taste followed with a lot of sweetness. Medium body.

Pint on tap.  Mahogany color, small persistent head - .  Smells familiar (I think its the scotch ale), rich aroma.  I taste toffee, toasted notes, marshmallows, a little vanilla (so a little sweet), but it has a pretty bitter aftertaste - overall it has a big body with lots of taste.  Quality beer.

12oz bottle. I know Ive had this in the past and it certainly wasnt $11 a sixer. Good thing I only bought one bottle. Dark brown, decent head. Aroma is a sugary brown ale, malts. Interesting brown ale concept. I was a bit hesitant, but pleasantly surprised. The sweet smell of coffee and caramel mixed with the hopy flavor made for a good beer drinking experience.

Dark brown pour with a small amount of off white/tan head. Smells of brown sugar, caramel, banana, fig, raisin. Initial taste is a dusty hop with some caramel like sweetness. Bottle poured a cloudy brown hue w/ a creamy mostly diminishing tan head and excellent lacing. Aroma of dark breads and molasses. Initial flavor moderate sweet to a light bitter finish of short duration. Tastes are coffee, molasses, citrus - lemon, raisin, and lightly roasted barley. Medium to full bodied, dry texture, soft carbonation, and light alcoholic feel in the finish.

Pours dark brown with small beige head.  Aroma is of roasted malts and caramel.  Taste at first is closer to a brown ale, but the hops creep up on you and leave that bitter aftertaste.  I really enjoy this beer.

Out of a bottle on a cold night.  Aroma is rich and warming.   Dark brown color is indicative of the full flavor.  Starts as a brown ale but transitions with a bit of scotch ale flavor then finishes with chocolate and stout.  With so many tastes it's hard to get bored of this beer

12oz bottle.  Pours opaque, dark brown.  Aroma of brown sugar, caramel, raisin, vanilla, peat, with a touch of anise.  Flavor is peat, brown sugar, roasted grain, smoke, wood, raisin.  Has a dry finish.
On tap at burger. in Santa Cruz. As I imagined, this scotch ale/IPA hybrid is kind of a mess. I dont like the combo of piney hops and tangy bready malt. Tastes coarse and disjointed.

Delicious and moderately hopped brown.  Beautiful dark brown colorwith dark tan head.  Notes of caramel, coffee and chocolate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer is very darn good looking. Brown, almost black, but with an auburn clarity when held up to the light. Monster head that doesnt go away, leaving great lacing.

Malty, roasted and toasted malts come through first, with nice light coffee, nuts and molasses accents.

Taste is much along the lines of the smell. Ever so slight smoke starts it off, followed by ever growing elements of coffee and chocolate, growing further still with great roasted malt flavors, with a touch of nuttiness for dessert. Hops balance is light but present.

Body is pretty full and creamy with nicely done carbonation.

It has a lot of the properties of a stout, reminds me somewhat of Guinness export stout, especially with the mouthfeel. Also has some of the qualities of a great porter, with the roasty malts and slight smokiness. Very interesting and complex!

Overall even though its not even a style that I typically much care for, this beer really comes out on top no matter what the style. DFH strikes again with deliciousness!

12 oz. bottle pours a dark reddish brown with moderate beige head but minimal lacing.  Aroma is full of roasted malts, molasses, coffee, and a bit of chocolate.  Taste is sweet with a bitter and slightly nutty finish.  Medium body with crisp mouthfeel.  I was pleasantly surprised with this one

Dark brown pour with medium sized beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, brown sugar and chocolate. Taste of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel and faint hops. Medium carbonation and crisp mouthfeel, sweet beer but very well balanced.

On tap at the Yard House in North ridge, CA. Pours dark with slight hints of amber. Lightly carbonated with a quickly dissipating head. Malty aroma. Flavors of roasted malt with a resin bitterness, and a slightly sour but clean finish. Not my favorite.

Bottle. Pours a dark red brown with a half finger of rapidly settling off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, dark malt, and minor hop bitterness. Flavor is roasted malt, dark malt, chocolate malt, fading into nice citrus, mildly resinous hop tones. Roasted and cocoa finish that lingers momentarily. Flavor is very well balanced. Soft to moderate carbonation with medium body and crisp texture. I enjoyed it a lot more the second time around, seemed a lot more complex. A very good beer.

This is a nice sweet and bitter IBA. Clean palate, dark brown pour and a thin light tan head. Taste is brown sugar, hops, and caramel.

12 ounce bottle at the brass tap poured adark brown color with aromas of molasses, light sugar, some nuts and chocolate.  Flavors follow suit a decent brown ale that I could drink over and over again

Pours a nice dark brown with beige head. Aroma is of chocolate and burnt sugar....very inviting.  Smooth taste with no bite...would have liked a little on the end.  All in all...a very nice balanced beer.
This beer is very well balanced. Very good chocolate, coffee and roasted malt flavor with a nice earthy hopness. Excellent beer, always a go to choice when I cant decide what else different to try.

On tap at the Upper Deck Pub in South Burlington, VT.  Served in goblet.

Opaque, intensely dark brown with tan head and excellent lacing.

Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, pine, dark fruit, chocolate and brown sugar.

Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, floral hops, pine and dark fruit. Complex, balanced and delicious. 

Medium body and medium carbonation. 

They have definitely tweaked the recipe on this one over the years.  What was once a very fine beer is now remarkably good.
