Beware the Head of the Dogfish. One of the first craft beers I ever tried, this is not your typical brown ale. Healthy nose of brown sugar and roasted coffee with some hoppy undertones. Almost light-blocking brown color, minimal head. Classic brown ale taste, bittersweet and malty without being as starchy as some of the black IPAs with their abundance of burnt dark malts.  Pipe smoke aftertaste. Crisp biting body with just the right weight. A unique beer a decade ago, it has inspired 
many imitators.  This one was bottled 10/3/2012.

Draft offering at brewpub...dark black..brownish head..getting some nice notes on nose of coffee..malt..chocolate..taste is smooth with some type of traces of anise..licorice..can see why this is considered one of the better offerings of the core dfh line..

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a thick, light tan head and great retention.  Smells malty, caramel, bread, chocolate, herbal hops, dark fruit.  Medium body, smooth texture.  Toasted/roasted malt flavor, chocolate, wheat bread and a light fruity hop and herbal flavor.  Not bad for a brown ale.

Im not a raging dogfish fan, but this ones pretty good. Nice deep dark pour with full head. Nose is full roasted malt with a fairly nice hop. Good chocolate presence. Flavor is rich and smooth all at once. Velvet-like. Good chocolate and hop balance. Liking this one.. Nice

Bottle 12 Oz. Poured a dark brown color, clear and with a little tan head. Taste is sweet like brown sugar and chocolate it also has a little bitterness towards the end. Nice Beer, another great offering from Dogfish Head.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2016 Draft at Farmers Cabinet in Jan 2013 and Fado in Dec 2016. Very dark brown sienna pour with beige foam. Tons of glassy lace. Big burnt malty Brown Ale. Notes of molasses, bitter dark chocolate, almonds, leather and deep red berries. Hints of smoke and ash. Slight peppery hop bite. Quite full and solid for the style.

Looks like Coca-Cola. Thin lacing throughout. An amazing bouquet of flavors. This has to be the best brown ale known to man.

Che birra magnifica. Nel bicchiere bruna, scura con poca schiuma poco persistente. Al naso perfetta, con note di cioccolata, caffè e la componente luppolata che equilibra il tutto. In bocca è una perfetta alchimia tra elementi dolci del caffè, del cioccolato e del caramello con quelli amaricanti (ma mai esagerati) del luppolo. Una bevuta magnifica.

Im happy to say this is probably the most enjoyable brown ale Ive ever had. Not that Ive tried a million of them, but this one was by far the most complex, delicious, and aromatic of the ones Ive tried. Browns are one of my favorite style, and I was so happy with this one- a nice blend of honey, malt, molasses and raisins all blend into a really damn near perfect beer.

Smelled toasty nuts, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, light coffee notes, light chocolate notes and even some smoky fire.

moderate mouthfeel, notes of coffee, raisins, toffee, dark chocolate malts. hoppiness seems moderate when paired with the dark malts. overall good, as expected from dogfish.

Aroma: moderate aroma of roasted malt and light aroma of chocolate and coffee.

Poured from a bottle, dark brown with good looking creamy off-white head. Aroma of malt and roasted coffee, slight hops in there too. Taste is slightly bitter and dry, not sweet. On draught at the Wharf Rat, Baltimore 5/12/2012. Dark, ruddy brown with a decent, off-white head. Spicy, citrus hops, with some berry fruits and dry finish. Very good.

This is a great beer. Pours cola with a nice head and good lacing. Nose is scotch toffee. Aromas are toffee, coffee, roasted malt and some limited grassy hops. Taste is med sweet with light bitter finish. Medium mouth wih lively carbonation. Great!
dark brown pour with thick light brown head - aroma of alcohol and dark brown sugar - flavors of richly roasted malt and molasses - finishes with a lingering molasses
Bottle->SA glass.  Dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is smoky with toasted malts.  Taste is very roasty malt, with a bitter aftertaste.  Very good.
From the tap came a cola brown ale with very little head. Aroma was faintly malty. Medium bodied with balanced malt and hop flavors with interesting earthy and nutty hints.

Tap. Brown with foamy tan head with coating lacing. Smells like toasted nuts, lipstick, and dark bread. Hoppy then sweet- almost a little chocolaty- and earthy. At first hard them creamy in mouth, earthy finish.

12 oz bottle to pint glass
Aroma of grain, cereal, roasted malts, and ginger. Deep reddish brown with a thick creamy light tan head. Taste is malty, with light sweetness, moderate bitterness, and a bit of alcohol at the end. It's medium bodied, creamy and slick.

Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Smells of dark malts and dry hops at the same time. Tastes roasty and toasty and delicious. Not too hoppy, mostly malty but the palate is long and ends with a great hop bitter taste. This is an awesome beer. Well balanced and alcohol is hidden well.

Poured from the bottle. Aroma is deliciously hoppy. Flavor has the malt backbone of a brown ale but with the hoppiness of a ipa. Really interesting take on a cascadian ipa. Finishes dry, not oily or sweet, really nice.
Poured dark brown with a thin tan head. Zesty aroma of sweet roast malt and coffee. Full creamy body, flavour of dark chocolate, coffee, dried fruit and some nuttiness. Medium-sweet, dry aftertaste.

Bottled sample T the public house in Las Vegas. Nice hop flavor. Great brown ale

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at home (Beermongers, Portland) 22/11/12.
Very dark mahogony brown with a big frothy tan head.
Nose comprises caramel malts, hops, metallic and mineral tones, barley, light dark fruits and a touch of cocoa.
Tastes of malt, barley, hops, toffee, raisens, chocolate.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth on the palate.
Decent - although my memories of having had it on tap at Rehoboth a few years back were that of a beer a few marks higher!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Pours dark brown almost black with a thick tan head. Aroma of heavy sweet malts, bitter hops and chocolate. Taste is bitter and hoppy upfront but crazy malty in the finish. It's like drinking two different beers! Hoppy up front and malty in the finish. Really cool beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nutty chocolate coffee all lightly expressed in malt forward aroma. Black with brown edges fluffy light tan head. Thick lacing. Very malty chocolate and nutty.

A superb brown, one of the best Ive had, though its not much like many others.  Has the sweetness youd expect, but rather than brown sugar, its more molasses and chocolate.  Rather than a subtle hop balance, its pretty aggressive though its not particularly apparent in the aroma.

Pours reddish Brown with a creamy light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts with hint of chocolate. Taste like a standard brown but with more hops on the back end than your standard brown. 

----Hophaze out
From a 12 oz bottle at home.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a short-lived tan head, receding with no some lacing.  Notes of coffee and caramel. Slight bitter finish.  Nice.

Bottle thx to adnielsen cons 2012-11-14 Göteborg
AR: thick chocolate aroma, wee sour coffey
AP: dark brown, stouthy creme brown semi steady head
F: rich chocolate, wee coffey, chocolate biscuites with wee vanilla filling, medium + bitterness, soft carbonation, finish is thick filling chocolate

At the Alehouse in Falls Church. Black with little head. Coffee and molasses in the nose. Coffee takes over in the flavor with some hop bite at the back end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a dogfish head goblet. Reddish dark appearance with a solid off white head and good amount of lacing. Smells a bit of yeast like a belgian ale, along with some sweetness. Tastes sweet up front on the tongue, moves to a coffee-ish stout on the middle of the tongue, and finishes with some bitter hops on the back. Chocolate/coffee/roasted malts heavy in the after taste.Overall it?s an interesting brew. I personally love it, and it has a lot to offer for a reasonably affordable 6 pack. highly recommended in my book.
Such a tasty brew, Ill definitely be looking out for it when Im not feeling so adventurous

Pours a dark brown color with a thick off white head that fades but leaves good lacing. Smells of chocolate, roasted malts molasses and slight citrus tastes of molasses, toffee, coffee, chocolate and grapfruit with a slight hop bite.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with a semi dry finish. Dogfish Head makes great beers this one is pretty good. Glad its back in Washington after a year or so of not finding it anywhere around here.

This beer is a great beer.  It is confusing though.  It has a stout aftertaste but goes down hoppy.  I think it's perfect when you start the night out with IPAs and finish with a stout.  Use this as a transition between the 2 styles and your taste buds will be happy. 

- check out more at www.beeriam.com
12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with full head. Aromas of toasted malts, dry hay, and old brown sugar. Nice flavor mix of honey nuts, raisins, roasted malts and relatively light hops. Nice.

355 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown colour with a creamy white head. Aroma of roasted malts, syrup and chocolate. Flavour of roasted malts, chocolate, cream, syrup and strong grassy hops. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and a warming, roasty, bitter finish. A bittoo rough and alcohol comes through a bit too much.
Interesting.  Dark brown/amber.  Smell is very malty but not much hops.  Roasty and toasty, malty, and bitter.  Soft carbonation with a sweet aftertaste.

Super duper. 





                                   

                                    

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Exactly what I was wanting. Roasted malt aromas and flavors of toasted nuts, roasted coffee beans, toffee, brown sugar, and charred wood, with just enough hops to give balance, keeping it from being malty sweet. Great mouthfeel, not to thick and not to light, with good concentration and length on the palate. Another new favorite!

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2013 Pours a thick brown. Tastes of toffee and chocolate. Chewey mouthfeel for a brown ale. Almost like a stout. This beer is just awesome. So much flavor. --Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours brown with no head (in sampler glass though...). Aroma was for me hard to get (nose tired?) but some sweet malts and hops in there for sure. Taste is milk chocolate, sweet caramel, resinous hops, toast, pine. Good brew!

Pours very dark brown   aroma is exceptional  chocolate, roasted candied pecans and brown sugar and hint vanilla and bourbon.  Wow   flavor is equally great  chocolatey roasted nut flavor with perfeect meld of hops  very smooth    body is perfect , heavy and matches the flavor profile yet continually drinkable    finish reminds me of being a kid and the finish on a chocolate milk !   What a unique beer   too bad dogfish doesnt distribute in missouri  i had to bring this back from chicago  anyway...well done ! A fav for sure !

It poured a clear reddish-brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of roasted malt, caramel and hops. The taste was of chocolate, roasted nuts, malt and hops. The finish was roasty with a chocolate malt aftertaste. Very good.
Bottle to pint (from notes).  Looks good; brown with beige lacing.  Smells and tastes of caramel malt and hops.  Average on the palate.  Solid.
This baby tastes great. Hoppy, grainy, toasty and cocoa. Very grainy. Chocolate and prunes. Ruby brown color. Dry and flavorful. A bit watery. Recomended.
Dark brown.  Minimal head.  Smells of cold coffee, alcohol, cola.  Taste is nutty, caramel, almondish.  Malts are balanced with a perfect amount of hop fruitiness.   Dont pass this one up.

Very sweet sugary caramel aroma. Blackish brown in color with a large tan foam top. Carbonated bitter hops upfront with a classic dogfish head caramelized sugar sweetness. Other notes of subtle coffee, nuts, cocoa and raisins are evident. Overall, this is a well done, strong ale with complex flavorings and a big alcohol finish. Intense carbonation and full body. Id give this an A+ rating.
Very tasty brew!  Vanilla, tobacco, dark chocolate, raisins and a bourbon kick. One of my favorites!

Pours a dark ruby red brown with a tan head.It almost looked like a light porter.The aroma was of sweet caramel with a hop sent to it.The flavor is of sweet malt with a rather strong hop bite.The body was full with a nice bitter aftertaste.Overall a good beer.
Smooth taste and even smoother finish. Tasty beer with alcohol content to boot. Way to go dogfish! A+
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Bottle, brown pour, white head, nose is coffee, taste is coffee, some cream, good

Pours dark brown with off white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is nutty and malty.  Taste is malts, molasses, carmel, brown sugar, and some citrus hops.  Very nice, complex beer.  My favorate brown ale!

In the glass it has a dark brown color with a medium head. The aroma has some sweetness like hazelnuts. Taste has sweetness up front definitely from the sugar that they added. There is also some roasted malts and then a mild bitterness in the finish. Good beer.

13 sept 2012, bottle. Dark reddish brown, clear. Nose is dark malt, burnt coffee beans, very dry, dark malt aroma. Med body and slightly fizzy. Tastes of nice but moist bread, faint hint of blue cheese, slightly tart, some alcohol notes. Very nice.

Pours dark brown, yellow head, that last forever. herbs, grass. chesse and onion in the aroma.  Heavy, omplex and perfect bitternes on the taste.
its a really great beer

Bottle - 12oz. Hazy dark brown body with average carbonation and a good off-white foamy head. Complex, well balanced malty/hoppy aroma with chocolate, toffee, and fruity hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Its malty/hoppy taste carries woody, grainy, and brown sugar notes. Ends with a long bitter/grainy finish. Interesting.

04/06/12 bottle to a lager glass. Color is a rich brown with a thin tan head and minimal lacing. Aroma is hazelnut, roasted barley, caramel, toffee, semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, and some pine. Pretty complex. Taste is nutty and malty. There is a rich coffee/chocolate flavor that balances with caramel, and a slight hop bitterness. Thinner mouthfeel and a well hidden abv. This is a fantastic brown ale.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2014 Cross of Brown Ale, IPA and Scotch Ale. Dark maple or light coffee color, deep copper, clear, tall brown head which persists. Assertive but fleeting nose. Medium body and bitterness, complex but not intense flavors, malty sweetness in the background, goodenough length, clean, roasty, bittersweet finish. Roast character, coffee, herby, bitter and hoppy but balanced. A hint of metalic (iron) taste. Tastes like a rich porter. Easy to drink but needs something with it or after it because of the bitterness.
Tap pour, deep brownish-black. Aroma is caramel, coffee, pretty faint. Bitter coffee, faint hoppiness. Comes off as a slightly hoppy porter.

Pours a deep cola color with aroma of alcohol soaked raisins and brown sugar.  Taste is of brown sugar with a scotch flavor.  A mildly bitter finish consistent with its IBUs.  Overall a good IBA I would have again.

12oz into Duvel Tulip 4/14/12 bottle. Nearly black with half finger tan head.  Aromas of dark roasted malt and a hint of hops.  Taste is nice, roasted malt, brown sugar, bit of coffee.  I dont really get the India part, this isnt any more hoppy than a standard brown ale, but its still quite good.  I suspect this is due to the bottle being 4.5 months old at this point.  Palate is medium body and smooth, really nice.  I really dig this beer but I need to try it fresher.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2012 12oz bottle poured into pint glass.  Dark brown with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, caramel and roasted malts.  Taste brings our brown sugar, nuttiness and some dark fruit.  Medium body and smooth.  Much more complex then a Newcastle.  Enjoyed.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear dark brown with a one finger tan head. Awesome head retention but very little in the way of lacing.

Nose immediately reminds me of chocolate milk. Wonderful rich milk chocolate along with some light roast coffee. Some roasted malt along with a hint of dried dark fruits. Also some caramelized sugar.

The roasty characteristics continue into the taste. Some dark chocolate and coffee along with roasted barley. The dark fruit is more predominant with figs and some licorice. There is a little bit of tartness in the mouthfeel along with a breath of alcohol in the finish. Bitterness is light to moderate.

Overall, a good beer that does cross style lines. I really was expecting more bitterness but there is enough there to balance out the sweetness. More like a cross between a porter and a RIS. Good to have occasionally.

Poured out of a glass
Small head
Roasty, coffee on the nose
No lacing
Taste is roasty malt sweetness not enough hops to live up to the "india" brown

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Bottle).   Aroma of cocoa, coffee and malt.  Similar flavors with pronounced malt.  To the brewers standard.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 ounce bottle from Capitol Beer and Taproom. Medium head, coffee notes, flavor is coffee, roasted barley, slight hoppiness.

Dark ruby with brown foam head. Aroma is strong caramel. Taste is caramelized sugar, little bitter, little yeast. Normal low bittersweet aftertaste. (Houston 201208)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Malty and nutty aroma taste has chocolate coffee and syrup. Smooth on the palate.

Very interesting. Pours a very dark brown with a small head. Lots of malts in the nose with some hints of chocolate in there. The taste is not as hoppy as I would have expected from the description, but I get some sweet fruit notes underlying the coffee and malt flavors.

Bottled. Dark reddish Brown coloured. Aroma of caramel, Cocoa, herbs, flowers, Brown sugar. Flavour of Brown sugar, caramel, sweetness, flowers, light bread. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a caramelly bitterness. Nice. Thx SS GT2 for this.
Very nice, rich tasting brown ale. Definitely a keeper. Nice change of pace from my standard newcastle
Dark brown w/ a beige head. Aroma is malt and caramel. Really nice bitter and a caramel sweetness. Flavor is nuts, caramel, dark fruit. Finishes with a nice hoppiness.

Bouteille 12 oz. achetée au IGA à Potsdam, NY. Couleur rousse foncée, mousse crémeuse beige. Arôme de noisette, herbes, malt et chocolat. En bouche, malt chocolat, noisette, un peu de houblons vers la fin. café au lait. Finale noisette et herbes. Excellente.

12 oz bottle poured into an ale glass. Wonderful sweet (yet balanced) flavor and syrupy palate. Molasses is a huge component to to the taste, along with notes of coffee and caramel. Absolutely delicious. Buy a 6er.

bottled, aroma is richly malt with notes of toffee and nutty earthy roast. Appearance is clear and a deep brown with a little amber hue. between a medium and a full body with a creamy texture and good carbonation with a delicious malty finish. Flavor consists of rich malt character with notes of coffee, dark fruit, and chocolate. The hop bitterness in this seems high for a brown ale and there is a lot of alcohol warmth, both of which I personally like in a brown, I think it provides a nice hop balance to the rich roasty malts. Overall this is a very drinkable brown from the aroma to the mouthfeel to the flavor they got a nice mildly complex mixtures of elements that come together in this brew.
A small head brown with some opacity.  The aroma of coffee, chocolate and malt.  The flavor is sweet with a thin texture and alcohol finish.  The low carbonation makes a smooth wholesome drink.
Dark brown pour. It has coffee and nut aroma, lots of coffee taste, nut taste, some cocoa. Delicious finish

Pours an opaque brown on tap with thin tan head and good lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and slight sweet toffee. Taste follows suit with more coffee and a slightly bitter finish. Good, alcohol hidden well.
like what Dogfish Head has done here. I am a fan of brown ales, and I like the little hop bite that DFH has added to this one. I like this beer and will definitely have it again.

Dark amber with large tan head.  Coffee and molasses aroma.  Surprised when I first tasted.  Tastes much more like a scotch ale than anything else - not as much hop as I was expecting.  Solid scotchish beer.

Bottle at home. Poured a dark, opaque brown, almost black with a frothy tan head. Aroma is very roasty, cocoa, whiskey, spicy rye, espresso, fruity esters, grapefruit, and marshmallows. Taste is roasty, dark chocolate, fruity hops, sweet pineapple, and bourbon, with a medium bitter finish. Creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Nicely balanced brew and very easy to drink. Great summer or winter beer.

Tap at legal sea in Philadelphia. Great dark nutmeg color with frothy head. Good nose and medium thick
Mouthfeel. Has a bit of sharp bite showing its balls. Well balanced and a good nut brown beer. 

---Rated via my mouth

A: dark amber hue with a decent sized head that leaves a nice sheet of lacing on the glass.

S: roasted / burnt malts, slightly sweet

T: A good beer. Its slightly sweet with pleasant smoky flavors. Mostly malt flavors with a hint of bitterness in the finish. Its definitely a scotch ale / brown ale hybrid. I dont really detect much of an IPA or hop presence.

M: medium body with plenty of carbonation. Good feel.

D: a good offering from DFH. Not my favorite brown ale, but enjoyable nonetheless.
From notes. Pours dark brown with nice tan head and lace. Aroma of roasted caramel malts and some chocolate.  Flavours of nuts, brown sugar and chocolate malt.

Bottle (12 oz). Brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma of caramel, malt, chocolate with slight fruity hops. Taste of caramel/toffee with slight roasted malts, spices and hops. Slight acidic mouthfeel Interesting beer.

Bottle.
Pours brown, with almost no head. Aroma is of malt, sligth acid, roasted malt. Taste is of malt, caramel, acidity. Overall: A good beer.
Bottle shared.  Pours clear brown with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet malts, ripe fruits, raisins and burnt oats.  Flavour is medium sweet and light bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.
35cl. Bottle shared with friends.  Thin off white head. Clear amber pour. A little bitterness.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours deep dark inky brown with medium off white head. Aroma is sweet molasses and lightly charred malts. Taste is smooth chocolate biscuit malt with floral piney hops on the finish. Just a touch bitter on the aftertaste. Rich yet balanced. Really restrained, when you think about it, would have been easy for Dogfish to overdo this one.
Off draft. Good hop aroma. Hop flair balances surprisingly well with brown ale character.

Pour from a 12 oz glass. Deep red / brown clear brew with big persistent head - looks like a rootbeer.  Aroma of burnt grains, coffee, grass. Taste is slightly sweet at the start, dark fruits and a little brown sugar transitioning to bitter coffee, burnt grains, and somewhat sweet finish with coffee overtones. Im not picking up on the dry hopping - was hoping for something like Green Flashs Hop Head Red. But, a very rich and flavorful brown ale - Id put it squarely in the brown category, though far better than most.

355 ml bottle @ Hotel room, Las Vegas.
Pours clear dark red color with small head. Aroma of caramel, sweet malts, ripe fruit notes and brown sugar. Flavor of topacco, raisins, malts, caramel and brown sugar. Bitter malty palate. Unbalanced, definitely a disappointment.
4424
bottle @ Jockey Club, Las Vegas. pours ruby with small beige head. dark sugar in the aroma. bitter, ashtray flavor.

35,5 cl bottle @ hotel room, Las Vegas. Bottled on 05.04.2012 18:49
Aroma is somewhat stale and slighly floury with some roasted malt, fruits, hay and flour. Flavour is tart, sweet, rather sticky and bitter in a harsh way with lots of brown sugar, some raisins, orange and coffee. Not my kind of stuff, too sweet and sticky. Feels like kotikalja with sugar added.

250712. Bottle at hotel in Las Vegas. Pours clear dark brown with a nice medium head. Aroma burnt malts, sugar. Brown sugary sweet low alcohol home made beer type of taste. Low palate for this amount of ABV. Very boring.

Elegant ruby brown with a thick, fluffy head. Brown sugar and creme brûlée nose. Opulent, soft palate countered by rustic nutty flavors. Malty elements add sweetened layers. High carbonation keeps this rich, but not cloying.

Sample at Studio 35 during the Dogfish Head tasting/Batman movie. Pours a clear reddish-brown color with a medium thin tan head that evaporates steadily. Spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and hops. Medium body with flavors of chocolate, roasted nuts, malt and hops. The finish is sweet and roasty with a chocolate malt aftertaste. Above average overall.

Bottle. Interesting nose, makes me think of malts in a brewery. Pours jet black-brown, off white to light tan head. I get some black licorice, woodiness, coffee, roasted malts - delicious. Long lasting palate.

I feel like everyone has a different take on this particular dfh...its definitely one of the most complex brews Ive ever tasted...I feel like its a very hoppy tasting brown ale; a friend of mine described it as if new castle and sam adams had a baby...brown sugar notes are very strong, a hint of maple syrup maybe?  Definitely a unique brew and worth a try...Ive had it both on tap at the Fairfax location as well as poured from a bottle into a tulip glass btw....

From a bottle on 7-13-12, thanks Howard! Poured into a pint glass with a one-finger head, rich brown color. Aroma is slight cocoa, maybe a hint of coffee. Taste is very rich, mimics the nose, with additional notes of caramel. Balance tends towards the malty vs. hoppy, but is a very enjoyable beer.

Pours a very dark ruby brown.  Aroma is malty with faint cocoa/chocolate notes.  Taste is very good, notes of caramel, malt, chocolate, roastiness which are then finished up with a crisp hop note which balances greatly.  The mixture of the rich notes followed by the crisp hops is great on the palate.  Very nice

12 oz bottle from De Bierkoning @ home. Clear dark brown color. Beige dense head, long lasting. Aromas: lots of roast, pumpernickel bread, toast, caramel/brown sugar, mocha/sweet coffee, hints of red fruit & citrus. Flavor is medium sweet, with a lot of roast and a light bitterness. Medium bodied. Finishes with more roast and rather bitter. Really like this.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 Clear ruby brown.Thin head but great lacing at first but diminishing.
 Strong raison chocolate notes,milk chocolate and mocha, sweet molasses.maple/vanilla, bready/slight toast,some alcohol .Very nice aroma
Taste has strong carmalized brown sugar notes hops are muted by the flavor but you know they are there. Strong dry sugar alcohol notes raisony flavor with nice bittering. Kinda slick and smooth with chocolate raison in flavor and a nice carmalized sweet with the bittering. Different and pretty flavorfull. Pretty good description header that matches. This is a hopdark- scotch. Pretty malty with some hoppiness to match.

It pours a deep dark brown with a thin tan head. Everything else can be described as complex. It has the undertone of a brown but its so much more than that!  I really smell the brown sugar & raisins. Those flavors also stand out in the taste. Its a touch thick & chewy for a brown but it tastes incredible!  A very, very nice beer.

Tempting aroma and a brown pour leads to an almost scotch style ale taste with a balanced mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tasted: bottle. Deep amber to brown color, with a cream head. A sweet caramel, brown sugar aroma with a touch of hops. Tasted of roasted chocolate, caramel and brown sugar with a bitter hop backing. The malt profile is very nice but it is hard to pick out the hop profiles. Heavier hop additions would be nice. Overall a very good beer.

Served at 52F.  Pours a deep amber with light tan head.  Simple aroma of toasted malt.  Flavor is well-balanced between sweetness and slight hop bitterness.  Finish combines both malt bitterness from the roasted malt, and an added punch of sweetness at the very end.  Medium mouthfeel with mild carbonation.  A very enjoyable beer.

Aroma is brown sugar, toffee, nuts, and chocolate. Poured a deep clear mahogany with a finger of tan head. Taste is coffee, chocolate, ginger, a slight nuttiness, and a little bit sweet. Has a lingering bittersweet in your mouth.

Pours a dark caramel with a shallow caramel head. Big malty, brown sugar aromas with hints of coffee and chocolate. Taste is a bit on the sweet side from the caramelized sugar, but the hop bitterness is strong and helps cut through that, but the caramel and sugar flavors overpower on the tongue and thats what sticks with you. Overall sweeter/heavier than your typical black IPA style, but thats not necessarily what this one is shooting for.
Earthy, caramel, deep bodied flavor. Little aftertaste. Strong flavor. Drinks well out of glass or bottle.
Bottle, pours dark brown/black with a light white head.  Smooth but flavorful, with a slight caramel finish.  Tastes a hair watery, otherwise a very good beer.
Draft. Pours dark brown to black. Tan head, mostly thin. Sweet dark sugar molasses on the nose. Malts and alcohol on the taste. Followed by lingering hops. Complex. Hints of dark chocolate and cocoa.

Havent had this in a while, but someone compared it to the Flashback the other day, so it needed a rating.  Not as hoppy as the Flashback, but still holding a nice balance between a brown and an IPA.  Roasty, mildly nutty, and hopped pleasantly.  Need to sip it again soon!
Very malty aroma.  Smooth chocolate taste.  Finish is very sweety with some coffee hint.  Overall east to drink stout but nothing that stands out

Bottle. Pours brown thin tan head. Pleasing aroma of chocolate, caramel, coffee, and brown sugar. Medium sweet chocolate and roast taste. Medium-full body, creamy texture, excellent bitter balance in the finish. Overall very enjoyable brown ale.

Tap. Pours clear reddish brown with a small head and some lacing. Aroma is dominated by roasted malt, a bit of coffee. Taste is slightly sweet, roasted malt, grain, a bit of coffee, slightly bitter finish, but overall the 50 IBU are masked extremely well, unfortunately.
Loved the malt and molasses (and other) undertones peeking through the hops.

12 ounce bottle. Rich mahogany brown color topped by a fluffy long lasting tan head. Nice roasted caramel malt aroma hints at chocolate, pecans and brown sugar. Wonderful chocolate malt flavor that coats the mouth. Nice hop prescence balances this really well. Probably my favorite brown ale ever. I love this brew!

Draught.
Pours a dark brown, with a beige head.
Malty, hoppy aroma, caramel, chocolate, toffee, spruce.
Off-dry, medium body medium to high bitterness, balanced CO2.
Spicy, malty taste, caramel, hops, candied sugar, figs, ashes.
Quite rich, slightly cloying.
(2012-05-02)

Compared to the Aprihop, this comes in below in my book.  Though both are operating under the big flavors fighting each other banner.  This works a little less.  This one weighed me down.  Caused me some palate fatigue for sure.  I got more of the Scotch and darker notes.

Bottle - Roasted malty woody nose with hints of espresso.  Very dark but clear brown, with a minimal brown head.  Tastes much like its aroma, but I dont get any much in the way of hops or bitterness.  A nice desert beer, great for the coffee drinker.

Tap. Pours clear brown with average, creamy beige head; decent retention and good lacing. Aroma is toasted and caramel malt, figs, grassy hops, and faint oak. Flavor is sweet malt forward with some dark fruit esters and faint hops; sweet finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

Tap in the Ginger Man, NYC. My one strong beer of the evening as a concession to it being a school night! Pretty serious stuff this. A very dark brown colour with a reasonable white head. Taste is very complex, lots of malt with toast, rye bread, bit of caramel sweetness, some booze, and a drier bitterness on the finish. Did have a slightly weird note on the nose, not sure what it was but didnt quite smell right. Overall very good though, and unusual.

A - Pours a dark brown with a thin finger of frothy khaki colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some good lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of brown sugar, caramelized and bready malts, piney and citrus hops, coffee, and a bit of chocolate and dark fruit.

T - Starts off with sweet brown sugar, caramelized malts, and some citrus hops and light bitterness. Through the middle, some biscuit and bready malt comes through with some pine hops and a bit more bitterness. The finish adds some sweet dark fruit with some brown sugar, caramelized malts, citrus hops, coffee, and chocolate.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet, dry, and lightly bitter finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nice hybrid style beer. There are a lot of flavors that come together and balance really nicely.

12 oz bottle.
Pours a dark brown, almost black with a 2 finger off white head.
Very dark,, almost as dark as an average stout. Mild carbonation with a malty light alcohol aroma. Wonderful flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee, full bodied... not bitter and well balanced. Nice crisp short finish.
Nice malt finishes medium sweet with a touch of complexity lingers, but still a very smooth brown ale. Dogfish takes everything that they do seriously, dont they? 
If tasting brown ales, make sure this one makes your list.
It is a nice beer, but kind of lacks a heavier body (too mild). Also, lacks more evident chocolate notes.
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2014 Aroma is malts, a good hoppiness and a nuttiness.  The flavor is dark grains, coffee, and an undercurrent of citrus hops/bitterness in the finish.

Originally reviewed: 11/6/09. Bottled on 09/09/09. Poured into my pint glass. 

Pours a ruby-tinted deep brown with a thin tan head on top. Little retention. Leaves some spotty lace on the glass. Scents of toffee, toasted bread, almonds, and light alcohol waft out. This smells very inviting. 

The mouth is a tad thin. Ive had this a few times and have noticed this same characteristic. Could stand a bit more carbonation zip. Sweet flavors of toffee, caramel, toasted nuts, and brown sugar are present. Theres a slight alcohol burn on the finish that is slightly annoying, but it dissipates quickly. Not sure I would call this an Indian brown as there is little-to-no hop presence. Just an all-around good sweet brown.
Perfect brown ale for sipping on day round. Easy to drink. Tastes of coffee and chocolate. Nice hop undertones and malty flavors.

Poured from 12oz bottle dated 1/12/12 into Nonic pint glass.
Aroma: malt, chocolate, hops, roasty, coffee, a bit nutty, dark fruits
Appearance:  Fairly clear but a deep rich brown.  1 finger of frothy milk chocolate brown head that faded in a minute or so.  Laces glass well.
Taste: mild sweet, medium sour, mild bitter.  
Palate:  medium body and creamy slick texture.  lively carbonation.  very tame finish that is hardy bitter and slightly sour
Overall:  This beer isnt what I expected it to be but I am impressed.  I thought it was going to be more hoppy from the description but actually ended up being maltier than expected.  Almost a bit like a hoppy porter with the chocolate and coffee aromas.  I will pick this up again next time Im in the distribution area.
Pours a very dark brown color with a good sized tan head and decent lacing. Aroma is of chocolate and caramel. Taste is coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, and toffee. Well balanced and medium bodied.

Poured into an English pint glass from a 12 ounce bottle bottled on 1-27-2012.

A: Deep clear garnet body with a medium sized tan head with decent retention.

S: Semi-sweet aroma of sugar and nuts.

T: Sweet yet semi-dry. Nice blend of sugar and nuts. Very easy to drink with good flavor.

M: Medium bodied with plenty of fizzy carbonation.

O: This is one of my favorite year round brown ales available at a good price.

From bottle. Pours almost black with lite cream head. Smells of figs and has a spicy hop backbone. Taste is very similar to the aroma. Chewy thick mouthfeel with a sweet malty finish. Wonderful hybrid of a beer. Watch the alcohol b/c it's deceptively drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: Pours a nice ruby reddish brown with one finger head thats creamy off-white in color. Head dissipates quickly and leaves some moderate lacing.

S: Not a very aromatic brew at all! I do pick out mild hops and brown sugar but believe it or not thats all and at that these are not very strong at all.

T: This one starts off with hop bitterness and then evolves into mild sweetness with a touch of malt. Then the bitterness returns on the swallow and leaves the bitterness behind. Well done!

M: Medium to thin with slight carbonation that that pricks at the taste buds nicely. 

O: Highly drinkable and enjoyable. Smooth and slightly hoppy with just the right amount of sweetness to balance the bitter notes. Best brown Ive had to date!

Dark redish brown body, whiteish head. Aroma has chocolate, brown sugar, slightly roasted malt, and coffee. Flavour is bit tight and roasted with dark molasses and herbal hop notes. Very much flavour though.
Darn good brown ale. Complex nutty flavor, and like most of the Dogfish standbys, very rounded out and balanced all the way through.
Dark brown with a big fluffy head. Smell is roasted malts, faint hops, and a very small amount of coffee. Taste is toasted barley, toffee, cocoa, caramel. Well carbonated.

Wow, one of the best brown ales I have ever had. The nose is big and complex. Strong notes of coffee, toffee, toast, and brown sugar dominate the malt side, but are balanced by a significant hop presence. The beer is a clear deep brown with some interesting highlighting throughout. The taste balances the malt notes from the aroma with dome rasins and then full hop development. The beer is medium, clean, and drinks easily.  A great beer for meals or just to knock back.

Dark brown with a small head and
dissipates quickly, looks almost black. A good wiff of malt and some light hops. The
smell isn't too strong. Starts off malty, then you get a little bit of
the hop bite, and finishes with a dry, alcohol like
flavor. Medium bodied, not too thick or syrupy.
Goes down pretty clean. I'm a complete hophead and not a huge fan
of brown ales, but their description inspired me to
give it a try. Definitely one of my favorite browns so
far, but the hop addict in me would like to see a little
more bite and the end (like Sweetwater's Imperial
Stout, Happy Ending). Good beer though.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2012 At the "Expired Beer Tasting" at Dagans Place. Thanks Lee. Pours brown with a small head, aroma of nuts, coriander, chocolate and light acidity, flavor of chocolate, bitter with lively carbonation, medium bodied
 6/3/6/3/11[2.9] 

Bottle Shared at a tasting at Ariels place. Pours brown to orange with a medium head, aroma of chocolate, nuts, some roasted malt  and hops, flavor is bitter and smoked with some hops, grapefruit skin, medium bodied, nice  7/3/7/3/14[3.4]

From notes.  First reviewed 11/26/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a DFH signature tulip.

Indian Brown pours an almost black mahogany color with a few ruby highlights. A full tan head bubbles up initially into a sea foam froth consistency, but a small foamy film maintains for the entire glass. Specks of lace dot the glass.

There are a few different things going on in the nose. Sweet brown sugar and caramel malt notes are fairly sweet, roasted malt provides some cocoa flavors as well, and there are some bitter earthy notes to close it out.

The flavor also tilts toward the malty end of the spectrum. Some caramel sweetness mixed with toasted grains, some light cocoa, and a bit of peat start out. Although there is a sweetness present, it does not dominate. The flavor turns to a bit of burnt brown sugar, peat, cofffe, and some earthy notes in the middle. Toward the end, the earthy notes turn bitter and pick up a bit of citrus for some further bitterness. 

For the style, this definitely has a nice, rich, full body. Creamy and smooth carbonation enhance the pleasant taste experience.

When I compare this to other American Brown Ales I have had in the past, a comparison is almost unfair. This is bigger, bolder, and more complex than what I have seen in the category.
Not your average brown ale.  Much more malt and strong chocolate, coffee, and toasted malt flavor. Tasted more like a stout than a typical brown ale.

A: Pours brown with an orange hue, and a two finger tan head. S: roasted coffee malts, brown sugar and earth funk. T: Toasty, sweet and bitter with notes of molasses, coffee, raisins, wood, leather and earth. Med body. Roasted bitter after taste with sweet cane sugar. Hop presence is there, but you dont get anything floral from it. P: Bitter sweet taste lingers for quite a while on the tongue, invited you to drink more. O: This is some what like a porter because of its toasty malt and hop profile, but it has some very nice complex flavors going on the are unique. Well balanced, and easy to drink.
olor a malta y caramelo,al paladar una sensacion de chocolate y suaves notas de cafe se perciben entre el lupulo bien pronunciado de esta increible cerveza
user_location: SANTIAGO DE LOS CABALLEROS, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

text: One of my favorite beers. Pours a nice dark brown. Aroma is chocolate, raisins, brown sugar and some  Strong coffee flavor, some cocoa. Caramel sweetness in the middle. Hops are present throughout but spike at the end. Biter but not too much. Awesome beer for sure.

A reddish-brown beer with a cream colored head.  Light on the aroma but big on the taste.  Has the flavors of a Scotch ale but the bright notes of an IPA.  The sugars are bold with caramelized cooked flavor.  Damn good afternoon beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a thick, dark brown with a thin beige head. Tastes like caramel and dark chocolate, with a dark coffee bitterness in the finish. Leaves a very pleasant caramel and sweet chocolate taste in mouth. Body is average, mouthfeel is very creamy. Slightly over-carbonated, but I gotta say this is an excellent brown ale.

A smokey aroma with a deep dark brown coloring. A sharp hoppy front is followed by a dark chocolate palate. The finish is reminds me of a light IPA, with added stout characteristics. Extremely interesting ale that is worth the money.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a very dark amber, looks like soda almost. Aroma is sweet and malty with some honey and biscuit notes also some darker richer smoked malts. Taste is similar in feel to the aroma with some of the biscuity feel sticking to the back of your throat. has the feel of a liquid coffee cake almost with a slightly bitter taste to it. The aroma definitely masks some of the bitterness. This is a very pleasing beer that will make my list for top 5 favorite browns.

Crisp, burnt  flavors. Dark in color and medium in body. a clean, well hopped brown ale with aromatic barley, caramelized brown sugar and whole-leaf Liberty and Goldings hops.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

on tap poured into standard pint glass

a: very deep mahogany brown color with a creamy 1/2" off-white head with slight retention

s: sweet malt aroma, slight chocolate and sugar aroma

t: very smooth and complex beer with layer of malt, chocolate, nut. Slight hop bitterness blances it well. alchohol well hidden until it warms.

m&d: full mouthfeel, not much carbonation

12er to pint....burnished amber with ample khaki top slowly rewarding senses with caramelized malts. As hops intensifies in the mouth pick up subtle fruit notes most notably raisin with underlying toffee/cocoa reemerging. All coming together quite delightfully as it finishes with savory bite. Very nice ale.

12 oz bottle poured into glass; why the heck did it take me so long to try this?  GREAT brown;  aroma is of malts, some roasted ness and hint of toffee.  dark brown pour.  Flavor is similar to aroma with some well balanced hops - great beer

Dark mahogany color with ruby highlights and an off white head from a brown twelve ounce bottle. Aroma is a cocoa/toffee and coffee smell. Taste also reflects the same. Aftertaste is on the bitter side, but not too extreme.
Decent brown ale: nice resin and caramel aroma; clear brown appearance with a frothy tan head; light amount of sweetness; bubbly sensation.

Det blir nästan inte bättre än så här. Ett generöst skum, ovanpå en mörk härlig öl. Doftar av ingefära, citrus och kaffe. Långvarig smak av mörk choklad, kaffe, citrus och så många andra smaker att orden inte räcker till. Detta är nog den bästa öl jag någonsin smakat, och det enda som grämer mig är att jag bara köpte denna enda flaska på min resa till Florida. Jag sparar 10:orna i smak och arom till något som kanske mest är en utopi.

bottle, sweet, malty.....light hoppy esters, color, dark medium amber, pours nice white head, taste, wow, neat double take on the malt and hops coming together quickly, slight sugary on the backend, overall, awesome brown ale! one of my favs!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Pours a deep brown with a slight reddish hue. A creamy off-white head that laced the glass well, signifying the ample hop content. Rich caramel and hazelnut flavor notes underlying a smooth malty profile. Tasted sweet with a chewy mouthfeel that transforms into a tangy, nutty hoppiness at the finish.
Pours dark chocolate brown with a medium tan head.  Asia is coffee, juniper berry and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is dark roasted malt with a nice hop bite.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2016 Fantastically rich flavor with dense, thick head. Roasted aromas, chocolate-caramel taste, and smoo-ooo-ooth!
draft - pours opaque brown.  Aroma is caramel and hops along with coffee.  Medium to full body and thin texture.  Starts sweet and ends bitter.  Not one for hoppiness, but this was very good.

Coffee, ginger, raisin and molasses aroma. Very dark brown with a tan head  that levels to cover the top. Roasted malt start. Sour in the middle. Very carbonated. Deep raisin notes sensed in the middle. Fades to a mild clean finish.

A - pours dark mahogany brown with 1 finger off white head that does not linger. S - aromas of dough, coffee, chocolate up front. Hints of smoke, molasses as well. M - rather light medium body with high carb and lingering chocolate ending. T - dough, chocolate on the nose. Lightly hoppy smoke, molasses on the palate. Lingering bitter hoppy chocolatey end. O - interesting brown ale, bitter hops and chocolate add to it. 6/6+

From the 120z bottle purchased at The BeerHive in Pittsburgh.  Could be the best hybrid brown ale currently available.  Leans to the sweeter side of taste, most likely due to the Scotch Ale influence.  Tastes of candied yams and a slight tang of metal add to its uniqueness.

"On Tap at the Dogfish Head Alehouse in Fairfax VA. Poured into a Pint Glass. Paid $7.
A - Two finger light brown head. The beer itself was dark brown with amber hues around the edges of the glass. 
S - Lots of malt, spice some cedar wood but also some brown sugar / holiday spices!
T - Still, lots of malt coming through, toffee, brown sugar and something floral but I cant quite place it.
M - Very heavy with a solid carbonation that makes me smile ear to ear.
O - I LOVE this beer. Just over 7% ABV means i can drink a lot of it and it goes great with salads and breadsticks. Just a nice beer to sip or gulp!"
Aroma is a maple malt as is the flavor.  Its a black ale with a brown head.  It has a bit if a strange aftertaste but pretty good overall.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2015 pours a dark  brown with minimul white head.aroma is of chocolate,coffee and malt but doesnt overwhelm.flavours of coffee and malt but once again nothing to complex about this.dry slightly hoppy finish.overall this is just average.i know it scores high and i dont why.
Pours brown with nice full head. Toasted malt and chocolate aroma, some sweet malts then a little bitter hops. Well made, but a bit sweet for my taste.

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a medium tan head.  Aroma is raisinettes and coffee.  Taste is sharp roasted malts, caramel, dark chocolate, and a slight acidity on the back end.  Full bodied with a bit of a woody mouthfeel.  This is delicious and more complex than most brown ales.  Theres a more satisfying hop bitterness with this beer that is rare with this style.  Good stuff.

On tap at Petrol Station. Pours a clear deep amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount bread and dark grain with some roast and a hint of brown sugar. Flavor has roast with a note of dark bread with some roast and a hint of brown sugar.
very dark brown pour. Reddish/tan hue. Aroma of malt, chocolate and hops. full bodied, earthy and some chocolate present. Hops on the backend.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2012 12 oz bottle pours  deep brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate with some espresso notes, caramel malt, caramelized sugar, slight spicy hops and a subtle touch of alcohol.  I had a taste of chocolate at first then I got caramelized sugar, vanilla, and slight hop bitterness in the back which helps balance

Bottle at WOB.  Pours a very dark brown with a thin beige head that leaves nice lacing along the glass.  Molasses on the nose with a hoppy bite.  Similar flavor with some roasted malt and tobacco notes in the finish.
This is a hoppy brown ale, but its fairly tame. Brown sugar and malt dominate with a hoppy backend. Nice beer.

Absolutely fantastic aroma. Pretty good cross between IPA and brown ale, as advertised. Balanced between malt and hop profile, though finish is slightly shorter than desired. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a white head. Smells of brown sugar, caramel and lightly roasted malt. Tastes a medium bitter with a strong mellowing sweet that follows. Finishes slightly chemically bitter.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 Bottle pours reddish brown with beige head. Smell is nice, a green hop flavor covers the chocolate barley (after 1 1/2 years smell is sweet toffee and a sweet scotch with some chocolate malt). The taste is awesome for a brown, rich and chocolaty but very evenly balanced beer, dry and sweet malt. The hops go so well that at 50 ibu you have to look for the flavor it blends so well. Moderate carbonation fits well and makes it drinkable at most all occasions. With some warmth it does have a little more scotch ale taste, not that it hurts it at all.

A deep brown color with a foamy tan head.  The aroma has hops, sweet malt, and a bit of coffee.  The flavor has strong malts, with an aftertaste of coffee, chocolate, and a bit of hop tartness and a smooth body.

Pours a very dark brown with little head. Smell consists of coffee, caramel, with a hint of hops. The taste starts out with chocolate and coffee flavors and clean crisp hop flavors appear towards the end.  This is one tasty and easy drinking brew.

Great taste of bread and loads of hops. Very smooth pour, clean head and a taste of fresh baked bread. The taste lingers long after youre done drinking a pint. Recommended for hop heads for sure. Havent met a Dogfish head I didnt like.

One of my faves, first had it on tap, tonight I am tasting a bottle up against my attempted homebrew clone.  Deep brown, nice reddish tones where the beer meets bottom of the glass.  The lightest hint of bittersweet cocoa, followed up with smooth dark malty flavor.  Just enough aroma hops to offset the malt, all in all a great balance achieved here.  If you find yourself tiring of too many hop-forward IPAs, this is an amazing effort from DFH.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 For some reason I didnt want to like this, but I did, very much so. I dont care what you call itscotch, Indian, brown, this is quite a beer. The initial aromatic assault is mostly of notes derived from the dark maltscoffee beans, toffee, chocolate, burnt caramel (in a good way) and molassesalmost like a lesser stout. The taste is more hop-oriented, with a grassy feel to it, but very good. Very pleasant and all-around good beer.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2012 Dark dark brown with a thin white head.  Smells of chocolate and roasted malt.  Tastes are some of the same.  A really solid every occasion beer.

Pours a dark brown with a foamy head.  Tons of carbonation, felt like the cap took itself off.  Maybe it was shook up and I didnt know it.  Smells of roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste a bit of whiskey, chocolate, caramel and coffee.  Very good brown.

This is quite a good brown! The higher alcohol gives it a slightly odd aroma and palate for a brown, but the complex flavor profile keeps me coming back. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cerveza color café obscuro, con pequeña cabeza blanca que presenta regular retención, aroma de intensidad media con notas de chocolate, malta tostada y lúpulo cítrico, me parecio excelente el aroma. El sabor tambien es delicioso, las notas de lupulo citrico son mas intensas que en el aroma, pero estan muy bien balanceadas por las notas de chocolate y malta tostada. Excelente Chela.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Dark reddish brown with small beige head. Nice aroma of dark roasted malt with hints of chocolate and coffee. Slight hop flavor and bitterness is present but this is definitely more brown/scotch ale than IPA.

Bottle.Pours a dark brown with a thin dissipating head. Smells of caramel, dried fruits, particularly raisins. Taste is of fruits.. raisins.. chocolate.. a little coffee.  This guy is really good but a little on the sweet side. Recommended.
Taste of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee and nuts that produces a very nice roasted and burnt flavor. A very good brown ale that is a  drinkable, creamy, and flavorrful beer.

Very dark commanding appearance, almost as dark as an average stout. Small head, mild carbonation with a malty alcohol aroma. Wonderful flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee, full bodied... not bitter and well balanced. Nice crisp short finish. Guess what ...The Dog did it again !!!!

Pours a dark brown, almost black with a 2 finger off white head.  Smells like a glass of hot chocolate (made with milk, not water) that someone then refrigerated overnight, marshmallows and all.  Very sweet chocolate in the nose.  Mouthfeel is chalky, kind of thick and very milk chocolate.  Im not getting any of the ginger they say in the description, but I am getting some hop bite on the tongue that I did not detect in the aroma.  This is a damn good beer.

Bouteille de 12oz. Encore merci Patrick. Bière brune translucide avec une mousse beige foncée, elle est peu durable. Le nez est une composition fruitée avec des notes prononcées de caramel et de houblon. La bouche est bien amère, ronde et sucrée. Bon goût de caramel et fruité (levure). Le corps est moyen et le finale est bien amère.

From bottle.  Nice colour (presuming you like brown ales) and moderate head.  Caramel, chocolate, coffee, and raisin tastes.  Not too sweet.  Bitter, strong finish.  A beer Id prefer after something lighter - i.e. not a session, but definitely worth trying.

12oz bottle. Pours deep dark brown with a nice eggshell head. Aroma of toasted, caramelized, and roasted malts with floral hops and dark fruit. Taste of deeply roasted malts with toasted nuts, maple syrup, brown sugar, dark chocolate, espresso, and bitter hops. Full mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Complex, rich, unique, and very drinkable. Awesome stuff.

12 ounce bottle bought a year ago at Sun Devil Liquors in Phoenix ($1.99).  Pours a dark brown with red highlights and one finger of frothy beige head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, toasted grains, nuts, molasses, and vanilla.  Nice and complex flavor of New Orleans-style coffee with chicory, creamy chocolate, roasted nuts, some dark fruit, and ashy hard roasted malts.  Creamy mouthfeel with some lingering dark roasted malts on the palate.  I certainly dont get the hoppy notes that this beer is supposed to have, but its still one of the best "brown ales" that I have had.  (1780, 639)

Pours clear deep ruby with light brown head and great retention.  Aroma is coffee, nuts, raisin, chcolate, caramel.  Taste is reminiscent of a nutty brown ale as well as a malt-rich scotch ale.  Notes of dark caramel, molasses, wood, chocolate, coffee, and dried fruit dance across the palate and leave a warming boozy aftertaste.  Body is medium, oily/creamy, low carbonation, roasty bittersweet finish.  Overall, a great beer that I have not had in years.  Just proves that when DFH sticks to "conventional" beers, they can hit a home run every time.

On Tap Bridge View Tavern. Sleepy Hollow Ny!  
Nice dark brown pour with a nice tan head.  Roasted goodness and crisp chocholet undertones start this fine ale out. Let it linger on your toung a while. Enjoy it. This is a nice beer on a cold rainniy day.

11.13.2011 - Houston, TX
Bottle

Dark, almost stout like appearance. Strong, distinct aroma of mocha and coffee. Hints of dark chocolate and coffee that hits the palate really strong and the settles to a wonderfully lingering finish. One of my favorites.

(12 oz, Richford, VT)  Une petite tête mousseuse plus ou moins tenace flotte sur un liquide profondément brun.  Le nez est agréable avec des arômes de malts foncés : des parfums chocolatés avec du caramel, des pointes de café et une fine touche de réglisse noire.  Les saveurs suivent les arômes : les grains rôtis sont doux et touchés par de petites touches fruitées.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence irréprochable et une texture légèrement huileuse.  La finale se fait sur des notes maltées et légèrement épicées.
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2011 Une des rares bière qui a sa place à nimporte quelle occasion. Avec ses notes de cassonade et de houblons floraux, elle est conçue sur mesure pour être engloutie sans compter.

1. Look  A ruby brown ale that looks very tasty and pours a small off white almost tan color head.
2. Sniff  It has a chocolaty coffee like aroma whit some roasted malt notes as well. 
3. Sip  This full bodied ale has a roasted malty flavor that is fairly intense leaving long lasting coffee and chocolate taste.  Additionally, this ale has a smooth, wet, and light hop taste that is very tasty.
4. Another Look  This is a good looking ale that has weak to average lacing.  
5. Evaluate  Overall, this is an interesting ale.  It has plenty of roasted chocolate and coffee flavors with a stronger hop taste than most brown ales.  I would recommend this to fans of porters, stouts, and heavy brown ales.

355ml bottle poured a reddish-brown color with big beige head that left some nice lacing behind.  Aroma is roasted malts and hops.  Taste is balanced nicely with roasted malty sweetness and a bold hoppy bitterness.  Medium to heavy body and ample carbonation give a nice mouthfeel.  This is one fine brew and was very tasty and highly recommended to try this out.

I expected a hoppy brew.  Instead I got balance - bravo Dogfish Head!  Dark amber with a generous head and lots of lace.  The caramelized sugar is there, as is roasted malt and molasses.  The hops are there as well, and strong, but not enough to take over.  A bit heavy and filling, but otherwise very well done.

Pours deep mahogany with a large, fluffy tan head. Smells like caramel and other malts and hoppiness and a bit of what could be coffee. Tastes like brown sugar, molasses, coffee, hints of chocolate and roastiness, and some bitterness aside from coffee. Full-bodied with a slightly sticky texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale finishes with a coffee or chocolate dryness.

Bottle from choice beverages.  Pours a deep brown/almost black with a thin off whute head.  The aromas are chocolate, citrus, dough.  The mouthfeel is slightly dry, bitter and bready with a heavy body.  Great beer!  Cheers!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2013 Before you hunt me down, I just do not care for their interpretation of this style. This just fell flat for me. Too much Dark / Black hops. The hops far outweighed the malty presence I desire in a brown. Not a fave....... But if I at a party, I take it over a macro anyday!
UPDATED: APR 23, 2014 Pours brown with a pilowy tan head. Smells chocolate and raisin, herbs.  Tastes sweet and moderately bitter - chocolate, hint of coffee, floral hops.

4/10/2011 on tap @ Rattle n Hum, NYC (2011-514)
Deep ruby red purple to brown beer, creamy beige head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: sweet cherry liquor, smoke and wood, quite some port, mocha, dark chocolate, heavy on the alcohol. MF: ok carbon, full body, thick oily texture. Taste: mocha, red fruits, sour cherries, dark chocolate, bit of smoke, coffee bitter. Aftertaste: port, fudge, coffee, black chocolate bitterness.
Does dogfish head do anything wrong? No this brown is perfect extremely smooth with a great flavor of brown sugar and chocolate.

Bottle from Bierkraft on my visit to NYC. Poured a lovely chestnut brown with a small frothy white head. Notes of chocolate nuts, molasses and piney hops. Loads of piney hops in this one with a very nice burnt caramel backing. Notes of honey and brown sugar in there as well. Enjoyed this one a lot

Wow, a good brew by DFH. Aroma has plenty of molasses and brown sugar notes, with some cinnamon and slight caramel notes as well. Pourd a dark brown with frothy khaki head. Nice. Taste is caramel and slight piney hops. Some notes of burnt sugar and molasses again. A very balanced brew for sure and drinkable as hell. Im glad they were able to present all the flavors of the hops and malts at once, leaving nothing missed out on. Excellent.
Molasses notes without being too sweet.  Perfectly balanced.  It says well hopped and Im not into over-the-top hops.  This was perfect!

Great leaping six-toed lizards!! This has absolutely got to be the MOST robust brown ale I have yet to savor! Its stated that it is a cross between a scotch ale, an IPA and an American brown ale  I call it delicious!!  The ease of drinkability on this brew is phenomenal and I found myself having to keep from going bottoms-up and chugging it down! (But Im oh-so-sorry to report that I could not resist the temptation any longer  but damn that was gooooooooood!) No other brown ale that I have tried thus far compares to this and Im afraid that the bar has been set very high  at least in my humble average joe opinion. Plenty will be on-hand for some slow grilled rib-eyes or perhaps some deep-fried turkey this coming Thanksgiving! Smooth, aromatic, creamy, robustly flavorful  now I am wishing I had more of this succulent brew!

Draft... Dark brown with a really nice medium mocha head, great retention, almost looks like a nitro pour, ridiculous lacing... Weak nose, but ok, a nice roasty note with a little chocolate... The taste is a bit plain but is appealing and its excellent mouthfeel makes me coming back for more

As some of you know from my other ratings, Dogfish is one of my favorite breweries in America. This beer is just another reason why I delight in their experimentation, even if it is just a brown ale. The aroma is outstanding, with key smell notes of brown sugar and smaller notes of caramel being noticeable. The taste is absolutely fantastic! You will get a nice taste of brown sugar, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, and umami.
Very dark brown, good thick tan head.  Aroma of toast and chocolate.  Taste is soft and of dark chocolate too.  Theres decent bitterness in there, but so much malt taste that it balances well.

Poured from a bottle. Pours a very dark brown, with limited by consistent head.  Beers has a complex aroma, with some coffee, caramel, and even some fresh/grassy scent mixed in.  Very rich, smooth beer with lots of body.  Its bitter, sweet, and smooth.  One of my favorite beers.  Hard to find in my area, I stock up whenever I see it.

Dark brown pour, opaque but not cloudy.  Good head lingers a bit, with the remnants persisting.  Nice lacing.  Bready, malty aroma with a hint of scotch sweetness.  Initial feel of scotch ale gives way to hoppiness that reminds me of an IPA, but without the strong bitterness, which then succumbs back to the scotch ale feel.  Its a good blend of malt and hops.   I like this.
Very nice aroma. Caramelly, fruity, a little bit of chocolate and coffee. A really interesting beer!

[bottle]
Vanilla and oak aroma reminiscent of a porter with brown sugar, raisins, and a touch of licorice. Almost opaque dark garnet under a bubbly, tan ring and wisps. Roasty flavour that is more sweet stout than brown ale, with vanilla and molasses malt in harmony with some pine hops and a blend of dark malt and hops bitterness. Good balance of sweet, tangy ethanol, and bitter dark malts and hops. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, slightly warming, with burnt almond bitter finish.
Love this beer. Dark and delicious. A perfect balance between hops and malt.
Pours dark, and has a nice strong aroma of coffee, dark malts, and chocolate. Most coffee though, and thats what makes this one awesome.

Aroma is powerful, dark roasted malts, coffee, espresso.  Amazing smell.  Strong coffee, caramel, chocolate but its really about the coffee for me. Dark, rich, like a morning meal.  Theres a lot going on.  Much love.

Dark brown pour, white head.  Aroma of roasted malts, hints of chocolate and coffee.  Well balanced, another complex brew from this brewery.  Malty taste, I like the hop flavor, full body, creamy, slight bitter finish.  Did I mention malts?  Worth buying the Dogfish Head Tackle Box for a variety of these four beers.

Bottle - pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma has notes of coffee, toast, and flowers. Taste is bittersweet, like dark chocolate, with a lingering bitter finish. The body is creamy with a medium weight.

deep brown, tan head.  Wow!!!  Aroma/Flavor are of a bit of roastiness that compliments the crystal malts in such a way to make it a biting, dark caramel.  Lots of piny, aromatic, floral hop flavor.  moderate bitterness.  Great!

355 ml bottle. Brooklyn, NY.
Black colour with red hue and small light tan head.
Roasted malt, chocolate and mild coffee in aroma.
Toasted malt and balancing dry hops. Very malty.

Sample, Mondial de la bière, savoured on June 8 2011; eye: dark brown, opaque, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: roasted malt, light burnt malt, light resinous hops, slight caramel; mouth: roasted malt, light burnt malt, acridness, resinous hops, light alcohol, finale in roasted malt with nice presence of acridness, medium-full body, average carbonation, mildly bitter, harsh texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, Mondial de la bière, savourée le 10 juin 2011; il : brune foncée, opaque, petit anneau de mousse belge, pas de dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, léger malt brûlé, léger houblon résineux, très léger caramel; bouche : malt torréfié, léger malt brûlé, âcreté, houblon résineux, léger alcool, finale en malt torréfié avec bonne présence dâcreté, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amère, texture rugueuse; en résumé : bien bon

Drinking this beer is a luxurious experience. Pours incredibly dark brown from bottle with a thin head. Nice notes of licorice and caramel on the tongue. Very thick and smooth mouthfeel. it feels a bit like pudding. You definitely get the malt but also some bread and raisin notes. The finish has some holiness to it. Its a superbly balanced beer. Part of the fun of drinking it is trying to separate out all of the disparate elements.

The beer pours a dark brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is full of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. An outstanding smelling beer. The flavor has a lot of coffee in it as well as some nice bitterness from the piney hops. I also get some roasted malt and some chocolate in the flavor. Overall, the mouthfeel is a little bit creamy and the carbonation is low to medium. A great brown ale.

Draught @ Iron Monkey, Jersey City, NJ
Pours reddish dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, choclate, caramel and fruity hops. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Poured a very deep, but clear brown. With a short-lived off-white head and syrupy lacing, this beer looks quite fantastic. The smell was complex with notes of hops, molasses, roasted coffee beans and a touch of cocoa. Id say this all smelled a bit like sweet potatoes. The taste was great - and I dont really favor brown ales! There was a rush of hops and burnt caramel, with an incredible twang of roasted malts and a touch of vanilla. The finish was dark and spicy, giving off to a very satisfied palate. Must find more brown ales like this one!
Pours dark brown with thin white head. Nose is brown sugar, caramel and earthy mineral elements.  Taste is sweet caramel, brown sugar and alcohol. A strong sweet brown beer.

12oz bottle. Dark brown, thin tan head. Light lacing. Bitter taste. Light hops aroma. Coffee nose (and aftertaste), coffee/chocolate through the front and middle, and roasty through the finish. Very nice balance. This brew, as well as Jackie-Os NelsonvALE, have brought my appreciation for brown ales up quite a few notches. Well done.

Bottle to pint glass.  Pours a dark brown / like root beer color.  Thin head with good lacing.  Has a nice roasted malt sweet flavor.  The alcohol content is pretty apparent, not that I mind.  Closer to stout than a brown ale in my estimation, but really good nonetheless.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 drank at mondial 2011 in mtl - and bottle at home. pours clear dark brown, red tint, with a decent med-dark beige head. aroma of coffee and fresh citrus-herbal hops. nutty, fruity esters, alcohol and a warm maple-smoked sweetness. medium body, soft carbonation, oily, sticky. nice stuff.
Always consistent, always good. Just the right hops for this style. I like to drink one of these a month, and everytime it puts a smile on my face.
12 oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a medium tan head.  Aromas  of roasted malts, nuts, and hops in the background.  Good flavors, with some sweetness at the end
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 Had at Small bar on Fullerton. Nice brown ale. You can smell the roasted barley. High levels of hops but not over whelming. Doesnt seem as strong as it is. Serving: Tap

I dunno why I was expecting something a lot lighter... Probably because New Castle isnt the darkest beer in the world and thats what I thought of when I saw "Brown Ale". Anyway, I bought a 6 pack today. Relatively speaking it doesnt have too strong of an aroma to it. Pours dark brown to black... Very chocolatey and nutty tasting with hints of caramel and a not too threatening hoppiness. I certainly wasnt expecting what I got but Im definitely not disappointed.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown with tan head that hangs around and some good initial lacing.  Smells of candied, roastef malt, a little brown sugar and a bit of coffee.  The taste is  very nice mixture of sweet caramel/toffee and the finishing hop bitterness with some coffee and earthiness.  Very nice and enjoyable. Quite surprised this is 7%.
this beer was ok for me definitly malty but had some nice flavors and bitterness

Pour coper/dark brown tan beige head ok lace. Aroma coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, nuttiness, cereal grain, light hops. Taste chocolate malt, coffee, cereal grain, nuttiness, good hop bitterness. MF medium body good carb. Overall excellent super easy drinking beer almost no trace of ABV very well brewed.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is mahogany with three fingers of medium kaki head; retention was above par, while the lacing was excellent.  Nose is caramel, malt, basement, toffee, and a yeasty smell that I associate with Scottish ales.  Taste is right on, but there is a surprising bitterness, akin to a pale ale with some bite, that jumps in for balance and lingers right into the finish, along with toffee and yeast.  This is a strange combination, but one that works surprisingly well to make a rock solid beer.  This could be an easy stable brew to keep a case around for easy drinking!
Pours dark brown with minimal head. Aromas of chocolate and raisins. A nice balance of hops and malts. Chocolate and raisins. This is a very enjoyable beer.

Good Brown Ale, darkly sweet yet offset by a firm hop finish, much more sugar-coated than your usual American Brown.  Of course, adding brown sugar to the recipe tends to do that, or at least, thats what Im told.  The use of "India" in the title is a bit misleading, since this bottle isnt that hoppy for a regular brown, much less an IBA.  A deep, roasted sweetness steals the show from the lackadaisical hops, but, strangely enough, such rampant sweetness doesnt overstay its welcome, nor does it grow cloy.  This beer comes off as what Belgian beer would taste like if Belgian beer had originated in the U.S. during the 90s.  (1/3/09)

Pours dark brown with some red on the outside when held up to light.the head is tan in color with big bubbles..disappears fast

The nose has roasted malts..kind of sweet..some hops..smells really good..

Taste is..roasted malt a bitter mid with a sweet malty finish

Cannot taste the alcahol..very very good brown ale
Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, hops, and molasses. Tastes the same as it smells, with a bit of chocolate as well. Ridiculously good flavor for a brown ale.
Dark brown pour, moderate tan head with nice lacing, earthy, roasted aroma, sticky caramel flavor, all around very pleasant experience.  But what else would you expect from Dogfish Head?

by far one of my favorites. pours dark brown in color witha nice malty caramel nose. taste is not as hoppy as i thought it would be but thats not a bad thing, it is a perfect balance, nice caramel, brown sugar taste. must try

My quest to rate all Dogfish Head beers I can find continues.  Pours a black opaque.  Aroma is very boozy, and sweet from the malt.  Taste has a lot of caramel. Palate is medium.  Will update as I try the other two bottles I have.

Pours a dark brown with crimson edges.  Drank at the Alehouse so the head is almost non-existant.  The taste is a dark chocolate and caramel. The finish is dry.  Overall not too bitter as the flavors really come through.

Pours a dark amber with a nice brown long lasting head, Aroma and Taste of sweet caramel malt, sweet spices, some brown sugar and molasses, and light hops. Palate is nice full body, with a rich and smooth mouth feel. Finish is sweet toasted maltiness, brown sugar and molasses, with some nice bitter cacao followed by some hoppiness for balance, a nice long bitter sweet finish. A very nicely balanced and tasty brew

courtesy of oh6gdx - dark brown colour with a little foam left; a fair aroma of toasted biscuits and chocolate, hops and licorice; medium to full-bodied, some sweetness and with a moderate bitterness; dry chocolatey and biscuity maltiness in the finish

12 oz bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, bottled September 16, 2010, served in a snifter. Pours clear chestnut with a small, dense tan head. The head fades to a thin remnant and leaves minimal lace. The nose has a rich, nutty roasted malt quality with generous earth and hops. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with lots of brown sugar and a nutty-boozy-fruity quality with a delicate herbal hoppiness towards the finish. The finish is moderate in length and hoppy. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice strong brown ale but not as hoppy as I remember. I suspect that some of the hops have retreated a bit as it aged. Definitely worth another try with a fresh bottle. 2011-04-21

Dark reddish brown pour with a nice dense light-brown head. Aroma is somewhat roasty with a hint of caramel. Also some notes of coffee, smoke, molasses, and toffee. Flavor is somewhat lighter than I expected. Strong coffee and roast notes, with trailers of brown sugar and caramel. Light, dry burnt toast and hop bitterness on the finish. Good stuff. I cant believe Ive waited so long to try it.
Tap at Beer Geeks. Great beer. Very dark with frothy head. Great mouthfeel and wonderful taste. Rich n creamy feel to it. Gonna be looking for more of this. =)
Coffee and chocolate notes in the aroma and taste.  A great mix of three different types of brews.  Lovely ending with great notes left hanging in your mouth.

Bottle. Poured into a DFH tulip (how appropriate?!) a dark clear brown color with a clight reddish tinge to it. Nice, big fluffy tan head that slowly settles and covers the glass with lace as it does. Caramel, vanilla, some dark fruit, and slight alcohol in the nose. Medium mouthfeel. Sweet, caramel and dark fruit flavors gives way to a roasted bitterness flavor with some alcohol flavors. Its pretty tasty but I think Id like it a little better with the abv knocked down a tad to really let the hops and roasted notes shine.

Another solid beer from Dogfish Head. Black/brown beer with a frothy, tan head. Aromas of molasses, brown sugar, and cocoa. Tastes of coffee beans, brown sugar, sweet caramel, molasses, and dark chocolate. Very creamy, and smooth blend. Lingering sweet finish, a bit dry. More of a hearty stout than a brown ale. Very good, definitely on the sweeter end of the spectrum for a dark beer.

Bottle from Utobeer, London. Pours dark brown with a good tan head. A sweet and hoppy beer. A near perfect blend of the sweetness from a brown ale and the hoppyness of an IPA. Hints of caramel, roasted malts and hops both on the nose and palate with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle from Breeze Thru.  Pours a rich dark, dark brown with reddish hints, lowly carbonated.  Aroma is over-roasted malts, coffee, some fruitiness, and some grassy hops.  Taste is coffee, chocolate nibs, raisins and some toastiness.  Sweet but not cloying - more oily.  Finishes sweet with some roasted malt, although somewhat thin with some alcohol in the end.  Very nice flavor and body to this.  Just a touch thicker would be a terrific porter.

pours a dark brown color almost like maple syrup.  the aroma is barley, caramel, and slight hops.  the flavor is bitter front to end, with a really sweet taste.  the taste consist of coffee,  chocolate,  molasses and hops.  the palate is really full.
Has a syrupy smell to it. Dark brown and sticky looking. The taste is pretty sweet and roasty at the end. Very smooth, delicate and creamy feel. I would buy this one again, no doubt.
Nice thick head and quite aromatic.  Almost a coffee aroma.  Taste is medium sweet and really balanced with hops and malt.  Great thick palate and it finishes quite long.  Overall a super brown.

bottle poured into tumbler. Deep purple colour with ample head. Aroma of maple syrup, sugar, hops, flowers, and chocolate. Taste is sweet and smooth but also some nice floral hops at the end.
