I drank this right after a St bernardus 12 and almost didnt rate it, but the fact that it stood up against an abbey powerhouse speaks volumes about the quality of this beer. Great stuff.
A brown ale with chocolate flavors and a huge kick of hops, though it isnt super bitter.

Bottle pours deep brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of coffee, cocoa powder, and a touch of nuts. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of dark fruit and pine.  Overall body is moderate with a light to moderately bitter finish.
Slightly hopped.  Deep brown with a nice tan head.  Medium brown ale with a nice touch of hops.  Nice and smooth.
A nice hearty ale that was not as bitter as I expected. Dark taste, yum......
Pours the color of a cola, and has a scent of coffee as well as chocolate. Subtle coffee flavor and goes down rather smooth.

Bottle @ home. Dark brown body with a tan/brown head. Roasted, slightly burnt brown malty nose with hints of molasses and nuts. Quite roasty and slightly burnt brown malty flavor with some bittering hops on the finish. The roastiness is the trademark quality of this beer. Another good brew from DFH.

Bottle, Pours deep dark brown with a decent light tan head. Nuts, grain, toffee, chocolate + roast aromas with a nice light noble-like hoppiness. Medium body, toasty medium-dark malt backbone; nutty with a touch of chocolate and a very nice lingering noble-like hop flavour. Nice malt finishes medium sweet with a  touch of complexity lingers, but still a very smooth brown ale.

12 fl oz bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black (barely translucent) with a fair tan head.
  
Aroma:  A good hit of dark chocolate and black coffee, slightly dusty, some light fruitiness and esters, I think there are some vague leafy hop notes, certainly malt-forward.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderately prickly effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Peppery, pine hops notes, a little resinous, the malts are there, but quite restrained and more stern, a slight grape note, a bit of alcohol, a little black coffee; dry with fair bitterness and a dusty, pine/leafy hop finish with some mouth-coating dark malts.

Decent.  Not my favourite example of the style, but decent.

12 oz. bottle in a shaker.  Dark chocolate brown pour with thin head.  Bitter coffee flavor with a sweet caramel chocolate finish.  Very well balanced.  A little smokiness on the finish.  Very nice beer.

On tap - Fillmore Pub in Plano.
Dark, reddish brown pour with a bit of tan head.  Roasted and chocolate malt aromas with some hop aromas and toast peeking through.  Flavor is a bit hoppier than the aroma but is extremely well balanced and easy to drink.  Small hint of brown sugar sweetness.  I used to not care for this beer and now I love it - funny how tastes change over time.  Seems to have possibly have been somewhat of a precursor to the Black IPA boom of late.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a Dogfish Head football-shaped tumbler.Appearance: Dark ruby red body - not completely opaque but translucent. Pretty color. A liberal pour produces a thick, tan, creamy/frothy head which retains very well and leaves good lacing on the glass.Smell: Such a complex nose for a beer of this caliber: smoke, dark chocolate, light hop flowers and brown sugar. Taste: The brewerys official description indicates its a hybrid of scotch ale, brown ale and IPA and I would totally agree with that and perhaps add a fourth style - stout. Theres a lot going on with this beer and yet it doesnt hit your palate like a ton of bricks. The first half is somewhat mild and sweet with brown sugar and light flowers. The second half is very smokey and woody with a coffee-like, dry bitterness. There even seems to be a dairy-like element found in milk stouts. Its amazing a beer can be simultaneously sweet and hoppy - what an achievement!Mouthfeel: Quite soft, but not as thin as most brown ales. A little intense as colder temperatures, but calms down as it warms.Drinkability: This is a beer where the statistics lie. Theres no way this beer is 7.2% ABV! It drinks like a traditional brown ale - smooth, quaffable and sessionable. This is definitely one of the most versatile beers on the mainstream craft beer market. The sweetness makes it a good dessert brew, but the hoppiness enables it to stand up to a red meat dinner.Overall, an really good beer bordering on a great beer. It doesnt quite knock my socks off the way an upper echelon beer might, but its probably the best good beer I can think of.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WoXE7-MyXT0

Deep ruby brown. Viscous and full bodied. Aromas of catamel, roasted malt, coffee, figs, raisins. A lot going on here. Taste is very bitter - 50 IBUs - but offset by brown sugar and alot of sweet roasted malt. Very intricate flavors of dried ginger powder, cola, licorice, coffee, herbal hops. Its delicious, but so much going on here. Is it a malty porter? An overhopped brown ale? A light Black IPA? I guess its an Indian Brown Ale. Overall very good.
I loved this beer. I had it with some sushi and it really paired well. Dark brown, but very smooth. The brown sugar is noticeable.

12 oz bottle. Pours a very dark ruby amber. Lots and lots of flavor- woody and scotchy spice, roasty malts, sour fruits, cocoa and coffee with a nice big bitter hop bite. All in all, very clean and very flavorful.

Pours a dark brown with a tan, creamy head. Moderate carbonation with a faint malty aroma.

Malty dark chocolate flavor with a bit of spice - licorice?  Thick and full in consistency, but light and sparkle finish.  Almost like a darker beer, but without the earthy yeast taste that would be expected.  A bit of a caramel undertone that becomes more recognizable in the aftertaste.

Not bad, but theres a lot going on here.  its good, but left me a little confused.
UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 My goto brown ale, roasted aromas and roasted malts on the palate, hops balance out nicely. Very easy to drink, easier than porters and stouts. Highly recommended

A: Pours a very dark brown color with some reddish highlights and a thin tan head.

S: Smells really roasty with some nice chocolate and earthy hop notes. There is a strange aroma that seems to be chlorine, but its sort of in the background. Some pretty decent coffee notes too.

T: Lots of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and a bit of coffee. Pretty bitter with a nice earthy hop profile. A nice toffee flavor and some toasted malt notes.

M: The body is medium with a moderate level of carbonation.

D: The strange chlorine thing was a bit of a black mark on this beer, but otherwise, this is damn good.

Fantastic Brown Ale from Dogfish!  Purchased individual bottle from World Market.  Pleasant sweet aroma of caramel, toffee, coffee and a hint of brown sugar.  Pours a dark caramel, with a soft, tan head.  Taste is very robust, daresay like a stout.  This one has some character that doesnt settle with the rest of the pack.  Medium build and very smooth on the palate with a wonderful finish.  Superb brown from Dogfish and would definitely drink again!

Poured a dark brown/honey color with a medium-sized light-tan head.  Aroma has lots of toasted notes with caramel and coffee.  Some vanilla and brown sugar as well.  Taste is quite roasted and hoppy.  The finish has some vanilla and coffee.  Overall a very nice beer, the balance is very good.  One of the best brown ales Ive had.

Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  Big aroma, with burnt malt, sweet chocolate, some fruit and a bit nutty.  Flavor of sweet chocolate, malts, and hops.  Palate is a bit watery, and there is alcohol present in the finish.  Overall, whether it is true Indian Brown Ale or not....  Its a very nice beer, its well balanced, and Im sure Ill buy it again!

12 oz bottle, poured black with little brown head. Little if any lacing. Aroma of coffee and a bit of hay. A great chocolate and raisin kick is immediately present with a balanced sweetness. A nice smoky malt finish. The 7.2% abv is unavoidable. I wish the alcohol aroma had hidden better because it detracted from the other aromas slightly.
great beer never had one quite like this.. beer pourd smooth with good head aroma was like a sugary choclate.  great beer

Roast malt and coffee dominate the nose.  Pours brown with a thick tan head which dissipates slowly, leaves some lacing.  Taste is coffee, roast malts, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, hops show up later in the taste.  Medium body, fairly silky with medium carbonation.

12 fl oz bottle at a place in downtown Miami, FL. Called something like Burgers & Beer. On January 23, 2011Clear dark brown color, light brown head. Sweet, roasted, fruity scent. Roasted, sweet, coffee taste. Alcohol and roasted aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

Pours dark brown with reddish tones under a modest head the color of wet (North Carolina) sand.  The sweet bouquet has hints of grain, ginger and whole brown sugar.

The sweet liquor features a pleasing tingle of alcohol.  Dark, sweet, toasted malt and brown sugar (again evident, as in the bouquet) are supported by an extremely subtle hop counterpoint.

It seems almost unfair that one brewery could produce both IBA and Raison Detre and not have one seem redundant.  Granted, the styles are technically different, but they share much in common.  Lovely brew.

Slight aroma of roast and coffee.  Ruby red color, thin light tan head.  Slightly sweet, with a nutty finish.  Strong roasted notes are present as well.  Not a bad beer, but not one Ill seek out again.

pours a deep and dark ruby brown color with a very nice tan head which stays for a majority of the drink almost like a guiness. some chocolate malts in the nose. cant put my finger on much else. taste is bittersweet chocolate and molasses. coats the mouth well. syrupy. definately a very roasty character to this beer. a fine brown ale and well balanced at 7 percent abv.
Same bottle as pictured. Really good brown ale but nothing to special about it. Not as hoppy as I would have liked.
bottle at home(23Jan11)pours brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is light roast and burnt sugar.  Flavor is light roast, thin peat and brown sugar lingering with a little smoke.
good for a brown ale. but bad if your going by the well hopped description on the bottle. no hop flavour at all. still a decent brew
Dark reddish-brown color, light-brown head. Medium to heavy sweetness. Fully body, slightly creamy. Hint of chocolate. Overall not my favorite of the Dogfishes, but a tasty beer nonetheless.
This beer is pretty basic brown ale. Not too special, I guess its pretty good.

Pours a clear, dark, reddish brown. One finger foamy off-white head, decent lacing. Smell is very malty roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar. These flavors come through very strongly in the taste, though their sweetness is balanced by hop bitterness. Medium-bodied, very smooth, moderate carbonation.
On tap at champs. Dark brown with thin cream head. Aroma is toffee. Flavor is toffee, toasty maltiness and some chocolate. Delicious.
Caramel, coffee aroma, brownish red color, medium bitter taste, full body with a creamy texture

I am a Brown fan, and this is simply the best i have had.  A bitterness was quickly overtaken by a medium sweetness which allowed the finish of the beer to be as enjoyable as a wicked cool lady gettting trapped in an elevator with you.
This a nice brown ale. I liked the complexity of sweetness of this beer. I got some caramel, molasses, and raisin in this beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 22nd January 2009 Dark brown clear beer. Smooth and rich. Creamy malt. Just a light touch of hop in the smooth finish. A plain beer but flavoursome and well executed.10th June 2012A bottle from the same batch as my original tasting. So nearly 4 years old. Semi sweet malts - nice mellow chocolate and coffee. Whisper of orange. A little cream. Cant detect any oxidisation. Pretty well aged and rounded off. Still very enjoyable.
Bottle, part of a Christmas present.  Pours a very dark brown with a tan head.  Definite nuts and coffee in the smell and flavor....quite impressive.

12oz bottle from Dobys Liquor World. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of toffee, caramel, little smoke, and earthy hops. Flavors of toffee, caramel, faint hops, touch of coffee, and some chocolate. Interesting but was hoping for more hops.
Pours a nice brown color with a nice head.  Thin aroma of nice malt and some molasses.  Taste is medium bodied with a nice smooth taste.  Just what a brown ale should be I think.

Finally got to have the dogfish head indian brown and it was a delicious hardy beer.  Dark dark brown color with a tan head.  The aroma was of chocolate, caramel, coffee with a smoky undertone.  Also detected a bit syrupy aroma (maple syrup?).  Medium sweetness with no hops.

This beer pours a dark, rich brown with a generous 3-finger creamy-tan head; aromas of toffee and coffee; tastes sweet at first with a bitter kick thats surprising, and finishes with strong hints of coffee.  This is a smooth brew that drinks with little carbonation on the lips and tongue.  A brew that doesnt hit you as a beer thats over 7% ABV - a nice, drinkable brown ale.
Fra flaske, dufter dejligt af karamel og rosiner. Smager lækkert af karamel og frugt. Sort med lidt lyse brunt skum. Ok fylde med en dejlig eftersmag af frugt. Ialt en dejlig ale

Bottle. Pours brown with a medium light tan head. The aroma is malt, caramel, fruity hops and light chocolate. Flavour is medium hoppy with notes of toasted caramel, berries, light chocolate and light alcohol. Medium body.

Pours a dark brown color with a small beige head. Aromas of sweet caramel, coffee, toffee, and some chocolate.The first round of flavor is of roasted malts and coffee,then comes the hints of chocolate and hops. Then a big blast of bitter hits your tongue, which puts a nice twist to this style. Very good, Very interesting brew! Thanks Andy for the bottle!

Very dark brown color with raspberry and ruby highlights.  Gorgeous off white/tan colored head that was very frothy and creamy.  The head stuck around for several minutes and had very nice lacing to go along with it.  Looks great.  Very aromatic toffee and caramel.  Getting both chocolate and brown sugar hints.  Almost like chocolate milk.  Vague hints of coffee also.  No real nuttiness to speak of, but no problem with me there.  This beer smells wonderful.  This brew has a toffee/caramel/chocolate type of flavor followed by the bits of coffee.  Some alcohol warmth comes forth, but in a stifled kind of way and it makes me want another sip.  Medium/full mouthfeel.  Creamy goodness.  Smooth.  Dry.  Coats the palate very well.  Really well actually.  This beer is super easy to drink at 7.2% ABV.  Really smooth and dry.  This is a great beer.  One of the best Ive had.  Perfect for cool evenings and worth a try if available.  I, most certainly, will pick this up again.

Excellent beer, walks the line of tasting like a stout, but still has the characteristics of a brown ale, one of the thicker brown ales I have ever had, nutty coffee flavor dominates, thick yet smooth, very rich dark beer.  Hop presence as well, but pretty mellow.

Clear brown color well carbonated tan thin head aroma is coffee and deep rich scotch malt and bread with a little bit of brown sugar first taste is coffe like then bread like yeast and finishes real sweet pretty good beer and amazingly light feeling for the alcohol percentage and all that is going on in the beer, gotta give it to dogfish for this one great hybrid balanced and represented the hops brown ale and scotch ale pretty well

Pours a deep brown, slight ruby tints around the edges when the glass isnt so full. Light tan rocky head. Aroma is somewhat simple and not too inviting, but it doesnt come across as bad, necessarily. Smokey malts and light grassy hops in the nose, and on the flavor as well. Much more bitter than I expect brown ales to be. But it has a hop bite for sure.  Subtle dark chocolate ending to make the bitter finish a little more manageable. Love the texture though. Smooth body with prickly, even carbonation. Its not a bad beer in of itself, Im just not a fan of this one.

Pours a rich dark brown with thinnish light brown head.  Main aromas I get are chocolate/caramel, with some pine in the background.  In the mouth you can add dark/tropical fruit like you might get in an imperial stout, and a bittersweet finish with red wine notes.  Must say I was expecting more of a hoppy character from it but they are there - without them the sweetness of this one would be totally overpowering.  Alcohol is pretty assertive in this one too actually.  Definitely a sipper.  Im impressed with the complexity for sure, but the sticky sweetness/heaviness is a bit much.

This is actually one of my favorite Dogfish Head beers. It has the most perfect hops you can use with a roasted malt flavor. The bitterness of the roasted chocolate like malt with the earthy different hop strains makes this beer fantastic. It also has a creaminess to it which Im guessing is the Scotch ale quality of it. This is almost as hopped us as the 60 and 90 but just minus that citrus hop which I think wouldnt make this beer as unique. Amazing beer A plus

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Pours a deep dark brown with very little head formation and no lacing at all.  The smell is strong with sweet raisins and roasted malts.  There is milk chocolate there as well.  As the beer sits, some black candy licorice comes to the nose as well.  Very nice aromas from this beer.  The chocolate is very easy to taste and I was able to pick that up right away.  Some strong roasted malts give a small amount of coffee flavor and dark fruits as well.  Very nice brown ale.

Pours very dark brown and touches of amber with a small white head. Nose is chocolate, malts, brown sugar, molasses, nuts, and hops. Flavor is sweet chocolaty with hops sticking to the sides of tongue and bitter through the finish. Awesome brown ale.

Outstanding offering from DFH.  Have started seeking them out after watching Brewmasters.   Malty hoppy goodness.  Not your typical brown ale. ABV comes through in the superb taste and finish.   Well done Sam!!!

Bottle.  Aroma is malty and chocolate.  I had a dark glass so really unable to comment on color.  There was no head.  It is full bodied with good carbonation.  The beginning is very good with malty roastiness but is overpowered by the hoppy finish.  I think the balance could be better but overall a good beer.

Dark brown pour with an off white head. Smell is mostly of burnt brown sugar and some molasses. Taste is of the same with a nice transition into some roasted malt notes. Very smooth and enjoyable brown ale.

Tasted on 12/16/10 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Sun Devil, bottled on 06/09/10.  Pours a brown so dark that it is opaque with an average off-white head that leaves a thin blanket of lace with a nice collar.  The nose is darkly roasted malt with some vanilla, molasses, burnt brown sugar, and resin hops.  The flavor starts with the molasses and brown sugar, and then moves to the bitter notes of dark malt and resin hops with just a hint of vanilla.  The body is full with lively carbonation and a long bitter and vanilla finish.

Ive had a few brown ales before and I am not a big fan, but this IBA was great. Pours dark dark brown body, aroma is light chocolate, caramel, and roastiness. Taste is same...smooth too. Tasted more like a porter. Great beer.

Dark brown body with nice looking cap, looks like a beer to me. Malty chocolate hop yum yum aroma, some chalkiness and burnt sugar. Burnt malty hoppy yum flavor with hints of banana. Sweet brown sugar, bitter coffee, and soapy hops all show in the finish. Dogfish does it again with consistently awesome beers excellent brown ale, high quality stuff.
Dark brown pour from bottle with a nice off white head.  Aroma is leather and earth.  Taste is charred wood, molasses, brown sugar and some booze.  Warm finish.  Another solid beer from DFH.

The aroma starts the tasting with subtle notes of tart chocolate.  The beer presents a deep dark brown.  Smooth pillowy mouth feel reveals a complex series of flavors.  With a sudden burst of caramel when it first hits the tongue this dry ale quickly goes bitter and ends with sour notes on the sides of your tongue surrounded by smoky flavor in the rest of your mouth.  Overall a good version of a unique twist on your average brown ale.

Pours a dark coffee color from a 12oz bottle with dense tan head. The aroma  is an ever so slight spice and malt smell with an alcohol twist. Very bitter / tart when swirled in your mouth, not sure why you would do that, but it is bitter. The addition of hops definitely make this a unique dark ale and one that was pulled off with success. This would pair good with dessert or possibly replace your morning coffee.

Pours a deep, dark brown color with foamy tan head; lots of lacing.  Strong nutty malt aroma.  Very nice taste.  Robust roasted malts w/ notes of nuts, dark chocolate, caramel and coffee.  Strong hop presence which makes it uniqu;. a well-hopped brown ale.  Nice kick at 7.2%.  This is pretty awesome.

A really nice brown ale.Pored a deep brown with a red hue near the edges. Nose is high on roasted malt with aromas of caramel, coffee, and brown sugar. It laced my glass really thick all the way until the finish.  VERY robust witha hoppy finish and lingers on the tongue well after you finish the sip.  The hops come through even more as the beer warms up.  Hop heads will like this brown ale.  I couldnt drink more then one because of he bitterness.

[355ml bottle from Beers of Europe that Dad shared with me - cheers!] Deep chestnut in colour with a large beige head and moderate fizz.  Rich and tempting chocolate aroma with coffee hints.  The flavours dominated by so much brown sugar that it reminds me of a Belgian beer (Achel 8?).  But theres some chocolate-coated raisins too and a twist of lemon (from the Goldings?).  The burnt malt bitterness lingering menacingly in the background alternates between balancing the sweetness and clashing with it.  From a messy beginning, it pulled itself together by the end and I quite enjoyed it, but the carbonation didnt work with the viscous mouthfeel.

On tap in a shaker.  Pours ruby/dark brown with a lacy beige head.  Aroma of hops with some sweet malr notes.  Flavor of these two dont mix as well as they could. I was expecting a better beer, BUT the bar was having problems with their tap so that could be the reason for my low rating.

Poured into a dimpled mug I got from Cheers in Boston. Appearance of a stout, but smells of dark fruits like figs and raisins. The beer has a sweet and malty taste with a tart finish. Overall this is one of the better and more unique brown ales out there. I enjoy this very much.

A: Very dark brown with a pretty good, long-lasting head.

S: Definitely finding the combination of beers here--plenty of hops as well as sweet, dark malts with chocolate and carmelized sugars. Dark fruit underneath.

T: Much like the smell with a little bit of molasses thrown in. The dark fruits are a little more prominent in the taste.

M: Medium bodied and very smooth. Chewy.

D: Very nice beer. Perhaps my favorite of the year-round, six-pack offerings.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-27-2009

12oz bottle served in a tulip. Pour was black with two fingers of tan head with a nice show of lacing. Nose was peat, earth, malt and light caramel. Taste was coffee, malt and nice hops toward the finish. This is a good beer nothing that blows my socks off but would make great session beer. Yet another tasty offering from dogfish head.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2013 Much better than most brown, maybe thats cause it has way more hops!  Really doesnt taste like a normal brown, not the malty flat stuff, this has big bold flavor and a great mix of brown malt, strong hops (like 60 min) and maybe some coffee?  Good stuff for sure...even if you dont like browns give this a try, its got balls.

A complex and flavourful beer. Sweet toasted aroma, with some sugar and fruitiness and some alcohol. The 50 ABUs referred to on the bottle are scarcely evident underneath the toasted malt sweetness. Some coffee and wood. Nice full body. Very good.

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours dark brown with amber hues topped by a large persistent tan head with sea foam lace. Malty sweet aromas of brown sugar, chocolate, light coffee, melon, and herbs. Nice roasty sweet flavor. Medium body, slick texture, and a smooth finish. Good beer.

from bottle.  Pours slightly darker than molasses with a medium tan head.   Nose is filled with a burned syrupy sweetness and some alcohol.  Tastes of coffee, molasses, some vinous character, earthy malt, and a touch of bourbon.  Watery mouthfeel.  This would be a really awesome beer if it werent so thin.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2016 Pours dark brown with thin white head. Nose is roasty. Aromas are eoasted malts, caramel, coffee, chocolate and brown sugar. Average carbonation, medium body. A delicious coffee and hoppy finish.

Deep amber color with a foamy tan head. Slightly grainy aroma with a hint of molasses. Flavor is a little dry and tart with a bitter finish and notes of dark chocolate, caramel and raisins.  Another unique and delicious brew from Dogfish Head.
Has a distinctive caramel coffee aroma and flavor. The appearance is a dark brown / deep ruby, minimal head. Great finish, leaves you wanting more!

Poured from a bottle I to a large snifter. Aroma is of coffee, caramel, and malts. Appearance is a dark brown with a beige head. Taste is predominantly coffee with notes of sweet caramel notes. Body is relatively heavy. All around this is a great beer. Love this shit.
Another well groomed beer by the none other than Dogfish Head. The best beer for the working mans dollar. Surpassed my expectation of beer vs. price. A future buy for a long time.

Bottle. Pour is dark brown black with a frothy kahki head that lasts. Aroma is amazing big roasted coffee with some coco in there too. Taste is toasted malt and coffee and some dark dried fruit. Palate is full and sticky and finishes dry. Amazing brown ale!
Tan head over black body. Cream, caramel, chocolate, some hops. Sweet aroma and matching taste. Afterwards more bitterness. Well balanced beer but this porter-like thing isnt really my taste.

355ml bottle.  Pours a very dark nrown with a small head, that doesnt last.  Aroma is burnt sugar, raisin, some alcohol and some hops in the end.  Sweet sugar start, harsh caramel malt finishes with some raisin.  Very bitter finish, sweet aftertaste.
On tap at brewpub as part of sampler.  Pours a ruby cola color.  tastes of roasted malt, nutty, chocolate, molasses, and soft creamy mouth feel.  really nice brown ale.

A bit of butterscotch aroma. Pours a dark brown with thick tan head. Tastes a bit like a Scotch Ale with a brown sugar flavour to follow. Medium bodied and creamy. Nicely balanced with all the flavour and texture in the right amounts.
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 As dark a ruby color as you can get. Smells like a scotch ale. Roasted, nutty flavor, slightly creamy, and a subtle grassy hop on the far end. Very good beer.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep, dark mahogony, with a nice tan head that hangs around. Aroma of chocolate, cramel, brown sugar, a little molassas. Smooth, almost chewy mouthfeel. Nice malt sweetness up front, followed by a nice hop bite. This is a homebrewers dream! At 7.2ABV, you cant do too many at a session, but its a real treat. Nice job.

Picked up a six pack using a Groupon at Schaefers in Evanston, IL.  Ive seen this all over the place but never purchased due to its higher price point, but boy am I glad I picked this up at a (fractionally) lower cost.  Appearance is a very dark brown with a thin and prosperous creamy head.  Aroma mostly of chocolate with bits of coffee, nuts, and roasted malts.  It seriously smells like a candy bar.  Taste is very smooth and decadent, waves of chocolate with a coffee and toffee backing, but its still bitter like a good IPA.  Fantastic stuff.

12 oz bottle.  Pours brown, almost brown, slightly hazy.  Nice big frothy cappucino coloured head.  Aomra is slightly raisin, and a bit of coffee.  Taste is quite sweet, again, hint of raisin, molasses.  Very nice!  Where can I get more??

I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it.  Ive had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh.

Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

Bottle. Beautiful coca-cola colored brew with light brown head that leaves beautiful lasting lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are very roasty walnuts and a bit of caramel and brown sugar. Palate is creamy and full-bodied with robust roasted malty-goodness. Love it.

Deep brown with a large tan skull, thick and strong willed enough to last the whole way. Aromas of deep roasted malts, i see raisinettes up in the description and I agree totally, chocolate, molasses, dirty coffee, marshmallows and some hops. Still an odd smell that I cannot place. Tasty but not great. Roasted malts mixed with a good dose of hops and coffee bitterness with a candy sweetness. Molasssssssses, nuts, orange? Smooth yet boring. Soft mouth feel. Excellent aftertaste of things. Afternoon beer rocks!

12 oz bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2010. Dark reddish brown color. The aromas of chocolate and nuts. Tastes of chocolate, nuts, some coffee and firm bitterness. Good firm basic flavors, satisfying ale.

In the flavor category there are some roasted malts,carmel,brown sugar,coffee. Its a great well balanced beer all around. It also has some floral hops lurking in the background

The aroma is just made up of molasses and some chocolate. To be honest I find it to be infectious

It pours a dark mahogany with a tan color head and a decent amount of carbonation. As well it has a small amount of lacing

It finishes with a little more of a hop bite than i use to for the style and a little sweetness.  But overall its just a great beer. Its a little different than some browns. But a great different. Which is what these guys are know for.
This is a unique beer. I loved the notes of brown sugar and chocolate - tasty but not too sweet.  Very hoppy and refreshing.

Very dark brown, bordering on black in color with a creamy, yet somewhat bubbly white head. Carmelized sugar, bittersweet chocolate in the the nose. Creamy texture with mild to moderate carbonation. Slight herbal hop finish. Very good.

12oz brown bottle. Dark brown pour with a thin and creamy layer of tan head. Aroma is sweet with raisin and chocolate and brown sugar. Flavour has lots of malt with dark chocolate notes, molasses, some black coffee. Finishes with a bit of alcohol, coffee like malt and some leafy citrusy flavours. Good finishing bitterness. Medium body, soft carboantion. Quite drinkable for 7.2%.

Appearance:  dark brown; out of the bottle, so no observation of head or lace.  Aroma:  very pleasant:  toasty dark grains, molasses, brown sugar, a solid malty backbone with fresh hops underneath.  Taste:  as the aroma indicated:  lots of sweet dark malt, but refreshing aromatic, floral and slightly bitter hops to balance.  Finish:  slightly sweet, toasty, then dry and bitter as the finish lingers.  Notes:  Very pleasant.  A well balanced beer.  Some of the malty flavors were actually reminiscent of an imperial stout.

Great pour. Dark, dark red body with a creamy, hazel colored head. Looks almost like a soda float. Smells of coffee with a sweetness to balance the bitterness; also has hints of nuttiness. Bitter taste that comes pretty abruptly on the back end and washes out, leaving a dark chocolate taste on the tongue. Thick, full-bodied feel. Overall, one I want to love, but just a little too hard on the bitter flavors and a little too subtle on the other flavors to become a favorite.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2015 Bottle. Very dark brown with tan head. Smells sweet, and of roast, dark candied fruit, chocolate, and caramel. Body is medium and a little creamy. Taste is chocolate, sugar, molasses and roasted malt, with a touch of hop presence. Excellent brown ale, complex and full of flavor.
Decent brown ale. Bold hops and dark malts place this on the extreme end of brown ales. Tastes like higher alcohol than it is...otherwise a pretty solid brown.

A- Poured Very Dark Brown, Almost black in colour letting no light in. Very thick and creamy head that lingered for a very long time. Head is also a fairly dark brown.

S- Very Dark Roasted and malty in smell. The Roast smell is very sweet,like coffee, brown sugar comes to mind due to some molasses smell that is detectable as well. Also a small hint of some floral hops in the back.

T- The roast flavour is very intense, just like a good cup of dark coffee. The Sweet flavour is also very detectable, the brown sugar/molasses is perfectly balanced with the coffee taste. Only a litte taste of hops are there, but theyre not heavily flavoured and definitely do not overpower the malts. Very in heavy in the mouth, also slightly creamy.

D- One of the best Brown beers Ive ever had. The Coffee taste is delicious and it goes down super smooth. Very delicious and easily drinkable

I like that this beer delivers on what it is and that is a Scottish Ale/IPA and the style just doesnt ring great with me.  I liked it but wouldnt seek it out again.  It pours great with a deep nut brown color and a nice head and solid aroma.  The hops jump out at  as an IPA y and are followed by the roasted malt Scoth Ale finish but I prefer the two styles separately.  Nice job for what it is.
Another solid offering from Dogfish.  Pours mahagony.  Aroma is caramel, coffee and dark fruit.  Taste is sweet with slight bitters.  The alcohol is very well hidden.

Let me start off with this:  Ive like this beer.  Its big and its brown and puts, from what I can tell, all other browns to shame. Pours a deep mahogany with ruby highlights.  Wow, on the nose, this is a very nice beer. dark fruits, plums, raisins, along with dark chocolate and some coffee.  Roasted malts and some caramel. No real hops to speak off.  Medium-full body w/ a somewhat balanced finish but the bitterness seems to come from the chocolate and coffee.  only a little hop bitterness running around.  Taste is something to behold, again with the dark fruit, plum, raisin, dark chocolate, roasted malts, and some caramel.  Bitterness, as described earlier, in the finish.  Not that it really matters but, I like it.

All I can say is wow!  After pouring this beer the aroma was amazing and intoxicating. The malt and barley came right out and almost smacks you in the face.  An unbelievable smell, but I wish that it lasted longer.  As great as it was, it almost disappears just as you are enjoying it.  As you swirl the beer it has brief re-appearances, but sadly fades away.  The look to this beer was nice with a charcoal clear black color to it.  If this is their brown ale, I wonder what their stout or porter looks like.  The head was a light brown that looked very creamy mostly lasting.  First tasting this beer a hint of caramelized sweetness comes out with a touch of a burnt charcoal to it.  The finish was quite pleasant with a heavier bitter flavor along with that charcoal hint towards the end that had a long lasting impression.  The feel in the mouth was also quite impressive as it had this very nice creamy texture that was full bodied and soft carbonation.  The finish at the end was surprisingly smooth and then faded to the lasting finishing flavor at the end.  As far as chugging this beer, I would stray away from, as well as perhaps not the beer of choice on a hot day for refreshment.  That being said this beer is the kind I would have with dinner, on a date, at a bar, or sitting at home relaxing.  A beer that screams sophistication and flavor.  A surprise for me, and one I would go back and keep stocked in my fridge.

Pours a deep dark brown with a minimal tan head. Very smooth coffee taste, with notes of apricot and raisin. Distinctive...enjoyed this one quite a bit. 

K-3.4
S-3.6

UPDATED: APR 2, 2015 Bottle. This smells exactly like gingerbread -- not the cheap stuff, but real, homemade gingerbread. Or molasses cookies, cant decide which. Color is opaque dark brown with a light brown, moussy head. The flavor is coffee, spices, brown sugar -- the official brewery description says Raisinettes, which I definitely get. (One of my favorite candies, too.) Finishes clean. This is damned fine.

Bottle, thanks to hobbersr. Pours deep clear brown, thin off-white head, lacing is spotty to poor. Nose is ginger, cocoa, some hops here, but not really "India", some maltiness here too. Flavours are spicy ginger, malty darkness, nice bright character in the mouth, some hop spiciness here too. Really, a nice brown, but I was expecting something more along the lines of "Sweet Nikki Brown" where the hops are almost sticky. Nice, but I wont be buying this again.

Very dark brown colour. Thick beige head. Great lacing. Rich malty Aroma lots of chocolate and caramel. Flavour is very bold lots of character. Roasted malts, chocolate, brown sugar, and toffee, followed by light delicate hops and a slight amount of coffee. This is a great beer but I think it is getting very colose to porter territory.

Quite a robust brown, how I like em! Hopps in the aroma but its not overpowering, lots of malt as well. Dark, not much on head, not too bad lacing. You can really taste the malt and the hops, steady and even. It leaves your mouth bitter and sweet. Pretty good brown, Very solid.

-Date Tasted : 9-24-10
-Rating : 3.8
-Brew Date/Batch# : N/A
-Mode/Price : 6pk./$9.99
-Source : Mtn. Spirts Liquors, Crested Butte CO
-Appearance : N/A
-Aroma : Smells of sweet raisins, chocolate
-Flavor : Tastes of strong malts with different notes of raisins, chocholate, apricot, coffee with a little too much sweetness
-Overall : Nice wintertime beer, seemed very heavy, drink only one.
12oz bottle. Pours a deep burgundy with very little head. Very different than most brown ales with the higher hop content. Sweet malty brown sugar and raisin flavors with a bite.

12 oz Bottle - poured dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma similar to a stout with the brown sugar sweetness, coffee scents, and roasted hops. Taste of dark malts, cocoa, coffee with roasty hoppiness and plenty of sweetness. Nice mouthfeel and the right level of carbonation for a brown ale - not overdone like some brown ales I have had.

12 oz bottle into dimpled mug. Pours a reddish brown with a medium-sized head with nice retention. Aroma is reminiscent of vanilla mocha coffee; some molasses here, too. Taste is bittersweet with a hint of sour. Alcohol is noticeable, but not overbearing. Some licorice comes out in the flavor. Carbonation is medium-high, body is full, texture is oily. Tasty.

Wow... in one word.  This one surprised me.  Pours a gorgeous deep brown with a quickly dissipating head.  The aroma is rich caramel with a toasted nutty smell.  This is what I would expect from an oaked stout.  The taste is complex with a nice bitter with a good hint of alcohol warmth.  The body is much thicker than I expected.  Chewy.  There is some carbonation but not much.  The finish is a pleasant bitter followed up by a nice reminder of the ABV.  Let me repeat my opening ... wow.  I bought this as an "extra" in a craft pack.  I think that I will be finding a 6 of this shortly.

Deep brown med carb. A:Chocolaty, caramel, dates, grapes, nuts, brown sugar enveloping and rich. T:Body is full and initial  finish finish is sweet then it finishes with a nice and pleasant bitterness. O:Super nice, well made will definitely try to grab some more. A nice in between for malt and hop lover.

Pours a very dark brown with overflowing and lingering head that produces a log of lacing. Aroma is of caramel, cereal and malts. Tastes sweet and malty. Palate is medium body with a creamy texture and a long finish. Ive had this beer several times and, although it is well made it is not one of my favorites and I cant usually have more than 1.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with almost no head.  Malty hoppy aroma.  Taste left something to be desired.  This didnt have the richness of other brown ales Ive tried. Too much hop flavor for the style. Somewhat watery mouthfeel.

As it should this pours deep brown with a loose, quickly lowing, off white head.  When this recedes a minimal lacing is left.  The nose is of roasted malts with a porter like aroma of raisins and plums, then honey and hops follow through.  In the mouth its all warm, rounded malts, brown sugar and those dry, aged hops.  There is an ashen note which again reminds me of a London porter, and in turn puts me in mind of that Saturday afternoon pub aroma.  The mouth feel is medium thin with a soft carbonation; the mid-range alcohol content is nowhere to be found.  On the finish the barley grows pronounced.  Its very much like the smell of mashed grain.  Although its a relatively simple beer, its smooth, drinkable and somehow manages to be sweet yet at the same time refreshing.  For its style its one of the best Ive had.

12 fl. oz. bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring. Mahogany brown with a trace of cream head; rich spicy toffee aroma with a touch of fruit cake; thick and unctuous in the mouth, with raisins and demerara sugar; then a dry warming finish with ginger masking the alcohol. Wow.

So, here I am.  Like so many nights before, drunk and rating beer.  This beer is being consumed after kegging its clone.  Poured from a 12-oz bottle into a pint glass.  Poured brown, with dark red undertones.  Aroma is of alcohol, malt, caramel and candy.  Taste is pretty much the same.  I dont enjoy dogfishs prices, but their shit is mighy tastey.

Pours a mahogany brown with a slight beige cap. The aroma is molasses, caramel, hazelnut, raisin, chocolate, and alcohol. The flavor is more or less an exact replica of that, with a slightly hoppy, burnt malt finish. A very enjoyable brew.

Bottle into a wide mouth glass. Pours dark with a fine-bubbled tan head that leads to exquisite lacing. Immediate wonderful aromas of smoke and roasted grains. Sits fairly thick on the tongue. Sweet and full bodied. Theres a little whiff of alcohol and carbonation to end. Absolutely delightful. Will buy again.

355ml bottle. deep brown with a mocha coloured head. Caramel and brown sugar on the nose with some smoke and a floral hop note underneath. Caramel and sweet spice on the entry with a long bitter floral hop finish. Exquisite.

Oh man, its too good to describe... Pours a very deep dark amber with big creamy head and moderate lacing. Aroma is malty scotch comes to mind with notes of roasted malts, toastyness, and chocolate that almost seems propelled by a hop background. Flavor contains a nice hop blast that sinks into strong sweetness and dark malt character finishing with a more sweet than bitter sensation. Full bodied yet completely smooth drinking.  One of my favorite beers of all time.

Pours a deep dark brown colour with a small tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, toast and caramel with a sweet sugar like scent quite present and some hop notes as well. Taste is malty with a sweet brown sugar and caramel flavour, not really bittter, abrupt finish. Medium-full body, soft carbonation and a thick mouth feel. Overall a very good brown ale and excellent beer.
si si si david, a esta le pegaste.  gracias.  en la casa de ramenend con los bichos andando en bici

Bottle; Pours a dark brown/amber, with an average off white head with good retention. Smells like floral hop, booze, and sweetness - Flavors are complex - I get an initial burst of hop, coupled with the caremelized brown sugar, molasses, and this toffee chocolate with a slightly dry finish. I had no idea a brown ale could be this amazing -

Dark brown.  Roasted nutty/molasses aroma.  Medium full body, easy to drink though and alcohol not that noticable.  A lot going on in the flavor with mostly matiness and caramel flavors and some coffee or bitter chocolate.  Overall dry though with some hops.  Really good.

pour amber brown with good head. nice caramel and malt notes. there is alot of tertiary notes in here but they are not out of balance with the rest of the aroma. i keep getting sweet notes of toffee and butterscotch. palate is full, rich and round. big butterscotch and malted flavours follow through. full bodied, great session brew.
Poured deep amber color and a quick to disappear head. Plum, molasses, ash, chocolate ans hints of smoke in the aroma. Medium body with high carbonation. Pretty good!

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale is a clear, dark, sparkling brown with a dense, bubbly khaki head that has outstanding retention and lacing.  It has a roasty aroma with notes of coffee, chocolate, caramel, grass and herbs.  Its medium bodied, soft and smooth, with a crisp, dry finish.  It has a full roasted flavor; a touch of syrupy sweetness and an herbal, grassy bitterness.  There is coffee and dark chocolate at the finish.  Its superbly balanced.  This is flawless and delicious!
As far as dark IPAs go this is one of the darker ones. It tastes and feels more like a stout than a brown ale and has plenty of roastiness to back up its hops.

Aroma: Very earthy and nutty, with hints of chocolate and bread malts.

Appearance: This is a beautiful beer. It is almost as dark as a porter.  This is not a very heady beer, but the small layer there is appears very frothy and is a quite dark tan color.

Taste: The taste is roasty and earthy. The chocolate malts are prominent as well as the roasted flavour of the malts, most often present in a porter. Resembles a lighter version of Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter.

Palate: The body is somewhere between medium and full, while the texture is creamy and thick. There is an average amount of carbonation, just enough not to hide any of the rich flavor. A slight bitterness is revealed toward the finish.

Overall: Great beer. The first "hybrid" as Dogfish Heads Sam Calagione so proudly puts it. Very unique and interesting.
nutty and dark, very malty with hints of coffee and caramel.  too dark for me    toasty and roasty

What a crazy embodiment of a "brown"!  Bottle pours a deep reddish brown, very similar to a scotch ale.  Aromas are minimal at first, but with a little warmth, they open up to a complex mix of brown sugar, molasses, caramel, a bit of licorice, and some breakfast toast.  Flavors are equally deep, with big blasts of sweetness from molasses and caramel, with a tartness of raisins (raisinettes, seriously?) and bitter black coffee/dark chocolate.  Alcohol balances nicely with such a punchy brew.  A touch oily, but otherwise great.

draft. rich brown with small head and good carb. citrus hops on the nose with some resin character. sweet malty presence with some biscuity notes, slight vanilla, and a nice mix of resiny/citrus hops. finish is less sweet and more bitter. well done.
Draft in pint glass.  Dark brown color.  Citrus hops.  Chocolate malts.   Med Sweet.  Med carbonation.  Dark chocolate bitter finish.  Slightly resiny.

Poured from a 12 once bottle into a becker.

Pours a deep, murky brown with a modest cream colored head that recedes slowly and laces decently.

Aroma is of caramel malts and deep roast. Slightly sour aroma o yeast like a flanders or traditional porter. Coffee, nutty and malty, taking each sniff makes my mouth water.

Flavor is dark roasted malt, nutty and roasty. Burnt meat and slightly smokey flavors come out. Sourness comes in the middle with a punch of sweetness. Maltiness overpowers at the finish and there is a slight bitterness there which takes more like from the roast than any hops.

Mouthfeel is creamy full and lush with soft carbonation. Slightly slick with a little stick left on the left.

Very tasty brew, I enjoyed it very much.

Reviewed on: 05-31-2010

For a brown->too dark.  I do enjoy the hop presence a tad, but I can not seem to find semblance while aquainting a brown and ann IPA.  Just does not flow for me.  Taste is too mixed up between the two, although you can taste them both.  Aroma is flagging with bits of barely bouncing off your nose.  Too much going on here, but it was fun to drink.
At Oregon Brewers Festival.  Smooth smoke and malt, with some hops.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  A decent brown ale.  Even though Im not a real fan of brown ales.

I must confess that I was disappointed by this beer.  When I poured the bottle into my glass, I was encouraged by the beautiful colour in the glass, but when I put the beer to my nose, I was shocked by how little aroma I actaully got.  When I tasted the beer, I have to say that the flavour that was there was, in fact, quite pleasant.  The unfortunate thing was that there simply wasnt enough of it!  

I had been expecting a much fuller mouthfeel -- in fact, I cant recall a beer with over 7%abv. tasting this thin!  I was looking for a richer, toastier beer - not a stout, mind you, just more body - and also found the hop character a bit lacking.  In my opinion, this beer needs more muscle and further hopping.  

The biggest flaws with this beer, in my opinion are the thinness of the mouthfeel and the very short finish.  

After all of this negativity, I will say that this beer was not all bad.  I will aknowledge that it is possible I am being a little harsher on this beer because it is brewed by Dogfish Head than if it came from elsewhere.  The problem is that I have gained such a respect for them over the years, anything that I feel is "under the bar" is a sore disappointment.

Pours a dark brown. some light tan foam, very dense, and leaves some lacing behind. Aroma is both sweet/sugary and spicy at the same time. Taste is rather spicy/bitter and sweet. Not sure what spices, either -- a bit biting and just a hint of a tinny aftertaste.

355 mL bottle.  Brown with a small head.  Nice malt profile in aroma and flavour.  The hops are there in the aroma as well, but really ony appear in the flavour to combine with the roast in the malt to give this beer a nice bitterness.  The malt is great, with the nuttiness that you expect in a brown ale, as well as molasses or demerara sweetness, and some burnt caramel.  Nice beer.
Trying to get into more brown ales.  Some have been better than others.  This one was pretty decent.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown hue with a small, short lived head.  Bready, nutty aroma with hints of toast, earthy hops and dark fruit.  Full, creamy body.  Flavor is dark fruit, chocolate, nuts and brown sugar.  Long espresso finish.  Another excellent brew from the great company.

I love brown ales that are hopped up.  Pours deep caramel brown with an tannish head that lingers the entire glass.  No lacing however.  Aroma of chocolates and toffees with a hop edge.  Flavor of perfectly bitter chocolate milk.  Malty and sweet at the start followed by a hop bite at the end.  Smooth in the mouth.  First tried at Gingerman in Houston on a MDA trip.  Glad I brought some back from Houston to KC.
Has a terrific coffee aroma. Is a bit sickly sweet. Still the flavor and experience make up for it.

A complex but easily tasty all-things-to-all people dark ale thats as much at home in a snifter as a shaker. Plummy, vinous, rum-tinged nose. Juicy. Dark purplish brown with a ruby highlight. Fairly bitter flavor with plenty of caramel, touch of roast coffee, hint of booze. Rich yet drinkable. Dangerous.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 $10 sixer - Once again Dogfish Head executes this unique ale extremely well.  Reminds me of the Raison D Etre, which is a little stronger in alcohol and, of course, has more raisin characteristics up front.  4 Months later - This continues to be one of my favorite beers.  I pick up a sixer of this every now and then and never get tired of it.  Most delicious brown ale experiment out there.  1/24/11 - yet another sixer purchased and this is becoming a perennial favorite.  I love the "bite" it has and yet finishes quite smooth with a little alcohol.  Every time I rate this I rate it a tad bit higher.  This could easily be my favorite beer of all time!  Maybe one day it will.

Bottle at Akkurat.

Pours black with a brown head.

Lots of hops and coffe. The big body balances the hops well.

Mild coffee aroma. Dark brown in appearance with little to no head. Begins slightly bitter and ends with a strong coffee flavor. Feels thicker on the palate than appears in the glass. Overall quite a good beer. Dogfish head does not disappoint.

12 oz bottle pour. Glints of Ruby peek out from this pitch black offering. A timid light brown cap provides a surpisingly ample amount of lace.  Coffee and caramel rise from the glass. Chewy in the mouth and warm in the belly. Coffee, chocolate, and all around stouty. The twist is the high level of bitter on the finish. An interesting take on a text book (though extremely well devised) stout.
pours brown with small head.  Aromas are of brown sugar, caramel and a hint of chocolate,  taste is pretty close to the aroma but with some spice.  smooth and enjoyable brown ale!

Pours a dark brown with a tan head. aroma has coffee, chocolate, molasses. pretty decent. Taste is again, coffee, caramel, chocolate and molasses. pretty good. Light mouthfeel, a bit bitter finish. A pretty decent brown ale

Wow, theres a whole lot going on with this beer.  Drank from the tap at a forgotten bar in Asheville, NC.  Pour is atypical of a stout.: Dark with a tan foam head.  Taste is much of the same, but also incorporates a slight nuttiness of a brown ale and a light hop finish.  A fantastic and well balanced ale.

Served from bottle into a Stone nonic.  Pours dark brown with a slight red hue in the light with a one finger off-white head.  Maintains nice lacing throughout.  The aroma is comprised of malt, sugar, chocolate, and fruit.  The flavor is of coffee, chocolate, malt, and caramel.  It was heavy on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this was a surprisingly good brew.  It was very complex in both the flavor and aroma which was very nice.  I am just glad that DFH is distributing in my area now so these are readily available.  A must try for any beer lover.

Pours a deep, dark brown thats almost stout-like in appearance.
Flavor is very complex & masculine.  Earthy & smokey with molasses, and chocolate coming through.  Very smooth & sophisticated.  Love this beer.

Sample at Mondial:

 Deep brown  color with a smallish sandy cap, soft carbonation. 

Aroma is very malty, burnt toffee, roasty, cocoa, fruits,leafy kent hops and earthy nuttiness.

Medium body, rich creamy mouth feel.

Flavour is almost like it smells, big chewy toffee-roasty malts in front, lightly sweet balanced with resinous hopping, midway we get fruitiness and nutty-tobacco tastes then a long roasty lightly bitter finish.

Well executed mutation of the 3 styles.

Growler thanks to Adam.  Aroma of hops and roasted malts.  Dark black body with thin lasting head.  Flavor starts of hoppy and is followed by dark roasted malts and coffee. Slight bitter aftertaste... very well balanced... the flavor of hops dissipates as you drink more...

Drank warm out of dusty, dwarf-sized Hook Norton chalice: the way all fine ales should be sampled. Pours mahogany with a dirty, yellowed collar retreating to the edges of the glass. Bags of alcohol and plummy Belgian-style yeast on the nose, giving way to a more toasted roundedness; coffee beans, cinder toffee, cocoa and molasses. Mouth an unexpected streak of mulled orange and ginger-infused dark chocolate over well-done, still smoking malts. Lingers with expensive filter coffee and burnt pistachio. A bit soapy, but deeply rounded and impressive.
Tastes just like its described.  Goes down real, real smooth.  Probably a bit too neutral for some.

12fl oz bottle poured into a scotch glass (Im at a hotel and its all I could find).  Dark brown with one finger creamy tan head.  Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, slight alcohol.  Flavor is toasted malt, caramel, slight alcohol.  Full body, average carbonation.  Finish is lasting, toast and alcohol.

Pours mid brown, aroma is raisen and malt, light hops. Taste is plenty of malts, an earthy background and some coffee in the finish. Not much alcohol considering the strength.  OK but not very punchy flavours.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark, reddish brown with a lacing tan head. Molasses and coffee aroma. Some smoked flavours, a lot of molasses, on the sweet side. Full-bodied, quite smooth. Tasty.

tasted at the mondiale de la bière in Montréal. pours deep mahogany, with a creamy long lasting head. aroma is malts, caramel, vanilla and hops at the end. taste is sweet with caramel and malt flavors, then quickly gets bitter with an IPA type taste in the mouth. some smokiness too. mouthfeel is sticky yet creamy. this is an amazing beer.

12-oz bottle.

A: The ale is a dark mahogany color, so deep red that appears black from afar. A very tall rocky and persistent tan head. Excellent lacing.

A: Highly aromatic. The nose is malty, thick with a smoky undertone that drips with peat and alcohol-soaked cherries. Caramel malts add further heft to the body.

T: A balanced smoky brown beer. Darker malts, toasted with chocolate, coffee and caramel, lead the way. They are followed almost immediately with a palpable smoky flavor. The result is thick and almost coarse brew. Hop flavor manages to peak through the malts and smoke but just barely. A very enjoyable drink.

P: The mouthfeel is full, smoky and thick, but not so heavy that it is burdensome. I was edxpecting a run of the mill brown ale but, knowing DFH, I should have known otherwise. Finish is fairly dry.

P: They label is a brown ale, but it sure tastes like a scotch ale. The finish is not heavy so you go right back for another drink. Excellent balance overall.

A really nice hoppy brown.  Hops are quite prevalent in the nose.  Chocolate and roasted malts are there too but the hops are not masked too much, or vice versa, a nice balance.  Taste somewhat malty with a subtle hop bitterness.  I have a feeling these need to be drank fresh to really get what they were going for.
12 oz. Bottle. Pours a beautiful brown.  Smells of coffee and some mild hops. Taste is smooth and lightly bitter.  Great beer.

12oz bottled May 14, 2010, just ten days old, nice.  Pours dark brown with ruby highlights, small beige head that reduces quickly and doesnt leave much lacing.  Aroma is strong coffee and almost burnt toast, along with molasses, brown sugar, chocolate, malty, some pine and floral hops, a bit yeasty and a bit funky.  Flavor is roasted & toasted malts, brown sugar, molasses, coffee bitterness, a little chocolate, some citrus, pine and floral hops.  Medium body, medium carbonation, tad sticky toward the end.  This is definitely the strongest aroma Ive encountered with a Brown Ale, quite unique and a tasty brew overall.
Poured deep brown with a thick dark tan head.  Nutty, chocolatey malt aromas.  Felt thick and slightly oily on the tongue.  Nutty malt taste with notes of chocolate and caramel beneath.
Very good effort by Dogfish Head . . not really my style of beer, but I see what they were getting at here . . All in all a very well balanced beer, something for everyone . . Great as usual
Very dark pour, almost black with a near perfect head that quickly dissipates. Taste is brown sugar and bitter hops. Rated 11/17/2000

Bottle from Brattleboro Food Coop. Dark brown body with slight head. Chocolate and vanilla nose. Nice taste of chocolate and vanilla. Lots of malts and caramel. Gets warm and dark chocolate like in the finish. Nicely done, as always.

This bottle resembles their World Wide Stout a lot .  I recall purchasing that boozy  mofo back in 03 at 7.99 a throw ,on its UK limited edition release in Safeway stores.   I didnt get a lotta aromatics in this brew, not especially floral . Just lots of roasty , chocolatty silkiness.  Aint sure what its meant to be but is cool and very plesant , swillable too.

(12 oz bottle). Pours a nice dark brown liquid with tan head.  Smell of roasted coffee, chocolate and earth tones.  Also some pine/resin notes. Salty and bitter/burnt are strongest tastes, but sweetness and to an extent, sour, emerge slightly as the beer warms.  The roast bitterness finish is dominant to me.  I think its a pretty good beer that would get more points if not for the roast finish. Its just not my taste.

Pours a nice dark burnt-umber to coffee-brown. Has a solid tan head with good retention and noticeable lacing.

Major notes of Chocolate, pumpernikel bread, molasses, a tiny hint of ground-coffee, and a faint hop aroma of resin or pine, 

Taste is solid chocolate and molasses up front, with some raisinated fruit on the mid-palate and finishing with a touch of hops and a lot of coffee and bakers chocolate. 

Palate is medium with solid carbonation, alcohol is noticeable but not out of balance. 

Overall this is a VERY drinkable beer for me, and I quite enjoy it.

Dark red and brown pour with a medium sized white head. Aroma of caramel, sugar, malts. Flavor of nuts, hops, and brown sugar. Very smooth and very good. Lots of flavors going on this beer and it all goes well together. Good stuff!
Bottled. Brownish color, short head. Sweetish cookie, sugar, brown malt, bit spicy. Decent stuff.

The nose on this beer is that of molasses and brown sugar, i get s touch of vanilla as well... extremely inviting. It pours a deep brown, almost black , with a soft mocha head.This is a great beer. I get brown sugar followed by dark chocolate and raisins, and then the hops finish this beer off perfectly. Heavy on the palate with the perfect amount of carbonation. i wouldnt expect anything less from Dogfish head! Well done!

Bottle. Beautiful black/brown body. Aroma is coffee, cocoa powder and honey. Taste is caramel, leafy hops with a red fruit finish. Standard Dogfish Head like palate. Straight forward yet excellent brew. Out of style, but very enjoyable.
Pours very dark brown with red tones. Smells of roast malts and raisins. Mouthfeel is crisp and full, tasting of roastiness with some chocolate.

Pours a dark brown color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit with hints of chocolate, caramel, and coffee.  Has a creamy mouth feel.  Sweet taste up front with notes of coffee and chocolate on the finish.  Some subtle bitters on the back.
Pours a dark brown, with nice tannish head. Chocolatey, hoppy aroma with only the slightest hops notes. Chocolate and toffe in the taste, smooth malty character. Another nice offering from Dogfish.!
Bottle. Brown with a small creamy head anda trace of hops. Left lots of lacing and a chocolate aftertaste.Different, interesting and classy.

Bottle. Pour was deep brown with an aroma of American spicy hops and a little citrus along with the toasted malt and caramel characters. Flavors were well blended with the hops, while dominant, only accompanying the malt, light caramel, and chocolate. Nice blend, and nice malt character.

Very aromatic with strong coffee, bittersweet chocolate licorice and fig notes.  Deep crimson/cherry wood color with thick tan head.  Taste is a medley.  Nice spicy hoppiness.  Once again coffee, chocolate and licorice are strong.  Has a sweet start at first but doesnt hold that impression. Very long, enjoyable, warming alcohol finish.  Well crafted and definitely worth a 6 pack or two.

Draft opens with chocolate, malt sugar and alcohol. Flavor has a minor citrus with tons of chocolate. Chalky. Very drinkable with a sweeping sweetness on the finish that ends super dry and clean, pretty amazing!

aroma of roasted malt and chocolate...good looking thin head good lacing blah blah..taste is most unusual..seems like the smokiness then the hops and spices hit you first in this brown ale then the sweet flavors..caramel honey burnt sugar..almost like a west coast brown ale an unusual hoppiness which just about but nnot quite overpowers the spicy chocolate  notes...very good

Bottle from Beer Ritz, Leeds.  Dark brown pour with a smallish lingering tan head. Predominantly roasted aroma, with coffee and nut notes. Sweetish flavour that was similarly roasty in character. Some hoppage begins to emerge through the maltiness, but never quite muscles through enough to make the IPA tag relevant. Not convinced by the balance here.  Drinkable enough, but no cigar.

12oz. bottle served in a shaker pint. Poured a medium brown with a finger of tan head. Nice chocolatey aroma with some hops as well. Tons of chocolate malt in the flavor. Medium bodied. Decent hop bite in the middle. Long lingering chocolate malt finish. This is a really nice brown ale. Easy drinking at 7.2% abv.

This brown ale from a 12-oz bottle poured a  clear mahogany with moderate two finger tan head.  The nose is sweet malts, raisins, ripe fruit and roasted nuts.  The body is on the heavy side of medium and the mouthfeel is slick and creamy.   The flavor rich caramel and chocolate malts with a hint of coffee and sugar. The alcohol is noticeable especially in the long dry bitter finish.   An unusual brown, but very good drinking.

A- dark brown body with a thin cream colored head. Leaves behind plenty of lacing in the glass.

S- dark robust smell of toasted malt and coffee.

T- strong initial taste of coffee and toasted malt. This is followed by hop bitterness. Hop bitterness and a roasted coffee taste linger.

P- High carbonation and a very thick, full body.

O- This is a pretty drinkable and very interesting brew. Its quite complex and is definitely worth a try.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-24-2007 03:52:25
Had this one in Scotland. Brown colored brew. Hoppy aroma. Roasted malts in the flavor, hoppy.
Brown Ales always taste sort of odd to me, not really sure what it is.  Definitely some smokey/porter flavor in there, and the dry hopping sure gives it a nice balance.
Bottled. The aroma has caramel, toffee, dark fruits. Clear, brown coloured with an off-white head. The taste has sweet caramel malts, little roast. Medium bodied. Okay.

From Beers of Europe, rating number 300. Crikey - caramel, brown sugar, coffee, malt, chocolate. Then theres the hops the carbonation, the richness, the smoothness. Only the 2nd of their beers Ive tried, looking forward to more. Utterly superb.......even my wife said the aroma was good and she was sat 2 seats away!

Dark black-brown color with light tan head. Hops, roasted malts, chocolate and coffee in aroma. Very rich and full flavor of stout with very good hpoppyness. Well carbonated which makes it crisp in mouth and palate. Great aftertaste of hops and raosted malts with hints of smoke

Purchased at Winslows Tavern, Greenville, NC

Dark brown, almost black.  Thick head.  Aroma filled with coffee undertones.

12 oz bottle poured into a Belgium fishbowl glass. Bottled on 9/19/09. Dark brown, nearly black. Medium head Earthy nuttiness, with some aromas of rum or bourbon.  Mild hoppiness, but mainly picking up caramel and nuttiness flavors, with some delightful chocolate tones to it. 
Medium/full bodied, creamy on the palate. Nice roasted malt finish.
Very versatile beer. You could drink this to complement a main course, or its smooth enough to have as a session beer (but watch the 7.2% ABV!)
12 ounce bottle a dark brown pour tan head taste of chocolate, coffee, nuts, caramel, Lots going with ths beer .sweet bitter hop finish

2 year old bottle. Aroma of somewhat old hops, citrus and grass, with rich brown malt, chocolate, caramel. Interesting combination: rich and chewy. Rich dark malt flavor, big caramel, some chocolate, still nice hops: grassy, earthy, pine. Smooth palate, light carbonation. Rich and full. Nicely dry. Great stuff.

Dark brown/black pour with a nice tan head. Smell is hops, some roasty malt, and coffee smell, along with some smokiness as well as it warms up. Taste is very rich, full bodied and flavorful, but still carbonated well and not too heavy or creamy. The 7.2% alcohol is hidden well and its very drinkable. Some definite bitter/burnt tastes noticeable, but overall it is very unique and well done. Like most of their beers, different and tasty.There is several types of beer in 1 bottle.
Pours dark brown with tan head that lasts.  Aroma of chocolate, malt, and hops.  Tastes of bitter chocolate.  Stout-like mouthfeel.  Overall a nice brown ale, but a bit hoppy for my palate.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Pours a nice looking dark brown with a tan head which fades to lacing on the edges the glass.  aroma is of lots of carmel, brown sugar, coffee, and some hops.  flavor is of carmel malt, brown sugar, cofffee, bitter hops, chocloate, molasses, rasins, and a little alchool.  has a medium-full body with a creamy, stout like mouthfeel and a bitter, hoppy finnish.  overall, a excellent well hopped brown.
Heavy caramel aroma, thick brown head.  Thicker body than most brown ales, with a stout-like finish.
a hoppy brown ale with an alcohol kick. not something I can see myself drinking much but an interesting beer.

Draft.  Pours nearly black with a small brownish head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, raisins, molasses, and alcohol.  Tastes like a mocha Baileys!  Sweet but not overly so.  Hops play around the edges.  Delicious but not really what I think of when I think "brown ale."
Bottle from The Cave. Brown colour, tan head. Aroma of  toffee and caramel. Flavour of dark fruits, malts, alcohol, molasses, toffee. Nice one.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark amber brown. Smells of barley, molasses malt, and hops. Flavor comes in stages. Upon first sip, there is a brief hit of sweet brown sugar that foreshadows a later stage. Becomes immediately bitter with notes of barley grain and ginger. Morphs into a boozy caramel flavor. Then develops distinct notes of brown sugar as the boozy character subsides. At some points, there are small hints of coffee amid the molasses (a bit in the aftertaste as well). The finish is a return to the bitter. A solid beer.

Interesting brew. Dark brown with minimal beige head. Nose is the anticipated malts, slightly chocolatey, a hint of cinnamon. Tastes of nutmeg, butterscotch, allspice, burnt baked apple; very sweet, very malty. Not tasting the hops very much. Nice left-field take on the brown ale style.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2010 Bottle pours brown, clear, with thin-moderate beige head.  Nice sticky lacing.  Tastes coffee, chocolate and brown sugar.  Lots of hops but not overpowering with very nice balance.  Palate medium body, thick feel, average carbonation,  tasteful and pleasing finish.  A favorite.

Pours dark brown, settles quickly with moderate lacing. Caramel with light herbal hop undertones create a refreshing aroma. Taste is a smooth brown ale with a great hop balance. Complex flavors finishes really strong.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Indian Brown Ale.  2002 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Slightly hazy amber brown color.  Medium lacy head.  Floral light toasted hop front.  Thin dry rich flavored carmalized rich IPA body.  Mild chocolate nut notes.  Balanced sweet citrus hop end.  Tangy Brown IPA.  Sampled 10/29/2002.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Indian Brown Ale.  2003 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Clear dark amber brown color.  Lacy mild head.  Toasted floral light cocoa rich hop front.  Thin tangy citrus sweet light cocoa nut toasted brown sugar body.  Crisp hot citrus hop end.  Goldings & Liberty hops.  Sweet.  Sampled. 9/18/2003.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Indian Brown Ale.  2007 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV--50 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Brown Ale.  6-Pack $9.99.  Mild lace mild espresso head.  Clear bright dark amber bronze brown color.  Toasted mild chocolate hop front.  Very tangy rich dry sweet chocolate nut mild black cherry fruit Porterish body.  Mild fruit hop spice tangy toasted end.  Fruity notes.  Sampled 5/22/2008.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Indian Brown Ale.  2008 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV--50 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Rich thin lacy off white head.  Clear bright dark bronze brown color.  Aromatic chocolate coffee herbal hop front.  Tangy crisp dry sweet toasted thin malt chocolate coffee zesty body.  Mild fruit notes.  Bitter hop dark malt dry mild citrus end.  Big Brown Porter IPA.  Sampled 5/18/2009.  6-Pack $11.79.

Reddish Brown color. Tan, average foam. Roasted notes in Aroma, more so than hops. For 50IBUs the hops are countered by heavy roasted and even chocolate elements. These dominate over hops. Medium dry body. Slight alcohol taste upon warming. A hearty beer.
Pours a dark brown with an small size tan head that was gone quickly. Malty along with some chocolate and a big finish of hops and alcohol. A good brown ale.
bottled. small light chocolate colored head. aroma: nuts, caramel, coffee, and hops. taste:  good caramel, toasted malts, floral hops
Aroma - coffee, nuts.  Taste - medium sweetness, lightly bitter.  This was a great find.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark red-black with a large, clingy, tan head that lasts.  Taste is of coffee, roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and hops.  Slightly sweet.  Well balanced.  Has a nice dryness and bitterness in the finish that lingers.  Similar aroma.  Good slick body.  Very drinkable and quite enjoyable.  Shows no hints of have 7.2% abv.  Well worth picking up again.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown, creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasty and nutty with some light citrus hops.  The flavor is nutty, sweet malt with a little bit of hop bitterness.  Medium body, average carbonation and a long smooth finish.  Overall pretty good.  Dont get all the hops that they claim...maybe an old bottle, but nice.

Another success from Dogfish Head!  Had it on tap at the 9:30 Club for a GREAT Cage the Elephant show. (shameless plug, but it was the best show Ive seen there).
Anyways, the beer.  Nutty goodness. Had a very british taste to it.  IT looked nice with a deep dark muddy brown color with an ugly dark creamy bubbly head (though not a very big head).  Had some coffee and chocolate flavors almost like a stout, a touch of caramel, some nuttiness.  An all around good beer. It wasnt that it was amazingly complex (which it was fairly complex) it was that had a little of a few different styles so it was just different and unique.  For that you have to give it good marks.  although it makes it tough to place within a category.

Thick, foamy, rish, dark brown goodness. Reminds me of demiglace. Almost too rich and flavorful to drink by itself. Makes me want to fix some meatloaf and smashed right now. No, better yet, kill something, grind it up and fix meatloaf. Its a manly brew, tasty.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.   Pours a dark brown with medium brown highlights.  Has very little head and little lacing.  It is a cross between an IPA and a brown ale, but mostly IPA comes through.  If you are a hop fan this is for you.  I am not a fan, too much hops.  Not sure why it is rated so high.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a big off-white head. Big nose to it, flavor is molasses, coffee, some burnt flavor, and chocolate. Solid brown ale.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2010 Bottle sample at work.  Dogfish head has long been know for its quality beers, and they didnt fall short this time either.  Well put together Brown Ale, though it really reminded me more of a coffee stout than a true Brown.  As far as their line goes, this falls somewhere in the middle, but for a lineup as impressive as theirs, that is still saying a lot.  Not much more to say other than Id drink it again.  Well worth the price.

From the Bottle.  Poured a dark brown slight amber color, very little head.  Aroma was sweet, with malts, malasses, and caramel.   This beer packed quite a punch.  The malts and hops are well balanced, and I tasted molasses, chocolate, and the right amount of sweetness.  The carbonation was also a pleasant surprise, excellent palate.  Great beer!

Tap at Busboys and Poets.  Very dark maroon with a medium beige head that lingers.  Aroma of cocoa and vanilla.  Flavor is butterscotch at first, then roasted coffee and pine nuts.  Very rich and tasty.  On of the nicer Dogfish Heads.

Pours very dark brown with red highlights.  Thick tan head.  Significant lacing.  Aroma is of caramel and roasted malts.  Really excellent nose.  Taste is incredibly complex.  Starts rather dry.  Ends with sweet malts.  Some bitter hops in the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is full-bodied and thick, and the beer leaves some spiciness on my gums.  Superb.
Bottle, opaque root beer pour, aromas of sweet malt, vanilla, and some booze, sweet and smooth with some bitter nuttiness on finish, solid brown ale

Bottle at Wilde.  Pours a dark thick brown with a thick head of slightly loose bubbles that dampens the scent of burnt coffee, cinnamon, and brown sugar.  Well hopped with a nice ringing bitterness.  I also detected hints of oak and snoke that rounded out the taste very nicely.

12 oz. bottle- Pours brownish black with a pour I had to rigorously pour just to get a quarter inch head, aroma is of light caramel malt and coffee. The flavor is weird, a hoppy-malty brown ale. Experimental as usual from this brewery, the question is did it work. I think it did because it tastes good, and that is the most important part of the structure of a beer. You can be experimental as hell but if it tastes like shit, you have a shitty beer. They blended hops and malt perfectly to make a well balanced hoppy brown ale.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 Looks very nice in a glass... poured a dark brown with a thick foamy beige head.  The aroma isnt overly appealing to me, lightly sweet and coffeeish.  Flavor is coffee, raisins, figs, chocolate, finishes a touch bitter.  Theres a flavor to it that throws it off for me, something reminiscent of iron on the midpallete.  Reminds me of having blood in my mouth.  Tasted awesome on the first sip and retains some good notes, but overall not great.

Has to be one of my favorite brown ales. The aroma is sweet and pleasant. It has hints of barley,chocolate,coffee and dried fruit. The taste lingers on the tongue and leaves a sweet bitter after taste.
Dark mahogany hue and thick white head. Smell of Ginger and coffee. Has molassess, coffee and caramel taste. One of the best brown ales I have ever had.
(bottle) deep brown colour, little head; aroma of toffee, chocolate; clean medium bitter flavour, excellent

pours deep better then that morning coffee, little head,aromas of mocha chocolate,and concordand a touch of alcohol thanks to the 7.2%  Taste   grape tootsie pop, soy  sauce,An iron blood like quality(game,beef) and coffee  although it looks very heavy  it has a  medium sourness, medium bitterness,overall Really smooth
Pours a rich brown, tan head. Aroma of coffee, bitter chocolate, some sweetness, slight hops. Taste is similar, Mouthfeel is rich and sticky.

Pours a deep brown with a thick frothy tan head.  Taste of malt chocolate and coffee with some hoppy flavor.  The hop taste is pretty subtle.  Really a great beer.

12 oz. bottle

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2011 Bottle. The pour was a deep dark brown in color with an average size light brown frothy head that lasted only a short while but produced some good lacing. 

The aroma was heavy of a toasted caramel malt, a mild resin hop and a moderate scent of a leathery yeast with a nice rich roasted coffee note.
