It tasted mildly sweet, malty and slightly bitter with just a hint of caramel and coffee at first and finished with a nice dark bitter coffee flavor that lasted a nice long time. 

Mouthfeel was very creamy in texture and full in body with a very soft carbonation. 

Overall this Brown Ale was robust and loaded with lots of flavor, as well as being very smooth and creamy.

Bottle sample at the DFH tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 1/22/10. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. Roasty and nutty aroma with caramel, some chocolate and grassy/earthy hops. Caramel malt flavor with a hint of chocolate before a bitter hoppy and roasty finish. Good brown ale.

( 12oz bottle) Pours a beautiful brown color with a nice 1 finger head. No lacing and the head falls quickly. Smell is of brown sugar, hops, and caramel roasted malt. Its very bittersweet, way too roasty, and the brown sugar and caramel malt play second fiddle in the background. Extremely disappointing. Nicely carbonated and feels good.

12 oz. bottle, pours a very dark (near-black) brown with a medium tan-head. Aroma is sweet roasted malts, nuts, coffee and brown sugar. Complex flavour of mainly roasted malt and nuts, with a bit of caramelized sugar and coffee. Mouthful is very smooth and creamy, with a very pleasant hoppy aftertaste. Wonderful brew.

12 oz. bottle from the party source.  Pours a nice dark brown color with a thin, creamy tan head with so-so retention.  Aroma of sweet roasted malts, nuts, earthy hops, brown sugar, a bit of coffee, and toast.  The flavor has more sweet roasted malts and nutty flavors, with less coffee than the nose but the same hoppiness coming through along with sweet brown sugar and caramel.  Medium-bodied, with a chewy mouthfeel and sweet roasty finish.  Great brown ale, a take on the style that nods to a few other styles to add some character.
Good brown with an extra hoppiness of IPA.  Solid flavor, more complex taste than most browns.  Solid beer.

12oz bottle 
Appearance: Dark brown with a reddish tint, small tan head with some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, pine 
Taste: Roasted malts and coffee with a nice hop bitterness 
This is a very good beer. Well balanced, clean and crisp tasting. Very drinkable beer.
Pours chestnut brown with no real head.  Aroma of brown sugar, caramel and barley.  Flavors of caramel, coffee, brown sugar, raisins with a touch of hops.  Smooth.  Good lacing.  Very nice!

Pours dark brown with light tan head, aroma full of caramel, coffee, and dark malts with a bit hop character.  Taste up front shows a bit of the hops but dives quickly into a complex malt taste of the brown sugar, coffee, toffee, caramel, and chocolate and bitters a bit at the end.  A very good brew, but more like a brown ale than IPA.

Wow this was an interesting brew.  Really dark brown with minimal cream head.  Huge malty aroma with notes of chocolate, caramel, sweetness, goodness, and a small amount of fruit.  More fruit comes out in the taste, but still a full palate of chocolate malt, a  little coffee, and an awesome hop kick on the end.  This and New Hollands Cabin Fever are my two favorite browns.  This has more of a hop presence than the Cabin Fever tho.  Different and exceptional

12 oz. bottle.   Pours dark brown with minimal tan head that doesnt last long.  Aroma is really good.  Toast, coffee, chocolate, raisins, some floral hops, and a small amount of alchohol can be recognized.  Taste is similar to aroma which is good.   Very creamy in the mouth and the hops finish it off with a nice bitter finish.  Ive had this beer before a long time ago and never rated it.   I forgot how good it was.  Im glad I gave it another try because this is a high quality brown ale.

Dark brown with a thin light brown head.  Aroma of brown sugar, toffee and molasses.  Dark coffee, caramel and black strap molasses flavor up front with a smooth, floral bitterness.  Finishes with a velvety smooth, creamy bitter finish that lingers for a good length of time.

Pours dark brown with an average-sized, off-white, frothy, and lasting head.  Brown sugar, coffee flavors clearly noticeable in the malt. Theres a light sweetness upfront with a very pleasing and lasting bitterness in the finish. Great balance. The palate is very smooth and inviting. A unique beer, very worth drinking again!

bottle.  pours beautiful dark brown with large caramel head.  Malts of brown sugar, coffee, roasted nuts, toffee.  just perfectly delicious.  This might be my favorite.  Not as complex as the raison d etre.

Pours to a deep brown with tan head. Noticeable molasses and coffee grinds with a hint of flower on nose. This is a lighter heavy bodied Ale with a velvet mouthfeel accented with tastes of coffee, and malty syrup and sugar.

Bottle - World Market - Not much hop aroma and some malts but not as much as I would expect in a brown ale.  Appears to be black once poured with thin brown head.  Lots of different malty flavors that tasted good on the palate.  Almost a liquor flavor with some caramel and maybe coffee tastes; but NOT hot with alcohol like some high ABV beers.  The 50 IBUs is noticed in the aftertaste.  For my taste, I wish they would have moved some of the bittering hops over to the favoring boil time to catch more of the Liberty/Golding hop flavors.  Overall - above average but prefer the 60 minute IPA.
Bottle. Dark brown/copper pour, offwhite head. Aroma of caramel, roast, and hop. Medium mouthfeel. Taste of malt, chocolate, nut - very easy drinking, yet has pretty good depth of flavor.

The commercial description includes American Pale Ale....where did they come up with this.  Dark, rich, warming, and thick is my off the cuff description.  Very tasty brew that is full of roasty flavours and nicely hopped.  Native Americans rejoice, this beer would have kept you warm in the winter!  So good that my wife, a confirmed hophead loved it.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2010 Bubbly, long-lasting head. Aroma of smoked caramel. Flavor of toast, caramel, nicely balanced by not too bitter hops. Very Flavorful. Well Done.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2009 Bottle, 7.2%. Vinous aroma, roasted, smells a little lagered. Clear dark brown colour. Small stable light brown head. The flavour is nicely roasted, slightly sweet. Not as vinous as the aroma, but still a bit vinous. OK balanced. Roasted aftertaste with a good deal of barley bitterness which gets a bit rough after a while.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a huge and slight brown head. Aroma is dark and slight chocolate malt. Smooth malty and slight chocolate flavoured. Smooth chocolate and malty flavoured, light vanilla note. Smooth malty into the far finish. Ends nice and easy.

(br-btl bu-lbl with coffee beans, 6 pack, 7.2%)

lct-br, thin tan head, med-full body, ^co2.

sweet-malt ^alchl leafy-hop aroma.

sweet-malt fresh-hop T1, leafy-hop §hop-bitter §chrcl br-ale(mineral) T2, dry T3.
 ^flavorful, complex , more clash than balance, nice hops, §too sweet from br-sugar.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass

The color is a dark black with light brown head with some nice lacing.

The smell is a coffee bean flavor with a deep roasty malt flavor. Some slight brown sugar and hops flavor.

The taste is roasty with some dark malt and burnt suagr flavor. There is some slight hint spicy brown sugar and caramel.

The feel is really great and is a nice medium feel. Its slightly carbonated and goes down well.
12 oz bottle from Casanova.  Deep brown color, big foamy tan head.  Malty caramel aroma.  Flavor is sweet, caramel, slightly hoppy.  Finish is hoppy with a touch of caramel.

(12 ounce bottle - pint glass)  Little head and lace.  Roasted malt taste that gives it a coffee chocolate toffeish tounge.  But it is balanced with a light hoppy side.  Also has notes of brown sugar and cinnamon.  Thick to medium bodied.

A mahogany pour with medium tan head.  The aroma is full of sweet chocolate malt and hops.  The taste begins sweet with chocolate and molasses then slowly fades to a dry bitter finish with a slight coffee aftertaste.  This beer is full of different flavor that meld together beautifully.

I must say that this is a very interesting beer. Dark in the glass with very little head. The alcohol can be smelled along with a faint fruity character. The first thing that one notices is the coffee flavor, but it is soon overwhelmed with what I believe to be an overly aggressive carbonation. This quickly subsides and one is left with a nice hoppy finish. At the end of the day, I would recommend this and will be buying more.
Nice combination of roasted malt flavors with a fair amount of hoppiness as well.  Really well made stuff.

Very good balance in this beer.  The great thing is that the sweetness balances with the bitterness of the hops.  This beer is great if you feel like a brown but dont want too much sweet, or if you want an IPA but dont want too much bite.  Flavors of brown sugar, dried fruits, and sweet barley.  One of my new favorites.
Pours thick and dark. Flavors of coffee and sweet grapes. A nice helping of hops balances out this thick malt. An amazing combination of two of my favorite styles

poured out dark brown with a nice frothy finger thick head that was a dark beige.  the body is a super dark brown with little light penetration.  the aromas are chocolate, dried grapes, some toffee and caramel.  it is also kind of sweet and a slight bitterness in the nose.  it is medium bodied and very malty with a really nice bitter finish.  it is a little grainy across the tongue but is very smooth throughout.  i taste slight sweetened coffee, candi sugar, roasted malts, clove and also some slight banana.  it is a little bitter from the hops, and is primarily sweet all the way through.  it finishes creamy and has a really nice soft aftertaste that hangs out with you for a little while.  pretty enjoyable beer through out the whole tasting.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Just what I want beer to always be! Pours clear dark brown with a strong head that happily stands a half inch above the rim of my glass.  Aroma is sweet malt with hints of brown sugar, toffee and molasses.  Taste is a little burnt with a lot of sweet malt and oak. Flavor really rounds out as it warms.  Finishes with toffee and more brown sugar and a bourbony feel upon the first breath after it goes down.  Such a pleasant beer to drink. Cheers!

Sampled at The Big Pour beerfest in Scottsdale AZ. We spent quite a bit of time at the DFH booth and ended up getting a few hats and T-shirts from the crew! This beer is a beautiful deep ruby brown with an intensely malty aroma, rich roast (coffee and bitter chocolate) and toffee on raisin toast. Chewy malty palate, roast-dominated, but with a refreshing fruity bitterness in the finish. Awesome!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
A: Poured with an average-to-large sized, light brown head that slowly diminished to 1/4-finger. Body is jet-black at first glance, and therefore opaque, until I hold it up to the light... you can then see some brown hints near the top. Fair lacing left on the sides of the glass.

S: Complex aroma of slight roasted malt, bitter hops, and chocolate... lots and lots of chocolate.

T: And the chocolate is what comes through first in the taste... bitter chocolate, which leads way to the lightly bitter finish from the hops. Very interesting and enjoyable... reminds me more of a stout in many ways than your typical brown ales. I cant detect the 7%+ alcohol at all.

M: Full-bodied with a nice, creamy texture, and average carbonation bordering on the soft side.

D: This is a damn fine brew... kind of a combination of a brown ale, stout, and an IPA as well. A fantastic sipping beer.

On tap at Coasters.  Dark brown pour with minimal head.  Dark roasted malt aroma with some dark chocolate and only a hint of floral hops.  Roasty malt flavor with some smoke and dark chocolate.  This really leans more toward a porter than a brown ale.  Im not sure the flavor is quite as complex as the commercial description would lead you to believe but this is a very good "brown" ale.

im just not getting it. on tap @ GIBF, I really dont know how this brewer gets such good ratings, i do like the 60 min IPA, but everything else Ive had has been way too overbearing, maybe i dont like my beers with that much flavor, but this one was too muddled, is it a malty IPA or is it a hoppy brown?

Pours a deep ruby, nice sized off white head with excellent lacing... Very aromatic, sweet dark sugars, coffee, chocolate, caramel, chocolate is very noticable as it warms.. Rich, roasty, coffee, chocolate flavors, and a touch of the hops to keep it in check... Lingeringly roasty, bitter finish with sweet undertones, dry, medium full bodied... this beer defines american brown ales...

Bottle. Quite like a porter, though the roasty coffee bitterness is balanced by a fullness and a perfumy hoppiness. Sweet. Its not a beer you want to drink a bunch of at one sitting, but not special enough to want to set one aside for savoring.
initial caramel notes with coffee and molasses , more hops than traditional browns, tending towards an IPA/brown mix.
Good thick head, nice mouthfeel. Taste of coffee and maybe molasses. Almost reminds me more of a porter or stout than a brown ale - which is fine by me, because I usually like those styles better.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Arômes de malt chocolaté, de mélasse, de caramel et de fruits mûrs. Robe brune foncée et claire, effervescence à grosses bulles et peu de mousse. Moyennement ronde et légèrement sucrée, la bière montre une très belle complexité maltée (chocolat, caramel anglais, mélasse, fruits mûrs). Finale légèrement amère de houblon. Très bon.

Dark brown which glows a nice ruby when held up to the light. Very nice fluffy head, which leaves behind layers of lacing.

Toffee, caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit, English hops - smells like a big English Brown.

Major malt explosion upfront - strong caramel, fruit and roasted notes, maybe even a slight smokiness. Bitter at the end, much more so than other Browns, with a persistent bitter aftertaste. DFH describes this as a cross between a traditional Brown, a Scotch Ale and an IPA; throw Porter or Stout into the mix (because of the roasted character) and that may be just about right. I didnt know a Brown could handle this much taste.

This is a very smooth beer with a full body and moderate carbonation. Slightly warming.

Great sipping beer. Almost too much flavor for multiple beers. This is a Brown Ale on crack.

Deep ruby brown with foamy light tan head. Rich caramel malt aroma with traces of fuggles and goldings. Quite remarkable flavours. The first is meminiscent of an english bitter. Then comes a huge malt punch; caramel, licorice, vanilla and butterscotch. A big hop bite at the end. Big body but a dry finish. A really smooth quaffable, but still interesting beer. Drinks like a session.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a ruby brown beer with a nice beige head. Very pleasant nutty aroma of caramel, great hops, maple syrup, mango, walnut, ginger and brown sugar. Nice balance in the taste. Extremely smooth. A lot of ginger, mocha and brown sugar showing up. Not much carbonation. Wonderful nutty finish which is reminiscent of coffee, ginger, mint and mocha. I like the taste more than the aroma. A great beer.

(Draught) Dark brown and hazy. Small white head. Nuts and roastedness in aroma. Medium bodied palate with medium carbonation. Roastedeness, nuts, chocolate, hops, bitterness and sweetness in taste. Malty and bitter aftertaste. Nice beer but a bit far away from brown ale. Luckily thats not a problem.

Pours a slightly hazy dark brown with tan head that retains well and laces well.  Nose has a fresh bread & nougat aroma.  On the palate the hops dominate far more than expected, almost leaving the roasty flavors too far behind in the background.  Its not a traditional brown ale and its a struggle to appreciate it for what it is.
Pours a dark brown, almost black, frothy, average carbonation, medium body, molasses. Great beer.

Pours a deep ruby brown with a good head and nice lace. 
Aroma of molasses and chocolate with some coffee notes, wonderfully pungent. The flavor is of coffee, some good roasty flavors with a nicely balanced hoppiness. 
As far as Im concerned this is a damn home run from Dogfish Head!

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a dark brown with glimmers of amber in the light.  The aroma is a mix of hops and rich dark malts, caramel and bakers chocolate.  The flavor largely profiles the scotch ale.  It is rich and creamy like condensed milk with notes of dark chocolate and butterscotch.  The bitter hops are subtle but round out the finish and offer a nice complexity.

Bottle.  Pours a dark coffee brown with a short beige head.  Arroma is initially roasty BBQ, then some toasted nuts, burnt caramel, and dark dried fruits.  Flavor has a bunch of raisins, some coffee and molasses.  Full bodied but not overly, with generous carbonation.

Pours deep brown/dark amber with nice brown/tan head.  Aroma comprised of roasted malt and brown sugar; not as hoppy of an aroma as I was expecting, but present.  Great roast taste, but overpowers the hoppiness a little.  Nonetheless, very good.  A strong showing.
Dark brown color with a small head. Aroma has some nuts, burnt grains and grass. Flavor is roasty with nuts and caramel with a nice sweetness and a bitter roast.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2009 What a beer first of all. A perfectly mixed combination of English styles, the IPA and the Brown Ale makes this IBA one to behold and savor. As part of my IBA tasting session, this one stood out amongst the rest to register as the best. An awesome hoppy and strong malt aroma mixed with a dark, mud-like pour adds up to an explosion of aged malts and strong, yet soft biting hops. Make no mistake, this Indian Brown Ale is one to seek out!

Pours medium dark brown with a quickly discipating head.  Significant bitterness is in balance with the massive caramel, toasty flavors with a hint of roastiness.  The finish hops could be a little more ascertive.  Definitely leans more toward a Scottish malt profile that toward a Brown.  Great Beer!
A dark brown beer with little head. Aroma was sweet, & nutty. The taste was sweet, smooth, & roasted malt. A nice brown with more hops than usual.

Odd combination of flavors.  Is it a brown or is it an IPA.  I guess I am a more traditionalist in this aspect.  Notes of coffee and molasses mixed with an infusion of hops that gives it an overly alcoholic vibe. Beautiful large frothy head that is rather lasting

Dark ruby-brown pour with light brown head. Aroma of sweet malt, roasted nuts, caramel. Taste is great-creamy, roasted malt, nutty, sweet caramel. Finishes with a nice roasted flavor. Hops is well balanced with the other flavors. One of the best brown ales I have ever had if not the best. Nice lacing on the glass.
Poured darker than I had expected, smells of chocolate and nuts.  Not as much hops as I would have thought.

It poured a very dark brown (close to black) liquid with small light brown foam that left little to no lacing. It had a scent of sweet chocolate and lots of it, also some soy sauce. It also had a strong taste of chocolate, smooth and very nice. But it didnt feel very complex and I would have loved some more different tastes in the beer.

Aroma: Roasted, sweet malt, coffee. 
Flavor: Initial sweet roasted malt and caramel continue into the mid-palate and finish. Ends with a long, roasted coffee note.
Comment:  Well-made with long finish.

[bottle into dimpled mug] The taste of this is chocolate and nuts. This is a very good beer, and is the first IBA i have had. There is a slightly overpowering hops taste, and the mouthfeel is a little tacky. Pours a deep red/brown with little foamy head.
Good - but too much like a scotch ale for me. Had those cloying overdone flavors Im not into. But tasty, and the hoppiness brought it back from the edge somewhat.
Strong molasses flavor. Almost like an oaked bourbon, but a little more fruity and sugary sweet. Very nice hop finish.

12oz bottle from total wine in norfolk. pours a translucent, dark brown with a soft, half inch, light tan head and solid lacing. aroma is very nice with big, dark, toasted malts, chocolate, and roast coffee with a hint of grassy hops and dark fruits. flavor is delicious with a beautiful balance of dark, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, molasses, and brown sugar with piney, bitter hops and a touch of fruit leading to a slightly sweet, roasted finish. palate is smooth, medium bodied and almost creamy with good carbonation. overall, and excellent brown ale.
Dark pour with thin off white head. Flavors of dark fruit and some coffee. Nice sharp finish with a little bite on the aftertaste...good stuff

(Bottle, Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Dark brown colour with ruby hints. Frothy, beige head. Malty, roasted nose with chocolate, hops, pine needles and a touch of resin. Malty, roasted taste with notes of chocolate, dark fruit, toffee and a generous bitterness in the finish. Great balance. Hoppy and roasted brown ale leaning in the porter direction. Very nice beer.
Full flavored without being heavy and overpowering.  Caramelized brown sugar aroma and very distinct in taste.

So, I am making a soup and it called for a dark beer...I went with a brown ale considering I like them so much :)  I had heard that Dogfish Heads Indian Brown Ale was a great brown ale to have, so I decided to incorporate it into my soup.  Good choice...made the soup very good...and the little bit I had to taste after was very good. 

The beer pours a transparent brown, on the darker side...but not quite opaque.  A foamy tan head that dissipate relatively quickly (but that could also be because of my poor pouring skills).  Aroma is very nice, chocolaty, a bit of coffee and hoppy floral.  Taste is really very heavy on the chocolate.  Creamy, milky (its almost like a milk stout), very refreshing.  Its awesome on my palate - hop flowers and light carbonation..sweet, and caramelly.  I like this beer.  Good job Dogfish Head.

Aroma of coffee and caramel malts. Poured a brown color with beautiful lacing and a strong head retention. Flavor packed with notes of chocolate, malt, ginger, and slight hops. All in all, this is the best brown ale I have ever had.
Poured a dark brown color with nice head. Aroma and taste of chocolate, hops, coffee, sweet candy. Very smooth with a coffee bitter finish. Very Bold and balanced overall.

Bottle.  Pours a dark opaque brown with a sudsy khaki head.  Nose is roasted malts, brown sugar, resinous hops, vanilla, cocoa.  Flavor is roasted malt, cocoa, hops, molasses.  Slightly creamy sweet and roasty palate.  A little bit of a coffee bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2009 Picked up 3 different brews from DFH. After being let down by 60 and 90 min I was greeted by this gem. This is a great deep flavorful beer! Will be getting some more of this. Chocolate, coffee malts and hops all balanced very well.

Normally I do not care for Browns. This one however has the added bitterness from the hops to make it drinkable. It still has the sweet malt that I am not a big fan of, which shows that a high IBU does not mean a bitter beer. The aroma is smooth of a light chocolate, even caramel, and ends with coffee. Not a bad beer, not a great beer.

A mighty fine beer. Dark brown with a clean, surprisingly lasting head. Bold flavors, malt and hop well balanced. Caramel is the prevailing flavor in this one. Coffee, chocolate, and hop bitterness in the back end. Darker than most brown ales and shares some characteristics of its darker brethren. Supremely balanced and shockingly sessionable for its ABV. Can be a quick or slow drink.
Pours dark brown like a stout.  Same coffee and chocolatety flavor of a stout with a nice hoppy bite to balance the caramel malts.  Good beer overall.

Pours deep coffee color with small, lacy, tan head. I get caramel, coffee, bitter chocolate and molasses in the nose. Flavor    is bitter-sweet chocolate, coffee, earth and spice with a balanced finish. Body is velvet and creamy. A highly drinkable brown ale that looks more like a stout.

bottle: pours dark brown with small beige head.  great arouma.  Rich caramel malts, molasses, chocolate... not as nutty as I expect from browns (maybe this is even getting close to a stout?) Still, very complex and delicious flavor.  Nice hop presence, but not overpowering.  Great sipper for any season.

12oz bottle into a pint glass

Very good for a straight up "brown ale." Big sweet taste with touches of coffee and cream. Not a huge hop flavor, but its there. The hop bitterness is covered by the malt flavor.
Very very good, super smooth, not very bitter, little heavy, totally delicious.
Chestnut pour with crimson highlights and a 1/4 inch eggshell head.  Coffee, cocoa, toffee, and dark fruit in aroma and flavor.  Medium mouthfeel...not bad...sessionable.

Appearance: deep reddish brown. Murky, but bright in front of the light. Big fluffy head. *Looks* like a Big Beer. The aroma is heavy raisin and dark grape. Some roasted mocha and coffee. Dark and rich. Hint of dark sweetness. Dark cherries and oak. The taste is bitter, bitter dark marlt. A bit sugary but also slightly sour. Grape, dates, raisins. A MAJOR burn on the way down, like rum. Burnt cookies. The feel is creamy and milky. Smooth and buttery; no grit. This beer is seriously bitter and hefty. A slow sipper and a beast, but a delicious beast.

Dark brown pour with ruby highlights.  Nose is of brown sugar, caramel malt, a touch of coffee and some raisin notes.  syrupy mouthfeel, sweet toffee and molasses with a touch of earthy hops and a finish of coffee bean.  very well balance, yummy
Another very good beer from Dogfish Head.  Smooth taste.  Average lasting flavor, but one that Im satisfied with.

Nearly black pour with a frothy tan head. Nose of rich molasses, chocolate, vanilla, and citrus spice. Bitter from roast and hops is this beer. Medium body, creamy texture and a bitter hop finish. All the flavors actually go very well together accenting the natural tastes of each ingredient.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99 Very good!

Bottle from Specs.  Pours a nice tan head, strong aroma of dark dried fruits.  Thick, maybe a little syrup, on the tongue.  You can feel the alcohol, but it does not overpower.  One was enough for me, but I look forward to matching this with food.
Right now my favorite beer. Really opened me up to what brown ales can be.  A must buy and try for any dark beer or brown ale lover. Just quit reading this and go buy some, you wont be disappointed.

On tap @ Mad Mex.  Pours a dark brown color with a nice tan head.  Licorice aroma, some roasted malts, toffee.  Very malty body, lots of caramel and roastiness here.  Slightly bitter, burnt toast finish.  Tasty and quaffable.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a small, foamy, tan head.  The nose is a little boozy with notes of earth, wood, roasted malt, dark brown sugar, and nuts.  Medium carbonation with a rich, slightly chewy mouthfeel.  It has a rich palate with notes of earth, brown sugar, a hint of coffee, burnt notes, and a little vanilla.  There is a little dryness on the back end too.  Medium finish with some lingering wood notes.  Overall a very full bodied brown ale that is highly complex and worth seeking out!

Bottle from JoeTheYounger.. Pours a dark red brown with a creamy light brown head with good retention.. Had a nice lacto sweetness with a little roastiness in the aroma.. Tasted like a coffee beer with some dark roasted malts.. Good stuff!

not what i was expedting from dogfish.  unlike most india browns there is a strong hop presence but not this one.  it was absolutely fantastic in flavor, aftertaste, and everything but lacked the normal dogfish hoppiness.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2009 Bottled. Dark, redish brown brew with huge light caramel head that lasts. sweet aromatics with notes of brown sugar and sweeter coffee. Tastes of nice blends of IPA-like hoppy bite and a typical brown ale caramel maltyness. Chocolate, great stuff!

Dark beer with a thick brown head.  Malty aroma similar to their IPAs.  Taste was full malty.  Probably a high AE.  Good beer.  The thickness was a bit much.  Sorry I didnt like this like everyone else.  Like a lot of homebrews I had that werent end fermented or high on the unfermentables

12oz bottle (Bottled on 1/09/09) and served in an English pint glass.  Medium brown pour with a thin head of tan foam that slowly settled into a lasting cap.  Good lacing.  The aroma consisted of strong coffee, burnt sugar, and some light herbal hops.  The flavor had mildly bitter coffee with cream, caramel, and some fairly aggressive hops (light citrus and herbs).  Medium to full-bodied.  Light carbonation.  Having had this really fresh and then this slightly aged bottle, this has held up pretty nicely.  The hoppy aroma and flavor have mellowed a bit.  An interesting brown ale.

Another personal favorite, the DF IBA is heavy and yet refreaching at the same time.

On tap at Taco Macs, the beer retained the malty head of a stout or basic brown.  A very smooth characteristic to the palate, completely the inverse of subliminal IPAs here.

The flavor is intensely malty and hoppy at the same time.  The palate begins with hops, alcohol, and carmel, but ends with the same heat, alcohol and toastiness.

Overall, a beer well worth shelling out $$$ for.

deep mousey brown, strong white head, barely tan.  The dense malt aroma is fighting to escape the hops, seems balanced in the nose.  If i homebrewed and made a brown, im sure Id throw a shitton of hops in, just to do it.  but sam beat me to the punch.  Caramely brown, medium bodied and not intense, strong leafy hop finish.  Not a typical brown by any means, but unique and assertive.  Coffee roast, leafy hop finish.  Just how I likes it.

Toasted coffee, malts and brown sugar are definitely dominate here, hops are present but dont let the Indian in the name fool you, this is more of a porter-stout than a ipa-apa..not my favorite style but still a very flavorful taste, and a interesting beer..
Brown with a small tan head and some lacing.  Aromas of caramel, bread, peppery hops.  Complex flavor of spicy hops, nuts and caramel, with an interesting aftertaste.
Pours a dark amber-brown with a tan head. Rich and dark, fairly smooth. Notes of coffee and brown sugar or molasses. Overall a good solid brew. Thumbs up.
poured nice and dark with a dough tan head.  smells of maple syrup, hazelnut, malty goodness.  by far the best brown ale I have ever tried

This is one of the beers that introduced me to microbrewed beers. This was the first time I experienced a  beer that rolled along my tongue with multiple flavours of malts and it will always hold a special place in my heart for beers. Very nice.

Poured a huge tan rocky head into a semi dimpled mug. Smell of molasses and malts and brown sugar. Flavour has a nice balance of Sweet and Bitter fresh Happiness- oops I mean Hoppiness. I had already had a few draughts at the Draught House Brewery in Austin so my Palate may have been dulled, but I did not detect a very strong alcohol flavour. The head did dissipate quickly. The bitter flavour though persisted pretty much till the bottom of the glass. I liked the over all effect of this beer. I would try it again. Enjoy!

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2010 Not sure what I was thinking the first time around but this beer really worked for me when I had it again recently! Super malty, chocolaty, roasty with a nice bitterness.  Delicious beer!
Original rating 6/23/2009: Malt and hops! The commercial description is spot on. Its like they took two different beers, a scotch ale and IPA, and mixed them together. Very interesting, but they dont work together real well, rather the flavors are very separate. Strange.

DOGFISH BREWS HAVE BECOME SOME OF MY FAVORITES  ALTHOUGH THIS ONE IS DELICIOUS IT IS NOT AS FLAVORFULL AS SOME OF THEIR OTHERS, ITS LESS HOPPY BUT STILL NUTTY AND SWEET, POURS A NICE DARK BROWN .  IT IS WORTH A TRY!

Chocolate pour, low head, nice lacing. Light caramel aroma. Nicely carbed with a deep chocolate flavor. Light smokiness, tinged with alcohol and a nice aroma of fruity sweetness. A light nut finishes with more alcohol. Very tasty, a little dry.

6 pack. Pours a dark brown with a creamy light brown head that stays a while. The aroma is nutty with hints of molasses, caramel, a little chocolate and coffee. The flavor is semi sweet and a little nutty with notes of chocolate, coffee, molasses, hops, and caramel. This one is mostly on the malty side but there are some hops that come through. Taste like several different styles in one. Interesting.

Pours a nice dark brown color with an off white head.  A coffee toasted nuts aroma.  Taste of nuts and chocolate and raisins (it does kind of taste like raisinettes) with a slightly bitter after taste.  Overall the beer is well balanced between sweet and bitter much like a good dark chocolate bar.

Pours dark brown with a ruby glow and a small tan head. Aroma is malty and rich with notes of coffee beans, chocolate, nuts brown sugar and spices. Flavor starts sweet and sugary with a smoky peat character behind it. Gains a sharp raisin, nuttiness and some bakers chocolate bitterness towards the finish. A nice sharp earthy hop bite lingers through the finish balancing the big bold maltiness. Medium bodied and a sharp carbonation. Big all around, though somewhat confusing as it tries to do so much at once.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 Thick rich head, immediate nut aroma, with hints of sugar and alcohol lifting the nose. Tastes not as nutty as the smell indicates, but still noticeably present. There are also traces of caramel and coffee. There is a great balance of sweetness and hoppy bitterness. It is rich and very smooth making this a pleasure to drink.

Bottle from my friend Chris- A deep murky brown, with a thick and foamy mocha cap. Spotty lace leads to solid retention. Nose of cocoa nibs, chicory,molasses, anise, milk chocolate, dark fruits. The flavour profile is sweet pit fruits with milk chocolate, some coffee, molasses, a bit of hoisin, leafy greens, and fresh bitter hops. Nice finish, but perhaps a bit sweet for me to have any more than one. Thanks Chris!
Bottle. Thanks to Rciesla for sharing. Great beer with a nice flavor but the abv doesnt interfere.

(bottle from Weber Street Liquor in Colorado Springs). Pours a clear, dark brown color. Medium tan head. Strong roasted malt aroma. Roasted malt flavor with light alcohol. Long duration. Slightly astringent finish. Good lacing. Moderate carbonation.

What a great beer poured a nice dark brown/black with ruby color tan head roasted caramel chocolate taste and smokey a great beer full body and slightly bitter at the end very porter like in ways and scotch ale a great beer to have a 3 or 4 of

Cant believe I havent rated this one yet.  Dark chestnut brown pour, moderate frothy khaki head.  Very malt-forward aroma, slight earthy hop cast.  Taste has more hops to it than the aroma lets on, and the back end has all the sweetness.  More so than Id like actually, since the sweetness doesnt let the hops out in the finish.  Ultimately unsatisfying, but ok.

Bottle. Body was the color of coffee beans with ruby highlights, and a moderate bubbly tan head. Aroma was perfumey chocolate, raisin, candy licorice, a hint of peanut and wood, light maple syrup; quite seductive. Flavor was chocolate and espresso, a hint of peanut, light raisin, wood, and a hoppiness that was both bitter and citric enough to compliment the espresso and play off of it for a wonderful finish. Palate is creamy and enveloping, with a warming finish.
Very nice light brown color. Aroma is malty, with a touch or sweetness & roast grains. Flavor is full of malt, hops and brown sugar...it is what it is...
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 12 oz bottle.  Coffee, chocolate, molasses flavors all mixed together in a very nice blend.  You really cant beat it for the price.
sweet warm malt nose. cinnamon, strawberry. garilc? garlic. salt on the tongue. super soft. great mouthfeel.
very interesting brown ale that is sweet with coffee flavors as well as some belgian quad thrown in. alcohol sneaks up on you though. id really like to see this on the west coast!

Plenty of coffee, alongside some chocolate, brown sugar and molasses. Dark Brown with mocha head, dark red when held to light. Emphasis on the coffee and brown sugar in the flavor, with some plum flavors as the flavor dissipates. Palate is creamy, but doesnt sustain for long. A very good brown ale, almost quad like.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 Bottle from Bottleworks.  Pours a dark brown, with ruby undertones with tan bubbly head.  Good lacing.  Has a nice chocolate and caramel aroma with bourbon undertones and deep rich cofee.  Bourbon is presence in the taste as well, which is very sweet with a nice hops balance.  Mild fizz, but has a clean chocolate finish with a dry coffee lingering on the tongue.

355ml bottle from Trader Joes Indinapolis.  Pours dark with a white head.  The aroma is subdude but pleasant, with some roast and some hops, almost like a porter.  The flavour is also like a porter until it reaches the back of the tongue, where it explodes with rich roasted barley and hops.  Lingering finish.  Very nice indeed.  Ill be getting a case of this on my next visit to the US.
chocolate, coffee, spruce, brown, hazy, a minimal head, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, creamy, lively, long finish

12 ounce bottle.  Pours very deep brown with a small tan head.  The aromas include a little bit of dark chocolate and a lot of roasted coffee beans.  The taste is deep, with some great malts which are very sweet and have some hints of gingerbread.  There is also some brown sugar in the flavor, the palate is strong but not too thick, a great brown ale.
Sample at DFH Falls Church.  Pours brown with a 2 finger tan head. Nose is sweet with clear caramel malts.  Taste is sweet malty rich, Good brown!

Bottle.  Poured a dark reddish-brown with a thin off-white head.  Nose is full of roasted malt, coffee, hops, some alcohol.  Flavor is very interesting, too malty for an IPA basically an over-hopped brown ale.  Notes of hard roasted malts, coffee, currant, and hops.  Actually very nice.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 Bière brune foncée ayant des arômes de boisé, de caramel et de café. Bière asser complexe et corsé, avec une finale trop forte de café qui est pour moi, légèrement désagréable.

Pours clear dark brown, with a medium tan head, very good lacing.  Smells of chocolate, chicory, and plum.  Medium body, velvety and smooth.  Tastes of chocolate, chicory, and light molasses, pine and grass in the medium-bitter aftertaste.  Tastes more like a porter than a mild brown ale.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2009 This was an amazing beer and readily available at my local Kroger in a sixer. Loved the syrupy, molasses-like texture with prominent brown sugar sweetness and powerful malt aroma. Well balanced hop addition, full-bodied and well-rounded beer. I even got my girlfriend to enjoy this craft brew. Sessionable at 7.2% and 50 IBU.

This is probably the best brown ale I have had.  It has a wonderful mouhtful of flavor.  The roasted barley and sugars create a very dleicious ale. You did not want the beer to end.  This is good one.  The ale poured a deep reddish brown.  The head was small and disappeared.  I am getting a 6 pack of this.  A fun experience.  This is why you taste different beers.  You have some discoveries that keep you coming back for more.
Dark in color. Tastes of coffee and roasted malt with a hint of bourbon.  recommend !!

Medium brown with a nice looking head.  Very roasted nose and opens like a brown ale, or maybe even a porter, mid palate is definitely weak, and finish has a bitterness that I did not care for all that much.  The first time I had this beer I was not that impressed, but last night it was a better experience..

Pours dark brown with beige head. Hoppy aroma with hints of coffee, roasted malts, alcohol. Roasted malt and coffee/caramel taste with a nice dry hop finish. Very smooth, stays with you. Another solid Dogfish Head beer.  Maybe the only reason to visit Deleware.

Chocolate, strong coffee, burnt caramel, toffee aromas. Reddish-dark-brown, brief minimal tan-white head. Medium sweet, heavy bitterness. Heavy bodied, soft carbonation, finishing long bitter mocha. A decent beer. Probably would enjoy it in cooler weather.

poured dark brown with red highlights and thin head.  Rich toffee and caramel in the aroma.  Alcohol was present up front on the tongue, coffee and mocha malts, hop flavor with bitterness to help balance but not over-the-top bite.  Hops balance more prominent maltiness.  A bigger beer without being too big in any one area.  Real nice.

Aroma:  Big Aroma raisins, dried fruits, coffee

Appearance:  Pours deep brown, tan head.

Flavor:  Full flavored with a strong bias towards the malts.  It has a complex flavor which includes roasted grains, coffee, caramel, molasses and dried fruits. 

Mouth feel: Full body with effervescence in the back of the mouth

Overall Impression:  Great beer with big complex flavors and aroma.  This is fun beer to drink, taste and enjoy as it doesnt match any particular style.  I am in wonder to where the hops were hid.  For a 50 IBU beer I would expect the hops to be more prominent.   Its fun to try and define, yet is doesnt match any style.  It takes the best characteristic from different beers and combines into a great beer.

Didnt know what to make of this one.  Looks like a stout but REALLY wants to be an IPA.  Thats fine with me, Roasted, hoppy, malty, hoppy, dark, hoppy, delicious, and hoppy.  Fantastic, almost a black and tan.  A hoppy one atleast.

Pours dark amber with a thin, tan head.  Faint nose of molasses and alcohol.  Thick smoky mouthfeel.  Tastes of coffee and roasted malt with a hint of bourbon.  Bitter finish, weighs heavy on the palate.

Beer poors dark brown with a very thin tan head.  Aroma is of roasted grains and a hint of hops.  Flavor is roasty which is exagerated due to the bitterness of the beer.  Hops play well with the grains hiding any strong hop flavors.  Beer finishes very clean with a slight astringency typical of the style.  Overall beer is a nice brown.

A very, very dark reddy brown ale with an airy yellowed beige head.

Aroma: Deep fruity malts, rich and boozy. Black cherries and sweet coffee.

Flavour: Thick chocolate with the tiniest hint of metal. There are some hops but they definitely play second fiddle to the sweeter malty flavours. Raisins and slightly grapey notes are apparent. Treacle and chocolate biscuits.

Quite thick with a tiny tingle of carbonation and a light dryness on the top of the mouth.

Nicely drinkable with the rich flavours of a more intense beer.

A thick clinging film sat atop a very deep brown body.  Aroma is mostly syrupy and chocolatey malts with a bit of roastiness.  Flavor is moderately sweet with some coffee near the finish.  Hops become very noticeable in the dry bitter finish.

Enjoyed via 12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown.  Aroma is one dominated by American hops, as advertised on the bottle.  A disappointment comes in the flavor, as it is overly dominated by hops, with not nearly enough malt character.  I am a lover of all of Dogfisheads products, and love their philosophy, but I think they would do well to add some specialty malt, as one simply gets notes of roastiness and ash on the palate.  Stick with the 90 minute.

Bottle: Poured fairly dark brown with a light brown medium head.  Smells of coffee and toffee. Taste was slightly sweet with tiny bit of bitterness, with a slight toast to burnt toast flavor.  I felt the mouth feel was medium to thin.  Overall I really like this, I get tired of over hopped beers and really like the sweetness of malt.  This has what I like!

Poured an opaque deep brown with a big off white head. Chocolate malt was obvious on the nose with hints of coffee. Caramel was also present.

Tasting this blew me away. Its a very rich, malty experience with each sip unveiling new flavors and experiences. Very smooth and creamy with a long coffee/smokey finish. Hints of citrus from the hops as well as chocolate.

A highly recommended beverage.
12oz. bottle Pours dark brown, aroma of coffee, smoky malt. Mouthfeel is lively, engaging, hop bitterness is evident, smooth, bitter aftertaste. A good earthy brown. Lovely

12 oz bottle - how have I not rated this yet? Anyway, dark mahogany pour with a thin brown head. Roasty malt nose, chocolaty and brown sugary. Flavor intensifies the chocolate notes, sweet yet bitter (it amazes me to this day how bitter and sweet can coexist like it does in this one) light molasses and earth. Some coffee late. Leaves a bittersweet chocolate flavor lingering on the tongue. Rich, thick body, smooth as silk. LOVE IT!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2009 Pours very dark brown (almost black) with a beige head. Aroma of light hops present but buried under a sweet chocolaty malt. Similar to a stout in mouthfeel, a thick, dark, malty backbone, but pleasantly hoped. Finish is excellent, dry, slightly bitter, but mostly sweet. DFH never ceases to impress with their knack of making one of a kind ales. Good stuff.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a small beige head. Nutty and malty aroma, with elements of coffee and dirt. Taste was heavily roasted malts, coffee and a certain earthiness.
Pours dark brown..sweet and malty aroma...Caramel and Hoppy all at the same time. Slight taste of coffee on the finish..Another great DOGFISH brew
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2009 bottle.  pours brown with a light tan head.  notes of coffee, raison, brown sugar, chocolate, sweet malts.  not bad
Another great beer from DFH.  Smells of crumb cake, tastes of coffee cake.  Sweet malty in the middle with a beautiful slightly bitter finish.

Poured into a normal pint glass this beer produced a dark brown body with a espresso colored head.  The smell is hops, sugar, and malts.  The bottle that I was trying was from 08/08 and you could tell that the hops had faded.  Regardless, the malt presence was very nice and made this beer very good.  I would recommend anyone try this beer as it is one of my favorite Indian Brown Ales.
Poured watery brown with brown head. Aroma of nuts, chocolate, and fruit. Weird. Cashew and caramel flavors with some coffee. Weird. Finished harsh.

Bottle.  Really liked this one.  Very similar to Terrapins India brown.  Very hoppy but the malts make it really tasty.  Chocolatey and coffee flavors mixed with the carmel malts very well.  Will have this one again.

Nice and dark brown/black with nice tan head. Smells of deep dark malts, nuts, molasses, coffee, chocolate. The taste is that of a mocca espresso. Nice and nutty in the finish. Sensational beer. The finish is long and very coffeesque. Wonderful wonderful stuff. It is complex yet simple.

12 oz bottle. Beer 2 of the rating beers that Ive already had quest. Pours a dark brown color wit ha half finger high off white head that is the epitome of what I consider a brown ale. Smells of coffee, chocolate, some malt, perhaps molasses (though Im not positive what molasses smell like), and hops. Tastes of coffee, sugars, chocolate, and a tiny bit of hops. Very smooth going down, and leaves a fresh coffee build in your mouth. Overall, possibly my favorite brown ale, only competing with Bells Best Brown Ale.

I think this delicious brown ale is a little harsh on the palate, but delicious overall. I only say that because with an ABV of 7.2, that booziness comes through on the brown ale moreso than in comparison to other like Newcastle. Sam would absolutely want it that way, being proud of his beverages being over 7% for the norm.It is also more bubbly.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 Bottle. Poors a deep brown body with a creamy tan head. Strong hops and malts create complex tones: fig, sweet tobacco and licorice. There is a snarl of alcohol with this beer, but it adds sharpness to the palate. Damn good beer.

pours dark brown with a lacy white head that sustains for quite a while. can definitely smell the raisins and brown sugar. taste is of figs, dates, caramel and butter. really nice balance of maltiness and hops. some smokiness in the background along with a very mild orange, grapefruit and ginger. quite tasty, reminding of great quality copper or red ale as well as a brown.

Bottle.  Aroma Is malt with a nutty underpinning to it.  Deep dark brown pour with generous beige head.  very unique flavor, hops, sweet malt, caramel, and plum, very well rounded.  Medium to thick on the palate, bit of alcohol is present but not overpowering.  I really like this.

Location: Had this one on tap a Cap Ale House in Richmond (Downtown location) Nov 08


Overall Impression: 
Another quality outing from Dogfish. These guys really make a great beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark red brown with a medium tan head.  Aromas of nuts, cream, vanilla, coffee, and dark fruits.  Flavor is nutty, creamy, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and a touch of hoppy citrus bitterness.  Some alcohol in the finish.  Not bad at all.

Tap. Pour is deep brown with foamy light brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, burnt sugar, smoke, and hops. Flavor is very roasty and full. Nice chocolate, coffee, and sweetness. I thought this one was a porter for a while.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Had to let it warm up a little to maximize its flavor. . Good taste not long lasting and smooth. Taste is that of hops and malts. Great Brown.

bottled, deep ruby with medium light brown frothy head, very light sweet malt aroma noted with hint of brown sugar, full mouth feel with noticeable coffee notes and lingering hop flavor and bittering, a beer to be drank a little warmer.

Bottle - Dark brown with red tinges and a foamy head. Malty and roasted aroma with some hints of coffee. Roasted taste with coffee, chocolate, hops and a sugary element. The finish is roasted and hoppy.

Pours a nice ruddy brown with a dense head that falls quickly. Smells like burnt sweets - toasted marshmallows, or seafoam. Roasty malts, with a strong hop undertone. This is actually really nice. Very, very dry, but with notes of flavors that are normally sweet - chocolate and molasses at the forefront. Some burnt caramel, and even hinting at some dark fruits. Im wondering if this is the base for the WWS, as I can definitely see a similarity. This is delicious paired with chocolate!

12 oz. bottle - Poured brown with medium creamy beige head. Great lacing on glass.
Aroma - coffee, brown sugar and toasted malt.
Flavor - coffee, hazelnut, brown sugar and mild chocolate taste.
Palate - thin and creamy mouthfeel with average carbonation. Finish is smooth and slightly bitter with little aftertaste. 
Overall - I really liked this beer, thought very easy to drink and alcohol is hardly detectable. Probably one of DFHs better brews.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 I really have no taste for Indian ales...  That being said, Im sure if I tried it again I would feel differently about it. 1.6
RE-RATE 3/20/11 Bottle from World Market.  The beer has a smearing of different colors which is actually pretty cool.  Near the bottom of the glass is a light orange that fades to a pretty red and then towards dark brown near the top.  Quite a lovely sight indeed.  The head is a foamy tan color that sits and doesnt fade.  Great appearance.

Lots of things in the aroma too.  The first thing I notice is a sweet raisin like smell that immediately changes to a roasted coffee ground.  Coffee!  I wasnt expecting that at all.  Roasted malts and cocoa beans too.

The flavor is big roasted malts too that stay with you into the finish.  There is a sweet dark fruit flavor too, like raisins and plums.  It has a burnt bitter finish of roasted malts that dries out the palate.  Some bitter hops can be felt on the finish too.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 Had this one bottled at the Real Time Sports in St. Charles, Illinois.  Dark brown pour with a lacy, white head, a caramel and nutty nose, a complex flavor, bready and a little spicy.  Strong, alcoholic finish.  This one is a keeper but would be tough to session.

Rerate: Actually, accidentally retook notes on this one and came up with the exact same rating.  Clear, dark reddish brown pour, thick, foamy tan head, cherry, woody notes with a potent coffee and cherry flavor, strong.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2015 Rerate:  5 years later.... 
Nice mouthfeel main present is raisin and brown sugar flavors and bitterness.  malty, an average beer but not bad at all. 


Old rating
In terms of other DogFish Head beers... this does not rate very high.  It is very dark, but not very thick.  Flavor has strong coffee flavors.  A tad of hops.... Ill not get again.

Pours dark brown and is everything you should look for a Brown Ale/Pale ale Mix.  Smell of hops and caramel malts.  Good taste not long lasting and smooth.  Taste is that of hops and malts.  Great Brown.

12oz. Pours deep deep brown/black/red. Nice tan head, dont recall the lacing. Malty and earthy, with a lasting taste- but the hops are there too. Surprising treat for someone who thought 60/90/120 was all DFH could do.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2010 Original rate 2009-02-17

Fruity yet bitter.  Beautiful look in the glass, but Im not entirely won over by the flavor profile.  Pretty decent but not something Id drink most of the time.
8/5/4/4/9 - 3.0

Re-rate 2010-08-27

Pours deep chocolate with a moderate tan head.  Aroma of carmelized sugar, chocolate malt, dark fruits, molasses.  Rich, more than medium bodied but not quite full, crisp with a hoppy bite.  Good beer but just not something Id crave often.
8/4/7/4/14 - 3.7

Dark, dark brown pour with a big tan head. imediate malt and a touch of brown sugar in the aroma. The flavor is all about the roasted malts and nuttyness up front. You can taste the alcohol almost imediately before anything then it finishes strong on the palate with notes of coffee. Very good indeed you could almost call it an imperial Brown ale.....although that may not be fitting cause my knowlege of this style is limited. but the more of this style I drink I like it.

pours a short lived 1\4 inch tan head. Is a deep almost black brown. Drak malty hop nose. Deep roasty malty hoppy taste. taste is held in palate for a while and the bitter aftertaste that I expected never came. great beer.
12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown with a about two fingers of tan head.  Aroma is mostly malts with a slight hint of some earthy hops.  Taste is matly with a coffee and molasses finish. Decent beer.

I am never very impressed by any beers named for a color.  Reds, ambers, browns, blacks, they just dont do much for me.  Probably because of the lack of hops.  I do like Belgian whites though.  This brown was better than almost any I have ever had.  The aroma was sweet and full of caramel malt.  The flavor too was sweet and full of caramel with hints of brown sugar and maybe maple syrup.  Not overly sickly sweet and actually this one finished a tad bit dry with the presence of some finishing hops.  A decent beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark chocolate brown with a two finger khaki colored head that is thick and fluffy. Lots of malty goodness on the nose that belies how hoppy this ale is. Creamy and thick on the palate, you immediately get the malts and then bam here come those hops. And unlike an IPAs  its not overpowering.  BBC should just go ahead and stop making Brown Ale. They got a long way to go to topping this one.

A- Pours a dark brown hue with rusty red highlights, slim amount of tan creamy foam, moderate lacing
S- Bitter coffee and roasted malts, caramelized sugars, underlying grassy hops, earth and tea leaves
T- Mild coffee and roasted malts give way to bitter hops and essence of tea, slight caramel and syrupy molasses, bitter coffee returns in the finish
M- Full-bodied, creamy texture, medium carbonation
D- Very unique and complex brown ale with a nice balance of roasted malts, caramel sugars, and bitter hops, all the flavors come through here, what a treat!
Tasty aromatic dark malt and light sugar followed by a resonating hint of light hops.  An intriguing blend of flavors that I kept trying to decipher until the beer miraculously disappeared!
Dark brown pour with a tan creamy head and good lacing.  Aroma of coffee and some chocolate, and yeast.  Taste of coffee and caramel, with a creamy texture.  Coffee aftertaste.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2009 Pours a nice rich red/brown, medium head.  A strong taste of alcohol.  I like the dry-hopped flavor and bite of an IPA

Wow, this adds an amazing depth to the Dogfish Head IPAs that I did not even realize they were lacking. The smell itself is fantastic- not overpowering but leaving a marvelous honey-baked-ham smell that is glorious. You have your usual glow of bitter hops but now with a cinnamon, brown sugar, and raisin repertoire. $11.99 / 6 pack at Gulf Liquors, Miami Beach
Dark brown with a decent head.  Nice caramel and malt aroma with a balanced flavor of hops and malts.  Good take to blend two styles.  Slight brown sugar taste as well.
A great beer, dark color. nice head, strong hop flavor, coffee, chocolate, and brown sugar. Again a great beer, i have one in my hand right now, would definitely drink again

Dogfish Head was one of my first loves and that love has never faded. This is another great beer from them. Complex brown ale - malty with hop bitterness, coffee, chocolate, molasses, and a slight smokiness. Nice coffee/roasted malt aroma.  Noticeable alcohol in a good way. I dont know whats so Indian about it - my guess is that theyre just trying to be racist.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 Re-rate 2/29/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks zvikar. Brown-colored. Aroma of slightly roasted malt, nuts and light hoppy notes. Sweetish malty flavor with caramel, nutty notes, light roastiness and a bitter finish with a bit of hops. Medium-bodied. 6/3/6/3/12=3

(11/13/08) Draught at Capones Restaurant in Norristown. Very dark brown color with a pretty, rocky, beige head. Aroma of some floral hops, roasted malt and some caramel. Bitter hoppy flavor with grapefruit hints, some sweet roasted malt , coffee and notes of alcohol. Medium-bodied. The strong hops and malt flavors are clashing and creating a train wreck.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 12oz bottle poured into an English pint glass.  DHIBA pours brown (duh!) with a medium-sized off-white head that leaves nice lacing.  The aroma is wonderfully full of light coffee, raisin, and roasted woods.  The body is very thick and chewy with a nice hops zing to liven things up.  There are lots of dark roasted flavors in here to explore to include coffee beans, hard wood and molasses.  There may even be a hint of ginger in there hiding with the hops.  Yum yum!

Id like to add a side note, some week later than the original rating.  I drank an Avery Thirteen and then had a DHIBA.  This beer is SO MUCH BETTER than the Avery.

pours a very deep brown with a thick and creamy tan head and nice lacing.  aroma is excellent and has notes of rasins and millk chocolate.  sweet coffee flavor with some roastiness and finishes nicely with well balanced hops and a lingering espresso taste.  only drawback is a mild alcohol flavor at the end.  though i expected a decent beer, this was better than i thought it would be.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2009 Can Dogfish Head do no wrong?  Im starting to think they cant.  Has a beautiful deep, hazy dark brown color.  Aroma is of malts, hops, nuts, coffee, and a little bit of a burnt scent.  This tastes so smooth, probably one of the smoothest brown ales Ive had.  Has a pleasant full bodied aftertaste that is nothing short of near perfection.  Another quality brew from Dogfish Head.  Cheers.

Bottle into Sam Adams Lager glass. Pours a very dark clear brown with hints of red escaping, and a one-finger, pillowy khaki head that doesnt want to go away. Solid wall of heavy lacing. Nose is a nice combination of roasty coffee, bit of caramel sweetness, molasses. Taste starts off with a dry, roasty bready note, hints of molasses and even cola sweetness, with dark fruit and molasses coming out more around mid-palate, hints of cocoa. Roasty coffee note starts to take over right before the finish, with just a hint of floral hops, and the finish is very dry and lingers fairly lightly on the palate. Mouthfeel is fairly creamy, medium bodied. Seems more like a combination of a dry porter and a brown than anything. Good beer, but not my favorite take on the style.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color, with a big rocky cotton candy-like tan head and prominent lacing. Aroma of raisins, coffee, ground roast, caramel. Big roasted flavors, with coffee being prominent and caramel finishing softly through the harshness of the roast. Smooth smokiness is present throughout. Drinkable, very good.

12oz bottle.   Dark brown with a small head.   Sweet malty aroma with caramel and some vinous, alcoholic fruit along with a light roasted malt character.   Roasty coffee is prominent in the flavor along with dried alcoholic fruit.   Finishes hoppy, but pretty sweet as well.   Tastes more alcoholic than it is.   It IS hoppy, but not really the dark IPA than people claim.   This just finished a bit too sweet and alcoholic; I definitely wouldnt drink more than one, which is what I want out of an IPA or brown ale

12 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours an orange brown color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Big aroma of chocolate slightly roasted malts and caramel. Taste is primarily hoppy with a finish of roasted malts and apple-like fruit notes. Full bodied with some slight alcohol warmth.
A very solid brown. Nearly perfect although the alcohol taste seemed a bit too harsh. Very much tasted of coffee, and had a nice thick brown head.

Sampled at the Second Cellar Reduction.  Sampled after the saranac version.  This one is much darker in brown with thin ring of offwhite head.  Sweet raisin and hop aroma with notes of alcohol.  Roast malt, coffee, chocolate, hop bitterness and some molasses on the finish.  Nice balance between malt and hops, but tends toward the malty.  Mildy creamy body.  Coffee to finish it off.
Bottle at Second Cellar Reduction.  Khaki head and deep amber body.  Smells roasty hops.  Nice slick and thick roasty toffee with a bitter finish.

malty with a hint of light peanuts and coffee like an iced mocha. 

poured with a thin head, deep brown color

watered porter with a nutty malt flavor

medium balanced palate. 

Slightly disappointing because of my high expectations for dogfish head and brown ales, but this just didn’t seem like a brown ale.

Poured a dark brown with a very thick head. Smells of hops, coffee, and caramel. Taste is slightly sweet and bitter with loads of coffee and caramel. Hops are also present in the finish. A very good brown ale.

This beer tastes like beer. The color seemed like a super dark brown with a thin head but holding it up to the light made it look cranberry red. smelled of light sweetness. tasted very roasted barley with a bitter finish and another taste that was like the charred bits of some sweet pork ribs. sweet but burnt.

Pours a dark, almost black, brown with a slight head. The aroma is full of blueberries... really reminds me of the blueberry beer that dogfish head puts out. Ther is also the usual dogfish yeastiness. The flavor is very similar to the palo santo, but with the dark fruit and nut character from the aroma. The finish is a little spicy in the dogfish style. A really superb beer.

2007 Bottle - Pours a deep brown with a small and quickly dissipating tan head...aroma is all molassas malt, a bit of fruit and a little char...flavour is sweet caramel on the front and fades to a bitter finish, middle is dried fruit, tobacco...I really get the scotch style coming through more than any other...kick ass

Bottle.  Poured a nut brown color, not black but dark brown.  One finger of head which dissipated in a minute or so.  Not much aroma but slightly hoppy.  Taste was very smooth, slightly bitter with sweet molasses.  There was a hint of alcohol but nothing major.  Very satisfying beer.  I would definitely drink again.

12 oz bottle, pours a dark copper color with little head. Aroma is full and roasty with hints of fruit/sweetness- very complex and satisfying. Taste was rather bitter and mildly sweet. Palate was a little on the rough side but is to be expected with the bitterness. Great beer.
Dark, reddish brown pour with an off-white head. Malty, caramely aroma with raisins, some coffee, smoke. Flavor is smokey and bitter. Mouthfeel is thick. Pretty cool beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours deep dark brown with nice thick toffee head. Leaves some heavy lacing.  Smells of strong malted barley with caramel touch. Nice amount of hops to match the maltiness.
 The flavor is strong but in a very good way.  Has a medium body and perfect carbonation.

Tap @ silvercould. this was quite a tasty brown ale...nice dark reddish brown appearance with medium head...aroma of roasted notes, caramels, and nuts....flavor is quite the same with an added cream element to it.... Nice balanced overall.

Great looking dark pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma of coffee, brown sugar, hops.  Flavor of strong black coffee balanced by malt, caramel, chocolate, and raisins.  The hops are there and at times strong.  I love Dogfish and almost everything they make.

Draught: A beautiful brown color and with tan head. An amazing smell of malts and unique hops. Tastes of coffee and brown sugar, but well adjusted and smooth going down. I recommend this beer throughout the Autumn season.
Solid brew. Like a cross between a stout and a hoppy IPA. Poured a thick brown with wispy head. Solid malty goodness and medium to heavy hops finish. quite heavy

Bottle.  Pours a brown ruby color with a hefty white tan head.  Wonderfully deep malt, toast, and hop aroma.  Deep malt flavor fills out a medium body and leads into a slowly developing bitter finish.  Not necessarily the traditional brown ale, but egads is this thing a nice change.  The extra hops definitely add a nice element to the beer.
From bottle.  Part of  Dayton Beer Tasting event.  Pours deep red/brown with light tan head.  Aroma of hops, coffee and nuts.  Taste follows the nose with some spice and earthy textures.

pours a very deep dark mahogony with notes of ruby. A nice crowning 1/4" of egg-shell colored head. Nice aroma of hops and some sort of underlining chocolate or even coffee bean. The first sip confirms the coffee and nice creamy rich fruity chocolatey malt. It’s a sweet combo that really works well with the hops. This is the only brown with any real hop flavor that I have had to date. This beer has a thickness not normally associated with a bruwn that isn’t a nut-brown. That thickness however does not stop this from being a very easy drinking brown.
Pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of nutty/earthy malts, abundant hops, and slight coffee hints. Taste was similar: very robust, earthy, and nutty.

I would never go so far as to say that Dogfish Head is the most extreme and creative craft brewery currently in the market. I see other craft breweries put out crazy, wild, extreme, and very deliciously exciting beers. But, I would say that the difference is that off-centered ales for off-centered people is the very credo and motto upon which Dogfish Head was created and by which it still lives today. They dont release the occasional extreme brew once or twice a year; instead, every beer they release is their extreme and intensely flavored versions of that traditional style. More often than not, they do so with great success and have brought many an eye-opening experience to my lips to further spoil my tastebuds and my palate. One of their year-round offers is the Indian Brown Ale, a dark, thick, and chewy brown ale.

My Indian Brown Ale poured with a miniscule head but a hugely dense, thick, and brownish-black into my glass, daring any light to try and peek through. Immediately a rich, sweet and malty nose wafts my way with huge notes of chocolate, molasses, and caramelized sugars. A faint earthen finish hints of wood barrels and smoke. Though she had little head to speak of, she does swirl and poof upon command, leaving traces of lace to mark her territory. My first quaff is thick and lusciously sweet with a mouth-sticking viscosity which proudly represents the thick pour and nose I had just previously basked in. Sweet and smooth milk chocolate greets me first, followed by a procession of fresh nuts, molasses, brown sugars, and some warm smoked wood notes. As she warms, she bitters up a bit with more prominent hints of darker chocolates and coffee. I definitely recommend enjoying the Indian Brown Ale after she has had a few minutes to settle into room temperature versus refrigerator temperature. For such a heavy brown ale, she maintains a very balanced palate which finishes pleasantly dry with faint chocolate esters.

An excellent heavy brown ale with a solid personality, she backs down for no one person or critic. She is meant to be sipped and savored, though that minor fact wouldnt keep me from enjoying a couple at a time. Even though the Indian Brown Ale came long before the Palo Santo Marron, I can see the faint beginnings of the inspiration which led brewmaster and founder Sam Calagione to the Palo Santo. I hear some very rare wood was also involved, but that is a store for another time. Once more, I tip my hat to Dogfish Head in respectful satisfaction.

Pours a very deep dark dark brown with a nice tan head. There is a bit of lacing throughout.

Smell is of burnt malts mostly with a bit of hops.

Taste is initially burnt malt followed by hop bitterness. After the bitterness fades away the caramelized sugar speaks through and further develops in the finish.

The mouthfeel is full, more so than I expected an a bit much for a brown. Not necessarily a bad thing though.

This is a mighty brown ale. If I could name it I would call it an Imperial Brown Ale. The stronger alcohol and hop presence makes this a truly unique brew. Not typical of the style, but very flavorful and rather complex. Definitely recommended.

Reviewed on: 04-13-2007

330 mL bottle. The best brown ale I have ever tried. Pours a deep, dark reddish brown with a nice tan head that leaves some fantastic lacing. Incredible nose of milk chocolate, vanilla extract, mocha, maple syrup, toffee. Tastes like a dark IPA with a little Wee Heavy thrown in. Awesome! Lots of roasted malt, great balancing and bittering hops, brown sugar, milk chocolate. Aftertaste is long and beautiful. Overall a pleasant surprise.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of caramel malts with some roasted notes.  Flavor is mostly roasted malts, as strong as a porter.  A nice medium to full bodied brown ale.

Bottle at the Bistro. Brown coat with tan cap. Bright toffeeish nose & the flavors follow - Toffeeish, hints of coffee bite, goodly notes of sweetness like dememerra with an almost rootsy-herbal quality. Hops are more downstaged but have herbal woody character. Slightly reminiscent of Raison or Chicory DFH beers.

bottle thanks to swalden 28.  poured a dark brown with ruby hues and beige head and some lacing as well.  aroma of dark roasts, chocolate, coffee, toffee, a little vanilla, and some mild dark fruits.  a nice blened nose on this.  flavor was great as well with dark roasts, coffee, toffee, alcohol spice.  this was balance really nice.  medium body with high carbonation.  perhaps my favorite brown ale yet.
Very tasty brew with a lovely mix of chocolate flavors and pungent alcohol. Roasty, malty and sugary.
Very good brew form DFH.  Pours dark brown with nice tan head.  Chocolate malt and roasts dominate the aroma.  Has a chocolate molasses taste with a roasted nutty finish.  Would drink again.

Pours deep deep brown with a tall tan head that lasts forever and leaves great lacing. Aroma is full of chocolate, roast, toast, molasses, caramel/burned sugar, and fantastic spicy, planty hops. Flavor is roast, smores-lots of chocolate, toast, chocolate, sweet malts, and marshmallows-toast, lots of graham and a little coffee. Finish is sweet with lots of coffee/roast malts, chocolate,and a little bitterness. The thing I like about this beer is that the hop character may play a back seat to the huge maltiness but the malts are full and beyond rich while letting the hops establish a slight bitter balance-the balance is fantastic. Finish is all roast, toast, and chocolate; with the slightly bitter hop character playing second fiddle. I would recomend this beer to anyone wishing to find a highly desirable beer for the masses. Palate is medium to thick and perfectly carbonated to set the scene for the huge character for the beer.
Pours brown with a medium sized tan head.  Aroma is chocolaty malt.  Taste is roasty and chocolaty as well with a bitter finish.  Pretty good.

This brown ale poured a deep black colour with a nice big foamy tan head. To the nose there are scents of coffee, caramel, cocoa and molassass. First taste was smooth and very full bodied with flavours of coffee, hopps and cocoa. The finish is slightly bitter with flavours of coffee shining through. The palate is nothing but roast! Delicious!
Bottle from Lithy, thanks! Deep dark brown color. Maple, malt and cinnamon in the aroma. malty sweet, thin and slightly alcoholic flavor with cardemom and cinnamon. Spicy finish with a hint of apple.

12oz bottle.  deep red-brown pour with a medium tan head.  aroma of roasted caramel malt and brown sugar.  sweet brown taste.  light bitter coffee hints.  creamy medium texture.  browns aren’t my thing, but this is a good one.  K-8
This ber has a nice overall appearence and flavor.  Its flavor is of strong coffee and  undertones of nuts and caramel
My favorite brown ale: readily available, full-bodied, superb chocolate and coffee malt balance (with a hint of smoke), and a light hoppy brilliance in the finish. An Imperial Stout’s little brother.

Thanks to Dandman629 for hooking me up with this.  Pours really black with a reddish tinge.  Definite roasted malt aroma almost like coffee and cream.  roasted malt flavor with a pleasing sweet bitterness that lingers like dark chocolate.  Overall, I am hooked.
Very dark brown with a chamois head, this ale’s hoppiness is too far in the background, the malt  too pronounced for my liking, and the overall flavor just to sweet..
12 oz. bottle.  Dark, ruby color.  Light tan head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Toasted malt flavor.  Nice hoppy finish.

Pours a dark brown that almost appears black in low lighting, however, has reddish tint when illuminated. Has a thick, frothy, sustainable head. Aromas of toasted malt, molasses, and brown sugar that really penetrated through my nostrils. Had great flavors of toasted wood chips, coffe malt, raisins, and a great blend of brown-sugar sweetness with a great hoppy finish. Has a dry finish and is medium bodied. I am a real fan of this beer even though brown ale is usually not my favorite style.

Great brown ale. I expected it to be a little creamier, but it is very full bodied and full flavored. Molasses and brown sugar flavor, but well balanced so that it isn’t too sweet. Light hoppiness in the background. Very drinkable. Low carbonation. No taste of alcohol. Some chocolate in the finish.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark mahogany color with a big hearty tan head that has amazing retention and wonderful lacing.  This is one of the most perfect looking beers I have ever seen.  The nose is VERY complex.  I get aromas of chocolate malt, coffee, a slight hint of wood and you can even pull the brown sugar in the description out.  Smell wonderful.  WOW...this doesn’t taste like anything I have ever drank before.  It is very malty and then the hop bitterness kicks in, then it finished like a porter and leaves a nice roasted coffee and chocolate flavor lingering in the back of your throat.  This beer is wonderful!  Another winner from an amazing brewery!!!

This is a damn good beer. The scent is a familiar scent of a stout I used to get at a local brewery (since the recipe has changed it has never quite been the same). You can smell the bitterness of the hops and barley with a hint of coffee. The color is a dark brown a few shades below a stout. The palate is amazingly smooth and creamy. Finally the taste is exactly what it says on the bottle. This is an all around great beer!

This ale pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head. The nose is of roasted malt, dark chocolate,and caramel. Taste is pretty layered. Unsweetened chocolate,raisins,roasted coffee,and good hop backbone. Full bodied and not a wimpy brown. Paired it with a Tastykake & it was Great!

pours a reddish brown with decent head and evident carbonation. Aroma light, mostly of hops and malt. Flavor is very nice, with a touch of honey and roast to compliment the malt. Nice palate, great for the style.
Very nice light brown color.  Aroma is malty, with a touch or sweetness & roast grains.  Flavor is full of malt, hops and brown sugar.  Very good

[Bottle] Pours a clear brown with a small beige head. Aroma is nice and hoppy, a touch of roasted malts and coffee. Flavor is more on the malty end, with a semi bitter chocolatey finish and a little hop.
Very balanced.  I had this at the brewery in Milton.  Beautiful dark brown color, with a dark tan head.  I loved every sip.
Botlle. Mostly malty. Brown sugar is a great twist. Nice balance of hops. Not bad at all.

A really solid entry in the brown ale category by Dogfish head.  I got to sample this on tap at the brewery and it was really nice.  Malty with lots of brown sugar notes and caramel.  Very nice brown ale, but at 7.2% is just a touch high for a great session beer.

Pours a deep brown, with a short lived off white head.  Massive malt presence with a more faint but detectable hop presence.  This is an extremely complex, pungent beer that no one other than an extreme beer geek will tolerate well.  Could not detect even a hint of carbonation in my bottle.  A difficult beer to say the least.  I am not nearly as high on Dogfish Head as many here are although I did have a nice consistent 4 pack of 90 Minute this weekend which was superlative.
Bottle. Pours a strong dark brown. Sweet aromas. Brown sugar and malt flavors, some hints of coffee. One of my favorite brown ales!
pours dark brown with reddish higlights and off white head aromas of hops,and roasted barley taste was of roasted barley,nuts and chocolate.  medium body, light sweetness,
on tap at 1702.  deep brown with think off white head.  aroma of biscuit and roasted malt.  flavor is clean and some chocolate noted present.  nice finish of slight alcohol and sweet chocolate.
Draft.  Pours dark brown with tan head that lasts.  Caramel and hops on the nose, flavor is a nice mix of brown ale and sharp citrus.  Great beer!

Holy aroma.  Smell drips from the tip past my lips till I need to get a grip.  Dark chocolate, molasses and cream come barreling out of the bottle straight away.  Pours a nice even brown with frothy awesome tasting head.  Taste is more of the smell but not to the same degree and with a slight alcohol dryness to the end.
