The sweetness might turn some off but 2 bottles of this is easily doable.  Mouthfeel is the only thing that brings this beer back to earth.  Could have been creamier but I wouldn’t want them to compromise anything about this beer to change it’s overall appeal. Very good to great beer.  2008 12oz. bottle.

12 oz bottle from Binnys.
Pours a deep, dark, mohogany/brown with a finger-width, fizzy, chocolate tan head that dissipates slowly, but doesnt linger too long. Leaves a nice and decent lacing on the glass. Smell is extremely potent. Not too complex, but a ton of aroma! Lots of sweet caramel malts, loads of brown sugar, nutty, molasses. Also, some roasted malts and bitter hops. One of the hoppier brown ales out there. I absolutely love this smell. A real mellow and soft body. Kind of watery, but really smooth. This brown ale brings a lot of taste to the table. Loaded with nutty and caramel malts. Really rich. Good amount of citrus hops add to the character really well. Some hints of roast, brown sugar, chocolate, molasses. Finishes with a dry bitterness that lingers for a very long time. Lots of taste still there even a couple minutes later. Overall, I have never been a real brown ale fan, but dogfish head continues to put out amazing beers and changes my mind about everything. This brown ale has opened me up to trying more and giving the genre a second chance. I am thoroughly impressed with this highly balanced and tasteful brew.
Pours a dark brown color with an off white head. Aroma is of nuts, caramel and hops. Flavor has that nice sweet muttiness that brown ales have, but is mellowed out by a nice addition of citrusy hops.

Bottle.  Fantastic beer and the sample I drank had been aged two years.  Well worth the wait!  Frothy head with an off-white color, diminishing nicely.  Aroma included molasses and some toasted, also had a cask and brown sugar smell.  Nice body and carbonation was soft.  Highly recommended and will drink again on multiple occasions.
Very dark brown pour.  Brown sugar on the nose  Rich, nutty, hoppy and full of sweet malts.

What can u say about DFH?  They make extraordinarily well thought out beers.  I have yet to come across a bad beer from them.  This is a unique complex mixture of everything that they say, molasses, burnt sugar, toffee, hops and more.  A beautiful color of dark brown with reddish highlights on the fringes, excellent lacing and head, what else can you say? They are at the top of their game for sure.... it went well with the franks and beans that I had too.

So, I had heard about this on a youtube video of a tasting, and I figured it sounded good. Well I was right, this stuff is amazing. It pours a very dark brown, with an almost light brown/offwhite head. The aroma is strong, with some licorice and sugar on the finish. And OH the taste. Its of raisins and burnt sugar, with a hint of alcohol, and some great maltiness on the finish. This is exactly what I expected when Dogfish Head decides to perfectly blend two different styles into one great brew. Cheers!

Very dark for a brown, it’s bordering a porter. Smell is caramel dominated with some chocolatey coffee goodness tossed in for good measure. Bigger and thicker than most browns. Incredibly tasty. Give this one a try!

As with some other DFH offerings, this beer took a few attempts for me to fully appreciate the contents. I was slightly put off by my first bottle, but after enjoying the remaining bottles over a week plus It did eventually grow on me. And abrupt, in your face aroma of burnt toast, coffee, cream, and roasted nuts hits you immediately. There is also a strong noble hop presence. Rich brown color with a deep red tint. A billowing tan head that ultimately settles leaving a stream of heavy lacing. Heavy on the palate, very bitter with a rolling creaminess. Assertive flavor that slaps your face before it settles down. Burnt malts that are both nutty and sweet. Bitter coffee and floral noble hops. Dark chocolate with brown sugar. Gritty and abrasive, this beer needs time to be enjoyed. Not an everyday choice for me, but once a year should do the trick.

Dark reddish brown with a finger of light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Nice heavy aroma, almost mocha like sweetness, hints of chocolate and sweet brown malt, even a little boozy.  Flavors are heavy and dark roasted malts, a little woody character, chocolate smooth bitter finish.  Everything sticks to the palate nicely but not too sweet.

Hell, I guess you can always count on Dogfish Head to create the extreme version of any brew.  This brown has body, color, a nice bouquet, and the flavor packs a punch.  I’ll always have a soft spot for Newcastle, but this is tops among browns.

12oz bottle shared by my pal John. Thanks! This style is really starting to grow on me, I must say. A well hopped brown ale, with a handsome body, decent frothy head. The malts arent actually especially sweet to me  but theyre also not just there for body and texture. Nice mild roasted notes compliment the hops, and the overall mouthfeel is somewhat creamy, creating a nice balance.

In bottle. Dark brown clear beer with bubbles and a dark beige head. Aroma is sweet and smells like melted dark chocolate. Flavor is immediate and unfolds, including roasted, spicy, chocolate, hoppy, hazelnut and caramel. Very smooth and delicious!

In bottle from Trader Joe’s Foggy Bottom. Dark brown cola appearance, with tan head that dissipates. Palate is very smooth. Smells like a chocolate malted, tastes rich, roasted, and hoppy. Additional flavors include chocolate, nutty, and perhaps maple syrup. A complex beer. Not your usual brown.

Am I a little high in my rating, yes, but who knew a brown could be so good!?  Wonderful nose of chocolate with roasted notes.  Nice lasting head on top of standard brown.  Mmmm big toffee, caramel, coffee, and molasses flavors mingle with other subtle malt flavors.  Hoppyness isn’t really that evident, but is obviously there, as the clean finish and perfect balance prove.  Unexpected full mouthfeel rivaling a good IPA or Belgian.  Overall wonderfully drinkable and delicious... Go Brown!

12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass. Dark brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma loaded with molasses, but also coffee and chocolate. Taste is full of molasses and just plain brown-ness (chocolate malts maybe). Somewhat creamy mouthfeel which makes it easy to quaff. Finishes quickly with little aftertaste. I’ve had quite a few of these in the past, and plan to do the same in the future. Good session beer.
Very dark brown pour, 1/4 inch quick fading head. Nutty aroma, Nutty taste, too much malt. The alcohol really stands out the most as far as taste goes. Okay

6 pack of 12 ozers from Frugal MacDoogal’s in Nashville.  Poured an ultra deep brown with a creamy and puffy tan head.  Aroma is of coffee and molasses.  Flavor reflects the aroma, with a little hop balance.  Well carbonated and creamy to the palate.  Another brilliant DFH beer.  This is by far my favorite brewery.
Poured a deep brown with a fluffy beige head. HUGE nose of coffee and molasses is echoed in the mouth along with a slight hoppy zing.Sweet finish.

Wonderfully well balanced.  Aroma is smoky and sweet.  Mouthfeel isn’t quite syrupy, but it’s definitely full bodied.  Flavours of maple syrup, rich malt, coffee, smoke, taffy, and alcohol.  A very drinkable brown ale, much more facinating than what is on the market today.

Sampled on tap at DFH Brewpub.

From a bottle purchased from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a dark deep brown and mildly chestnut hue with a thin yet creamy tan head. Rich roasty, nutty, mealy, and grainy nose.  Apparent  hop spiciness, but predominantly malty and with a dryish grain finish. A meal in a bottle.

Aroma is a sweet roasted caramel scent.  Color is a deep dark amber with good carbonation and a nice thick tan head.  Taste is malty and bitter.  Starting with a medium body it goes down smooth.  Finish comes in with a sweet caramel flavor, some roasted and spicy malt tones and a mild bitterness.  After taste is sweet then a bitter nip.  This is a very good brown and my favorite so far from this brewery.

Bottle.  Deep brown with a thick beige head.  Aroma isn’t very present, but still makes an appearance with some malt and coffee.  Flavor is malty and bitter, with a few hints of sweet chocolate.  Much more bitter than you would expect from an brown ale, which offers a nice twist.  Pretty good brew, great for a brown ale.

Another super  offering from Dogfish. Unlike a few of their other fine brews, this one comes in a six pack, instead of a four. Nice pleasent aroma, good appearing color, nice pleasent taste, good on the palate. I have to rate this one just a little below Dogfishs 120 and stout.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 My favorite Dogfish Head beer thus far.  
Flavor is sweet coffee, roasted malts, caramel, and perhaps a touch of peat.  Nice hoppiness to go with it.  Attractive dark brown color.  Very drinkable.

(bottle): Pours a lightish brown color body, very clear. Foamy off-white head, creamy & lasting. Grapefruity, nutty aroma. Grapefruity, dusty, somewhat nutty aroma. Nutty taste, some hops. Somewhat bitter aftertaste. Okay.

Thin head, nice dark color, some lacing, complex aroma, good mouthfeel, complex varied flavors, good hop finish, although I wonder if it wasn’t a little too much for the style. However this is an excellent brew.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown, with thin head.  Aroma is of sweet dark malts, reminiscent of a porter.  Flavor starts out with strong, citrusy west-coast hops, soon followed by coffee malts (the provided description of being a cross between a Scotch Ale, IPA, and APA is quite accurate).  Not my cup of tea (beer?) at all; while the component flavors are all nice, they do not blend together well, and the overall effect is somewhat revulsive.

8/04/2008:  Indian Brown Ale has clear brown color with smooth carbonation and a creamy whipped tan-colored head (good lacing).  Wow, the aroma is very inviting and includes lots of richly caramelized malt, dreamy dark chocolate, molasses fruitiness, and a tinge of tobacco/cigar.  The flavor is somewhat dry with some lightly citrusy bitterness in the finish.  Roasted malts, plain coffee, cocoa power, some sort of fruitiness (more molasses like, I guess), distant nutty quality, hints of ash (toward the backside when colder) comprise the overall flavor characteristics.  Some alcohol shows around the edges toward the finish, but it works really well with the overall flavor.  The body of htis beer medium to medium-full beer and it is really smooth on palate.  Overall this is a pretty complex, unique, and very pleasing brown ale.
12 fl. oz. bottle (7.2% Alc. by Vol.) from tish.  Thanks for all the beer!  I appreciate it.  Rating #1194 for this beer...

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2008 (Bottle).  Caramel and coffee aroma.  Very dark brown color with tan head.  Flavor is caramelly malt and toffee, hints of chocolate and coffee.  Well balanced, with a nice clean finish.   Delicious, but (as others have noted) it’s not a typical brown ale...instead, a rather strange hybrid.

Beer poured a nice brown amber with a thin off white head. The nose was a mix of toasted malts and brown sugar. The flavor was full of toasted malts and sweetness with a slightly heady taste of alcohol. A very good brown ale.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 Not my favorite kind of beer.  Looks very appealing.  Nice, dark brown color with foamy off white head.  Aroma is strong coffee.  Very malty taste with overpowering coffee and chocolate flavor.  Kind of bubbly on the palatte, but finishes smooth.
Tasty, dark brown.   Sweet carmelized sugar makes this the liqud sugar cookie for beer drinkers.  Dogfish balances another beer to victory!

355ml bottle from a trade with a non-RBer.  I mean in what way is this a brown ale?  Yes, it’s a nice beer, but really an Indian Brown Ale, what is that?  It’s a malty choccy beer, a strong (stout) porter perhaps, but a brown ale?  Growing up in the pubs of 1950s East Cheam, brown ale never tasted like this, or am I confusing myself with Tony Hancock again?  Innit marvellous! Or perhaps there’s a joke here that I’m not getting?  It’s got some American hop on aroma and then a rich lush dry malt mouthfeel and flavour and yet remains with some juiciness.  Crunchy milk choc malt.  As much as I like the US beer scene, sometimes I’m left in complete disbelief.  Anyway, forgetting the IBA problem, is the beer any good?  Reminds me a bit of Wychwood Hobgoblin with a bit more hop and alcohol, an Imperial Hobgoblin perhaps.  Bit too syrupy on the malts maybe.
Bottle.  Clear brown pour with little head.  Aroma of roasted malt and nut.  Similar flavor with lots of hops.
UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Feel like a good stout with some extras? Check it out its fantastic. The right amount of sweet and deep flavor dont skip it.

"A cross between a Scotch Ale, an IPA, and an American Pale"??? Hmmm.... more like a stout and an IPA. Pours and keeps a nice beige head. Good roasty barley taste throughout, with strong hints of chocolate and lighter hints of coffee. A nice dark brown... good balance of hops and malt. Pretty thick palate. Slight alcohol burn. Not too far from a stout.

Had this beer on Tap at Sharp Edge.  Dark amber, with nice tan head, and lacing.  carbonation just right for me..  nutty sweet start, warming with some chocolate hints and astringent rubbery bitterness on finish.

Dark brown body with a small head.  Malty aroma w/ hints of chocolate, and coffee.  Nose is similar to the aroma, very sugary/malty with chocolate overtones.  Nice hop kick at the end.  This is a great beer that is full of flavor and well balanced.  One of my favorites.

Pours a very dark reddish brown color with a thick 3 finger foamy medium beige head.  A little bit of lacing as it goes down.  Aroma of sweet caramel, floral and pine hops, and a touch of molasses.  The flavor is a roasty molasses flavor.  Sweet creamy coffee notes with chocolate and a nice flowery bitterness in the end.  A rich oily body that leaves a nice roasted bitterness on the tongue.  The perfect balance between roasted flavors and hops.
Pours Dark Brown with a huge frothy head with peaks and valleys.  smells sweet with a strong malt taste.  The large hop additions are needed for this beer.
At the brewpub in Rehobeth.  Dark and dense with a small head.  Good balance between hops and the sweetness of the brown sugar.  Slight taste of alcohol lets you know there is some substance here.

(12oz bottle from Whole Foods; Sample from July 18, 2008 Beer Club Meeting) Great frothy head excellent lacing.  A deep dark color aromas of raisins and malt.  Flavor much like a lively porter.  Chocolate, roasted malt, earthy and dark.  Aftertaste solid and sweet.  Yep, like a very good light porter.  Sweet!

hard to believe outside of a porter you could find something this decadent.  this is richer then a chocolate milkshake.  others disagree clearly, but this is very balanced for a DFH product, the malt truly shines through, the hops are upfront but truly in harmony with the roasted notes.  nice dark brown sugar coats the tounge and like a scotch ale it exhibits porter qualities without being a porter.  this is a brown ale to wild levels of excess, kudos to the brewers for taking yet another style to the nth degree, where n equals infinity!

12 oz bottle. Pours a lovely mahogany color with a small beige head that dissipates quickly. Nose is more like Orkney Dark Island. Roasty malt with some smoke and caramel and piney hop notes. I am expecting a hoppy scotch style porter. Much like many DFH beers this is a bit unbalanced. To much hops and not enough malt, however they are going for a bit of a scotch IPA so maybe they hit the mark. Regardless the bitter coffee finish is a bit unpleasant a bit to aggressive. The middle has a nice malt background and the alcohol notes are just right. There is some chocolate and caramel present but this is not sweet enough to be a scotch anything. A nice attempt but I don’t think it quite achieved what it wanted to.

12 oz bottle from The Galway Tribes (Frankfort, IL). A very interesting concept that I was excited to try (But hesitant to by in packaged form). Pours a deep dark almost black with ruby notes hue with a small dark brown cocoa head that is bubbly and pretty. Aromas are largely chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and a hint of the typical dogfish hops. Initial is largely the same. A full bodied mouthfeel consisting of chocolate, cocoa, roasted dark malts, and touches of dried dark fruits and a very nice hop presence (Hitting spot on with the Brown/IPA concept). Porterish almost though (with some of their hop presences). Very drinkable, very enjoyable. Grrrrrreat!!
Pours dark brown with a thin off white head.  Nice roast flavor.  Heavy malt and some dark fruit.  Very drinkable brown though, well done.

Pours a dark brown in color with ruby highlights around the edges.  No head on the pour, only a slight froth around the perimeter of the glass.  Smell is dark, roasted malts and a hint of piney hops.  Wow, there is a lot more coffee in this brown than I was ever expecting.  Caught me off guard.  This is a very good brown ale.  Full and roasty on the mouthfeel.  There’s just a bit of a harsh roasted coffee aftertaste.  Other than that, this is a winner.

Smells sweet, sugary. Strong, chocolate, toasted coffee, brown sugar malt taste with a background of hops. Extremely complex ale here, lots of taste, well balanced. I’m not usually a fan of brown ales because they tend to be watery, but this was actually pretty thick. This is what all other brown ales should aspire to.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Pours dark brown with one finger beige head. Nose of citrus hops and caramel malt- quite powerful and even evident before pouring. Flavor is roasty and sweet with sweet raisin, caramel and molasses. Slight hop tingle in there as well. Malt character is outstanding for the style and well hopped as well. Palate is thick but not overbearing. Quite drinkable. Definitely the best ale of the style I have tried to date.

I was surprised by this one, more complex than some of the hoppy dogfish head ales I’ve had before. Pours a little darker and with more of a thickness than other browns.   Almost like a porter with a bit more hop bitterness and also a slight molasses like sweetness.  All around excellent, very drinkable.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown to black with two finger tan head that settles slowly. Lacing on the glass. Aroma is hops, malt, barley, raisins, sweet ripe fruit, yeast. Flavor is sweet malt, yeast, coffee, chocolate, caramel. Medium-bodied. More resembles a porter than a brown ale.

12 oz. bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a very minimal ring of a head.  The aroma was nuts and dark malts.  The flavor included hints of molasses, nuts, honey, and a faint trace of hops.  It was thinner than the abv and appearance might suggest on the palate.  Overall: this beer is good but not super interesting IMO.  Solid though.
exactly what it says it is, tastes like a mix between an IPA and a Brown Ale, a brown sugary undertone, but not overwhelming at all, the most balanced beer ive ever had

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2008 Bottle and on draft.  What can i say this is something i would introduce to any new craft beer drinker.  you get 7+%,  a great malty chocolate caramel flavor thats easy to drink and even less intense served cold.  A great mesh and probably a top 3 brown ale IMO.  love it.  One of the most sessionable craft beers that ive had in almost 2000k beers great stuff.

Bottle, Kegs & Barrels in McKinney, TX.
Pours a deep dark Brown with ruby highlights. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, coffee notes. Flavor of chocolat, some coffee, with a nice hop flavor with very nice bitter. Mouthfeel is very smooth with med carbonation and med-full body. This is a GREAT Brown Ale.....Will have again!!!!!

bottle, a sweet dark malt aroma with slight fruitiness, pours a dark brown with a two finger tan head. great sweet malt taste with carmel, toffee, and hints of coffee and chocolate. slight cidery malt finish beautifully masked by earthy hops.

Bottle: Courtesy of A. Haliday.  Another Dogfish 6er day.  I really liked this brew.  Maybe the best session beer dogfish makes in terms of alcohol, flavor, and price.  Best of class in the browns for sure.

I am sure this is the brown ale I have been looking for all along.  This is the best of its style that I have had.  Nice dark reddish/brown pur with a tan head. Aroma is dried fruit, malty and roasty.  Taste is a mix of sweet dried fruit, complex malt and a nice backbone of hops. Well balanced and really delicious.  Bingo!

12 oz bottle from SoLan. Pours a deep chestnut brown color with a beige head. The head had poor retention and disappeared fairly fast, and left no lacing. The aroma is a bit understated with raisins and roasted malts. I also picked up a slight whiff of alcohol. The flavor was complex with roasted malts, toffee, walnuts and biter chocolate.  Very tasty. The mouthfeel was light and  silky smooth with mild carbonation. The finish was long and dry with lingering black walnuts. Overall: A very enjoyable concoction, very sessionable. Im glad I had the chance to try it. Thanks.

Decedent head and creamy texture. Its nearly black but where the glass is thin enough to let light pass. God I wish there were more beers like it. Hoppy like an IPA, creamy and thick like a scotch and drinkable like an apa

6/15/2008.  12 oz bottle, pint glass. Pours deep brown with hazy chestnut head.  Very full body and taste with an extra hint of hops which is nice for an India Brown Ale.  Another great beer from Dogfish.

[1242-20080401] 12floz. Smooth chocolate coffee grounds aroma has sweet roasted malt and a little bubbly alcohol. Clear, dark brown red body with a long-lasting foamy light tan head. Dark roasted coffee beans malt flavour with a sweet plasticy grain aftertaste. Full body is a bitter. Super coffee, quite good.
(@ BeerBistro; Toronto, ON)

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010 Nice aroma of caramel malts, chocolate, and and earthy hops.  Beautiful dark brown color with a tan head.  The flavor is extraordinary, a mix of chocolate, caramel, nuts and earthy hops.  The hops make for a nice finish, which also has lingering caramel sweetness.  A rare and perfect blend or sweet malts and bittering hops.   Very unique and enjoyable.
This beer gets better every time I drink it.  Has a hoppier flavor than other browns Ive had.  Full finish.
bottle, nice brown color, no head, good malty flavor with some hops in there, nice finish
Im not generally a huge brown fan, but this is a unique beer.  A nice caramel flavor with more hoppiness than usual for a brown.  Body seems a little spritzy to me, but otherwise really nice.

This beer is the best brown ale Ive had, because of the hop content and the carmalized brown sugar. That makes it vey unique. Its vey sweet in the aroma but very hoppy in the flavor with strong notes of molasses and chocolate. A very good, unique Brown Ale indeed.

Bottle courtesy of GMCC2181.  Pours a clear dark brown with minimal tan head.  Nose is chocolate, coffee and nuts.  Palate is chocolate, molasses and coffee with a hop bite in the finish.  Medium, semi-creamy mouth feel.  This has the characteristics of a stout  which was a nice surprise.  Good brew G.

Tastey- pours a dark mahogany colour with no head, however lacing is beautiful and intruiqite. Aroma is nutty, lightly hopped- coffe beans and dark chocolate. Taste is creamy with coffee beans again, oak and subtle smokey undertones.

Intersting beer, kinda like an mix of an IPA with a brown ale. Very hoppy, but also very malty. THe aroma is quite hoppy, but the sweet malt presence is very evident. The flavour is roasty, and malt, with a good dose of hops in the finish for bitterness..........very interesting.
Odd combination of styles, but not too bad overall.  I got a sense of the molasses and caramel from the aroma, and some roasted bitterness in the flavor.

Bottle; pours deep brown in color with creamy tan head; chocolatey roasted malts on the nose, which follow through on the palate along with a little caramel; medium-bodied mouthfeel with roasted bitterness on the finish; great value

I give the most points for this beers balanced aroma of coffee and hazelnut, but its overall rating is just okay.  The beer is enjoyable; but has no wow factor, forcing me to pick up the bottle too re-read the label.

Bière #6 au Mondial 08 (28/5/08), bouteille. Brune noisette, pas de collet. Arome dhoublon chocolaté, un peu amère et un peu sûrette. Goût de chocolat sûrette, pas très houblonné, plus malté. Pas si impressionnant que ça, peut-être que la boutelle a resté ouvert trop longtemps?!

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Pours a dark, dark brown with a foamy tan head. Aroma is amazing. Elements of lots of things but very sweet, malty, earthy. Flavor is very...hmm. Malty. Sweet. I can taste notes of caramel and sugarcane. Maybe some roasted nut. Good Good stuff.

bottle.  aroma mainly of mocha and coffee.  Rich mahogany in color with a very small cream head that goes away quickly. Nice hops evident in the start, with mocha and coffee coming very smoothly through long lasting finish.  Not bad at all.  May be better than hazelnut brown.

Out of the bottle.  The description enticed me to try.  I was entrigued by a great blend of well-hopped beer with a strong Scotish Brown Ale, but found that it fell slightly short of the former.  While I enjoyed the beer, my initial reaction remained. 
The aroma was dominated mostly by the dark malts and I found little hop presence, despite its description.  There is little evidence of a well-hopped beer, not only in aroma, but also throughout. 
It looked quite quite nice, both in clarity as well and creamy, rich foam retention.
The flavor is thick with darker caramel and chocolate. Sweetness permeates the brew, but is somewhat balanced out by the tart coffee flavorings, somewhat.  
An above average mouth feel, not too watery, not too thick.  

Not bad at all, but I think the billing for this beer is a little off, as the IBUs(if indeed around 50) dont tend to translate as far as aroma, flavor, or even bitterness.

Pours a thick and creamy DARK brown, with a thin tan head.  Aroma more reminicient of an Imperial Stout than your average Brown Ale, with chocolate, nuts, and some dried fruit.   Flavor has hints of molasses and coffee, to go along with the chocolate and nuts.  Bitter, but well balanced.  I taste more malt than hops in this one, probably due to the mild(ish) flavor the Goldings.  Palate is medium and creamy but finishes a bit dry for me.  Overall a very good, highly complex brown ale.  Certainly not a session ale, and not particularly refreshing, however this is a perfect choice after a long day at the office.

Calibration beer at the Liquid Poets first and a half homebrew slam.  Scores in () are BJCP, scores in [] are ratebeer
Aroma: Malty, toast, some roast (7/12) [6/10]
App: Dark Brown, clear, tan head that falls quickly (3/3) [5/5]
Flavor: Plasticky Phenolics noted.   Some sweetness, hops in the flavor, some solid bitterness (8/20) [4/10]
Mouthfeel: Med. Body, Med/high carbonation.  Some astringency in the finish(3/5) [3/5]
OA:  Interesting.  Hoppy Brown ale.  The plasticky flavor is problematic and would prevent me from having more.  hope that was a bad bottle(5/10) [10/20]
Draught: Poured a thick brown color with a beige color head. The aroma is caramel and barley. Taste is very rich with caramel malt.
One of the best IBAs Ive ever had. Unfortunately for this beer, it was stuck between tasting Burton Baton and Midas Touch, which clouded my judgement a bit, but it was very good.

Clear brown with thin brown head.  Heavy roasted malt aroma with caramelized sugar and nuts.  Nutty taste of sweet malts, brown sugar, sweet malts and mild alcohol.  Better than your average brown ale.

Pours a semi-hazy reddish brown with slight head. Aroma is is hops and light caramel and malts. Flavor is a bit tangy with caramel, hops and floral undertones. I  can taste the raisin undertones. Body is light medium with fair carbonation.

No surprise from the guys at Dogfish Head. A complex mix of flavors all poured in a bottle for your enjoyment. A maple aroma with a caramel color, generous carbonation, with a small tangy taste initialized followed up by a hoppy, fruity aftertaste.

Totally unexpected beer. Dark brown with white head thats gone almost immediately. Scents of fruit and roast dominance. The taste is similarly sweet, though roast bitterness and some hop citrus is present and roast/medicinal aftertaste. Dry finish. Whatever this is, it tastes like a subdued coffee stout or really subdued imperial stout.
One of my personal favorites.  I am thrilled I was able to get this in keg form for my wedding reception.
Not a huge fan of browns, but Ill try anything that Joe brews. Good beer - a bit too much alcohol in the aroma and on the palate. Not DFs best but still a solid beer.

Pours nice deep reddish brown with a finger of tan head. Aroma is roasted caramel malts and a hint of the 7.2% alcohol. Flavor is outstanding, a complex array of sweet caramel and brown sugar, dried fruits, coffee and chocolate. Great full body, smooth, and warm from the alcohol. A fantastic brown ale.

Pours a massive and lasting 2 inch head.  Dark brown, almost black in color.  Could easily mistake it for a guiness if not for a more bubbly head.  Taste is ridiculously complexed, and but somehow still balanced.  Little alcohol hint in the finish.

Pours a light brown with a thin head and nice lacing. Slightly tinny hop aroma with notes of brown sugar. Sweet brown ale taste with present hops. Creamy body, good carb. As an IPA this is lacking, but as a Brown Ale its excellent. Thanks to SoLan for the trade!

(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com)
As I recall, this was a very tasty Scotch ale with notes of caramel.

pours dark brown with a tan head. smells overwhelmingly like espresso. has a bitter bite at first then fades to nutty. taste a little bit of grassy hops. leaves an alcohol warmth in my mouth reminiscent of a higher abv brew

12 ounce bottle. Poured a nice mahogony color with a nice tan head that disappeared quickly. The aroma was metallic at first but as the beer warmed I caught a lot of roasty malts and nuts. The taste was malty with some bitter coffee flavors and a touch of sweetness. The mouthfeel was very light. For some reason this one reminded me of a watered down porter. Not bad, but nothing that I would readily seek out.

This is a really well rounded brew.  It has it all roasted  and coffee like Malty flavors, a little molasses-like taste too along with a nice mild hoppy dry-like finish.  It could best be described as a October fest on steroids!  Balanced like a true Marzen Octoberfest should be, yet this is also darker, and more flavorful.  This could still be a session beer tho.  Anyhow this stuff is really good. Try it youll like it !

Poured a dark brown with a nice inch of tan head on top. The head receeded somewhat quickly, but maintained a thin layer atop the beer throughout.

The smell is somewhat vague, hints of toasted malts and coffee.

Taste was excellent, the coffee taste, the toasted malts, and some maple syrup were dominant. It had a very earthy taste.

Definately a nice full mouth-feel, a bit creamy, and a good carbonation level. The aftertaste is of burnt wood and not at all unpleasant.

I was very satisfied with this beer and will definately drink more of it in the future.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours deep brown, almost black with a dark reddish tint.  Nice, tan head that holds up very well.  Aroma is smoky, roasted malts and floral at the same time, quite complex.  Tastes sweet and smoky at first with the hops coming through in the end.  Im thoroughly enjoying this!  Another good beer from a great brewery.

A bit heavier aroma with definite notes of coffee, chocolate, and malt. Appearance is deep brown with a mahogany edge and creamy head.
Actual flavor showcases strong elements of chicory, walnut, and cedar, leaving a grassy, floral perfume on the palate.
Probably best as a sipping beer alongside a pork roast.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark cherrywood color with a thin brownish head.  Aroma is earthy and sweet, with notes of caramel, coffee, roasted malt, and grains.  Taste is medium-bodied and unexpectedly hoppy, with an initial flavor of bitter citrusy hops later joined by burnt coffee, dark fruit, and chocolate.  An interesting confluence of styles and flavors suitably eccentric for a Dogfish Head beer.

I wasnt sure what to expect after poured the bottle into a glass and took in the aroma - not what I expected.  However, that quickly changed when I took a sip!  Very drinkable beer, packs a punch, and I will drink it again.  Brown sugar with a hint of caramel aftertaste.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 bottle: dark brown. Hop and burnt smell. Taste was roasted barley, some hops and something sour. I didnt enjoy the carbination in this one.

A- Pours a reddish brown hue with a 1.5 finger light brown head which fades fairly quickly leaving little to no lacing.

S- Smell is faint but coffee is distinct as well as roasted barley, perhaps a bit of chocolate.

T- Taste is much hoppier than expected. Starts off with piney hops and ends with bitterness but also a deep roasted flavor.

M- A bit thick and sticky with quite a bit of carbonation.

D- Decent tasting but for a brown its definitely extremely hop forward and that coupled with the thickness lowers the drinkability in my book.

Pours a dark but transparent brown with a thin off white head.  Nice aroma, chocolatey, nutty and roasted coffee.  The roasted flavor shines through very nicely, another well made beer from these guys.

Poured a dark brown, almost black color with a light brown head, that mostly dissipated.  Aroma of hops, caramel, and especially coffee.  Tasted overwhelmingly like roasted coffee, with a slight bitterness.  Creamy mouthfeel, went down very smooth.  Because of its darkness and  strong coffee flavor, was very reminiscent of a stout.  It grew on me the more I drank it, I could see getting into this one.
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 Poured a nice brown color with malt and hops aroma. Flavor was coffee with nice hops finish and slight fruity twang. Not your classic brown ale but good anyway.

Brown beer with a good-sized light tan head that lasts and leaves lace. The aroma is at first floral hops but then mainly roast malt and burnt notes. The flavor doesnt have much hops except a hint of bitterness atop a base of roast malt, with the usual chocolate, perhaps coffee and burnt toast. Some sweet caramelly flavors as well. Finish is burnt notes, not hop bitterness. This isnt terribly different from your average brown ale.

12 ounce bottle-  poured out a translucent brown with a beige colored head that lasted the full glass.  Aroma was hops and smoke.  The taste was coffee, smoke and toasted malt with a citrus back.  The caranelized sugar seemed to take the edge off the bitterness and smooth out the brew.

Draft at The Old Toad in Rochester NY. Poured cola brown with a beige head. Aroma is lightly nutty, roasted malt, coffee, and a hint of hops. Medium body, quite smooth. Flavor is roasted malt, bitter coffee, and floral hops. Nice.

Muted hop aroma, mostly sweet caramel, some coffee and some bourbon. There wasnt near the hops in this that one mmight think being its a "india" brown ale. I got a lot of sweet, bourbon like taste on the pallate, which i didnt care for to much. Its pretty decent, but more of a typical brown ale, with very little hops.
Bottle. Light roasted aroma with a hop note. Deep brown color with a beige head. Sweet body with a roasted chocolate and nutty note. Hop palate with a smooth finish. Not bad.

Simply nothing to not like about this beer or its brewers. It pours amber brown with unsettling head. It has 4 notes maybe five your palate goes in after shock. Warning do not drink a different beer right after this one. There is a balance of spice, sweet and hops that can be simply said matchless.
Dark brown pour, definitely taste the carmel and sugar tastes, but also a hint of a coffee-like aftertaste. Would be good with a dessert or something chocolate. Hides the 7.2% ABV, which is awesome.
pours dark brown,thin off white head,malty carmel aroma.sweet up front with light biter finish,molasses dark fruit are present.pretty good.

I think this might be my favorite Dogfish Head beer to drink. Ive had it bottled and on tap. On tap, it pours a nice dark brown with a small off-white head. Sweet aroma with lots of malts. The flavor is pretty much devoid of hops. Just sweet malts and only a hint of bitterness. Also, brown sugar, maybe some caramel. Its great, easily drinkable, and generally good.

Something Ive been thinking about trying for a while, finally bought a sixer. Pours a deep amber color with a moderate tan head and a decent amount of lacing. The aroma is sweet, nothing special but nothing bad either. This is a very drinkable beer. Slightly sweet with a roasted flavor in there. Very little bitterness. Im not really sure why they call it "India" and advertise it as "hoppy" because I really didnt taste a whole lot of hops in there. Still its a solid beer and they hide the 7.2% abv quite well. There are some mild stout characteristics in there too which is interesting and makes for a nice all around beer.

12 oz bottle from a trade with GMCC2181. pours dark brown with an everlasting tan head. aromas are almost non-existant. some roastiness and slight hint of hops. whats there smells good. flavours are nice typical brown ale but slightly more hoppy then most. not bad in any way but not that memorable.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small off-white head.  Sweet aroma, lots of malt.  Tastes are brown sugar, molasses, caramel, toffee.  Its sticky and sweet, and lingers.
Dark reddish brown. Small off-white head. Aroma of coffee, molasses, fruit.  Flavor is sweet and bitter, sweet complex malt balanced with hops.  Full body and smooth.  Very good hard to classify ale.

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale
ABV: 7.2%
Calories: estimated at 175 C
Volume: 12 fl oz
Glass: 6 oz goblet
Purchased at: Princeton Community Liquors
Price per fl oz: $1.60 / 12 fl oz = $0.13 per fl oz
Consumed at: Home

sensory first impression: Beautiful deep dark ruby color. Nice hoppy flavor with caramel malt overtones. Beautiful lacing with a present, but thin dark tan head. Not quite a robust stout, but stands on its own as a beautiful brown ale. A delicious example of the type.

Aroma/Olfactory: 9 out of 10
Malt flavor is: caramel, syrupy, dark crusty bread, granola, coffee, nuts, roasted
Hop flavor is: dry grass, orange slices
Yeast flavor is: dust, chocolate, granules, dry
Other flavors include: alcohol, dark, burnt, water chestnuts, raisin, sulfur, soy sauce, walnut

Visuals/Appearance: 5 out of 5
Color is: dark, red, brown, ruby
Liquid is: clear, dark, immaculate
Head and lace are: minimal, brown, lace stands up

Taste/Flavor: 9 out of 10
Maltiness or Sweetness level is: light
Hoppiness or Bitterness level is: light
Sour level is: light

Palate/Tactile: 5 out of 5
Body or Mouthfeel is: medium
Texture is: creamy, slick
Carbonation is: soft
Finish is: astringent, bitter, warm, long

Overall experience: 18 out of 20. A very nice experience. I liked the color, the aroma, the flavor, and the effects. I did not like the small short lived head.
Enjoyable interaction between the hoppy and malty flavors. A tad bit too sweet for my taste

On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  I was expecting a typical brown ale, but had a little more roast/chocolate malt-- maybe closer to a brown porter or Scotch ale.  Nice body, not too roasty.  Probably a good session beer, but not sure Id order it again if something more interesting were on tap.
On draft at the DFH Alehouse in Falls Church. Dark brown. Much sweeter than i was expecting, with a slightly smokey and bitter finish. pretty good
Sweet and malty and roasted, with more hops than I was expecting. Not a huge fan of this style, but this is a good beer.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste of toffee, malt, molasses and fruit. One of DFHs more mediocre beers.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 Pours a dark brown, almost opaque.  Nice tan head that lasts.  Aroma is of a roasty porter.  Flavor of ginger really spikes up for me, with the raisinettes on the swallow.  Very close to the commercial description on the flavors.  A very strange brew that has a lot going for it.  Another winner from Dogfish Head!

re-rate--- don’t get as much ginger then 2nd time rating.  Heavy on the raisinettes though.  Almost like a chocolate covered wine...   try to wrap your head around that one.  Definite alcohol kick to this one.  2nd time around gets a little bump in the flavor department...  thankfully I can get this beer where I live...
A pretty clear light brown beer, neutral aroma, good mouthfeel, Burnt Coffee taste, balanced bitterness, slightly astringent

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 12oz - The stank nose here really put me off.  I had my doubts, but the nice head and small bubbles called me in.  The first sip is a brief shot of starch, followed by a chocolate rush, giving way to a strongly hopped finish.  A sound ale for sure, maybe a little out of balance.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown color ale with a nice foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of nutty caramel malt with some dry hops. Taste is also dominated by some toffee and caramel malt which are well balance by some dry light bitter hops. Good body with some good carbonation. Very well done for a session ale that can still retain some character.

black pour with a big tan head ..... fresh malt aroma, smells fresh ... coffee in the start .... some cardboard ... some sweet malts ... caramel ... light chocolate ... cardboard in the finish ... light bitter adds to the complexity .. dogfish head doesnt let me down .... good solid brown ale

bottle. pours dark brown with a thin off white head.  nutty, malty aroma.  aromatic malts add good body and a creamy mouthfeel.  nice roasted flavors in there as well.  hops add solid bitter and fruity citrus to balance things out. a really unique beer. definitely worth picking up.

Nice medium brown pour with a thin, creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee with a little chocolate. Tons of coffee flavor that moves to a chocolate in the middle and back to a nice, light, and smooth coffee finish. A little thin on the body but very good.
From plastic cup at brewery. Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head. Coffee aroma. Roasted coffee and molasses flavor with a hint of hops. Tasty.

Pours a deep brown with a small tan head that dissapates quickly leaving some lacing.  Dark chocolate and roasty coffee aromas.  Flavor is similar, with caramel and dark fruit notes.  Another very good brew from Dogfish!

Oily big beer with little head retention. Floral and cocoa. Very much like a big American porter. A huge thick mouthfeel with cocoa and coffee coming through, then hops on the back end. A very good beer, just not exactly my taste.
taster at rehobooth beach. good toasty aroma and flavor. caramel, sweet, soft with malty finish VERY nice

Nice dark brown color with a thin lasting head. Chocolate, roast, coffee, and darker fruits in the aroma. A touch of earth. Nice roast and sweetness up front is finished with great bitter hops. Definite cross between and IPA and a Brown/Scottish. I enjoyed the balance between the initial sweetness and bitterness.

Pours a deep brown with a small tan head that faded fast. Smells of malt, raisins, chocolate and a touch of coffee. Tastes of roasted malt followed by mildly sweet chocolate and finishing on a light floral hoppiness. Mouthfeel is creamy and finish leaves a slight bitterness akin to a mocha coffee on the tongue. Deliciously wonderful.

Purchased at Trader Joes in bottles.

Rich appearing dark brown color with malty aroma.  Tan head disappeared quickly.  Nice full mouthfeel and very malty satisfying flavor with caramel malt presence quite pronounced.  Sweetness well-balanced by significant hop bitterness which is accompanied by fine English-type hop flavor.  Darn near a porter, I would agree with Dogfishs description of a cross between a Scotch Ale and IPA, though cant see any American Pale resemblance.

Dogfish scores again!

12oz brown bottle - bottled on 05/01/07
Pours a very dark brown with a hint of crimson. Thin head that remains through entire beer.  Sweet and malty with a faint hint of alcohol on the nose.  The flavor is a fantastic balance of hoppy bitterness, mildly sweet chocolate, and slight alcohol. Great taste with nothing overwhelming, just extremely balanced.
Medium body that matches the taste balance. This is a good beer. Substantial, but not so much that I couldnt have a few.
A decent brown ale from Dogfish....nicely malted and roasty but at the same time there is a hoppy bitterness present. Not a bad beer overall, but nothing to write home about.
Pours a dark brown from a bottle with a slight brown head. Strong coffee aromas. Great roasted malt flavors with a hint of hops. My favorite brown ale, really good beer.

12oz bottle dated 11/19/07, thanks lb4lb, a bit odd that i had you send this to me but hey it was on my want list. pours ruby brown with off white head. nose has more roasted espresso notes than i was expecting. nice molasses and raisiny flavor with some floral hop notes. lively carbonation comes off a bit fizzy. a solid beer and more interesting than most browns.

Very interesting, malty and roasty, yet with a large hop presence.  Almost like a red-brown.  The hops are largely on the bitter side, with little aroma or flavor.  Its very interesting to such a bitter beer with such strong sugary maltiness.  Interesting, but not amazing.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a dark brown/black with a 1 finger tan head that lingered around with significant lacing.  Aroma was of carmely marts with an oh so slight touch of bitter hops.  Taste was mostly of dark carmely malt with a bit of a bitter kick, from the hops Im guessing.  Had a very smooth chocolate/coffee aftertaste...nice!  Light carbonation and a thick body made for an overall pleasant mouthfeel.  I think the description of a cross between a Scotch Ale and an IPA is pretty accurate.  However the hops dont really come through due to the malts.  All in all Id say it almost tastes like a slightly more bitter (hopped) Porter.  Good beer though, but not my favorite DFH product.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown almost black with a thick creamy light tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Thick sticky lacing on the glass. The taste is a sweet roasted malt and brown sugar, very syrupy and does not hide the alcohol well. A very good brown ale from Dogfish Head.
(USA) Brown color with a Sm-Tan Head. Strong Malty Aroma with Bitter /Fruit taste. Not Bad, But this one is not my Favorite by D.F.H

Bottled. Beer is very dark warm brown. Head is very large, off-white, frothy. Pour might have been a little hearty, though. Strong pickets of lacing hold to the glass. Head diminishes steadily, mostly, but lasts.

The aroma is malty with light notes of roasted grain, light-to-moderate notes of molasses, coffee, trace of milk chocolate; Hoppy with light notes of lemony herb, resin; Yeasty with a moderate-to-heavy note of sticky dough; Trace note of current concentrate.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly-to-moderately bitter with a long, slightly grippy, moderately-to-heavily bitter, moderately sweet finish. Slight astringency on gums.

The body is medium, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is average-to-lively.
resin, basement aromas, earthy, alcohol, red, brown, cloudy, tan foam, it didnt taste that well.  I wouldnt recomend it to anyone.

Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of hops, malts, dark fruits, candy/brown sugar. Tastes different than the brown ales I have had before, hoppier and less sweet, but it is very good. Another good brew from a quality brewery.

Awesome beer- my favorite brown ale - foamy off white head. pours a nice deep dark brown color w/ a ruby hint. aroma - caramel, corn, fruit, raisins. taste - bitter sweet on the front develops into a complex combo of coffee and butterscotch and fruit. subtly salty and buttery. sweet hoppy finish that lingers... palate, light mouthfeel, syrupy, perfect. love this beer. have had on tap too and its amazing.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with mahogany highlights (under direct light) and a one finger tan head. Nose is of sweet malts, caramel, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is a fantastic combo of chocolate, molasses, coffee, brown sugar, sweet malts, that is followed up by a spicy hop character. Notes of alcohol and roast finish this out with a bit of brown sugar sweetness. A very soft and at times near oily mouth feel with soft carbonation. This is the brew that brought me into craft beers and its about time I gave it a rating. Still a favorite to this day.
Bottle.  Malty aroma with a bit of nut.  Nice dark color (dark amber in the light) with a tan head.  Starts malty, than turns a bit nutty and then has a hops finish.  Very nice.
bottle.  deep brown color - cream/tan head - nice flavor and great balance of hops and malt...good stuff

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a slight white head.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Taste of coffee (primarily), chocolate, molasses.  There were a lot of complex tastes in here and I dont think I got all I could out of this.  An interesting beer.

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours out in a dark reddish brown colour with a small tan-coloured head. Big aroma of cocoa, nuts, dark chocolate, toasted malts, mint, resin and grass. Medium-bodied with strong notes of minty and grassy hops with a solid malty backbone of dark chocolate and nutshells. Bitter and dryish long finish of roasted malts, roasted nuts, mint, grass and resin. Really tasty dark IPA.

Bottle. Aroma of coffee, roast/smoke (maybe im crazy for getting smoke), as it warms some candi sugar. Flavor at first very much coffee, thought it was going to be one-dimensional at first, but those candi sugars keep popping through, the hops show their face, it actually becomes a really interesting and very unique brew, and Im a sucker for uniqueness. For me the best way to describe this beer is to say that normally I dont like going back to back in the same style, I like to mix things up. But after this beer, I couldnt think of what to go to next. It just had so much of so many different styles in it, Belgian notes, porter notes, APA notes (a different list than they give, but thats how I felt), that it seemed to just stand alone. Very nice brew.

12oz, bottled 1/9/08.  Easily one of the best brown ales I have ever had, next to the Rogue Hazelnut.  Pours brown with a tan head that lasted through 90% of the beer.  Nose is roasted malts, raisin and chocolate.  Body is similar in taste but adds some awesome coffee, nuts, sweet malt and shoo-fly pie.  Mouthfeel is smoooth with good carbonation.  Goooood hops on the long finish kind of puts this in a league of its own.  Much better as it warms close to room temperature.  A great beer.

Aroma dominated by coffee and chocolate malts, some fruity (cherry) hoppy notes.

Texture is syrupy.  Finish is chalky in a good way.   Goodn bubbly.

Flavor of toasted sourdough and coffee with sugar and cream.  Nutty Alcohol and mid with slight spicy hops finish followed by delectable roasted malt finish.  Plenty of dark maltiness to match a good dose of hops.  This is what I like in a beer.

Dark brown. Small, creamy, tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate, subtle hops, and some sweetness in the aroma. Same flavor with more hop presence. Medium body, very easy drinking. You could put down the 6pack without realizing it. Great session brew.

On tap. Classic brown ale flavor x10, accompanied with the many dark flavors of a stout, with a good hit of hops. Feels very thick on the palate, extremely satisfying combination of flavors and texture. Im not normally a fan of brown ales but I knew I was in for a good one from dogfish.
paired nicely with a beef brisket. would prob work well with any red meat. 12oz bottle, nice dark brown color, nutty caramel at first but finishes hoppy.

Surprisely, had at the Melting Pot in Red Bank. Poorly poured into a pilsner by the bartender, why Im not sure. Nice dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, brown sugar and a hint of coffee. Taste was excellent. Nutty and rich with bit of sugar in the beginning along with those notes of coffee. Nice hops toward the end. Really enjoyed this beer. Will have it again.

Bottled 09/12/07; 12 oz bottle from mcbackus; Nose is roasty and nutty with caramel and coffee notes; clear dark brown with a medium straw head; flavor has some coffee, toffee, smoke, and caramelized sugar, but I can taste a lot of hops; only a smidgeon of bitterness in the finish!

Pours, well, brown with a few fingers of frothy tan head.  Aroma of hazelnut, and oats.  Interesting taste, strong molasses and chocolate tastes combine with the nuts.  Malts and Hops clash- it ends up tasting like a mix between a pale ale and a porter.  Very interesting.

Thick billowy foam on top of a deeply colored brown ale. Lacing is lovely. Nose is all chicory and freshly cut timber but also rich black earth. Metallic flavors. Finishes thin and is not as complex as it could be. However, I could drink this often, as it is in a really good zone in between sipping and session.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2009 "A cross between a Scotch Ale, an IPA, and an American Pale"??? Hmmm.... more like a stout and an IPA.

Pours and keeps a nice beige head.  Good roasty barley taste throughout, with strong hints of chocolate and lighter hints of coffee.  A nice dark brown... good balance of hops and malt.  Pretty thick palate.  Slight alcohol burn.  Not too far from a stout.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2008 Is that a picture of coffee beans on the label?  Nose-clearing aroma of hops and alcohol.  Flavor is full and well-hopped, with coffee, malt, and noticable alcohol in there too.  The flavors clash a little, and It is not as good as I had hoped, but it does get points for originality.  An odd alliance between a brown ale and an IPA.
Every Dogfish head beer Ive had just keeps getting better and better. This beer is amazing dark color with a nice head. The beer has a good roast flavor to it, one of my favorite Dogfish Head!
Poures a dark amber.  Frothy tan head and tastes of roast, coffee and chocolate.  The hops are present in this beer, it was a little bit dry though.  Overall pretty good.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2008 What the hell this tastes like a Dogfish head! Uck! ....


No just kidding this was pretty good. This would be a good session beer and it doesnt seem like it is a 7.2% beer.  Has a good balance of hops, malts, and brown sugar.  Not overbearing in the least.

Aroma is heavy hoppy with some coffee, barely and butter. Upon pouring there is a frothy light brown head that goes away pretty quickly. The body color is black (nearst makes no difference, right?). Decent lacing. Flavor is alcohol and coffee at first with a bitter and somewhat salty finish. Dry body with a bit too fizzy carbonation. Quite drinkable, but not as good as some of DFHs other products.

Pours a deep brown with a thick cream-colored head.  Aroma is of coffee and hops.  First sip is full of coffee and dark chocolate maltiness.  It is like a dry stout, but hoppy and full of flavor.  Very heavy beer, one of these and I need a break.  Good stuff.

Pours dark brown color with minimal head. Most aromatic Ale Ive encountered. Big flavor profile with a lot going on. Kind of reminds me of Guiness Stout but more complex. Hop bitterness nicely balanced with rich, dark, sweet malts. Seems a bit too much alcohol on the palate but I think that sensation may be enhanced by the ginger flavor. If you are looking for a brew with big favors give this a try. Well recommended.

Nice dark brown pour and similar roasted hop smell.  Tan, off-white head and some thin lacing but all carbonation seemed to disappear towards the end.  Very drinkable and smooth blend with a barley hop nip, just a tad flat at the end.  Over all very good.

Pours a clear but pretty dark brown. Nice sized tan head. Nose is evenly roasted. Flavor is smooth and robust, but not overpowering. Seems like I get a very small touch of alcohol on there. Feel is smooth. Decent level of carbonation and the liquid is good. Overall this is a very drinkable brown ale. Deep and appropriately thick. Definitely worth trying.

A near perfect beer. Its got it all. Flavor is nutty and malty. Lasts a loooong time on the palate. Finishes with a warm sweetness that is matched by very few. A wonderful lacy head and dark brown pour. A top five beer of mine that destroys so many others. Superbly complex.
jet black pour with a thin caramel head.  roasted malts and sweet sugar scent.  great thickness with a very smooth malty flavor.  delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 WOW!!  Big props to GMCC2181 for sending me this as a bonus brew in a trade. He described this as one of his faves, and it is very easy to see why. Think NewCraple, only good. A lot goes on in this beer. Pours tannish, with a tan head. Looks almost like weak coffee. Aroma is almost as complex as the taste. Carmel, malt, slight chocolate, coffee, oh my! Add in a smooth nutty flavor and a few spices (like the ginger!) and this is a delicious beer that Id suggest to anyone. On par with Rogues HazelNut for sure, but too different to really compare them straight up. GMCC found me a winner here!!

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2008 Pours translucent dark brown with a medium one finger head.  Aroma of brown sugar, toffee, and hops.  Initial taste of dark malts with strong molasses, brown sugar and toffee accents.  Bitter finish.  Stong, well balanced beer with payoffs in both the sweet malt taste and the bitter finish.  A really nice beer.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 Poured a dark brown almost black color. Small white foamy head. Smelled like coffee, chocolate, malt with some sugar. Taste just like it smells. First you taste the coffee, malt and then the hops. The after taste is when you can taste the caramelized sugar. This beer is one of my favorites because it is strong yet smooth. Over all a solid brew!---Update---
Just had this on tap at the brewery in Milton and had to re-rate since it was so fresh. So good! To be honest one of my favorites for a while. Top ten for sure! This beer is good all year round, on a hot summer day while grilling; or even on a cold winters night.
This was very smooth and strong Brown Ale. I would recommend any beer lover try this beer.
Bottle from local store. Pours nicely with a good size brownish frothy head. Not a typical Brown Ale, much better. Strong hint of coffee aroma but very smooth. Highly recommend.

12 oz bottle pours a dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is dominated by hops with a little malt presence.  Flavor is caramel, a little chocolate and hop bitterness.  I think this is my favorite Brown ale ever.

pours dark brown with a hint of ruby, thick tan head that leaves some nice lacing. smells of chocolate, brown sugar, and dark fruit. taste is mostly chocolate with noticeable alcohol. nice balanced finish with more chocolate, raisins, and a flourish of hops.

bottle. LOVE THIS STUFF. it smells great and tastes even better. you can smell the hops and taste them but its very smooth and little to no after taste. nice redish brown color. very small head. brown sugar ,malt ,a bit of chocolate a put in to one little bottle!
Poured brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and nuts. Sweet malt flavor to start with some chocolate. Finished with a slight alcohol burn. Not bad.
Brown sugar reigns in the taste with a hint of hops to remind you that it is a beer. When craving an Indian brown ale, this one is a above average choice

Bottle. Pours a dark brown and almost porter like in color. No head and no lacing. Aroma of raisins, toffee, chocolate and mild coffee. The taste is similar with malt dominating the flavor. I sense very little hops in this beer. I think the low carbonation of this beer poses a problem for the overall taste experience. A beer that I  was expecting much more from.

Aroma: brown sugar & malt w/ a bit of anise and chocolate with a tinge raisiny wood and alcohol. Needs more hops in the aroma. Taste shows more bitterness mixed w/ darker malt bringing me back to Stone 11th Anniversary, although the similarities end there. Mouthfeel is smooth but slightly too thin. Seems pretty good when spliced up, but as a whole it fails to satiate me.

It pours a dark brown color with a small creamy head.  The aromas a bit dull with some dark malts and not much hops.  The taste is coffee and chocolates, but Im not really finding much of a hops presence which is disappointing.  Its not very bitter, but thats not particularly good here, as the hops dont seem to balance the malts.  It is pleasantly smooth though.

The aroma leaves a bit to be desired with notes of stale hops and dark malt. The beer looks decent with a dark brown color and almost non-existent head. The taste is burnt molasses, dark chocolate, coffee, with a noticeable, but not too prounouced gingery hop character. Pretty smooth as well. Decent overall.

This is a great, smooth beer.  Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head, disipates quickly.  Flavor is coffee and chocolate.  Very good sweet notes.  The beer is lightly hopped.  It says 50 IBU, but I dont perceive much bitterness.  I could drink a lot of these.
This beer is awesome. Reminds me of eating a double chocolate chip cookie. Strong notes of coffee, bitter chocolate. Very dark color, tan head. Sooo good. This is one of my new favorite beers.
A nice swing on the traditional IPA. Worked very well and would like to try again. Next time in US I guess.

Bottled 1/9/07. Aged on purpose. I love this one with a year under its belt. It morphs into a tasty rauchbier. Smokey, roasty, toasty, malty, and sweet, with coffee and chocolate notes. Very full in the mouth and drinkable. I wouldnt expect this to age well, but it does. I dont like brown ales, and I love this beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma is chocolate, brown sugar, nuts, and even a hint of coffee. Flavor is much more coffee like with unsweetened chocolate, dark burnt molasses, and ginger. Finish is moderately bitter with a lasting cocoa powder taste like those oatmeal cocoa balls my family used to make. Overall pretty tasty stuff.

dark brown appearance with slight tan head.  nose is predominately of sweet malt and sugar.  flavor has a great sweetness from the crystal malt and brown sugar then an impressive hop presence.  a very tasty and drinkable beer that can be appreciated in many aspects.  one of my favorite dogfish head beers

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2008 This beer is fucking amazing! Chocolate and coffee flavors, with a bitterness that reminds me of fine semi-sweet chocolate. The aroma and lingering flavor is that of sesame oil? Amazing. This beer is very good - probably one of my favorites. Too bad I only scored one bottle from Sun Devil Liquors in Mesa, AZ.
Pours very smoothly into a coffee color with a very light tan head.  Tastes like a combo of an espresso and chocolate.  Smooth on the palate.  Very good.
Very good brew - color and feel a bit different than browns I am used to.  Aroma has a roasted quality, taste a mix of chocolate, coffee, and maybe molasses.  Pleasant finish.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with a coffe colored small head. Chocolate, coffe, molasses wonder on the buds. The after taste is very pleasant and long lasting. A very good beer.

I wasnt in the mood for this. I wanted somthing more subtle. I wanted somthing less alchoholic. Dogfish head always overdue everything. It was a good beer dont get me wrong. The store was closing and I was rushed into my desiscion. I just wish I read it correctly. I saw the brown and just grabbed.

Pours brown with a thin, lacy oatmeal head.  The mix of flavors is really interesting: brown sugar and coffee, with sourness and hoppiness too.  The alcohol provides a stronger finish for what I expected from a brown ale.  Another creative beer from Dogfish Head.  Cool.

A great example of a brown, with maltiness up front, then a higher than normal alcohol coming through, and finished with a refreshing amount of hops to balance it all out.  This beer has a moderate amount of malt, alcohol, and hops, and it adds up to a great tasting beer with way more flavor than any other brown ale Ive had.
Very smooth for a 7% brown ale. Dark brown with tan head. Malty and full with a touch of spice.

Ive had the Dogfish 60/90/120 minute offerings before and was looking forward to trying something else of theirs. 

Pours a nice dark amber, almost dark brown with a one finger head that dissolved into a pleasant lace that went down along with the beer nicely.

Smelled great right from the pour of what I would expect from this style-malty, a bit sugary, and some chocolate/coffee hints. 

The taste follows right through from the smell and it was well balanced with malt, chocolate, sugar, coffee, and hops (of course!) flavors all of the way through. 

Not too heavy, but definitely a full beer. I was a little weary of the 7.2% ABV, but I didnt really detect too much alcohol-that can be a bit dangerous as it went down pretty smooth. I could drink these things all day if I wasnt sure that they I would have a problem standing later! 

A great beer that I would definitely recommend and try again if I have the opportunity.

bottle poured into a  glass-  presence of alcohol on the nose, but overall smooth with a clean crisp finish-  it feels like a northwest brown -  chocolate finish without too much hops-  could definately drink another!
From a bottle.  Pours a dark brown with small off white head.  Brown sugar, syrup, and some coffee in the nose.  Taste is more of the brown sugar along with some hops.  Nice medium body.  good brew.
Draft at Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  Pours a dark brown.  It is fairly bitter and hoppy and has a slight finish.  It has just a bit of sweetness.

Very sweet smelling aromas, coupled with a dark color that just begs to be sipped.  The barley is immediately recognizable, and the sugars make you think youre just having a bowl of fermented Golden Puffs cereal without the milk.  Incredibly flavorful.

Im not a big brown ale fan but this is the best Ive come across so far.  Definite notes of brown sugar and roasted malt in both the smell and taste here.  Most of the browns that Ive tried are a little watery but not this one.  Quite full of flavor.  I really like this.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours clear dark bown with  short lived tan head.  Lots of rising bubbles.  Notes of dark honey, molasses, raisins, and chocolate in the nose.  Quite malty.  Roasty.  Coffe with sweetner.  Very bitter as well.  Medium body. High carbonation.  Dry finish.

Thanks to my homey J Carney for smuggling this back from NJ. Pours a medium brown, not too light, not too dark. Has a thin yellowish head. Smells sweet of brown sugar and nuts. There is a touch of the hops as well and of course the barley as well. Tastes sweet up front with quite a bit of bitterness in the background. The hops arent bitter like an IPA because I think the bitterness must be balanced out by the sweet brown sugar and nutty flavors. Pretty thick for a beer thats only 7.2%, not that 7.2% isnt much. Pretty good carbonation. Drinks like a way bigger beer because of all the flavor. This brew is so tasty it could get me in trouble. I just want to keep drinkin it to get to the bottom of all the flavor.
Has a pleasant sweetness that isnt over-powering.  I definitely agree with the commercial description when it comes to the notes of molasses and coffee.  Another exceptional beer from DFH.
a slight coffee aroma with a dark brown tint.  I can taste the caramelized brown sugar.  It starts smooth on the palate and then heads toward the bitterness of the hops.  I like this beer.

Served to me a very dark brown, resembling a stout with a thin layer of head that remained and laced throughout. Smells of sweet malt, toasted nuts and a breath of fresh hops. Starts off tasting of some toasted malt, some coffee and a beautiful hop finish. Mouthfeel is nice and full, some carbonation and a tasty bite from the hops that lingers on the toungue. For a stout this is good, for a brown ale this is fantastic. Very smooth and filling, if it were winter right now this would be a pint of $3 liquid crack. A must try on tap (my only experience)

From bottle, pours very dark brown and nearly opaque with slim tan head. Aroma is of chocolate and brown sugar. Rich mouthfeel. Taste is of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and brown sugar. It pulls back with a hint of nuttiness, but I dont detect much of the Indian here (i.e.,  hop bitterness). As a result, its veers close to being too sweet. Still, I like it a lot. Cant sense the ABV, but the richness (and price) would keep me from drinking too many.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of brown sugar, ginger, and malt.  Bright on the palate with brown sugar, chocolate, and coffee up front.  Bitter and hoppy at the end with ginger evident.  Another fine brew from Dogfish Head.

bottled.  Very dark brown colour with red/amber highlights.  Small tan head that settles quickly into a film.   Aroma is molasses, figs and candied fruits.  Full flavour and nice body make this an exciting brown.
Pours a medium brown color with little head and lacing. Aroma of malt , chocolate, and a little hops. Flavor of caramel and malt with a bitter finish. Very good.

A: Pours a beautiful brown color with a thick off-white head. The head fell fairly quickly leaving only a thin layer of foam.

S: This beer has a hearty malt aroma with a good chocolate blast. I dont get any hop aroma off of this.

T: This is a very full flavored beer and I like it a lot...definitely more than last time I had it. It has malt, caramel, and a bit of chocolate in it and finishes with some bitterness, but not overwhelmingly so. Its been a while since I had this and I think my IBU tolerance has gone up by a factor of 10 since then, and now this barely even registers.

M: This is one hell of a creamy beer. It is decently heavy bodied for a brown, but not Double Stout thick.

D: I am usually impressed with DFH and this is no exception. Another great example of a style breaker.

100th US beer- from 12 oz. bottle- poured non transparent very dark black-brown, lacing head, aroma of chocolate, molasses, and coffee.  Hits the mouth with a well defined medium malt body, a bit of sweetness to it, finish of hops with a kick of sugar.  Tasty!

Pours a dark brown with a little caramel head that doesnt last all that long.  I love th aroma of this beer.  Coffee, chocolate, roasted barley and chestnuts.  Seems like a very Christmastime beer to me.  Rich, full flavor.  Hints of coffee, cocoa and barley with a crisp hoppy finish.  Deliicious.
Bottle:  Dark reddish brown colored pour with medium sized head.  Nutty, coffee aroma with a roasted, bitter finish.

Bottle from trade with Beachbum25!  Brew pours a deep brown with a reddish hue.  Head was a light tan and left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma off ground coffee, molasses and chocolate.  One of the best brown ales Ive had in a long time.  Thanks Beachbum!

Pours a deep brown color into the mug.  An inch of off-white head slowly subsided to a trace of bubbles.  Scents fo hops, caramel, brown sugar and malt dominate the nose and the tastes up front.  A hoppy, bitter bite characterizes the finish.  Surprised at the ABV here.

Murky reddish brown color with a fizzy off white head that fades quickly. Nice smell is of caramel malts and earthy hops. Good taste of lightly sweet malts and toasted grains. Finishes with a nicely bitter hop bite. Well balanced and easy drinking , a good session brew. 03/06/2006
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: dark brown with a small off white head.  Plenty of caramal and chocolate in the nose,  a bit of hops.  The taste is a nice blend of hops and malts.  Maybe some coffee added in along to it.  Finishes very smooth,  little carbonation.  Evenly matched bitter to sweet,  but neither are overpowering.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 Pours a dark amber brown with yellow/brown head. Full-bodied aroma of chocolate, malts, &coffe. Tastes of creamy chocolate malts with a little touch of zippy hops. Palate, is thick, smooth and pleasant. Low carbonation and respectable alc/vol. Not sure how anyone could rate this as any IPA, much closer to dark amber ale, but a special brew nonetheless

As a huge fan of IPAs, I had no trouble trying this one a few times.  Its hard to find a more aromatic, hoppy, perfectly colored IPA than this one.  Once again, Dogfish has marketed a winner.  This one can go head-to-head with just about any North American IPA.
Nice dark color with small head.  Malty and sweet, with a hint of coffee.  Would buy again.

I dont know if its truly a combination of a scotch ale and an IPA, but it works pretty well. Gorgeous reddish brown color, modest head, and that nice nutty molasses aroma typical of a scotch ale. Caramel and molasses flavor with a fairly bitter finish which doesnt last very long. Id like it a little more if mouthfeel were a little thicker and chewier. Very dry for a scotch ale.

Had this on tap at the Dog and Pony Ale House in Renton, WA.  Pours very dark, not quite black, with a tan head.  Strong aroma of toffee, and coffee. Flavor was rich in malt, with brown sugar and caramel notes. Hops balanced it out nicely. Smooth, moderately heavy on the palate, keeps the roof of the mouth involved, even after the finish.  Very nice beer. Ill probably be getting a case as soon as I can get my hands on one.
Smells like a fresh cup of coffee.  Tastes like coffee with caramel and figs.  A little heavy for me, but a great means of redefining brown ale.

nose of coffee and roasted malt. poured a dark brown amber color with the head dissipating quickly. pick up flavor notes of raisins, molasses and coffee as described. tickles the sugar glands on the palate while leaving a bitter hoppy after taste in the back. overall tasty.
This was an exception brown ale. The flavours are so incredibly complex. Raisins and cherries, with the hops of a great APA. Nice. Hints of creamy malts too.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Smells and tastes like a great brown ale with all the hoppiness of an IPA. Very dark brown color with  light brown head. Great carbonation, hoppy finish. This Brewery never dissapoints.

12 oz. bottle from mj.  Pour is deep brown, appeared to be some haze.  Fair amount of layering on the pour, with a two inch tan head that drops pretty fast.  Aroma of raost biscuit malt.  Just a hint of sweetness and some bitter hops.  Taste is nice, good slight roast flavor, malt body and a bitter hop finish.  Certainly one of the better browns I have tasted.
Im not sure what an Indian brown ale is but I liked this one a lot. A bit fruity would definitely get again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle:  Pours a dark brown/amber color with a nonexistent head.  Raisins, dates, plums and brown sugar come through in the nose.  Full bodied, sweet malt base with some fruity esters coming through.  I can definitely pick up on some of the ginger that is described in the commercial description.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 Excellent beer! Very intense, full-bodied chocolate brown flavor. Dark brown color with full brown-tinged head. Not exactly a session brown like Newcastle, but certainly one of the finest beers I have ever tasted. My only criticism is that it is so intense, almost a porter, that I can only drink one in a sitting and it makes it hard to continue the session.

on tap @ papago. dark woody brown colored with red highlights and a lasting tan head. aroma is brown sugar sweet with caramel, malt, dark raisins, floral and piney hops. flavor is the same but not as robustly malty as browns tend to be. still, really unique flavors with a very fresh herb/floral hop finish and lingering dryness. medium body and carbonation.

Excellent beer! Very intense, full-bodied chocolate brown flavor. Dark brown color with full brown-tinged head. Not exactly a session brown like Newcastle, but certainly one of the finest beers I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 I think the commercial description is exactly right.  The Scotch smokiness is particularly unnerving when you consider how smooth and balanced this brew is.  For me, a great everyday beer -- ranks up there with Paps Mandarin Hef for perfect sun up/sun down beer.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2008 old rating:
7/3/8/4/16 - 3.8

pours a dark ruby with a small beige head, and good lacing.

smell is caramel, dark fruit, just a small touch of cocoa, and some spice.

taste is bitter-sweet chocolate, caramel apples, coffee, and roasted nuts, leaves the mouth dry and bitter, also ends a little sour too.

Pours dark brown with very little head.  Nose of fruits (raisins, chocolcate, alcohol). Tastes of alcohol is very evident, with malts and hops very noticeable.  A different but enjoyable beer that defies categorization. Suggestion-Since you cant drink too many of these anyway, power up the ABV to make this a strong ale.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle.  Thanks to my sister for hauling this up from Maryland for me.  Pours a deep dark brown, with a thin beige head.  Hoppy malted aroma.  A sip brings the flavor of hops and leaves a dry coffee-ish taste in the mouth.  My first Dogfish, and a good one.  Looking forward to trying 90 Minute.

im just gonna copy and paste something in to here....
Home > Brewers > Delaware > Dogfish Head Brewery >

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale

* picture credits
copyright may apply

	
	 Percentile 	

93
	overall	
	A Brown Ale brewed by
Dogfish Head Brewery

This is always one of my favorites, unlike most other browns out there.  Much more hoppy and dry tasting, which is great if you want to do a brown but dont need the sweetness.  As much as I enjoy 90 minute, this may be my favorite Dogfish beer.
Smells like dark roasted malts and strong hops. Taste is strong dark coffee, creamy with the perfect amount of hops for a brown.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 Pours a nice dark brown with a very small tan head that fades quickly.  Sweet mocha or chocolate aroma with a hint of hops.  Flavor of molasses, raisins, hops, and just a touch of alcohol.  Nice coffee and chocolate finish.  Dogfish Head scores again.
dark amber pour, molasses and raisen notes, great chocolate/coffee finish, love the added ginger as well. started to see more beers add ginger to their brews

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a whitish head.  Strong chocolate aroma, coffee.  Tastes chocolatey and sweet.
