I have to admit that when I first tasted this I truly thought I was drinking a stout (someone handed it to me in a glass and said "Drink this" and I drank obediently.) The only thing that would normally give it away as not being a stout is the lighter color.  Either way, its pretty damn good.  One of my favorite Dogfish Heads.

A darn brown almost black ale. Pours with little head. Little carbonation. The aroma is a little musty. The flavor is ok, and the carmelized onions really come through in the taste. Has a mellow aftertaste.
Huge surprise here. What a great brew, glad  I picked it up. Seems almost like a stout at first, thick brown head. Big caramel and chocolate notes.

Coffee and Chocolate aroma.  Thick creamy chocolatey head.  Very dark brown color.  Thick with an initial bite, smooths out and provides a satisfying finish.  This is a well crafted beer.  Would definately recommend.

Wow this was gooooood.  True to form, it poured a deep dark brown with a respectable tan head.  Aroma of hot chocolate and molasses.  Taste is full.  Very full.  Strong notes of chocolate, dark malts and caramel.  Alcohol very well hidden.  Almost more Porter like than a traditional brown ale.  Somewhat bitter and hoppy.  Perfect on almost any day with almost any food or cigar.  Wont be my last of these.

17-Jun-07 (12 oz bottle: Purchased 07-Jun-07 for $1.90 at Liquid Solutions in Tigard, OR) Assertive aromas of roasted malts, molasses, dark fruits, dark chocolate and coffee jump out of the glass and aggressively convey that this is no ordinary brown ale, though the beers name of Indian Brown Ale is also a strong hint.  On the palate, this is intensely flavored for a brown ale, with plenty of medium-dark roast, chocolate, brown sugar, sweet black fruits, and blackstrap molasses balanced by a good dose of moderately bitter, classic hop flavor, plus yeast notes and light tartness in the background for added complexity.  Other than the increased roasty bitterness in the long-lasting finish, this beer is fairly linear.  Medium-full bodied on the palate with medium carbonation.  Dark brown in color and fairly clear with ruby highlights toward the edge, this beer is capped by a small, light-tan head that dissolves to a wide ring and fails to leave behind anything more than a few spots of lace on the glass.  Dogfish Head has shown that brown ales can indeed be packed with full-throttle flavor, and complex enough for contemplative sipping.

A dark chocolate brown with a nice tan foamy head that slowly settles. The apperance reminded me a lot of a really good root beer. The aroma was very subtle to me. Nice fragrance, but nothing that really stood out. The taste was initially a nice hoppy bite and rolling flavors of roasted nuts, coffee and leaves a flavor of an aged wood charded barrel on the palate for a long lingering finish.  You cant go wrong with this one!
Had this in Atlanta on tap at Brick Store Pub.  I was super happy with this hybrid, as I have been with other Dogfish Head brews.  Hoppy and malty mellow at the same time.

Pours a nice chocolate brown with thin off-white head that lingers wewll and leaves okay lacing. Aroma is a sweet mix of caramel, toffee and roasted nuts, but the mouthfeel of this fairly thin bodied beer is somewhat watery. Flavor is a continuation of the sweet caramel and nuts, with a finish that is warming, but somewhat on the sweet and watery side for my liking.

Not a bad beer, but DFH makes better.

Caramelly chocolate nose.  Deep brown pour with an oily tanish head.  Light caramelly sweet body with a light tinge of hops all about.  Mouthfeel is quick and gone.  A bit watery at the end.  thanks to the slob.
Pours dark brown with rich creamy beige head; smells of earth and mild hops; taste w/ a well-hopped front taste and pleasant alcohol taste with earthy undertones; finishes strong and taste lingers on

Poured an attractive brown color with slight off-white head that begs to be drank. Aroma is of caramel and chocolate with a maltiness to it. Taste was also of caramel and chocolate with exceptional hop balance. Lacing was good. Mouthfeel was very pleasant. This was a really nice brown ale. What is there not to like? Good drinkability.
Bottle.  Pours thick and dark.  Heavy and malty, with slight hoppiness.  Drinkable, but not quaffable.  Not a big fan of brown ales personally.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2011 12 oz bottle. Wow, Ive had a few brown ales before and I am not a big fan, but this IBA was great. Pours dark dark brown body, aroma is light chocolate, caramel, and roastiness.  Taste is same...smooth too. Tasted more like a porter. Great beer. RERATE :: Draft at RnH with Linh. Pours a deep brown body with very slight lacing. Aroma is nutty, sweet malts, and a tad of alcohol. Mouthfeel is okay - similar notes in the flavor as in the aroma.

bottle.  wonderful.  pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head that lasts throughout.  chocolate, coffee and malts are the most prevalent.  medium body, low carbonation, sweet and full of flavor.  much better than your typical brown ale.  Dogfish delivers with this one... will definitely buy again... a pleasure to drink.

Bottle.  Its taken me surprisingly long to get around to rating this.  Chocolate and peat nose, dark slushy malt and hidden fruit, with roast coffee notes and a touch of alcohol.  Deep ruby pour nears pitch, with a soapy, creeping tanned head.  Taste alternatingly sweet and dry, edges closer to the latter, and thankfully avoids DFHs typical sugar.  Gritty dry notes ala a Scotch Ale, but the peat and swashy malt is missing.  Yeast and light nuttiness toward the finish.  Figs and raisins but without the sweetness of either.  Toasty malt with caramel and light hoppiness.  Chocolate and berry.  Medium body and lightly warming after a few ounces - of the really pleasant kind, in the chest and stomach only.  Touch of hoppy cottonmouth around the teeth, but its not so bad.  Goldings shining nicely in the aftertaste.  Pretty exceptional for a brown, though I agree with some below that its closer to a Doppelbock.
Dark brown with a decent head.  Nice caramel and malt aroma with a balanced flavor of hops and malts.  Good take to blend two styles.  Slight brown sugar taste as well.

Pours very dark with a fizzy beige head.  Aromas of nuts, molasses and a spicy hop bouquet.  Rich, porter-like flavors; a bit of molasses sweetness more than balanced by a hoppy finish.  A bit of a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. Really dark brown, almost black, thick tan head. Caramel and roasted coffee aroma. Theres a ton of nuts, coffee, and even powerful hops melding in this brown ale. It truly is a blend of styles making this a heavily infused brown ale. Im not normally a brown fan, but this is the best one Ive ever had.

12oz bottle. Fantastic near black pour with malty roasted nose.  First sip, sooo much going on at once...  Grassy hops, roasted Malts, and some Alc tang  having an orgy in my mouth.  Smooth finish.  Medium bodied, well carbonated, it wants to be drank.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear very dark brown body under a fleeting fizzy light brown head that completely vanished immediately.  Aroma is a nice blend of nutty, slightly husky malt and a hefty amount of hoppiness.  A little coffee and cola notes also.  A very unusual Brown Ale, lots of nuttiness and coffee but the hops of an IPA.  Its missing some of the depth that that might be there because of the filtration though.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a slightly oily texture and moderate fizzy carbonation.  Pretty nice for a Brown Ale, and quite distinctive.  I can only imagine what a nice bottle conditioned version would be.  Its been a long time since Ive had one of these and it was nice to revisit it.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2008 barley brew feels and almost tastes like chocolate. there is a slight more toasted flavor here. the brew is quite velvety with its light brown cap. coffee flavor not really present in my bottles. looks all deep brown and lucsious. cant easily discern the hop character but, i could easily tell if it was unbalanced sooo... this is a good brew. what else do you expect from dogfish head! CANDY SWEET well hopped great for this time of year!

Dark dark ruby-brown with some bubbles and a medium sized light tan head.  Aroma of toffee.  First flavor is of strong bitter hops quickly washed away by very sweet malt.  Has some coffee and raisin.  Burnt malt aftertaste.  Sticky palate, fizzy carbonation.    I dont know what to make of this... I see the scotch ale and IPA sides... but as a brown ale this is intense.
Poured a reddish brown with fizzy light tan head.  Roasted malt, chocolate, hops, a little bit of fruit, and molasses.  Medium mouthfeel.  Pretty decent brown ale, but nothing special.

dark brown with  a loose tan head that doesnt stick around for too long. great molasses pine ginger light chocolate aroma with some light raisin notes. sweet molasses bitter spicy pine and ginger and some sweet raisin and chocolate notes. very nice sweet molasses chocolate finish with some spicy pine and ginger and a touch of raisin. medium almost full bodied with nice lively carbonation. well done. interesting interpretation of a brown ale.

[Bottle] Pours brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma is honey, roasted malt, coffee, brown sugar.  Could be a little stronger, but quite pleasant.  Taste is largely malt with the roasted character coming out in the long finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Quite highly carbonated.  Pretty nice.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with just a very thin off white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is heavy on roasted malts, with a lot of coffee and some faint hops and alcohol.  Nice sweet malt upfront, with some raisin which gives way to a roasty and hoppy finish.  Not too bad.
This is by far one of my favorites..this is a nice hoppy brown ale that you can taste the brown sugar in

Pours extremely dark for a brown ale.  Preety hoppy  on the nose.  This has a nice sweetness, but it comes off more like a porter.  I can taste the thick alcoholic notes that are caused by the brown sugar.  This is a good brew, and the black coffee notes reminds me of a good quality stout.  Even though I think this is mislabeled, its a good brew
Draft. Dark, lovely, and delicous, almost a stout. Lots of caramel and coffeeish flavor, mild hoppiness, not too terribly heavy for what it is.
Very clean and smooth with an aftertaste of coffee and caramel.  Great effort.

Jana took me out for a few beers after work @ the winking lizard Friday night.  Nose of vanilla & licorice, coffee, berries (dried), and flowers.  Pours a walnut with garnet highlights.  The tall mostly lasting creamy beige head leaves a nice sheet of sticky lace.  The brew tastes mostly of roasted espresso, has decent acidity, and finishes with a roasted and somewhat fruity quality with notes of anise.  The medium body is soft & creamy.  The finish feels very dry.  Thanks again Jana.
Deep brown body with a small tan head. Chocolate, dark fruits, followed by bitter, dry finish. Interesting but just OK.
Poured a nice dark brown color with an off white head.  Had a nice aroma of malt and coffee.  Could taste some hops in the flavor and on the palate with a nice sweet finish.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Fruity roasted malty caramel aroma with some hoppy hints. Roasted malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Roasted malty finish with a bitter aftertaste.

Reminds me of a lighter stout - strong smells of caramel, coffee, and malt. Fizzy texture like most browns; however, not as carbonated as my latest additions on the forum/blog. Dry bitter finish. A favorite.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2007. Reddish black beer with a sweetish and malty aroma and a malty and vinous flavour.  Overall a nice malty, sweet and fortified beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark brown color with a small creamy beige head.  The aroma is sweet caramel malts with an additional roasted character.  The flavor is medium sweet with caramel, molasses, roasted malts, and bitterness at the end.  Medium bodied.  Another interesting take on a standard style by Dogfish Head.

This one was a nice surprise.  Bottle poured dark brown with a smallish tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee.  Taste is sweet brown sugar and molasses, nice malty sweetness, finishing more bitter and alcoholic when the hops kick in.  Well-balanced and very drinkable.
Great beer some sweetness caramelized malt notes and bitterness in the finish from a bottle at the Olympic. Refreshing beer for late summer.
A real savouring brew.  Slowly sip this in the brisk fall days and taste the smooth rich full flavor the roasted malt and hops.  Yum!
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 More like a mixed scotch drink than beer. Good stuff though. I prefer the Bells by just a tad because of its sweatness.

Pours dark brown, medium head with some nice lacing.  Sweet dark candy aroma.  I would say caramel, but its darker than that, more roasted.  Slight noble hop aroma.  Flavor is sweet with huge, dominating presence of the caramelized brown sugar.  Not nearly enough hop bitterness to balance the sweet roasted flavor and syrupy mouthfeel.  Almost felt like I was drinking molasses.  Not what I expected at all.
brownish purple in color. Lots of malt in this one.. and fairly sweet. Toffee and caramel. This is pretty flavorful, but maybe a bit too sweet and not quite pulled together.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma:Brown sugar sweet with caramel malts and spicy hops present in the background
Appearance:Clear dark brown with a decent head that could have lingered longer but laced nicely
Flavor:Caramel malts and brown sugar sweet nicely balanced by the hops that were present.  Alcohol was there but not overly so
Palate:Sweet at first with bitterness coming on and lingering at the roof of the mouth.  Nice
Overall:Another solid offering from what is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries

From bottle : Nice aroma, coffe, sweet malts and hints of the hops.  Pours dark brown with finger offwhite head that doesnt last very long.  Flavor of some coffee, malts, and at the end hops, the aftertaste is hoppy as well.   Medium bodied, kinda creamy on the palate.  Note my favorite brown ale, a little different, but not bad.

WOOOO beer 100 for me. after taking a sip my first thought was, wow this is a great beer. pours light brown with 2 finger tan head. smell was caramelized sugar, light hops, and malt. the taste was a mix of sweet brown sugar, than coffee almost stout like for a second than finishes with medium lasting hops. chocolate and bittersweet. a very flavorful brown ale.
8/29/05. 12oz. Clear brown with large creamy tan head. Burnt sugar aroma with some hop in background. Mild understated malty nutty flavor.

Poured from a bottle.  Poured a deep brown color with a thin khaki head.  Aroma of chocolate.  Initial hit of roasted chocolate malts has some nutty undertones that transition into a lightly hopped finish.  Really nice brown.
This is possibly my favorite beer out of Dogfish.  Lots of flavor for a brown.  Not too bitter but delicious.  GREAT FINISH.  I buy it every time I see it and will continue to do so.

Dark brown color with a sweet and malty aroma.  The alcohol is a prominent component in the flavor profile, which I like.  The only drawback, if there is one, is the strange lingering aftertaste, which could be eliminated with the appropriate accompanying meal (molasses cookies).
I really liked this one.  Pretty brown pour with a light tan head.  Chocolate aroma.  Slight floral hops taste with full mouth of chocolate and nuts.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 
Date: August 19, 2000
Mode: Bottle
Source: Total Beverage, DC
Appearance: hazy brown, whispy tan head
Aroma: rich candy sweet malt aroma
Flavor: well balanced complex malt flavor, light bitter finish, dogfish house character from the bottle
Overall: a clean well hopped brown ale with aromatic barley, carmelized brown sugar, and whole leaf liberty and goldings hops, 7.2%

Date: April 10, 2007
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Score: 3.1 to 3.2
Aroma: lightly sweet nutty chocolate aroma
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor well balalnce with an earthy and citrus hop blend
Overall: rich and flavorful but more brown than IPA

Date: September 10, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: summits woodstock
picking up more of the hops in the aroma but flavor is still on the brown ale side but well balanced with plenty of hops, 

Date: October 14, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: summits woodstock
chocolate flavor is coming through big time, hops have a light citrus character but are taking the back seat, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Very carbonated, dark brown head disappears immediately, deep brown-red. Aroma is subdued, roasted, musty, raisins, caramel,. Initially bracingly bitter, coffee malt flavor develops, fine bittersweet medium-long finish, a sweet brown sugar/chocolate flavor lingers. Very good.

Bouteille 12 oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur brune rouge foncée et transparente. Nez de malt rôti, de caramel toffee, moyen de chocolat et de noix, léger de houblon herbeux et aux notes terreuses, de biscuits ainsi que des notes boisées, de sucre brun, de fruits (petites notes de raisins), dalcool doux et également des traces dépices (anis) et de café. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse et aux petites notes sirupeuses. Moyen goût fruité (léger de raisins, notes de prunes) accompagné dun léger goût épicé (réglisse noire) et de notes boisées lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût moyennement amer de malt rôti, de caramel toffee, moyen de chocolat noire et avec des notes de mélasse et de sucre brun puis en finale lon retrouve un goût dalcool doux et réchauffant, de houblon assez herbeux et aux notes terreuses ainsi quun léger goût de café et un moyen goût de noix asséchantes.  Post-goût long-moyen et un peu sec, moyennement amer de rôti, de houblon herbeux (notes terreuses), léger de café, de noix et dalcool doux avec des notes de chocolat et de fruits (moût de raisins) ainsi que des traces boisées.

Bottle in Jul 07 - part of the stamp rubbed off.  This pours very brown with a beige head that dissolves fast.  The molasses aroma comes across strong.  A heavy mouth feel.  The brew tastes more smoky than hoppy.  Overall I liked it.

Bottle.  Rich deep brown with carbonated head.  Roasted smell, almost reminds me of the smell of burning however. It smells and tastes like burning.  Slightly bitter smell and taste.  It dries out the mouth.  Can begin to taste the alcohol as it warms - not my favorite thing.  Almost seems flat on the palate.  I think this beer tastes like AA Meeting Coffee - bitter, burned and unenjoyable.

Strong roasted malt aroma with some hops.  Dark brownish red body with a tan head.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolaty, light woodiness, mild hops balance. Sweetish but balanced.  Creamy palate with dry finish and a light bite.  Rich but even.  Strong roasty flavors but not overdone.  A very good brown ale.
Coffee and chocolate aroma. Dark amber color with a medium dark head. Starts slightly bitter with a scotch like taste. Finishes very light not much taste.

Cask gravity @ GBBF 2007, London. Medium brown color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, raosted, caramel, licorice. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration. Nice balance. Body is medium to full, texture is creamy, carbonation is flat.

Poors a dark, reddish brown with a thick, dingy brown head.  Aroma was understated, but mostly caramel and malt with a slight hint of coffee.  Taste is a splash of hops with some sweetness, lots of malt and hints of chocolate and syrup.  Hops mingle well with this semi-sweetness giving both bitterness and sweetness in turns.  Nice tingly mouth-feel and a surprisingly refreshing finish for a relatively meaty beer.
Nose is hoppy and malty, deep copper, small tan head. Flavour of rich malt, hops and woody too. Medium bodied, well balanced. Great little beer! Thanks Radek kliber.
Robust but not overpowering.  Good companion for hearty summer meals.  Malty with coffee and dark chocolate notes.  Rich brown color.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark brown colour, mediumszied beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, and some fruity hops. Flavour is alcohol, malts and hops in a mix, where alcohol is quite aggressive.

On tap at the Collins Pub. Chocolate and anise aroma. Same in the taste with the chocolate really coming through. Didnt get tons of hops in this, but it was so drinkable that I couldnt keep the glass on the table.

Cask-GBBF. Dark brown with a small head. Rich malt aroma, with toffee an biscuit, and a hint of pine. Roast and malty flavour, with a dry and slightly bitter finish. Im disappointed that it wasnt hoppier - perhaps it comes out better in the bottled version than this specially made cask version.
12 oz. bottle. dark brown with a smallish light brown head. mildly hoppy throughout, with a sweet finish. I enjoyed this, and will keep some around.

[12oz Bottle] Dark, mahogany brown with an off-white creamy head--great retention. Aroma consists mainly of roasted malt, some chocolate and coffee.
Flavor is well-balanced throughout! There is a nice blend of front hop notes (acidic) with a caramel, malty body. The clean yeast comes through on this one nicely. Malt is predominantly roasty--and hops, though faintly, are detected throughout; alcohol presence near the end. Palate is more thin than I would expect and flavors dissipate rather quickly. Im not a huge brown ale fan--but this one keeps it interesting enough for me.

Bottle. Dark brown, very little head. Aroma was slight carmel, chocolate & coffee. Flavor was the same but well done and subtle. Short palate, as flavors didnt linger, not a bad thing, just different.

Cask, GBBF 2007.  Very dark brown with a small head.  Aromas are chocolate and Winter fruit with caramel, wheat and spices.  Burnt toast and mollasses with alcohol.  Flavours are malty with chocolate and caramel.  Some coffee notes.  Vinous, viscous and rich.  Smooth and tasty.
12 oz bottle shared with fordest and toncatcher. I am not a big brown ale fan, but this one is done well. Very tasty and sort of sweet.

12 oz bottle thanks to Secret Santa.  Brown on the pour as expected.  Decent head.  Aromas were chocolate and some coffee with a touch of hoppiness and some metallic too.  Flavors were more malty with none of the Metal from the aroma.  Some citrusy hops on the finish, but not a lot.  Pretty good stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2008 Cask GBBF ... near black ... lovely sweet rich sweetie toffee nose ... sweet rich fruit malts ... toffee and coffee ... mellow and rounded. THe best of the US casks at GBBF. Would love to try again.... 4.2 Tk2 Bottle... nice  but not the same as the cask ... Deep brown ... rich woddie malt nose... rich toffee ... again woody ... a little burnt malt ... caramilzed suger... 3.4 shame its didnt like up to theCask but its still not bad .

Ruby/brown with decent head.  Nice smokey malt aromas, quiet caramel, sugar and chocolate scents combine to produce a delicious nutty aroma, with whispers of floral hops.  Hoppy smoke tastes roll around the mouth as well as some deep roasted nut, chocolate and earthy flavors.  The beginning reminds me of an IPA with a distant smokey finish reminiscent of a scoth ale.  A nice brew

12 oz. btl. pours deep mahogony brown with a light tan head that tightens with time. Aroma of fruit and toffee. Starts  out withdark caramel/toffee malt sweet flavor then lends way to a floralness uncharacteristic a a brown, and finishes with a nice dark mollasses soft finish. medium to heavy body.

Pours a dark brown with a small light brown head.  Smells of mostly dark fruits, with just the slightest traces of some roast.  Very malty characters to it as well.  The taste is much more roastier than the aroma.  Very nutty, malty roast, with the dark fruits more in the background and masked somewhat.  The finish is more of a bitter roast which I really didnt care for.  The aftertaste is toasted malts and very light chocolate.  Decent brown, but slightly overrated in my opinion.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very strong aroma, molasses, soya, salty. Dark brown color, light brown head, fair lace. Very sweet, salty soya, chocolate. Thick and syrupy. Strange brew, especially if its considered to be a brown ale.

What is this beer? Its called a brown ale. It has the richness and fullness of a porter. It has the hops of a mild pale ale. I dont know what it is, but I like it. Very well done. As others say, dark red/brown color that looks black until you hold it up to the light. Taste is dark roasted malt/coffee/chocolate like a stout/porter. Crisp hops add nice balance. Very good beer for standing besides the grill, which is exactly where I had it!

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 A Mes rate: 
Gravicask at GBBF. Very dark brown with no head at all. Nutty, brown sauce aroma with a malty background. Uninspiring brown ale flavour. Nutty, a little sauce and vinegar etc. etc. No real body to it. Watery palate. Whatever.
Bottle Dark pour with off white head and decent lacing. Aroma of hops, caramel, malt. Flavor follows with higher complexity. Very well balanced between hops, malts, and other flavors. Great brew.

Cask at Great British Beer Festival 07. Very dark brown with a small off white head. Coffee aroma. taste has liquorice, coffee, dark fruits and some alcohol. Low bitterness. Quite liked this, though I thought it was a bit predictable.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 Great hoppy brown ale.  Sticky mouthfeel with sweet bitter taste.  While Im not sure molasses describes it, its definitely got a sweet sticky mouthfeel and flavor.  The aroma is sweet.  Chocolate, roasted malt like a big stout.  Very good brown.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2007 If you like to visit Starbucks you will love this beer; the taste of coffee is very heavy with light accents of chocolate and burnt hops.  The finish isnt as strong as some of the other beers Dogfish Head has produced (some are almost overwhelming) but it is just strong enough. Very interesting beer from a very interesting brewery.  

Please note: I would have given this beer a higher score but I dont really care for coffee.

Fantastic blend drink; Malt-to-spare with enough of everything else to round out the character. Love the complex, woody vanilla, sweet malt base. Brown-sugary sweet. Heavy mouthfeel. Somewhat roasted. Smooth and creamy with a hint of a hop finish. Outstanding.

Bottle...I cant believe Im just now trying this beer. It is excellent, very complex, with flavors of milk chocolate, coffee, vanilla, accented by a moderate hop presence. Color is opaque, with a cream colored head. Perhaps my favorite from DFH thus far.
Thanks to Juancho.  Pours into a very dark brown color with a nice head.  Definitely a malty beer, and some hops at the end.  Sweet with coffee and raisin notes.

Bottle from Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a clear garnet-brown with a frothy, tan head. Slightly nutty, toasted malts on the nose with notes of cookie dough and faint earthy hops. Medium to full-bodied, slick and lightly metallic and bitter. The flavor is a solid toasted malt front, some caramel and light chocolate and coffee notes with an earthy hop backing leading to a lightly dry and spicy/bitter finish. Just a hint of "warmth" at the finish. One of the better browns that Ive sampled.

Bottle- A fine brew with so much complexity, it is hard to catagorize. A brown ale??? Ehhh. Not so sure. At first taste, you might think it a porter due to the prominent roasted/coffee/chocalte flavor. Or is it an ipa because there is some hop flavor there. A great complex brew with some well hidden alcohol that I will go back to.

Super smooth....a great tasting beer.  Giving it a good rating because its good, but by no means phenomenal.  Certainly could drink this a bunch. 

Aroma consisted of a moderate amount of malt, roasted coffee and chocolate.  Toffee and maybe a bit of cherry when it was a bit colder.   Pours a nice creamy head, and the taste is nothing but smooth.

350 mL bottle.  Dark brown with ruby highlights and a small fizzy off white head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, and brown sugar as advertised.  Great mellow taste of chocolate, molasses, hints of dark fruit and sugar.  Very good.
Ooh, wow!  Succulent sweetness.  See description for the details and mixture of what it is, but wow!.  Goes superb with a steak.  A year round offering sampled from the Dogfishead sampler.  Look out!
Poured no head and dark brown. Smells of wood and roasted barley malt. Tastes of malt, some cocoa, grass, barley, and assorted nuts. Medium carbonation and full-bodied. Not bad.

Bottle.  Wow, what a unique beer.  Pours a deep brown with a tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, malt, hops, and a bit of rye.  Taste is chocolate up front fading into a bit of malt with a nice hop bitterness at the end.  Very smooth on the mouth and a well-done beer overall.
I felt this beer had an increbily creamy taste which i did not care for much. But this beer had a very rich and bold appearance.
Small head, nice sweetness. Reminds me of a bock/doppel. Interesting to say the least.

Draught at d.b.a. Dark brown colour. Small beige coarse head. Appley and nutty aroma. Bold rounded hop flavour. Notest of oxidization and a sherry-like note. Nutty flavours with hints of roasted malts. Rounded and rich.

Bottle from Whole Foods dated 05/08/07. Pours a nice dark brown color with a nice looking off-white/beige head. Smell of sweet chocolate. Has a nice malty chocolate taste whith a good hop bite. Finishes off clean with a nice trailing hop flavor. Probably my favorite brown ale. Have had this on draft before at the Flying Saucer and I look forward to when I can get it.

Poured a dark brown color with creamy tan head that left behind good lacing. The aroma was of chocolate, roasted malts, some coffee and hops. The taste was roasty from the chocolate and malts with a nice hop bitterness in there as well. The hops and malts balanced each other really well and left a nice flavor behind. It was medium bodied and really easy to drink. The finish was chocolate and hops. A really good brown ale, one of my favorites.
Bottle. A good hoppy brown ale. A mild to heavy body, but not too hard to drink. A creamy tan head.

Bottle: pours a clear but very dark brown with amber highlights. Thin and creamy off white head that sticks around the whole glass. Not much aroma but hints of malt and earthy hops. Flavor is malty with some carmel and roasty notes. Moderate bitterness and earthy dirty hop flavors. Not sure i like the blend of hops and roasted flavor. Medium slightly creamy mouthfeel helps.

Bottle, bottled on 10-31-05, these are my notes from 12-18-06, the bottle was over a year old.  Pours brown with a small fizzy off-white head which fades away quickly leaving no lacing.  The aroma is very nice, roasted caramel with some nuttyness.  The flavor is very nice too, brown sugar, maple syrup and molasses along with some chocolate.  The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and lively carbonation.

This beer is just everything!  The discripition says a cross between a scotch ale, IPA and American Pale but it pours like a porter/stout!  Its dark amber/black, and thick.  Great smell, chocolate/coffee smell.  What a great smell!  Chocolate/coffee, very smooth.

The color was a deep brown with red hues.  It was very dark for a brown ale.  The head was creamy, light beige, and frothy.  The aroma was some roast and raisin.  The flavor was very nice for a brown ale.  It was very roasty with some nut.  The palat was medium bodied and the finish, roasty.
bottle.  black/cranbeery pour with frothy off white head.  fresh hop, nutty aroma.  coffee, nutty, rich malts.  nice hoppy balance.  slightly bitter finish

First tried on draft at Dogfish Head Brewings & Eats, Rehoboth Beach, DE.  Then took a 6-pack home.  Ill rate the 12 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown with a medium tan head, dissipates pretty quick...smell is rather toasty of brown sugar and malt...taste of caramel and a bit of coffee notes, hint of hops in the background...medium body.  Nice lacing.  Pretty robust for an ale.  I really enjoyed this one at DFH...Im glad I brought some home.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2009 pours a dark nutty brown with nice lacing that stayed. smell is dark malts, coffee, and bakers chocolate. taste is malts and coffee, rather smooth but not really a brown ale almost a stout. really nice one and would be excellent on tap.
Nice brew. Just about right combination of hop bitterness, brown sugar sweetness and roasted malt. DFH is not my favorite brewer (thats Bells), but they are so creative, I keep buying their beers.

12oz - bottled on 1/16/07 - Aroma of toasted brown sugar and chocolate.  Pours dark brown with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with a lot of chocolate in the finish and a touch of raisin sneaking in.  Palate is sweet and sticky.  A unique and tasty brew.

For me the aroma is chocolate. Some sort of dark carmelized malt as well. Dark mahogany color, approaching opaque. The beige head came and went rapidly. Thin to medium bodied. Frothy carbonation. Starts with coffee, a little caramel, then more coffee. As the coffee leaves, there is more caramel. There is a nice bitter, but not too dry, finish. Very tasty. Not your mothers brown ale. 50 IBU? Could be, but all that coffee provides enough bitter, so its not necessarily 50 IBU from hop. Just wonder where the chocolate that generated the aroma went. The chocolate aroma fades too. Quite a drink.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2009 Dark brown with decent, creamy head / Medium, creamy body with big hop boost / Nose of molasses and roast coffee / Sharp, winey flavors of raisins, tobacco, molasses, coffee and ginger, and roast coffee finish / Terrific, though more like a porter or even a dry stout.
xxx Dogfish head is a great brewery, cant go wrong with what they make.Good beer

Pours out dark with a big off white head. Bitter, malty, sugary aroma. Very smooth with a little bitterness to even things out. This beer has a great dark, slightly sweet ale taste that is just so unique. It is very easy drinking and just a wonderful overall beer.

ndian Brown is dry and stout-like in its acidic finish and lightly bitter aftertatste. But then Dogfish Head makes so many beers that are slightly off style. Bottom line is that this is a tasty, interesting brown-stout-IPA-Scotch. Small to average light brown head. Clear body that is dark brown. Heavy aroma of molasses, roasted malts, nuts and leather with a hint of licorice. The flavor is moderately sweet and heavily acidic with a moderately bitter (and slightly metallic) finish. Medium body and fizzy carbonation. Warming alcohol.

12 oz bottle. Poured a deep dark brown with some red highlights and a small light brown head. Lots of raosted malt aroma with some notes of chocolate and brown sugar. Lots of roasted malts in the flavor with a fair bit of sweetness too. This is a great brown ale and one of my favorites.

12 oz botttle. Poured a dark brown with small tan head. Average mouthfeel, not dry, but not oily either. The taste was a real pleasant surprise. Tastes of molasses, coffee, malts, brown sugar. Seems more like a porter to me. I didnt pick up much in the way of hops. Finish was not bitter. I picked up a sixer of this for $7.99. Im going back for more.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 Roast, whiskey, and molasses aroma.  Dark black-brown with thin head.  Carmel, whiskey, and notes of hops.  Hoppy bitter start to finish.

Can DFH save me from a world of boring brown ales?  12oz single bottle.  Pours a dark ruby without much head but lots of little bubbles.  Light aroma of malt - not off to a great start yet.  Ah, but the taste is better than the smell.  Heavy on the malts and a lot of flavour overall.  Im getting some roasted coffee flavours.  In a blind taste test, Im sure I would have mistaken this for a porter.

Interesting, but not great. Very dark brown. Nose of molasses, coffee, and prunes. Roasted malt and hop bitterness attack hard and dig in. Some caramelized flavor, but not enough. Notes of molasses, raisins, and chocolate get overwhelmed by French-roast coffee. The texture is too thin to support the roastiness--a beer like this needs to be thick and creamy like a stout. Indeed, the predominant flavors are stout-like. This beer lacks finesse. Its highly rated because of its punch.

(Bottle) Pours a deep brown color with a nice tan head. Flavor of roasted malts, some coffee, burnt caramel and raisins. Sweet finish, which really extended the bitter aftertaste. The alcohol is well disguised in here. Very good palate, and fine carbonation. A unique brew!

Bottle: Pours, as one might expect, dark brown, with a light brown head. The head quickly dissipates. As I begin to smell the beer, I notice a bit of a dark nuttiness, but the thing that struck me the most was what appeared to be a hint of something almost like lemon in the background. The taste is a bit of dry, bitter coffee. Just a bit on the nutty side, with a hint of hops biting at the tongue. The taste is a bit a nice bitter sweet, not overpowering. This is pretty easy drinking, but a bit high on the carbonation.
Really nice color. Deep brown with little head. Smells of coffee and cocca. Taste is muted raisin, plenty of malt, and some sweet caramel. An excellent brown ale...top notch.
Dark ruddy brown, thin foam.  Lots of caramel and molasses aroma.  Flavor is more balanced, some bitterness and spice balancing the sweetness.  Thin to medium body, long bittersweet finish.
Dark brown color with off-white head.  Bread and alcohol in the nose.  Mollases, nuts, and raisins in the body Faint chocolate and coffee on the finish.  Hops floating around in there as well.

Bottled 9-18-06. Dark brown with tinges of red, topped by a thin-medium tan head. Aroma of raisin bread, cookie, and alcohol. Generously malted and hopped (as expected from DFH). Nutty, brown sugar sweetness. A little soy sauce. Big body, smooth and almost syrupy. On the back end of each gulp to the finish to retronasal is BIG time banana (and apparently Im the only one that notices this). Good beer in an otherwise underwhelming style.
nice dark ruby color. Intresting malt sweet fruits and choc nose, spicy roasted malt, lotsa bitterness, some alcohol, great brown ale

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2007 Dark brown/black pour with a nice tan head.  Smell is hops, some roasty malt, maybe almost a light licorice, and coffee smell, along with some smokiness as well as it warms up.  Taste is very rich, full bodied and flavorful, but still carbonated well and not too heavy or creamy.  The 7.2% alcohol is hidden well and its very drinkable.  Some definite bitter/burnt tastes noticeable, but overall it is very unique and well done.  Like most of their beers, different and tasty.

I was expecting a seriously hopped brown ale, like something from Surly.  But there are hardly any hops at all.  But this is still a solid beer.  More of a Scottish rather than a Scotch ale.  It isnt sweet enough to be a Scotch, and lacks the fruit, sweet malt, and vinous qualities common to those beers.  But there is abundant malt.  The malt is a little bitter, but balanced by prominent brown sugar and just a little raisin.  The coffee and ginger are not perceptible.  Very dark brown, good palate.  A little bit nutty in the finish.

There I was, last weekend, talking about beer, and bemoaning the fact that I cant find a decent brown ale back home in Atlanta. 

And BAM, what shows up in the cooler at Once Upon a Vine during my roadtrip to Richmond, but Dogfish Heads Indian Brown Ale!

Appearance: Poured out a crystal clear dark-reddish brown color with a khaki-colored head recedes to a thin band around the glass.

Smell: Chockablock scent full of sweet satisfaction - hazlenut coffee, brown sugar, and candied dark fruits. 

Taste: The flavor of this brown ale is so far superior that it barely warrants mentioning, but Ill do my best. A rich, assertive malt base charges the tongue. Fiendishly sweet flavor suggesting coffee, toasted nuts, and cooked caramel (which carries with it a delicate smokiness). A restrained herbal hop bitterness allows the malts to really shine through. Finishes with a lasting roastiness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Light on the carbonation, keeping this brew singularly smooth and creamy.

Drinkability: Yeah, to sum up: Dogfish Heads Indian Brown Ale is strikingly drinkable and incredibly tasty! For me, that was enough, but the beer is unique and clever and well done enough that any fans of the style should check it out.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2009 Bottle. Toasted malt aromas jump out the moment you pour this beer. Heavy smells of dark bread, nuts and a bit of coffee. A very light citrus and leather smell with a little smoke in the background. Head is rocky, off white with fair lacing and its mostly diminishing. Color is dark brown. Flavor starts off moderately sweet and the long finish is moderately bitter and a touch acidic. Palate is medium, oily with lively carbonation and both lightly astringent and alcoholic in the finish. Another great Dogfish Head creation.

Sweet toasted caramel.  Pours black with a nice thick foamy tan head.  Full somewhat sweet toasted caramel flavor with a little tiny bitter ending.  Frothy, crisp on the palate with a small warm ending.  A pleasant warming and drinkable ale.  This brown is a great brew to have hanging around your beer frig.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 First taste 6/1/07.  Pours dark redish-brown with a very small tan head with minimal lacing.  The aroma is that of coffee, roasted malt, a fair bit of alcohol, and more hops than I expected.  The taste follows suit, but also folds in a bit of sweet chocolate and even some hazelnut.  The hops give a nice finish to balance out the sweetness....something I think alot of brown ales lack.  The melding of excellent flavors and aromas, and most importantly the unique sharp finish, make this an excellent brown in my book.  Strong recommendation.

The pour begets a beauty of an ale that is mahogany colored, with a halo of ruby, and a thin tan head.  The smell of freshly baked pumpernickel bread and molasses wafts up from the glass.  Upon drinking, the mouthfeel is adequately heavy, with a softness and silkiness that is unexpected.

Many flavors are present, some moreso than others.  The most prominent are that of a dark bread, rye or pumpernickel, that is lightly toasted (the toastedness lends itself to an even lighter roastedness); molasses; brown sugar; a hint of raisin; and a minor alcohol edge.

A great example of a brown ale, and a reminder of why I like the style overall.
Bottle.  Chocolate malt aroma with slight hint of pepper.  Dark brown with small head.  White pepper and chocolate malt flavor.  Very different - a spicy brown ale.

This beer is quite good. From a bottle, the first sip was a bit of a surprise as I hadnt noticed the alcohol content. A nice sweet aroma and hoppy flavor. Seems more like a porter to me. Definitely will get this again.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.  Pours with a deep brown with red highlights and a rapidly collapsing tan head that laces the glass nicely.  I notice an aroma of citrus and coffee and some indistinct spice.  Slightly bitter up front then fades to chocolate, more coffee and ever-so-lightly burned toast.  Finishes with warming alcohol and quenching hop bitterness.  A great offering from Dogfish Head.
Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Burgundy color with thin off-white head.  Aroma is of malty molasses with some roastedness.  Flavor is pretty bitter and hoppy with a long, dry finish.

This is an amazing beer. I wa scared off by the almost ten dollar price tag, but finally took the plunge. The aroma and taste are very different, which I love. Smoky aroma with a sweet and hoppy taste meld superbly.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2008 There is a moderately strong aroma of oak and cedar. It is dark mahogany brown with a thin yellow head and coated the glass rather nicely. The flavor is robust and strong with a great balance of smoke and hops. Blackberry is also noted. It finishes with more smoke and dark choclate which lingers a while, but not too much. It was perhaps a bit too smoky. Id say it is rather stoutish, but very pleasant. Finally, a DfH that lives up to its reputation!

Pour was a cola-like brown with an off-white, two-finger tall head.  Some lacing, nothing spectacular.  The aroma was very malty initially.  As the beer opened up aromas of coffee, sugar and even some faint chocolate came through.  The flavor was very nice.  Roasted malt and coffee with hints of brown sugar and chocolate.  Nice hops give it a solid, dry finish.  Slick mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  Best example of this style Ive ever had.

Pours a dark, but clear, brown with a medium-sized tan head consisting of very fine bubbles. The head leaves some lace and subsides into a thin ring around beer where it touches the glass with some slight tan clouds over the surface. The aroma is very nice and sweet: lots of malts, toffee, and brown sugar with some notes of roasted grain and a little alcohol. The flavor starts very roasty and porter-like. The middle of the tongue finds lots of sweet malts, toasted bread, molasses, and caramel. Towards the back of the tongue the flavor of alcohol is apparent. The beer finishes medium in body with a very bitter end. The after-taste is bitter from both hops and from dark grains. The mouthfeel is light and dry and tickles the tongue with a decent amount of carbonation. It tastes more like a robust porter than a brown ale - but is, overall, exceptional.

dark amber with hints of read color. slight chocolate flavor with hints of nuts. hoppy taste with malts. my biggest peeve of this beer was the strong alocoholic aftertaste, which reminded me of vodka rather than scotch. maybe i had an old batch i dont know. overall pretty decent brown. would probably give it a second chance.
On tap at Manny Browns Neshaminy.  Pours dark brown with a minimal tan head.  Chocolately, hoppy aroma.  Malty in taste, with a mild molasses sweetness.  Really enjoyed this beer.

From a 12 oz. bottle with a bottling date on the neck of bottle, sampled at cellar temperature in a pint glass.

Poured a clear, deep reddish hued brown with a foamy, creamy pale tan head, good retention, small amount of ringed sticking.

Earthy, herbal and floral hoppy nose with a roasted nutty and dry chocolate malty backing.

Good carbonation and a crisp, dryish, textured, smooth medium bodied mouthfeel, very nice.

This one is an easy drinker, lightly roasted malts, bitter chocolate, nutty and caramelized sugar, assertive hops, herbal oily and floral leafy, a brisk, balancing bitterness, a soft black currant fruitiness that meshes with the alcohol that provides a low temperature warmth in the palate, and a dry herbal, leafy, roasted malty finish.

A very enjoyable American Brown Ale, another interesting beer from DFH.
on tap @ Coles Buffalo NY Brown ale with sweet malts & nice hop backbone. Confuses the palate with all the different charateristics. Starts like a scotch, then Hops then smooth Dark malt finish
Pours dark brown with minimal head...I enjoyed this beer...fairly syrupy wit a nice balance of hops and malt

Pours a dark brown color with small creamy tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and hops. Taste, the hops and malts crash together causing a vinus reaction. Finishing with a malty roasty coffee & chocolate aftertaste. Medium Body and Carbonation.
dark brown pour with hops and malt in the aroma...alittle werid because of the hops and the malt together but def a good beer all around

Bottle.  Small, light-khaki colored, somewhat creamy head w/ good lacing.  Clear dark brown cola colored.  Aromas of chocolate, molasses, light  sweet coffee, and light hops.  Flavor:  okay the hops should have been more apparent in the aroma, cause it is very apparent in taste.  Light metalic flavor in the finish.  I have found that I am not the biggest fan of brown ales but the kick from the hops makes this one an enjoyable one.

Dark translucent brown with medium tan head. Nice hoppy and malty aroma, but very light. Hops and malts make an awkward mixture creating a bitter and sour flavor. The sweet brown sugar is a nice touch though. Not the greatest.
Smells of coffee and chocolate and pours nice dark brown... plenty of malts and coffee in the flavor with a good bitter finish..

Another success by these folks at DFH.  This brown ale has a fine aroma that seems to change over time.  it had a good firm head and the flavor offers a typical cocoa and coffee with nice feel of bitterness.  It has a great textural feeling in the mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown/amber with a one finger light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, molasses, and light chocolate. Taste is malty and sweet with notes of caramel and roasted malt but then lends way to a slightly harsh bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and slight alcohol warmth. Different for a Brown Ale but good.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2007 Aroma roasted and hoppy.  Very complex flavour, with low to moderate bitterness, quite a lot of sweetness, and a lot of malt flavour.  Tastes like everything the commercial description claims, but honestly, I think this brew is FAR too sweet, and it is also dominated by the alcohol taste.  Ive had much higher alcohol content beer that masked the alcohol much better than this one.  The sweetness and alcohol taste seriously detracted from my enjoyment of this brew.  While my initial impression was very positive, this beer came across as extremely heavy and tiresome.

Mmmm caramel sugar and hops.  A couple of my favorite things in beer.  Deep, dark color and an offwhite head that gives you some creaminess.  Sweet aromas.  Hops on the front end and a sweet candi sugar maltiness on the back.  A great addition to these guys line up and a great brown ale.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2007 Scrutinous rerate - Let me tell you guys something. Im The Motherfucking C.E.O., and I know Beer. I have the most experienced palate out of everyone at RateBeer.com in fact....and Im telling you...this is a decent Beer, but it does NOT deserve a 4 or higher...as many SUPPOSEDLY "experienced" raters here have suggested. Tastes like a better version of BridgePort Black Strap Stout..

Moderate malt aroma with molasses, caramel and brown sugar. A tiny tan head on top of a black body. This is very similar to a stout IMO in both looks and to some extent taste as well. The taste is moderately sweet, not cloying, and slightly bitter. Strong roasted malts and coffee flavors. Its medium bodied with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. The finish is somewhat bitter and hoppy with light alcohol. I really enjoyed this beer and think that it is very well put together. It seems to be a harmonious brew, but like I said it really reminds me of a stout.

This beer pours a nice dark amber color but no head to it at all. It has nice smells of chocolate malt and hints of fruits. There is some strong chocolate malt falvors that tend to stick around for a while. There is also some nice hints of fruit but they are very mild.

Pours a dark brown with a ruby hue and a microbubble tan head. The aroma is amazing , with burnt coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and some vinous notes from the hops. The palate is velvety smooth, with medium carbonation. The flavour is sugary sweet molases, coffee, ginger, and a bitter, almost metallic finish from the hops. An amazing brown ale that crushes most browns, mostly because its not really a brown ale.

Dark brown with big caramel head.  Scent of brown sugar and molasses.  Bold flavor with raisins and coffee.  Balanced out nicely with a hop and alcohol bite.  A candy like sweetness lingers. Very good!
Dark brown with little head.  Hints of coffee and alcohol.  Very good beer.
very nice brown ale here.  the saying of the cross between the three different styles is dead on.  lots of flavor and goes down very smooth.
Pours a dark brown. Slight hops on the nose with plenty of malt. Not a bitter as expected. Finishes like a scotch ale.

A - nutty and malty
Ap - nice dark brown, with a tan head
F - brown sugar, slight coffee & chocolate, sweet, but hoppiness balances it well
P - very drinkable, not too heavy
O - Very good beer, sweetness caught my attention first, but its not overbearing.  Another fine beer by Dogfish!

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2008 Dark brown...little foam...smells of alcohol and malt..and oooo  nutty sweetness.... flavor profile is nutty and dare I say, "ive had better brown ales, and the name is rogue HazelNut Brown Nectar"...still, its very good...and even better on draft, its heavier and richer
Deep brown color.Hops and malty aroma. Sweetness of molasses, carmelized brown sugar, with hints of chocolate and coffee in the taste

Pours a deep brown core with caramel highlights and a firm white cap.  A prounounced hop presence balances the equally malty aroma.  Caramel bread and citrusy hops continue in the body - which also notes baked bread, light coffee, caramalized brown sugar and earthy yeast.  Very interesting indeed.
What a great chewy beer, so much to dig into here. The balance is on point, with hops to bite down and clean off the sweet tastes. I sweat this beer.
bottle. deep dark red/brown. nice roasty aroma. smooth and creamy, with the hops out front, coffee and chocolate in the finish. bought a bottle, next time it will be a six.
Just a little too sweet for my tastes.  But a good beer nonetheless.  Nice color with a good head and some lacing.  The higher alcohol didnt seem to be balanced by the other flavors.
From bottle pours dark amber/ brown with a good amount of head.  Nice strong flavor, that leaves a nice finish.
Pours a very dark amber / brown with a small light brown nappy head. Aroma is raw malts, hops, and some nuttiness. Flavor has traces of sour malts, hops, hints of smoke and nuts. Not too bad.
It has been a while since Ive tried this, and from recollection, it was nothing I got too excited about.  But there isnt too much from dogfish that is bad.  A decent brew

Bottle. Simply the best dark ale Ive ever imbibed. The caramel/brown sugar taste blends seamlessly with the burnt flavor. The carbonation is very present and adds a pungency that drives the entire taste home. Forms a thin, light brown head - the first Ive ever seen from a dark ale. Goes down effortlessly and enjoyably.

Found it at Greens Liquors in Atlanta.

This beer was great. The reason why is because this is an ale, and I am closely relating this beers taste to an imperial stout. A nice burnt caramel, chocolate smell. The beer is DARK brown, and almost black. Very nice taste, with a burnt wood taste. Very nice palate, nice and smooth but again too thin for me. I can taste some dark bourbon or whiskey notes, but they are not heavy. A nice beer fromm an accomplished American Brewer.

This beer was a huge surprise to me!  It poured a dark brown with a thin head.  I dont have the words to describe the complex tastes in this beer - its very unique and VERY good!  Its a little heavy for an IPA but it makes up for it in alcohol content and deliciousness!
A dark translucent pour, with a flavor of raisins and caramel malt. The aftertaste is similar to a shot of whisky (not quite as strong!)

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 Seriously one of my favorite beers. Tastes like teriyaki! Sticks to the ribs and feels thick on the teeth. Pours a dark brown color with a foamy brown head. Low alcohol taste and has a lasting warming finish. Fantastic Beer that is a border line too sweet but has a bit of a bit for a finish.

Solid. Although I may have seen this beer in stores before, I never paid much attention. Finally on a whim I bought some and needless to say I am not disappointed. Yes, insanely hopped beers get alot of attention, but a good brown ale is something to be appreciated as well. They mention caramelized brown sugar on the bottle, and it is apparent in this beer. Seems to have a bit of spiciness in it as well - possibly ginger. Last come the hops to keep the sweetness under control. One of the better brown ales I have had.

Had in a flight at DFH restaurant.  Was pretty good, a real crowd pleaser.  Nice and sweet with lots of different flavors, but far from overpowering.  Surprised to see the 7.2% abv, not too shabby for such a gentle and pleasant brew.  My favorite brown ale so far, but Im saving a corsendonk for a rainy day.
Pours a opaque brown color with a tan head. Has hints of roasted malts, caramel, carmalized sugar, coffee. Finishes with the taste of hops and spices.
Dark brown.  Hoppy aroma for a brown.  Sweet taste at first followed by a nice bitter finish.

I poured this one out from the bottle, and was pretty satisfied overall.  The aroma was heavy in brown sugar, with roasty, wheaty hops and caramel malt.  There were subtle notes too, as advertised, molasses and ginger were particularly noticeable.  It had a very dark brown color with a red tint, and a small, foamy tan head.  The taste was mostly sweet, with some bitterness.  It had a very lively moutfeel, was fizzy and wet, with good carbonation.  While I did enjoy the beer, the taste was just not quite as good as I had hoped.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2008 12 oz, 6 months in bottle (bottled 10/04/06) in Ball quart jar. Opaque, stoutish-looking black-brown with medium-sized, dark tan head. Aroma is of dry hopped bread, flavored with metal and ozone.   Flavor is mostly dry, slight molasses and raisin-date with a little hop tingle, and a brush of brown sugar in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is medium heavy and almost chalky dry. Takes my tastebuds about half a bottle to get used to the dryness, but after that the dark fruit sweetness I was looking for subtly appears! Could be a nice 2-3 session beer.

Clear dark copper pour with creamy tan 1minute lasting head, syrupy texture soft carbonation medium to full body, tangs of toffe/chocolate/coffee, full of flavor, excellent representation of the Dogfish Head Brewerys diversity.
I liked it. DFH has a way of making strange beers...some are not so good, but this one is pretty good, a hoppy brown ale. Lots of alc. but you dont taste much of it. The beer is tasty though.

Deep mahogany pour with a small tan head.  Roasty malt aroma with brown sugar, spicy and citrusy hops, chocolate, hints of coffee and dark fruit.  Flavor is mostly roasted malts and caramel with a healthy dose of spicy, citrusy, and piny hops.  Molasses and coffee notes popping out here and there with some chocolate and alcohol on the finish.  Smooth medium full body with just enough carbonation.

12oz. bottle - pours very, very dark, ruby highlights catching the light, with a small off-white head. Aroma is actually sort of faint off the top, but increased as the glass warmed. Fairly malty/nutty in the nose, with a faint hoppiness in the distance. A bit like an English ale. Flavour however, changes all of that, and this beers awesomeness starts to show itself. Let me take you through it: hops and English malt character off the top, which then transitions to notes of coffee, chocolate, caramelized sugar. This then settles into a roasty, chocolatey finish with a lingering finish not totally unlike an Imperial Stout. You know, or something like that. Im no expert. But I know this is very good.  Its like an English ale, an Imperial stout, a brown ale, an IPA. The finish on this might be the best part...its incredibly long, roasty, hoppy, and awesome. Another kickass beer from DFH.

Clear dark brown, almost black beer with a small tan head and nice lacing.  Coffee and chocolate aroma.  Flavor is very rich dark roast coffee, dark malt and raisin, with a brown sugar sweetness.  Hops appear in the middle and finish with a nice bitterness.  Coffee drinkers will love this.  Excellent balance around the coffee flavor.  Good alcohol hit but hardly noticeable in the taste.   Not a typical brown ale but well done and enjoyable.

Rich, chocolaty color with a nice thick and persistent head. Aroma is hoppy and promising of a great brew. Flavor is rich and dark with strong hoppiness and nutty undertones. I did try this one under unusual circumstances, but I am confident enough of the normal flavor came through for me to appreciate this ale.

Bottle: Clear brown in color with a tan head. Aroma was nutty with some caramel in there as well. Flavor, a bit of coffee, nutty, caramel, some toffee. There was a nice earthy bitterness in there as well. Nice beer.
Not a real style, an IBA, but an improvement over the regular for me. Taste has some nuttiness but some nice graininess at the end.

Bottle.  Pours a dark red/brown with a light brown head.  Aroma of brown sugar, honey, malts, coffee, caramel.  Great smell.  The taste is about the same as the aroma with more chocolate.  I didnt get much or any hops in the taste and its not too sweet at all.  Very well balanced.  Impressive.
draft....Has a sharp hazelnut and sugar aroma and has a trace of the Scotch Ale with brown sugar in its flavor along with the IPA bite. Another big big winner from Dogfish Head. Super!

dark brown with a medium sized tan head.  aroma of hops and a hint of cappacino.  flavor is bitter biting coffee with hops.  light-medium bodied.  a little too light bodied for a brown.  very roasty almost comparible to a stout except for the light body.

Took a whiff and pictured a stack of wet carboard boxes.  The aroma is the only downside to this brew.  Poured a dark clear copper with good head.  Aaaaahhhh....  Tastes like biscuits soaked in bourbon - my work week breakfast!  Finish is balanced and smooth, makes me want another.  Think I will...

THOUGHTS: This beer was my New Years "Revolution." I was initially confused by the name, but the flavor want confusing at all  it was great. I wasnt expecting much, but it brings together the best of each of the styles it combines. One of the biggest surprises of my beer drinking life. This beer deserves a category all its own, or at least to be put into some sort of hybrid category. There was caramel, coffee sweetness followed up by a nice and not overpowering hop bitterness. Great aroma. DfH gets so much cred for their extreem beers, but this beer is proff that just about anything they try is a quality beer. After each sip I just wanted another. I imagine that this is what beer would have tasted like in Scotland if hops were more readily availble in the past. I even gave this a few bonus points in the Overall category bor creativity and the ability to execute it this well.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a small, almost soapy-looking, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was moderate caramel and mild coffee, light to moderate citrus (grapefruit) hops and just a little alcohol as it warmed. The initial flavor was moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter, while the finish was moderately to heavily sweet and bitter with an average duration. Incredibly well balanced. The body was medium to full and a little dry up front, but that might have just been the carbonation, and syrupy with fizzy carbonation and a metallic but not overpowering finish.
Excellent beer. Very nice Brown ale packed full of flavor. Dogfish head makes some excellent beers and this is no exception. Very smooth and pure. If you have a chance, do sample.
Probably the best brown ale I have had.  It is so dark it flirts with being a porter.  Lots of hops balance the sweet malt.  Very nice.

Very dark brown, almost black pour with a thin but lasting white head.  Chocolate and coffee aroma.  Lots of hops up front with a bit of citrus.  Middle is malty and has some brown sugar.  Nice carbonation but not distracting.  Finish has a slighly resinous hoppiness.  This is a really good brown ale!!

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 11.05.2007 Re-Rate: 12 oz bottle.  pours mahogany, yet with a slight shimmer. the head is solid, slow to recede, and lacing is on the thicker side for a brown ale.  aromas hint at plums, ripe apricots, raisins, and light chocolate.  its not quite as sweet as ive tasted before.  taste hits like a roasted nutty explosion. a bit of roasted coffee bean touches the top of the palate.  theres not much on the back palate, but the front hits with a malbec-type dryness.  still, tastes of slight hazelnut linger on the velvety finish.  i just wish it would coat more of the palate, and last a bit longer.  it almost just quits it the middle.  good beer, dfh still rocks.

------  12oz bottle.  pours brown or deep ruby, depending on the lighting.  about avg head, more foam than bubbles.  this is one brew where the description actually fits the beer to a "t".  the finish is very smooth and well-rounded, like a nice pinot noir.  though one aspect DFH left out was its high propensity to have many of them at once.  the drinkability is very high here.  DFH has found a way to not produce bad beer.  kudos to them.

Aroma: 8/10
Appearance: 3/5
Flavor: 8/10
Palate 4/10
Overall: 17/20

4.0
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 very well hopped beer...smells a little like coffee..tastes real good..goes down real smooth..no real bitter after taste...would highly recommend this beer for all.

Pours deep brown, with a dense half finger off white head that holds up well.  Some lacing.  Strong coffee aroma.  Smoky malt flavor initially is balanced well with some hops.  Syrupy flavor, more than brown sugar, but not quite molasses. Nice smooth finish.  Good stuff

12 oz. Dogfishead makes it to GA !!! Very good, brown - chocolate color with a medium but nicely persistent brownish head. Aromas of sweetness though always wiht a nice hop profile. I taste hops, brown sugar, and faintly molasses. Good Brew.
Had this on tap at the Summits Cumming East Coast Beer Dinner.  Dark Brown, Thin Tan head.  Great lacing.  roasty flavor and aroma.  tastes of dried fruit.  rich malt. happy balance.

35,5 cl bottle. Reddsih dark brown colour with a little head. Sweet aroma of hops, nuts and brown sugar. Nice flavour of sweetness, brown sugar, carmel, little chocolate and ends up very smooth and nice.
Delicious brown.  Thin head, light lacing, Slightly fruity taste with a nice bitter finsih.

Strong aroma of roasty chocolatey maltiness. The flavors of creamy hoppiness (strange) are really nice.  This is quite an interesting brew that continues to please after the first sips -- its interesting while remaining palatable.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 Bottle... Poured a deep borderline black tone with a fluffy, light brown head.  Strong malty and sugary aroma.  The palate was mildly carbonated with an acidic character.  Flavors were nicely complex with malt, brown sugar, nut, salt, soy, and chocolate, all complemented with bitter barley. This is an awesome brown ale.  Its described as being well hopped for a brown ale, I didnt seem to get sense of the hops too well, but I still like it for what it is.

Got some sweet malt and some slight chocolate in the aroma.Pours dark brown with a thin to medium off white head.Got some brown sugar and some slight hops in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a slight sweet chocolate finish.

Bottle.  Clear dark brown with an almond colored foamy head, diminishing quickly.  Chocolate, coffee and molasses malt aromas with some soapy yeastiness--cant really pick up ginger or raisinettes.  Flavor of dark roast coffee/mocha malt, a bit of charred leaf, basically like most browns but with a noticeable hop finish.  Medium to full bodied.  Doesnt work for me.

Poured from bottle. Very dark amber. Tan head that didnt last long. Very sweet, citrus smell...Tasted the caramel brown sugar right off the bat! Along with maybe a slight cider taste...Hops was in the finish, but blended pretty well that even I liked it and I dont like the taste of hops...YET...Very good beer.
This beer tastes great.  There is a lot going on here but it works well.  Incredibly smooth and sweet.
bottle. very dark amber color. bit smokey aroma. bit roasted. nice. bit coppery and malty.

Rather dark brown body and a light tan head that is quickly descending, but nice lookin at the same time. Quite a sweet smell if I could say so, which I surely can say: carmely! The beer tastes quite good. It has a really sweet taste that is somewhat remeniscent of an IPA. Not really hoppy, but the hops are apparent in the taste. The high alcohol content is barely even noticed under the plethora of flavour. Good stuff never the less.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a thin head.  It has a very malty, sweet aroma.  It has a big caramel malt taste with noticeable brown sugar and a little hops.  That 50 IBU is pretty buried under all that sweetness.  I think it needed all of those hops to give it balance though.  Its full bodied and lightly carbonated with a somewhat dry finish.    I expected to taste stronger hops given the name of the brew, but nevertheless this ale is good.
nice raisiny smell, beautiful dark color.  sugary coffee taste.  nice texture too.  good change of pace for dogfish.
Pours a dark brown with a large, creamy head. Full of brown sugar and molasses, with sweet notes of chocolate. Lots of hops, great brew.

dark brown beer with a light brown, foamy, airy head.  I had to pour aggressively to get this head.  a previous pour down the side of the glass resulted in virtually no head.  hoppy with a sweet finish.  pretty easy to drink, actually.  i was shocked it had over 7% abv.
Dark brown with lasting foamy beige head.   Aroma of hops, lots of hops. Flavour of hops cut with brown sugar. Sugar malty finish.  Seems not as strong as it is.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Im not a huge fan of this one.  All I can think of in the flavor is soy sauce.  Id rather have a Raison.
Very rich brown color with a long lasting head that laces nicely. Mild aroma of yeast that increases. Slight sweetness offsets the bitterness. Flavor remains the same as the beer warms. Very good.

Bottle.. Thin head that lasts and klings to the edges. The color can only be described as what cola wishes it could look like. Ruby. Nose is a little sour, maybe yeasty, but rounds off well. Flavor is subtle with a taste of coffee followed by nutty accents. Smokey. Creamy to the palate turning dry. Leaves you craving another sip.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Re-rate. Bottle. Nose is strong raisins and coffee on top of some chocolate and other malty sweetness. Deep amber tints around a black beer with a swirly head. Heavy dose of coffee up front, fades into a bit of chocolate in the finish. Palate is smooth and finishes dry.
Thick, creamy head. VERY deep brown coloring. Very strong sweet quality with a bit of a hop bite. Similar tastes to chocolate, coffee, and especially molasses. Very thick mouth feel. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 dark brown, but still lets some light through.  some chocolate in the aroma, i cant really describe it since im brewing and the whole place smells like beer.  lots of roasted malt in the flavor but plenty of body and not overly bitter.  the 7.2% alcohol is really surprising.  i could probably pound these as a session beer.  rerate: aroma is lightly smoked.  flavor is pretty empty.

Yeoooowzerssss!!!!!! ooohooo. the kick ass brown ale on the block. luscious thick creamy head, rich aroma, thick clingy lace. This is THE brown ale. Englishmen, yallve been served notice. This is the best brown Ive ever had. gawd. flirts with porter, but maintains the brown identitiy. killer. Had this one on draft at Bodega, and I think they have it in bottles too. However last time I had it in a bottle it was really nothing like this.....

Bottle. A black potion, almost opaque.  The pour leaves a creamy white head contrasting with the body that remind you of a Guiness.  It enimated smells of caramel and sugur and I expected a supersweet concoction.  To my pleasure I was wrong.  It is superly hopped to give an awesome contrast - swwet for a second then mature bitters, than warm from the 7.2% alcohol.  A complex taste, all beer lovers should try this unique style.  One of Dogfishs best!

Dogfish head, a well respected brand on this site. This beer has some stiff competition; Troegs, wild Goose and Bells all make some decent brown ales. On tap at the Bocktown bar & grill in the Robinson twp shopping complex. Pours dark reddish brown in my glass with a light tan head.  No outstanding aroma but it does have a hint of stoutness to it. The initial flavor reminds me of a stout or porter, roasty/hoppy bitterness in the onslaught.  Many porters Ive had are not this bitter. Pretty complex, too much like a lighter imperial stout.  If you can get over the bitterness, this has a decent flavor. If you are a lover of imp stouts or IPA, you better check this out.  IMO this has too much bitterness for a brown ale style, which I believe should be more mild, enjoyable and repeatable.  The finish is lasting bitterness that holds true for awhile once done drinking. Troegs, Bells and Goose are much better.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12oz bottle (thanks to Ty5592) poured a dark brown color with a nice tan head. Aroma was hops, chocolate malt, roast and some caramel. The taste was well bittered with a good balance of complex malts. The brown sugar is slightly noticable, but fades to some alcohol in the finish. I think this beer should be in a style of its own, som many great flavors mixed all in one. My fav. beer from Dogfish Head.
(Bottle)Aroma similar to rye.  Pours a pitch dark brown.  Sweet, malty and bitter-all balanced well.  Malt at first but nice hop finish.  Not a session brown ale but very good.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 Pours a dark amber brown with slight caramel colored head.  Aroma has a strong sense of barley with a bite of alcohol.  The taste has a sweet sugar appeal that finishes dry with a clean hoppiness.  Highly recommended.

Pours a very dark brown with some reddish highlights around the edges. Theres a half inch tan head that fades slowly to a thin cap, leaving behind a tattered lacing.

Smell; dark chocolate with roasted, almost smoky malts. Theres a bit of coffee, and a touch of hops.

Taste; the chocolate and coffee come out nicely along with a slightly nutty flavor. The sweetness from the malts are there, as well as th smokiness I picked up in the aroma. Finishes with a bit of a hop bitterness that balances out the sweet. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, and very easy to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Bottled. Good brown Pour (Thanks Dennis Bell for this beer) I smelled a grassy hop aroma right away then in the back round  a malty caramel roast can be detected. Hoppier then I expected but smooth and pretty well balanced. An odd brown ale but I like it. Dog Fish scores again !!!!

WOW! This beer is really big on flavor. Poured a very dark brown with a slightly offwhite head. Tons of Maltiness going on with hints of chocolate, coffee, and some intense sweetness due to the brown sugar. Cutting through all the malty goodness was a nice amount off hoppy bitterness to round it all out. Very good brown ale.

Pours a small, receding beige head on an opaque reddish brown body. The beer shows decent lacing.

Aromas of chocolate, nuts and a hint of caramel which combined with what Ill call pine-flavored cough syrup hops probably gives the descriptor molasses.

Creamy and silky on the palate, medium-full bodied. This beer is all about flavor contrast. Up front its chocolate sweetness. This is met with a wave of bitterness later on. I got a nutty maltiness hinding in all of this.

The beer produced a longish finish which was slightly drying. I enjoyed this beer mostly for its flavor contrast. It cant hide its Scotch Ale roots.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Suggest you let this one warm before drinking. Malty coffee aroma. Creamy and full-bodied. Very sweet malts, raisins and coffee, on the front. Bitter hops on the back end. One of the better prominently available browns out there.
Dark clear brown color with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor of sweet malts. Finishes with coffee and hops.

Brown/ruby pour with a compact tan head.  Molasses/brown sugar/hops aroma. Initial flavor is sweet & malty then moves into brown sugar/candi sugar flavors and a bitter finish with some alcohol present.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2007 Pours deep brown/ruby red with a small off white head. Nice aroma of toasted malts, brown sugar and licorice, chocolate. Taste of sweet malts upfront, then brown sugar, and then alchohol which is very present. A bit of hop bitterness at the end, but a belgian ale sugar flavor also comes through in the end. More coffee and chocolate came out as it warmed. Solid. Wow, that sure is a lot of typing.

Love Dogfish Head and had high expectations for this one, esp. because I love brown ales.  Smooth even when bottled.  The dry hop bite at the end catches you off guard.  Lengthy flavor variation throughout a sip.  Give this one a shot.

Bottle 12 oz.

Pours brown as name suggest, clear, lively carbonation. Medium receding creamy (tanned) head.

Medium dark chocolate, clean earthy, nutty hops, brown malt as base. Good.

Medium bodied, slightly dry brown roast, a bit like light Baltic. Good coco-hop complexity. Sadly finish was bit flat. Overall good medium dry brown ale with clean hop touch.
Aroma of bittersweet chocolate and roasted coffee beans, pours a chocolate brown. Nice thick mouth feel, not too bitter. Not Dogfishs best, but still great. I will be buying this again.

Pours chestnut brown with a long lasting silky cappuccino head.  Aromas of chocolate, citrus hops and raisin.
