Fantastically drinkable flavor of roasted maltish coffee and chocolate accented by some citric bitterness.  Consumed very quickly, because it was likeable and subtley rich though simple by design.

pours deep brown/ruby red with a small off white head.  Nice aroma of toasted malts, brown sugar and licorice, chocolate.  Taste of sweet malts upfront, then brown sugar, and then alchohol which is very present.  A bit of hop bitterness at the end, but a belgian ale sugar flavor also comes through in the end. More coffee and chocolate came out as it warmed. Solid

Root Beer brown pour from the bottle with a full fuzzy white head.  Smells sweet  with a big malty roast and some hints of molasses and licorice.  A slightly sour palate with some brown sugars some skunkiness and a big of hop.  Alcohol is very present... giving me flashbacks to the Worldwide Stout!  Mellows a bit after a few more sips.  Not the best of the Dogfish, but a welcome addition to my ratings collection.  Ill stick to the Hazelnut from Rogue.

dark chestnut color, golden brown at edges.  head is thick and dark tan.  aroma is hoppy and carmelized brown sugar/light molasses.  flavor is deep roasty caramel malt, some carbonized brown sugar, then balanced hop bitterness.  a little earthy.
A deep brown amber color with a very strong hoppy aroma. Fairly thicker than expected. Toasty while maintaining the IPA bitterness. A very unique and pleasant beer.

[12oz bottle - Bottle Works Seattle]

A deep brown color with a great hop aroma.  Liked this beer a lot it was thicker than I felt it should have been a tad carmel and toasty malts this was a very good beer.  Well Done Dogfish Head.

Draft, DFH Gaithersburg.  Cherry-cola appearance; light tan head with good retention and lacing.  Roasted malts and bitter chocolate.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: plenty of charred malts, dark chocolate, hints of smoke; very malt-dominated.  Much more charred flavors than the previous recipe.  Medium finish, showing bitter chocolate and hints of citrus hops.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 Pours a deep brown into the glass with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet and roasted malt.  Taste is very bold with a nice deep malt character that finishes with a crisp bitterness.  Terrific beer

I didnt examine the bottle closely, but from its name I figured this beer would be a very hoppy brown ale, and I was a bit mistaken in this expectation.

The beer poured a dark color with an abundant fluffy tan head.  It definitely resembled a porter more to me than a brown ale, but was still a handsome thing to behold.

Odor was of caramel with some coffee notes, with just a whiff more hops than I would expect from a stout or porter.

Flavor mirrored aroma, as the product tasted very good with abundant caramel malt character and coffee taste notes, with some hops evident at the finish.

Mouthfeel was pleasant.  Drinkability was not hugely high...I had a several beers prior to this one, and after this one my evening was over.

This product was very good, however given my previous experience with Dogfish Head beers, I expected something different, bolder, or more unusual.  I thought this beer would be super-hoppy, and it wasnt.  A fine beer, but not what I expected.

Color is dark with reddish hue which brought dark chocolate covered cherries to mind.  Head was slightly tan and provided a creamy sensation.  The aroma was slightly bitter with hints of coffee and hops.  The relatively higher level of alcohol was first tasted, but did not overwhelm the coffee and raison flavors.  The ale finishes with a mild bitter and hoppy base.   The ale fills the mouth with complex flavors that invites additional consumption.

A very dark brown ale.  Mild carbonation and translucent.  The creamy head is very appealing.  The aroma is malty with notes of coffee and a bit of chocolate.  Very complex flavor- lots going on here.  The beer starts tart with hops (odd for a brown ale), finishes a bit bitter with more of a traditional brown ale taste.  Like all dogfish beers, great mouth feel.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 pours a blackish brown with a one finger off white tanish head. big barley and malt aroma with some hops and brown sugar as well. flavor is a lot of sweet barley and some malt with a little hops and some brown sugar. light to medium body with some lacing, and some carbonation to the toungue almost like a little sting. there is also a little molasses caramel taste halfway down. very nice session brown ale i love dog fish head!
Deep brown pour with light brown head.  Aroma is like bitter chocolate and slightly sour, not bad.  Flavor is nice, bitter like chocolate with a hint of coffee.  Slightly metallic aftertaste.

Brown ale is not something I drink regularly, but if available I would drink if free. This taste was like a hike in a park in a bottle. Nutty and earthy in taste. This is like a politician. Too in the middle for me, but good if its your thing
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 Bottle.  Aroma of coffe and almonds.  Dark brown pour with thin tan head.  Outstanding aroma, smells almost like a mild hazlenut coffee.  Solid finish.

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in an English pint
Bottled 05/06, fished out 11/06

Poured a clear dark brown mahogany with an average creamy light brown somewhat lasting head. 

Smelt of strong coffee, brown sugar, leather, nuts.

Taste was upfront moderate bitter nuttiness and sweet burnt sugar followed by a strong bitter ginger, soy, burnt nuts, pine hops with moderate sweet burnt sugar on a long finish. Palate was medium bodied, softly carbonated, soft and creamy, and moderately astringent.

Overall, this is like a juiced up brown ale.  Tasty!!!

Bottled. Pours a clear reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma of caramel and fruit, with a touch of citrus. Medium body and carbonation. The taste is sweet and loaded with caramel, nuts, molasses with some grapefruit rind in the finish.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with creamy tan head. The aroma found a subdue sniff of malts and fruits. The flavor was a great blend of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Light body with a creamy feel in the mouth. Coffee aftertaste.

Very deep brown-black with good lacing.

Expressive nose of mocha, roasted coffee, and molasses.

In the mouth, starts off dry, then suddenly becomes sweet, then ends in an absolutely delicious sweet-bitter balancing act, with a lot of brown sugar character.

Lots of flavor in this brew.  The flavors manage to be interesting, too, without losing their balance.  Great beer; not one that Id necessarily session with, but great nonetheless.
beautiful red-black pour with a lingering head.  Molassas, coffee, brown sugar, and sweet malt.  Really nice bitter finish.

Pours very dark brown with a thin foamy dark tan head. Aroma of molasses, aromatic malt, dark crystal, rye bread and spice. Tastes of dark chocolate, bread, and coffee liqeur. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied and slightly oily with lush carbonation.

Very deep brown with amber at the edges. Big malty aroma, cinnamon, brown sugar, hazelnut coffee. Complex aroma. Almost like an abbey dubbel. Creamy roasty body. Robust sweet maltyness, yet its toasty and roasted. Burnt almondy aspect. Roasty frangelico liquer (alcohol flavor) with a roasty surprisingly dry finish with evident alcohol. Theres a very late coffeeish bitterness left on the back of the tongue. Interesting brown ale.

Poured out dark ruby brown, with an aroma of sweetness and almonds.  Malts, a bit of hops and raisins abound.  Small beige head of foam, which quickly disapaited.    Yep, taste of brown sugars, almonds, hops and a bit of coffee.  Damnit, Dogfish Head does it again!!  Bravo.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Clear red/brown head - white head. Roasted, berries, caramel, nut, pleasant, light hoppy finish.

Bottle.
Clear red brown coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of malts, caramel and fruits with notes of nuts.
Flavour of caramel, fruits, dried fruits and nuts.
Hoppy finish.

Bottle, poured dark brown almost like a stout, had some bubbles that ran away some, smelled like a stout with the brown sugar sweetness, little bread and wet coffee ground fragrance, little hops in the nose, taste of dark malts, cocoa, coffee and bittersweet background, small hops on the tongue, nice mouthfeel, the brown ale and brown sugar go well together, this could easily be a dessert beer, very nice.

Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a sizeable tan head and great lacing.  Aroma is malty and sweet, with a bit of fruitiness.  Taste is an intense blend of malts, sugar, coffee, chocolate, and fruity tones.  Very rich and smooth - a great brown ale.
Bottle thanks to Bager. Ruby colour with a big beige head. Malty, chocolate, hop, light smoked aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet dry finish.
Bottled. Dark brown and reddish coloured with a small head. Malty and very slightly smoked. Sweet notes of caramel and maybe a weak hint of chocolate. Well balanced.

This brown ale pours a deep red color with an average, light brown fizzy head. Virtually no lacing behind a fully-diminishing head. Sparkling body. Aroma is of light, toasted malts and light hops. Initial taste is lightly sweet which carries right through to the finish with a malty, nutty taste. Light to medium on the mouth, a creamy consistency is left behind with soft carbonation.
Poured a dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma was dark malt, with some coffee mixed in.  The flavor was the same with some chocolate mixed in.   This was a very good brew.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2007 Poured a dark brown, almost black brew.  Medium head, medium length, creamy tan with slight lacing. The aroma was sweet with hints of chocolate, raisins, and spicy hops. Tasted sweet, like molasses, chocolate, and spice. The palate was crisp and very full. The finish was tingly, not harsh but you feel it. As good as Rogues HazelNut and probably the two best brown ales Ive had.

Pours a very deep color.  Brown sugar really comes through, and the balance between the sweet, molases malt and the hops is excellent.  The finish is great, with some lingering sweetness that reminds me of really good chocolate.  A very good beer overall.
Pours a dark brown, with a tan colored head. Has a nice caramel aroma, but there are hops in there as well. Taste is nutty and malty.  Good balance and very interesting.  Solid mouthfeel as well.

Bottle, true to its name it poured a dark brown. Another very good beer from this brewery. Glad the local beer store hear was finally able to get Dogfish. Thought this beer had a nice smokey malty taste. Very drinkable, which can be a problem due to the higher alcohol contents.
Solid brew. Poured very dark brown with a small head. Aroma nice and toasty. Flavor roasty, hoppy and dry, and extremely smooth.

Bottle. Roast and fruit,
caramelly.
Dark, red brown creamy golden head.
Dry raisiny, vineous. light herbal edge, light citrus.
Almond aftertaste.

Pours a clear brown color with a nice light tan head.  Light spotty lacing.  Has a roasted malt and molasses aroma.  Has a slighty bitter-sweet  chocolate flavor.  Medium body.  One of the better Brown ales Ive had.
very dark pour. nice blend on hops and other flavors (sorry cant pinpoint im new :(   ) very nice flavor. one of my new favs

Bottle served in a dimpled mug. This beer had my mouth watering upon first pour. Deep, deep, deep dark-ruby hues with a two-finger foamy tan head that retains most of its mass throughout the session. Held under the nose youre immediately hit with a wallop of delicious roasted malts, thick molasses and a tantilizing earthy hop presence that promises an extremely well-balanced brew to come. Taste is a perfect dance between the smokey, roasted flavor of the malt, dark sugars and the hop bitterness that slaps your taste buds back to their senses. Overall this is a very good, very drinkable beer.

This is a another great brew form Dogfish head. It has the rich deep malty flavor of a nice brown ale with a great hoppy finish of an IPA. This beer is just right for a IPA lover looking for something a little different. The only problem is the High Alcohol % :-)

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 Bottle, Liquid Solutions. Pours a clear dark ruby color. Sweet malty coffee aroma with some chocolate. Crisp spicy flavor right up front. Lots of roasted malty goodness along with coffee bitter. I think the alcohol seems to give a little bit of an extra kick that separates it from your typical brown. Good brew.

Poured a nice looking clear dark brown color with a good sized tan head that stuck around a long time, but didnt overstay its welcome.  Aroma was rather nutty and caramelly, slightly funky or cheesy, with a bit of citrus hops in the background.  Taste is well balanced and relaxed, with uprfront earthy nut flavors coming through, and hints of caramel and tofee to make things more interesting.  The hop finish fits in nicely to the overall picture without being too hot or separate from the malts.  Mouthfeel was good and medium, right where a nice brown ale should be.  Good stuff.

Bottle.  This looks like Coca-Cola.  It has a smokey, sweet, woodsy smell.  The taste is extremely flavorful on the front with the same smoked wood hints in the back with almost undetectable hops for a clean finish.  One of my very favorites.

Pours a dark brown/black with a tan head.
Arome is brown sugar, grains, hops. Flavor is nicely balanced between the hops and the sweetness of the grains and sugar. Very drinkable, didnt even notice the 7.2% ABV. Another good beer from Dogfish Head.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2007 gooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooood.  Description says it well,dont fall under one category mix between a brown ale and has similiar qualities to an IPA.

Aroma of roast coffee, chocolate, caramel, and a wisp of soy sauce.  Appears a deep cherrywood color, with a small brown head that dissipates.  Flavor is both roasty and smoky at the start, giving we to a depp malt backbone, and finishing with an assertive though mellow hop bitterness - a tad salty at the finish.  Palate is medium-thick and slick on the tongue.  Overall, a unique brew that defies classification but that is somehow supremely balanced.

Bottle.  Looked syrupy when poured.  Color was a dark brown, light hint of red.  Good size head.  Aroma of chocolate, some roasted coffee, and malt.  Taste was complex and nice on the palate.  Smooth on the palate.  Mild sweetness, very light on the hops.  Chocolate, molasses, malt, light coffee presence, and a little brown sugar.  Very interesting flavor.  Very good.
On tap at Dogfish Head, Rehoboth Beach location. Dark ruby brown, with off white head. Aroma is molasses, coffee, caramel, chocolate. Flavor is the same with hops. Nice medium body.

Very good brew.  I have yet to be dissapointed by Dogfish Head.  Wonderful chocolate color with nice tan head.  Aroma is of grape but not wine-like, with sweet brown sugar.  Flavor isnt as sweet as I had expected, which is a plus for this beer.  Palate is just perfect, wonderfully creamy mouthfeel, nicely carbonated.  This is a very drinkable brew.

Excellent beer for the style. This beer pours a dark stained-penny hue. Nice creamy head, lacing is done well. Almost a mix between a brown and a porter. Has good chocolate and caramel flavors. Nice and complex for a brown. Another great (but expensive) beer from DFH.
Bottle.  Deep, dark brownish-burgundy coloring.  Soapy thick head; slow to dissipate.  Chocolate, brown sugary aroma.  Complex flavoring.  A real surprise winner here.  Ill have another soon.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving some edgy head.  Aroma is dark roasted nutty caramel malt (cookie, biscuit), yeast (dough) and chocolate.  Medium bitterness and mild sweetness, mild acidity, chocolate and nutty, caramel malt.  Medium bodied, smooth and refreshing palate.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 12 OZ Bottle from Liquid Solutions. Pours a dark dark brown. Has an almost bock like aroma...plums, chocolate, cherries, vanilla, and molasses. Medium body and over-carbonated. Hard to discern the flavors due to the carbonation but there is some molasses, toffee and some mild citrus hops. Pretty good for a dark ale, albeit a bit hoppier than most dark ales. Ahh, let it cool down for 20 minutes and it is much better! Does not really FIT within any style.

Brown,small tan head.Sweet and roasty nose.Lots of malt, medium roasted,barely noticeable  hops and alcohol. Good body. 
Interesting!! Somewhat undercarbonated

From a 12 oz. bottle it pours with a clear light brown color. The head is tan and medium bodied. Carbonation is relatively high. The aroma is of cane sugar, milk chocolate with some roasted flavours. The taste stats out bitter with some malts but comes to an almost sour and flat ending. The aroma promised more than the taste could deliver and the body is light for an IBR.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2009 Dark brown with no head. Smell of roasted malt,some coffee, and alcohol. The taste was a good mixture of semi sweet chocolate,molasses and hops. Complex semi sweet hop finish.

Not my favorite DFH, but definitely good beer.  Hard to nail it down as a straight brown ale, as it is hoppier than most. All the usual sweet, roasted malt flavoring with a hint of chocolate and raisins. Excellent finishing, very smooth.

Cold on tap at Redbones:  Pours a dark cherry brown color with a moderate tan head and lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malt, alcohol and notes of cocoa.  Taste is of roasted malt and cocoa with some bitterness that appears and then fades quickly.  Nice, smooth ending.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2006 If they did just change the recipe to add hops, great move. Another unique brew from Dogfish. Dry borown IPA. some notes remind me of founders dirty bastard scotch ale.  Love it.
bottle.Pours a very dark brown with aromas of sweet malt roasted barley,hints of coffee and raisin.Flavors of brown sugar,malt and hops.This is balanced and smooth and a pleasure to drink.

This seemed to taste like a baby stout. It had notes of roastiness, coffee, chocolate, and alcohol. The color is almost completely black like a stout also. The only down part is it is a little too sweet. I was not getting as much hops as I was expecting.

Bottled.  Pours very dark, soild head that lasts for awhile.   Aroma is malty & hoppy.   Taste is like, sweet, carmel, but yet has the hop bitterness.  Takes a few sips to really appreciate the taste!

The best! I know everything there is to know about this beers creation. Ive seen it being made and tasted it right off the line. One of my favorites. However, the recipe has been tweeked in the past months(July-Aug06). The hop % has been increased by 4x. This gave it more of a bite. Kinda off-sets the balance a bit but this beer is like home. Drink it with DFH pride!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2006 Bottle.

I think Im losing it. Ive been quite consistant in being underwhelmed by the just about everything Ive tried from DFH (with the possible exception of Raison dEtre) Heres today, coming into this beer with a minimum of expectations, I poured the glass (dark dark brown with a scant head), and the aroma was intriguing - warm smoky malts, brown sugar, hints of metallic hops. The taste - the taste was marvellous. Definately malt and smoke like a good scotch ale, but well hopped, any plenty of sweet nutty rich brown sugar,  a DFH experiment that I actually like. Somehow they avoid the "too roasted plus too hoppy" trap that befalls so many West Coast seasonals, and instead come up with a dark IPA + more that really works.

Wow. Ill be back. Did I mention that this thing is dangerously drinkable?

Pours a deep rich brown with a 1/4 inch frothy brown head. Rich sweet brown malt, strident hoppy aromas.

Rich brown malt. The brown sugar gives it a unique flavor to say the least. Lots of bitter hops as it finishes. Rich and lightly sticky aftertaste. This is unique and decent.

This poured a nice brown color, with a pretty mild aroma of both hops and  chocolate-coffee. I really enjoy the balance of slightly bitter hops with the tastes of the sweet, chocolatey malts, and the hint of raisin. It also has a nice smooth yet creamy palate that suits the malt flavors very well.
This offering from Dogfish had aromas of chocolate and coffee and raisins.Those were also in the taste as well as molasses.I thought this was a pretty good beer.

I think this is a very good DFH brew. I got a sort of toasted malt note which is very pleasant. There is also just a hint of coffee on the end, not too much. The smell is enticing, and brings forth the brown sugar, with just a hint of coffee. The hops provide a nice accent on the end of this one.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2007 Re-rate. Pours very dark brown/red with a nice small tan head. Aroma mostly of coffee, cream,  toffee malts, and a pleasant bit of hops.  Flavor is full of coffee with cream, a little bit of toffee sweetness, and very nice resiny/earthy hops. Palate is oily/resiny and bitter-sweet. More complex than I described, and very enjoyable overall. Very unique brown ale, but this should probably be in a category of its own. Perhaps a Brown IPA, or American Pale Brown, or even a Pale Stout. Delicious either way.

12 oz bottle.  Aroma is of light chocolate, lots of caramel, and some hops.  Taste is big malts up front and some dark fruits, and some hops, with a sweet middle and a balanced hop finish.  nice brown ale.
I love this one! Good work! I like a litlle bitter beers but this one is sweet without been to much.

A dark brown pour with an aroma of hops and alcohol. A flavor of sweet  roasted malt and alcohol. This beer has the mouth feel of an old ale or nice stout. It has a smooth full palate. Damn fine carbonation. Excellent bitter combination from the malt and hops. I like a beer with that alcohol undertone. Nice beer.

What is with dogfishs obsession with sweetness? This beer could have been great, but instead was just average. It poured an interesting brown color with a quickly receding head. The aroma was strongly malt. However, once in the mouth it was thin with little complexity and certainly not enough backbone...all of the structure was from malts, and it appeared that there were a variety, but the result was a watery, fairly sweet offering. If I wanted Pepsi, I would have bought one, they are certainly easier to come by here in Panama. Thanks James Maley for bringing this down.
Pours dark brown, with a thin head.  heavy body with a mostly malt aroma.  Not as bitter as I expected, given the name.  Good, but a bit of a dissapointment
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
Appearance: Pours a deep smooth brown color, thick and sticky looking with very little head but lots of lacing.

Smell: Sharply sweet caramels, brown sugar and nuts. Very toasted malt and sugary aroma.

Taste: It is not quite as sweet as the aroma would suggest. Nice and malty and pleasantly caramel sweet, but not cloyingly sweet. The alcohol shows through slightly and serves as a balancing agent, along with a bit of spiciness; and then there is also a hop presence in the finish and the aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel: Very nice and smooth. It is not quite sticky but it is thick and almost chewy. I like that aspect of sweet brown ales.

Drinkability: As a fan of the style I was expecting to be pleased. DFH rarely lets me down and this is no exception. It is a very decent sweet Brown Ale that I found quite easy to drink. I would not however consider it sessionable as it would end up being too sweet after a few.

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Fizzy, bubbly, light brown colored head which dissipated quickly.  Dark brown color with red-orange highlights.  Nice aroma of sweet malt, caramel, hops, and dark roasted grains...a hint of coffee.  Sweet malty and nutty flavor balanced with hints of hops, coffee, cocoa, and dried fruits.  Better than I had expected, pretty awesome brew.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2010 In short: A very hoppy brown ale.  Very good.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Re-rate for fresh 2008 bottle
The look: Clear dark-ruby/mahogany body topped by a medium beige head
In long: Fruity and hoppy nose, unusual for a brown ale.  Taste has some of the nutty brown ale elements with chestnuts and roasted almonds but is also very fruity and creamy.  Feels like drinking an alcoholised fruity cake dessert.  Interesting mixture of brownies and grapes, earthy notes, some plums, and more.  The hopping is really what makes that beer.  Citrusy and lemony hops create a sharp contrast with the brown ale elements of the beer.  I will always remember when I had it at the Vermont Brewers Fest 2006 when they served it processed through an invention that dwarfs any of Thomas Edison creations. Behold the Hop-Inducer thingy! (basically a big 3 feet-tall tube full of hops where they pour the beer on top and gather it at the bottom).  Nice.

The smell and appearance may be a bit meak, but everything else is good. The taste is smooth, refreshing, and somewhat remniscent of a downtown brown ale. So good on a hot summer day.

Pours deep brown with hints of ebony with a nice stout head that is thick, foamy, and lasting. Aroma is very uplifting and cerebral with hints of NW hops. Typical brown ale palate, but a bit thinner in conrtast to the head, which was quite large.

The taste is the biggest thing going on for this beer. Very smooth, promising, and making you want another swig. Not a sipping beer, this is best served IN THE BOTTLE or in a frosty mug. Yes, in the bottle, sometimes you just cant wait.

Bottle. Pours a thick dark body, almost stout like look with good size head that stays. Smells like a stout for the most part also some malt smell. First taste is thick and rich but smooth tasting and very drinkable. Nice hop and malt balance with a slight bitter taste. This one has really surprised me and makes me want more. Cheers!
Very smooth nice taste.  Good deep brown color.  Very considerable lack of smell.  Good blend of hops malt.  Tastes good, feels good.  Dogfish Head strikes again

Bottle, gift from a friend.  Saw the brown on the label and expected a traditional brown. Pleasantly surprised.  Rich, medium brown in color, good 1" head.  Excellent balance of smooth maltiness and biting hops.  Every sip has a different mix of brown vs. pale flavor.  Nice kick from the alcohol on the back end.  Catches up with you quick.  Slightly sweet, but lost behind the alcohol.

Dark brown pour with a small head that hit my nose with hops straight away, not what I was expecting in a brown. Lacked a but in the maltiness that I would expect, but having that amount of hops in it made it very interesting.

DFH Indian Brown is a very dark amber/brown colored ale with a thin layer of light tan head. Smell is hops and roasted malts. Good amount of bitterness on the palate especially with the coffee flavors. Slightly unbalanced burnt flavor, but brown sugar flavors are nice. Its got a nice kick to it, pretty tasty!
Pretty good for a brown - sweet, but not a candy bar in a glass.  Surprised this one is not pushed as much as Raison Dtre, at least in my area.

Deep Dark brown color, with a small bubbly tan head.  The malt and hop make themselves appearent in the aroma.  There are also hints something sweet, must be the molasses from the description.  Full bodied beer, nice hoppy nose, with a malty finish.  The finish is a bit sloppy and long.  Plenty of other flavors present to make this a pretty complex beer.  Very good.

12 oz bottle: deep mahogany color, with nice inch of tan head.  aroma is of molasses, slight hop, and plenty of malt.  Flavor has many deep elements, raisins, brown sugar, and molasses.  Hop flavor comes through, medium bodied.  The best Brown ale that I have ever had.  try it if its around

The deepest mahogany into the glass, with a nice creamy tan head, small retention and nice spiderlace.  Caramel, toffee and roasted sourness to the nose.  This, of the 3 brown ales Ive tried tonight, is by far the best.  It has a sweet caramel malt and molasses characteristic, with a nutty finish.  The malty sweetness is prevalent from the beginning throughout the end of the pull.  The alcohol is noted, especially as the finish progresses, but provides a warming richness instead of astringency, very reminiscent of a desert wine.  Nice offering here.... recommended.

Pours a rich deep mahogany red with a thin light tan head, it looks rather promising.  The aroma quite as regal.  Not unpleasant, the aroma is dominated by alcohol, caramel, and sweet malts with subtle english hops.  The mouthfeel is luxurious and creamy without being so heavy as to hold this back from being relatively sesionable.  Above all else, the flavors are unbalanced.  Sweet and malty, with rather forward alcohol, the hops are so mild mannered that one could miss them all together if ones focus was slightly amiss, or even if engaged in lively conversation.  The alcohol returns at the back end of the beer, giving this the feel of a ruby port or sherry rather than any of the beer styles this is intended to bear semblance to.  A lingering bitterness in line with those gentle hops is one of the few redeaming qualities of this brew.  A rounder or subtler malt bill with less sweetness or more robust hops could easily bring balance to this beer, but in the mean time this beer is a bit wobbly.

A translucent dark brown beer with almost no head.  The aroma and flavor are very similar.  In both, the alcohol is too overpowering, and I expected/wanted it to be heavier on the hops.  Its super sweet, with lots of caramel and raisins.  The sweetness really lingers, and this is more of a fruity sweetness.  The malt is there, especially in the aroma (but is overshadowed by alcohol).  I find myself trying (too hard) to find the malty flavours underneath everything else- in the end, both the hops and malt are a little too weak.

Bottle - thanks to HogTownHarry. Deep chestnut brown with a small tan head. Aroma is very roasty and nutty, with notes of caramel and malt. Flavour is sweet and roasty, nice malt character, notes of chocolate, nuts, brown sugar, coffee, and a subtle dry hoppiness in the finish. Another solid & unique beer from DFH.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 12 oz bottle. Pours a nice cola color. Tan head. Nutty and roasted malt aroma.  Nice malty flavor with a hop finish.  This beer has a syrupy mouthfeel that is not harsh at all. Pretty mild overall.
Dark brown color  with a beautiful tan head. Very well hidden alcohol. Real roasty flavour of burnt coffee or caramel. The finish is somewhat bitter and too much to my liking.

Holds a long-lasting, creamy, ecru head over a deep mahogany/brown body. Nutty aroma (slightly rancid) with complements of tobacco and roasted malt. Quite bitterly hopped for a beer I thought would focus on malt. Nice coffee presence. Smooth and easy-drinking for a full-bodied brew.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Events-Detail.asp?Eve Park Brewhaha, June 24, 2006<font size=-1>

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2006 Dark brown almost black with medium tannish head.  Nice buttery, malty, caramel, toffee aroma.  Has a nice traditional sweetness to it, and a nice alocholic warmth to it.  Well balanced in the hop department, as the finish is nice and bitter.  A very unique brown ale, and a very good one at that.

Deep brown with tan head.  Aroma - alcohol at first,  toffee, butter, raisins, resiny? hops.   Sweet at first then med bitterness and a little sourness, salty.  Unlike any beer Ive tasted.  Pretty good and balanced.

Really dark brown, small bubbly brownish head.  Really strong aroma of molasses, soy sauce, burnt brown sugar.  Very nice.  Medium carbonated mouthfeel.  Taste of more burnt brown sugar, dark dry bakers chocolate, and molasses.  I really didnt get any hops, which was a let down, given the description.  Really nice roasty aftertaste that lingers.  A really nice hybrid brown ale - well done Dogfish Head.

12 oz bottle, bottled on 12/02/2005: Pours dark amber brown, taste is light and sweet, hoppier than a typical brown, the high ABV is very well hidden. Pretty good brown, but there are better browns to be had.
Pours a nice reddish brown.  Aromas of toasty malts, brown sugar, and nuts.  Flavor is lightly sweet malts and a nice touch of hops, and a nutty finish.
Pours dark brown into a shaker.  Off-white microbubble head that does not subside.  Dark caramel and molasses notes.  Upfront sweet caramel with a metallic slightly hoppy finish.

On Tap-Rehoboth Brewpub-Pours a dark reddish brown color w/a medium creamy, tan head. Has a roasted, hoppy aroma. First thing you taste is hops, but they are quickly balanced by a roasted malt bitterness. Has a long sweet finish which is very satisfying. Caramel, nutty, grassy, barley, chocolate, has a lot going on-in a good way. Dont really taste the alcohol. Very enjoyable-will definately have this again.

Poured clear dark ruby red with a thin off white head. The aroma seems all malts. It smells sugary sweet along with roasted malt aroma. No hint of hop in the nose. Too bad. The taste is heavy on the malts and very light on the hops. Very much like a Scotch Ale. The finish does come with a nice even hop bitterness that cuts the sweet malt and sugars. Pretty good. Id prefer a bit more hop presence to help keep up with the dominating roasted malt flavor.

I first tried this beer at dogfish heads brewery in Delaware.  Tried it again tonight with deltamarik.  The only downside i felt was a little too much carbonation, but otherwise id gladly drink it all day.  This is another winner from dogfish.

The bastard child of a brown ale and an IPA.  All the advantages, few of the drawbacks.  If you want a pure IPA or a pure Brown ale, there are better options (Bells Two-Hearted or Rogue Hazelnut Brown come to mind), but this is the best of both worlds.  Even better, its always available.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark ruby-brown with an average size somewhat-lasting tan head. Aromas quite malty, both caramel and roasted, with some fruit, chocolate and faint hops. Flavour starts a little thin but has a big malty middle along with some chocolate and a  big finish of hops and alcohol. Medium bodied. Brown Ales dont usually do much for me but this is pretty good.

Light brown with a good amount of red shining through. Medium sized head with little retention but a good deal of thin lacing.

Heavily roasted malt and chocolately peanut butter are big in the nose from the start. Slight smell of alcohol and dark fruits.

Huge roasted malt taste. Slightly nutty and followed by sweet chocolate.

Very smooth feel with good carbonation and loads of creamy waves.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2006 Mixed results on this one, rating represents better experiences, although not the "best." Normally pours with an unimpressive head and with a deep brown color (some red when held to light). Aroma was slightly nutty and smoky. Flavor was coffee, chocolate, somewhat nutty with a grainy mouthfeel. As it warms the smokey peat flavors of the scottish ale influences come out and in the worst cases start to dominate the beer too much and overrun the hops. Thick malty base overall. The beer finished with a bit of hops, somewhat dry, except for when the peat malts overrun this thing. A litle too much sweetness in the aftertaste.
Bottle.  Dark brown color.  Roasted flavor, with malt and caramel.  Slight chocolate and nutty flavor as well.  Alltogether pretty decent brew, something I wouldnt mind having again.

Bottle--Poured a dark brown color with a tiny brown head that disappeared completely.  The aroma was filled with roast, malts and some caramel.  The taste was mostly malty caramel with some chewy feel.

Aroma: Nice with a molasses and raisins.  Some underlying fruit aroma.

Apperance: Crystal clear with a dark brown ruby color.

Flavor: A well balanced beer with the bitterness up front and nice sweet finish.  There are chocolate notes and light molasses.

Palate: Medium to low carbonation.  A nice medium bodied finish.

Overall: Dogfish doesnt make a mediocre beer.  This is a real good beer, but not outstanding.  Well balanced and well hopped.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 Julios Spring Beer Festival. Pour of clear deep mahogany, ringed with a slick of off-white. Aroma is a rich creamy nondescript malt, with a touch of chocolate and light earth. Flavor is a powerful blast of dark chocolate mingled with an woody oak of musty bark. Theres a good nutty quality, with plenty of hazlenut, light roasted peanuts and a touch of cherried chesnuts. Excellent for the style, with a light sweet hop sugar resin finish and smack, creating good balance.RERATE: 12 Oz Bottle. Aroma slightly unimpressive and lack much depth, beside a wisping of chocolatish malt. Flavor is impressive for me, lots of bright candied ginger, roasted chocolate edges, mexican moles and toasted nuts and seeds. Complexity and warmth I didnt really remember or expect. A touch of crisp lemony hops bring calming balance. This is actually the best example of a DFH beer I can remember.  A brown ale that wins. Surprising.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2007 I wonder, as my breadth and depth of experience in beer drinking continues to flourish, which direction my tastes will move.  On one extreme is the minimalist Japanese Zen approach where architecture to food should be presented simply, but beautifully.  If it were a beer, it should have a clean, minimal palate of flavors.  But, those flavors should be of the highest and finest quality.  Opposite is what I term, and Im sure what scholars would shun, the complex and dramatic Baroque.  Painters like Nicolas Poussin or the sculptor Gian Bernini found beauty in the dramatic, the passionate and the peak of the moment.  In a beer Baroque would be tantamount to unsettlingly deep and complex symphonies of flavors, coupled with indescribable colors and admirably bountiful aromas.  At the moment I eschew the former, firmly embracing the school of thought that instructs the deeper the beer, the finer the beer.  And on most occasions I agree, but some brews are too crowded, too collided and too well crafted.  Perched on some breezy Belgian hill there is a man or a woman who sits on their sunlit porch over looking the hazy valleys and fields and identifies a beers components, flavors, and even brewer.  But Im just an avid consumer.  There is a possibility that the simple and simply good beer will come to represent my beer preferences.  The Dogfish head Indian Brown Ale is the one that started all this ruminating on lifes complexity, and for good reason.  It really is a simple beer, as brown ales usually are whether or not they have Indian preceding their title.  This brown ale in particular had a deep, shaded and rust color body that adumbrated the taste to come.  The head sat smugly on top of the beer, neither growing nor fading, but content to sit atop its magisterial throne of beer without care.  From this floating disc of bubbled brew came a delicious blend of flavors whose members included hazelnut, caramel, dark chocolate, soy sauce and the unmistakable weighty textured aroma of heavy cream.  And within the beer itself was a light though thorough maltiness which had me doubting the labels veracity.  It was a self-satisfying taste, with a calmness altogether like a brown ale, but with more flavor like a port.  Whether my beerological cupidity goes one way or another, to the Spartan brew or to the ornately flavored Baroque I cannot say, but this Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale has at least opened possibilities for the Zen side of beer.

Bottle:  dark cream head that doesnt last long.  no lace going down.  Dark brown  with no red color.  It tastes as described, mostly scotch ale, with American pale, and a little extra hops, but not at the back-end aftertaste, that is slightly sour. can taste a little of the alcohol burn at the back of the throat.

12-ounce bottle. Pours a very dark brown with little glints of amber against the light; has a small off-white head that disappears. Clean dark sweet malt fragrance on the nose, followed by more of the same on the tongue. Some toffee and good roast balance the palate. Good medium body with light-to-medium bubbles. Very sessionable beer, with plenty of subtle complexity for the style.

Bottle (12oz).  Poured bright clear deep ruby with an average creamy-rocky tan head.  A pleasing dry roast nutty caramel malt aroma, with yeast, mild chocolate and dry herbal earthy hops - heck, Ive had porters less roasty than this.  Taste is even earthier, some coffee joins the chocolate, light molasses roast caramel malt with what seemed like oatmeal softening it.  Pretty solid body for a brown, a little sticky, finishes quickly, mostly malt-sweet but enough herbal hop to keep it from being like a soda.  Excellent brown - and browns usually disappoint me.

<!-- i -->Bottled on 01/31/06<!-- /i -->.  Pours a clear brown with a small beige head.  Aroma of coffee, peat, roasted malts, nuts, tiny bit of brown sugar.  Peat very apparent throughout flavor, coffee as well.  Moderate bitterness thoughout, dry finish.  Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.  Hoppier than most browns.  Pretty good!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours dark brown with nice tan head.  Very toasty aroma - lots of grains and some chocolate.  Medium bodied with light carbonation.  Toasted malt flavor that has a hint of coffee, but mainly hearty grains.  There is a bit of hop bitterness and spice to the finish.  Overall a very nice beer.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a dark ruby with a large, frothy, off-white head.  Nice clarity.  Mild aroma of fresh, quality coffee.  Moderate hoppiness and some lemon rind.  The brown sugar is there like the lable says, and maybe some amaretto too.  Initial flavor was sweet, but then the bitter jumped right in and kicked its ass off my taste buds.  A long, refreshing bitter finish.  Good beer, but I would have called it a porter if I didnt know better.

Dark ruby body with an off white head.... it was very bubbly!  Sweet aroma of caramel and brown sugar.  Taste was rather sweet too.  I didnt really get either a brown ale taste, nor anything Indian(IPA).  Hoppy finish, just not like an IPA.  I was very surprised at the sweetness, but as I drank it, I enjoyed it more and more.  Different to say the least, but it was a good beer.

Bottle, pours dark amber/brown, decent head and lace.
Chocolate, coffee and carmel all come thru.
A bit too scotchy for me however.

Bottle 44F Tulip Glass.  Aroma of Caramel, dark malts,  Slightly sour citrus aroma from the hops.  Slight tan head that fades quickly.  Dark amber to smoked ruby color very opaque.  Swiss chocolates filled with caramel, balanced by great floral notes of pine.  Good full mouth feel.  A very relaxing beer, the hops and malts combine with the alcohol to provide a very nice warming sensation.   A nice and very enjoyable brew.
Never ever disappointed with this brewery. Good, not great effort. Everything about this brew was average, as far as Dog fish goes.
Draft.  Pours a clear brown color with an ivory head.  Nutty, caramel aroma.  Flavor if nutty and malty with caramel and chocolate notes.  Clean finish.

bottle ..ruby to brown pour ,good tan head. aroma of coffee and roasted malts. sweet flavors of coffee , chocolate and brown sugar . smooth and creamy maybe a little thin . more of a porter i think..  but i liked it
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 On draft at just Sports with Stegosaurus. Pours dark amberwith an off-white head. Aroma of roast, nuts, and caramel. Flavor is roast, nuts, caramel, and bitter.

Much better than I expected!  Aromas are yummy of brown sugar, toffee, caramel and a hint of chocolate.  Maybe some dark fruit tones as well.  Pour is brown with a smallish head.  Flavor is pretty close to the aroma with the exception that the chocolatey flavor comes through a little stronger and there is a slight spiciness that I didnt pick up on in the nose.  Wonderfully blended together.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The aroma has coffee, toasted malt, and chocolate. The appearance is brown with a medium head. The flavor has plenty of alcohol with coffee, brown sugar, and toasted bread. The palate is average. The aftertaste is mildly bitter. This beer reminds me more of a porter than a brown ale.

Pours a dark brownish-amber color with a thin tan head.  Sweet, roasted malts on the aroma with coffee, molasses, and caramel.  Flavor is the same with a small hint of alcohol warming to finish.  Better then I was expecting on this one, very delicious.

Deep brown with red highlights; yellow-brown, huge head. Exploding coffee nose, roasted beans, hints of hop trying to creep out, and definitely some brown cookies. Mellow coffee taste, sweet molasses, some chocolate; finishing in roasted tones. Very creamy, near cloying MF. Discreet but nice coffeeish ale.

Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  Aroma of brown sugar and raw grains.  Flavor is pretty much the same.  Strong brown sugar and molasses, but without much sweetness.  Mossy and spicy.  Nutty and cherry flavors as well.  Hop bitterness comes in the back.  Not hugely powerful, but a good bit of it.  A bit overcarbonated, along with a grainy texture takes big points off for the palate.  A valiant effort to make something interesting out of a boring style.

This brown ale pours a cola color with red hints.  Its fragrance is sweet caramel and overripe dark fruit.    It has a medium head that disippates quickly  and settles around the outside of the glass.  First taste offers a surprise.  A hint of Irish cream is evident and the taste of alcohol prevails.  The feel of this  beer in the mouth is rich and creamy.  Very nice.  This was really a super beer.  I kept waiting for a dropoff in the finish but it remained consistent.

12 oz bottle.  Clear ruby-brown with a dirty tan head that sputters as it settles.  Woody-earthy with hints of sweetness; Bit-O-Honey.  Odd stuff; burnt latte with a pickle chaser.  This is the 3rd beer (Ommegang & 3 Philosophers) that I got from Total Wine in Claymont, DE that didnt seem as good as others rated.  I had liked the 3-P in a previous tasting.  Hmmm.
dark brown. malty smelling. taste roasty and a little nutty. good slow sipper.

Pours clear and sparkling with a brown color and and a rusty orange tint.  Faily small off-white head that surprisingly diminishes quickly.  Nose is wonderful, full of brown sugar, chocolate malt, even a little coffee roastiness.  Taste is good, but nothing of the nose; Not as sweet as I thought it would be, with chocolate taking over with the "Scotch" peat flavor emerging and a nutty character and hop bitterness very subdued.  The body is medium to light with a very lively palate and a little watery.  Maybe a little too much carbonation which may have contributed to the slight wateriness.  Finishes nice, dry and bittersweet with  chocolate and hops.  Hops were not as prominent as I thought by the description; more like a scotch ale and an American porter.  Like no other beer Ive had; good, but not great but for sure interesting.

Bottle  Pours a clear brown with a small deminishing light brown head, which laces quite nicely.  Has a very nice malty aroma of carmel, molasses, and hints of brown sugar.  Has a good carbination and a medium body.  The texture is a little creamy.  A real good duration and a decent finish.  Has a very good mix.  This is a nice desert beer in the evening.  A good beer to help wind down a tough day.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 The first beer that I ever bought a case of.  Pours a deep, mahogany, redish brown.  Flavors of bittersweet roasted malts are prevlanet with a dry raisiny note on the long, lovely finish.  Head produced beautiful lacing on my glass.  Watchout for the alcohol, its sometimes hard to remember its in there.  Altogether enjoyable.  I was sold on my first drink.
aroma is a a mix between a tad of caramel and coffee, with maybe a hint of hops.  very dark brown colour, coffee taste, bit roast, bitter/dry aftertaste, almost a coffee type aftertaste too.

bottle. pours a very dark red with a decent off white head no lacing. aroma is nutty, smoky a little hops and even a slight coffee note. tase is incredibly smooth with flavors of vanilla coffee most dominant. very drinkable but dangerous with the fairly high abv.

Bottle.  Aroma of brown sugar,raisin and molasses.  Poures  a coffee like brown with a thin off white cap.  Flavor is good, molasses,coffee and tinge of sugar.  Palate matches well, thinly bodied with just a light stickiness that comes with the sugar.  Overall this isnt too shabby.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 12oz bottle purchased at the local Hannaford. Pours a translucent dark brown body with a thin film of light tan head. Aroma consists equally of caramel and chocolate malts and citrussy hops. Tastes like chocolate and caramel, with a good portion of citrussy hops to balance it out better than many browns. No alcohol flavor, but a hint of viscosity and warming, along with moderate carbonation. Somewhat of a sipper, though goes down easier than some beers with this abv and flavor... Wow, this is a lot better than I remember it being. A new favorite American brown!
Bottle:  One of the best brown ales I have tried.  Sweet chocolate aroma.  Full flavor of coffee, chocolate and nuts.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Dark brown and translucent. Moderate head.  Caramel malty aroma, with some molasses and some nuts, and some hops just peeking through.  Initial burst of chocolate in flavor, followed by caramel malts, and finishes with bitter coffee.  Hops can be noticed in flavor if you look, but contribute just enough to be out of the way.  Good beer.
Deep mahogony color with a meduim volume ivroy head.  Caramel, malts and nuts dominate the aroma.  Heavy coffee accents with hop backing in the flavor.  Bitter coffee ending.

Bottle poured a clear, dark brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of toasted malt, coffee, and cocoa. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, cocoa, a bit of coffee and a hint of hops in the finish.

Smells wonderful of hops and malt.  Very crisp aroma.  Poured very deep brown, nearly black, light brown head that was slow to rise but didnt stay around long enough to enjoy much of the beer.  Has a distinctive Dogfish Head taste to it.  The flavor, though robust, isnt delicious as I had hoped.  Becomes more complex as it warms.  The most likeable DFH Ive had yet.
Dark brown, thick tan head.  Aroma of caramel, nuts, and coffee.  Flavor of nuts, raisins, coffee bitterness.  Brown sugar noticeable in the finish.  Nice smooth, thick mouth feel.  A beautiful beer.

Brown sugar, and caramel aroma. Very dark brown in color, almost black, with a quickly fading tan head. Flavor is dark sugars, breads, and caramel. Absolutely amazing. There is a nice hop presence that is not overpowering, but definitely makes itself known, lingering long after youve swallowed the drink. It will beat any english brown ale, hands down. Give it a try! An exceptional beer from the boys at Dogfish Head. Two thumbs up.
great beer one of my favoirts , some nice scotchy type berral flavore, a hint of chocalte but not much ,
Dark brown without much of its off white head.  Extremely smooth and complex flavors with a delicious flavor of alcohol on the palate.  Coffe chocolate delicious.

Dark chestnut brown with quick fading off white head.  Aroma is roasted and caramel malt, some scotch and a nice hop presence.  Flavour is complex, lots of different flavours come thorough, brown sugar, molasses,  slight scotch alcohol and hops.  Nice hop finishe leaves a bitter ending.  Full thick mouthfeel.  Not like other Brown Ales due to the hoppresence.
Complex flavor (molasses, brown sugar, chocolate?) and good presence on the tongue, this is just as intricately delicious as it is tantalizingly drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2006 On Tap @ DFH Ale House in MD.

Poured dark brown with ruby highlights. Frothy light brown head. Aroma sweet, malty, sugary, and chocolate hints. Flavor a little hoppy, and sweet (sugar, molasses?), slightly roasty.  The flavors really meshed well. Mouthfeel thick and creamy. Easy and smooth to drink
pours a lovely dark brown, opaque which lets the red show when peering through this brew.  robust flavor, very slightly bitter.  nice balance of carbonation.

First off i want to say this was WAY better than i expected. bottle, pours dark dark brown with a creamy light brown head. didnt notice much of an aroma, but what i did  notice was very nice; sweet and malty with a bit of molasas. flavor was top notch; roasted malts, brown sugar, molasas, with hints of mocha and bitter chocolate. nice slightly hoppy finnish. mouth feel was Super creamy, goes down so smooth. reminds me of Shipyard Longfellow ale, but with a higher abv.

Bottle.  Brown with a red tint when held up to the light.  Medium sized head which shrinks to just a coating quickly.  Sweet chocolate aroma with hints of coffee.  Very smooth flavor.  DFH is more known for their hoppier beers but do a swell job on this brown ale.  Only negative is the slightly alcoholic taste.  A good brown ale.  Slightly below the Rogue Hazelnut Brown.

Nose: very malty, almost smells like dark toast

Appearance: Dark brown with a reddish glow, no head.

Taste:  Malty with a strong alcohol bite, mabye a bit too strong for a 7.2% beer.  I can taste only a very weak hop aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours brown with an off white head. Nutty, sweet, and moderately hoppy aroma. Flavor was interesting. Roasted malt, nuts, and raisens offset by piney bitter hops. Finish is crisp and bitter. This beer could use a little more balance...sweetness maybe. This sample struggles for identity in my opinion.  I am not sure if I would revisit. On tap maybe.

Being a fan of brown ales, this one lef tme pretty flat on first impression out of a sampler set at DFH Alehouse in Gaithersburg, MD (2/4/2006). Nice bouquet, but the taste was overly malty for what I wanted, although when pared witht he food (Jambalya) it wasnt too bad. I would have hoped for something better, but it was 5th int he five beers sampled that evening (minus the desert Worldwide Stout - 2002). Very red, would have expected something tending towards more brown given the ingredients and name.

12 oz bottle, bottled on 9-26-05.
Clear iced coffee brown, with a 2" reddish tan head Aroma is light, malty, toasty,coffee,caramel.
Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, watered down coffee. 
long coffee like finish. nice

This is amighty big beer for being a brown. Admirably, Dogfish makes this so smooth, you wouldnt know it. Lovely aroma, toasty with hints of chicory. Pours a dark dark mahogany with a nice cream head. Taste is roasty with more of that chicory. Finish is smooth, body is bigger than most browns. I enjoyed this brown from DFH, they dont disappoint.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2006 Pours midnight brown w/ medium semi creamy froth. Aroma is malty w/ slight brown sugar. Medium to full nectar w/ mellow residual effers.  Flavors are fruity w/ a malty backbone. Cocoa, brown sugar, roasted coffee bean, slight leather. Alcohol  is well hidden. Finish is long with a mellow asprin bitterng. Overall: Its a well balanced, complex, strong ale that amazingly asprins up on the finish w/ no hop presence before hand. Highly recommended.

Nice aroma, malty.  The color is a nice transparent dark brown with a thick, long-lived beige head.  The flavor is nutty with hints of mocha.  Its very smooth and the mouthfeel is clean.  Overall another solid beer from DFH.

This is a very interesting beer, in the fact that stylistically is a cross between a Scottish ale, and an IPA. This beer has great malt character, and sweetness, from the use of caramelized brown sugar, that is balanced to some degree, with vibrant hop character. At 7.2% abv, it is a great sipping brew, and one I enjoyed while watching the ball game at the bar. Available in 6 packs that retail for $7, this is a year round brew, and one that doesnt get the attention other DFH beers gets, but one that I think should get more. 

Indian Brown Ale pours to a beautiful, bright, deep chestnut color, with a thick and creamy tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is very inviting, with lots of good sweet, malty, and nutty aroma paired with some citrus/piney hop aroma. The palate is very firm, with lots of good sweet malty, nutty, and caramel flavors, that is full on the tongue. Indian Brown Ale finishes with more good sweet and nutty malt up front, then ends with just enough citrus/piney hop bitterness to take the cloying edge off this beer. 

I really enjoyed this one. You really get lots of sweet malt character in this beer, and the hop character while very apparent, is there to cut the sweet malt character of this beer. I wont say it balances, as this beer is more malty than hoppy, but make no mistake, you can smell and taste hops in this beer as well. I like the fact that you get lots of malt and lots of hops in this beer, and it is a great beer to sit and relax with.

Pours a dark brown from the bottle.  Nice off-white head sticks around and provides lace.  Malt and coffee dominate the aroma.  The full-body is noticable before the flavors of nutty, bitter coffee and caramel.  Creamy aftertaste followed by hop crispness is very pleasing.

Tap at RFD, Washington DC. Dark amber coloured with a large off-white head. Malty aroma with some chocolate and coffee perhaps, plus brown sugar. Medium bodied, similar elements in the taste plus lots of hops. Very good.
A really hoppy, really dark Ale, balanced malt and hop characteristics, I doubt the 50 IBU figure.  Tasty though.  And dont expect Dogfish Head to stop being hoppy.

Beautiful.  Brown balanced head that laces down the glass like grandmas doiley.  No bite or after bite or extra bitter.  Just a nice balance of sweet, nutty malt that sooths and satisfys.  My wife calls this the most social of all the dogfish samples weve had.  Well hell.....Social

Draught at Tylers in Chapel Hill, NC. Clear brown color with thin off white head. Smells mostly of artificial grape candy. Toasty, nutty flavor. Dry, but there is a hint of brown sugar flavor. Not their best offering.

this was quite a tasty brown ale...nice dark reddish brown appearance with medium head...aroma of roasted notes, caramels, and nuts....flavor is quite the same with an added cream element to it....nice creamy palate, especially for this style

Bottle. Poured a clear dark brown with an average frothy light brown head that lasted. Good roasted malt and molasses  aroma. Medium body. Good sweet nutty flavor with a light bitter finish of long duration. Good brew.

12z bottle.  Reddish brown with a thick, oliy, looking body and minimal white head.  Strong sugar in the nose.  Chocolate and cocoa.  Cola and cookies, coffee and citrus.  It has the body and effervescence of a cola.  Coffee and caramel notes.  Oily and dry.  Finish is slightly sour with an alcohol burn.
Another well made beer from Dogfish Head.  A roasty flavor that finished better than it started.

Rating #2000.  Bottle. Tan small head that quickly dissipated with sparse lacing, carbonated, transparent, and a red hue. Aroma was malty, sweet, caramel, some coffee notes, roasty, and burnt. Flavor was sweet, malty, caramel, burnt, roasty, and dry. Mouthfeel was mildly tingly and dry. Medium body.

Hey I know its not quite to style but its a very enjoyable brew for anyone willing to live a little.  More like a hoppy porter to my tastes but with a nutty character that asssures you they tried to make this some version of a brown ale.  Rich mahogany color medium sized head.  This one didnt last long.

Bottle from Steilacoom Wine and Brew. Heres a beer that is fun, although I think the discription for me would be more like a mix between a Scottish beer, and a IPA but I think it has all the roasted qualities of a Porter (not a pale)... much darker than their Chicory Stout, very good beer!

This stuff looks great.  Beautiful dark brown/red appearance with small tan head that leaves nice lacing around the glass.  Love how it looks when theres a little light passing through it.  Aroma isnt too strong, but there is something about it that turns me off.  Molasses?  At first sip, the taste comes on too sweet but after the hops come out, the finish comes together quite nicely.  A bittersweet ale that will mainly appeal to those who can enjoy a sweeter beer.

Bottle. Little to no head or lace that I noticed. Has a bown sugar, chocolat and rasin aroma. Taste is pretty much the same. Has a good bite to it. Not overpowering but its there. Leaves some bitter aftertaste in my opinion. Good beer. Just not one of my favorites.

"Wow if you had not told me this was a brown ale i never would have guessed. Taste much more like an IPA ton of hops. Pours a amber color with average head that leaves quickly and leaves nice lacing. Sweet caramel aroma. Has a dry mouthfeel. Not my kind of beer but a good beer. "

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2006 Wow, this is a great beer and one of the best beers Ive had. Aroma is good, but a little weak. Appearance is great; very dark reddish brown and tan head that has good lacing.  A steal at just under $10 a six pack.
Bottle 341ml: Appearence: dark brown color with small tan head. Aroma: Nutty and caramelly sweet. Flavor: Roasty coffee, nuts. Thank Danny.

Pour medium/dark brown with nice tan head. Nice blend of chocolate, toffee/mollasses, dark fruit and faint coffee in the aroma. Flavor is all mollasses up front, fades to dark roasted grain, raisin and cocoa, again faint coffee in the finish. Lingering vinous aftertaste. Nice oily, semi sticky mouthfeel. Well done.

12 oz brown bottle purchased from Armanettis, Mundelein, IL.  7.2 % ABV. Clear dark amber hued ale having no discernable head.  Soft carbonation.  Toffee, sweet malt aroma. Medium bodied that starts with light sweet malt, burnt caramelized sugar, raisin and toffee flavor. Finishes dry with slight malt aftertaste and burnt bitterness. Some slight metallic aftertaste as well.  This is a good drinkable sweet malt beer but some may find the burnt caramel flavor to be oppressive.

12 oz bottle:  aroma is  of caramel, malt, hints of chocolate and burnt roastedness, slightly spicy. appearance is that of brewed iced tea...little head.
sweet caramelized flavors upfront with a balancing more roassted coffee like dry finish. this is a very balanced easy drinkning beer. nice full mouth feel, smooth. spicy flowery hops.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin light tan head that quickly diminishes.

The aroma is doughy caramel and toffee with some chocolate, some spiciness comes out as it warms.

The flavor is sweet and sugary cola, some nutty malts, with a tame spicy hop finish.  The alcohol is well hidden, but warming.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied but very watery.

Overall, I didnt much care for this.  I wasnt too impressed with the flavor or mouthfeel.
A very innovative and complex example of the style.  The start is immediately sugary-sweet, but the miiddle and finish balance out the overall aim at the palate.

Looks like a pepsi or coke.  Thin tan head that goes away.  Aroma is malty, burnt popcorn kernals and dying campfire (Interesting).  Palate is medium bodied and seemingly slick.  Flavor is more subtle than one might expect having just observed its aroma.  Smokey/malty is the predominant attribute, but not necessarily overpowering.

The pour reveals a clear brown color with a medium tan head. Interesting aroma of malt, molasses and raisin. Very good flavor of rich malt, molasses, raisin, theres also mild hops and coacoa, it finishes mildly bitter and roasty. The body is mediuml and the mouthfeel is great, very creamy with a touch of dryness, the carbonation is moderate. I didnt know what to expect from this beer but Im impressed, the malt in this beer is great.
The coffee comes through loud and clear once it has some time to breathe.  realy roasty flavor.  Beautiful deep brown.  nice finish.  Lots of chocolate raisins and coffee on the nose.

Bottle.  Poured out a cola brown color with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma was heavy malt with some coffee and chocolate overtones.  The flavor was quite delicious with its nice balance of strong malt on the outset and crisp hops on the finish.  In between you get some nice brown sugar, chocolate and coffee flavors to dance on the tongue.  Pretty full bodied and outstandingly complex.  The best Ive had thus far from Dogfish Head.
Pretty malty without any head.  The taste grew on me but not one of my favorites

Small Tan Head.    Strong Malty Coffee aroma.    Rich deep chestnut color.  Interesting complex palate:  first you are hit with malt toffee, chocolate, coffee, fig then the hops hit you with the other half of the taste.  Excellent twist on a brown ale!

on tap at RFD in DC

weak, disappointing amalgam of strange flavors, like Thai keffir lime leaves.

Barely drinkable. Would never reorder.

Compared to the other Dogfish Head offerings I was a little disappointed. The appearance is quite nice with a beautiful amber color with a firm off white head that leaves a nice lace trail as the beer is finished. The aroma is a little weak, rather difficult to make out the specifics. Taste is quite smooth, Flavor of Molasses and light coffee flavor? Overall a pleasant beer.
Most like a Scotch to me. Taste was moderately hopped with some chocolate coming through, decent but not exceptional.
Short lived off-white head with a very dark cherry color. Very light aroma with a light hint of malt. Very little hop flavor to this beer, but its possibly covered by the malt flavor.

Pours a nice opaque brown, slight head.  Not much aroma.  Flavor is pleasantly  interesting, not very hoppy.
"ginger,raisinettes"??  Maybe not.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2005 So delicious.  The pour is flawless but not outstanding in anyway.  This seems to be another one of those beers where the flavors all work synergistically to make a really good tasting beer.  A very nice sweetness, nuttiness and heaviness to it.  Well balanced with a perfect amount of bitterness.  Fantastic for a flagship brew.

Pours a dark ruby brown, light tan head that lasts fairly well. Sweet malty aroma, and there is a hint of alcohol. Taste is a sweet rich caramel malt. Very lightly carbonated, and this adds to the smoothness. Very little hop flavor, and only the lightest bitterness in the finish.
A lot of sweetness and not enough drieness for me. Smuttynose Brown Dog blows this away.
dogfish head  - amazing beer - without question.  everything they put out is great.  Swet aroma - strong complex dark deep rich flavor.  And a slow lingering rich after taste - grreat beer
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Pours a dark brown with a small white head. Malty with notes of brown sugar and coffee and hazelnut.  Strong taste of alcohol.

On tap at the Map Room in Chicago. This brown ale poured with a fluffy tan head - it took a while to pour. There was a very malty sweet flavor with a slightly chalky finish. This beer tastes a lot like Loterbol Bruin (the brownest of the brown ales), but is not quite as rich.

Bottle.  Poured a deep reddish-brown with a moderate layer of toffee-colored head.  Aroma was of coffee and cereal malts, brown sugar, and toffee.  Quite sticky on the palate, with lots of sweetness in there (chocolate, molasses, and caramel), semi-fresh coffee grind, and a roasted nuttiness.  Medium-bodied, and not a whole lotta carbonation in there.  It worked well with the flavors slowly creeping through the mouth.  Nice finish of roasted barley and sweet molasses.

Light hops, malts in the nose, it was very faint though, I could hardly smell anything.  Pours brown with a faded white head.  It is hoppy at first then there is a nice roasted malt flavor.  It has a smokey aftertaste and was quite nice overall.
a very agressive brown ale.

Bottle.  Big fluffy head slow to disapate.
The dark rich looking color scared me into thinking it was a stout in hiding.  In the end result it is sure not like a brown ale but way beyond my ability to classify.  Complex.  Fist strong with lots of carmel, coffee and sweetnes but finishes hoppy but yet mild.
this beer did nothing for me...tasted a little sour,  not bitter, might have been a bad keg, but i doubt i will go back to this if i see it again

Pours a very dark brown with creamy tan tan head.  Aroma is sweet with brown sugar prominent.  Notes of maple and caramel.  Somewhat malty and hoppy.  Moderately bitter, dry finish.  Very good, complex beer.

Clear dark mahogany under a fairly stiff dark khaki head with good retention and lacing.  Aroma of toasted nuts, roasted malt (almost porter-like), pine oil and alcohol.  Sweet toffee notes on the tongue at first followed by chocolate, malt, vanilla backed up by a welcome kick of hops.  I thought the mouthfeel was just a bit thin given the flavor but the carbonation was just right and the finish was short, crisp and pleasantly bitter.  Another winner from DH.

Dark Amber color with a thick tan head.  Aroma is nutty, with a nice roasted malt character (chocolate, coffee, and caramel) along with some floral hops.  Very balanced flavor.  Lots of malts with a strong coffee taste and hints of chocolate, nuts, smoke, and caramel.  There is also a lot of hops present - spices and grassy with a bitter alcohol biting finish.  A great and complex brown ale.

A little darker than Coke to my eye. Fantastic but contradictory nose with a little hop spice mixed in with a roasted malt essence. Nice on the tongue. Reminds me favorably of Smuttynose Porter. Pretty great.

Looks like coke with a nice tan head.  Flavor is very nice but a little on the hoppy side which is a trait im starting to savor.  Chocolaty with hints of coffee.  Aroma is that of semisweet choclate.  wonderful!
A chocolatey and malty smooth beer, yet also pleasantly bitter.  Its resembles as stout when it first hits your mouth, but finishes like an IPA.  My favorite of the dogfish head so far.  Very unique.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2012 Draft at DFH-MD ale house. Clear, dark brown body with a bubbley off-white head, diminishing.  Aroma is molases, nuts and chocolate. Flavor is sweet with some roastedness. Molases, chocolate, dark fruit, toffee, nuts and a bit of coffee.

12oz bottle-pours arich light brown head and color is black with a tint of red.  Aroma is malt, dark malt with coffee notes.  Taste is dark malt, creamy, good carbonation, backed up by hops.  Builds a coffee aftertaste as I progress through the beer.  This style is not quite my taste, but well done, good occasional beer.

Pours a very dark brown ruby color with a fizzing beige head.  Aroma is malty, nutty, slightly chocolaty with a hint of smoke to it.  Taste is malty, nutty with hints of coffee,caramel,chocolate and toffee.  This beer has grown on me and I tend to like it a lot more now than before.
bottle. nice brown color, clear hoppy scent.  Not really what I was expecting... smooth and drinkable but not especially to my liking.
Bottle. Nutty, has a little bite to it. Rich mouth feel. Pretty tasty, more character and flavor than most other brown ales Ive had.High alcohol content is well masked.

Dark dark brown to black, minimal fizzy brown head.  Aroma of caramel and most strongly of coffee.  Got my mouth watering.  Flavor is of caramel malts, chocolate and coffee bitter.  A little bit of alcohol.  Dominant flavor is of a sweet cup of coffee.  Great beer.  Havent had one like this in a while.  The palate is a bit disappointing though.

Bottle.  Dark brown color (slight ruby) with a beige head.  Aroma is malty, nutty and chocolate.  The flavor is very rich.  I taste malt, chocolate, raisin, caramel, sweetness, and has a nice hop aftertaste with a slight alcohol afterburn.  Super hybrid.

Bottle. Pours a deep ruby-mahogany with a thin beige head. The aroma has chocolatey malt, a touch of raisins, some earthy hops, and general sweetness. The flavor is pleasantly complex: lots of malts, caramel sweetness, a variety of earthy tones, redwood-tasting hops, a hint of alcohol, and a nice tree-bark aftertaste. Good beer, and I definitely have to throw in some creativity points.

There is a roasted aroma.  The beer pours a rich dark brown and has a decent lasting tan head.  The flavor is initially a caramel sweet and builds to a roasted bitterness finish, with hints of brown sugar.

pours dark brown/ruby color. small quickly dissapating head. hoppy  and crisp on the first sip.  sugary caramel taste. roasted aroma. definitely not your normal brown ale, not as smooth, but still good.

Dark brown. Small, creamy, tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate, subtle hops, and some sweetness in the aroma. Same flavor with more hop presence. Medium body, very easy drinking. You could put down the 6pack without realizing it. Great session brew.

Bottled.  Very, very deep brown coloring with a small off-white head that stays around for awhile.  Big coffee notes in the aroma, with a very sweet flavor that smacked of chocolate and coffee.  Finish was moderately hoppy, providing a nice balance to all the sweetness.  Very nice.

Nice deep brown in color and translucent with ruby accents when held to light.  Icy, dark tan topping for the head.  Aroma is charming as usual, with brown sugar, whole wheat honey bread dough, Coca Cola, chocolatey roasted pecans and scores of silent black licorice.  Prevailing sweetness of caramel, chocolate and licorice register first in the flavor department.  A peppered trait curtails the nutty positioning of brazed pecans.  Potentially rye and beet sugar added for additional nuances.  Pecans are most relevant in the follow through.  Borderline syrupy, with hops providing the sprits in place of forced carbonation.  Finishes like liquefied brown sugar and melted Rolos.
Sweet and malty nose, slightly sweet, warm and round mouth feel, caramels and burnt sugar (though its not too sweet).  Hops evident but not dominant.  Nice bitterness though.

Sweet malty caramel aroma. Dark body color with decent tan head. Flavor has a malt sweetness, balanced by the hops and some spicy flavor as well. Felt a malty molasses taste on the palate, if that wouldnt of been there this would of been a 4.

This is what i like to see when i look for the best brown ales, rogues #1 brown ale should take notes, this is a dark ruby colour, some lacing, lacking head, but who cares..good pleasing smell...sweet bitterness, a winner and highly recomended if u want a solid brown brew!

Whoa -- knocked my socks off.  A lovely deep chocolate colored brown with a nutty, coffee like nose.  Taste was very sweet and hoppy presence Liberty and Warrior probably.  Brown sugar was a tad overdone, a tad sour, and the alcohol presence was noticeable, but this beer was mightly and enjoyable.  Looks, smells and tastes great -- thats all there is to it.  Another in my rotation now...
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours darker than I had expected.  Coffee, nutty, caramel and some spices in the nose.  Good aroma.  It was much roastier than I though, especially for something classified as a brown.  (Although classifying DFH isnt the easiest task.)  It wasnt as hoppy as Id have expected, but the hops were present.  It was also a little sour (not in a good way), a little malty sweet, and some caramel and brown sugar ... hmmm, just like the label says.  Funny thing is, I had this both out of the glass and straight from the bottle, and the bottle tasted a bit better.  Go figure.

A nice brown ale with plenty of hops. As mentioned in the description it has the typical flavors/aromas that you would come to expect in a decent brown ale, especially molasses, brown sugar, and caramel. But they dont mention that there is also lots of hoppy notes that make this beer truly stand out. Delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 bottle. Pours a very rich, deep, dark brown with a great tan head. The aroma is of hops and plenty of roasted barley. It goes down very smooth and the hops blend excellently with the roastiness. This is a darn good brown.

[Nov. 30, 2007]------- a tasty brew! Its full bodied with up front flavors of soy sauce, bakers chocolate, and pine. DFHs brown ale does not suffer from any of the flaws I may be weary of, given the style, but goes the extra mile by delivering a roasty, bitter, savory ale.

Sampled from bottle. Pours clear mahogany with a creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet with molasses, dark fruits and cocoa. Flavor is balanced with coffee, cocoa, special-b malt? (raisins), plums, moderate amounts of spicy, floral hops. Medium to full-bodied and moderately carbonated. Leaves you lips a little sticky. A very good brown that closely resembles a porter. Im glad it is now available in Texas so that I can put it in my rotation on occasion.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2006 Dark brown with a huge off-white head. An abundance of sweet caramel with hints of chocolate and coffee, there is also a strong presence of hops, this balance of malt and hops creates a combination that works very well. This is a fine beer, one of my new favorites.

Poursa lovely dark brown with a lasting white head. Aroma has coffee, molasses, and a good amount of hops. Sweet taste with a bitter finish. Its always nice to read a brewers description of the flavor and agree with all they said. I didnt get much ginger in the flavor but theres definitely coffee, molasses, rasins, and chocolate. A great interpretation of Brown Ale.

I was dissapointed with this beer. I absolutely love Dogfish, but I thought this beer was not up to their standard. It had a nice malty nose with hits of coffee and dark chocolet and pepper. The body was decent, but the flavor was just not there for me. I to me this was reminicent of a home brew trying to hit many different styles, but not hitting any one.

Deep and dark in the color with a big diminishing head.  Bitter dark chocolate in the nose,  roasted grain heavy in the aroma.  Semi-sweet complex flavors, caramel chocolate, malts, roasted barley.  Hops come through in the end, a coffee flavor lingers on the palate. AN interesting blend, very drinkable. Would be very nice with  roasted poultry, will seek out again during thanksgiving a great complement.

Very dark brown in the glass with nearly an inch of off-white head.  Some lacing.  Aromas are caramel, chocolate, woodsmoke and coffee, with a raisin/currant sweetness.  A tnagy, dry hop bite on the taste gives way to roast coffee, chocolate, and malt.  Dry finish.  This is a complex brew, it’s unique, and it surely deserves better than a 3.66 average rating.  There is a level of sophistication and tremendous balance that vaults this to the top of my list of browns.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2008 Sampler from bottle at Binnys, Orland Park.  Hmm. My first impression is that its more like a porter than anything else. But DFH themselves lists it as a cross of three different styles, and isnt that how porter got started?  Kind of lighter in malt body. As I might expect, it has a full load of hops, but theyre more support than for conquest. And some notes of figs and perhaps a touch of cinnamon. Delicious!

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2005 Pours with a frothy four-finger thick, amber to light brown colored head.  The beer is a brilliantly clear, ruby highlighted deep amber-brown color.  The aroma is sweet and fruity up front with notes of caramel, cherries and a bit of sweet herbal hoppiness.
