I enjoyed this brown ale. Right amount of sweetness and bite. Very good brown ale, not like anything ive had before.

This chestnut brown beer pours with a medium tan head that displays excellent retention. As it slowly fades, it leaves behind a layer of film that hints at maltiness in the beer. It also leaves more of a sheeting than a lace on the glass sides. The aroma is nutty, with a quality I can't quite pinpoint. Almost like a chocolate malted milkshake. Very little hops going on there. The flavor is strong on roasted malt, with some very evident chocolate notes. A bit of english walnut slides in as well. Alcohol is very apparent on the finish, as is strong roasted coffee notes. Very flavorful and powerful for a brown. A bit of bitterness is also there, but it seems more like coffee bitterness than hops. The sweetness seems to come from the alcohol, but there is a big malt background to back this beer.
Nice brown color with a tasty creamy head.  Good balance of hops and malt with a bit of a toasted flavor.  I'd definitely get this again.
Deep red-brown, diminishing tan head. Fully malty, solid hoppiness in both aroma and flavor. Some roast. Quite tasty.

A very aromatic brown with a beautiful color and nice creamy head.  Excellent flavor - smooth and malty - but the alcohol content adds too much of a tang to finish.  I don't understand aracauna's comments below -- the nose-tickle at the end ruins the experience.  If the brewers would cut back on the Scotch Ale factor, this would be an excellent brown.  As it is, it's not worth the price.

Very dark brown with medium lasting head.  Nice maltiness at first blush but the hops definately kick up the finish.  Hoppier than most browns which makes it score high in my book.  I was afraid that tasting it after 2 draft 90min DFH offerings that it would not register - I was surprised

Tastes like a brown with a lot of alcahol.  I was hoping this would have more body than a regular brown, but it doesn't really.  Nice creamy head.  Kind of nutty with apple tartness.  Finish is dry, and has a bit of cocoa.  I'm glad I bought a single and not the whole six pack considering the price.  The only brown I really enjoy so far is the Rogue Hazelnut.
It pours a nice creamy head, with a nose of caramel and fruit.  The taste is a hint of fruit then caramel.  Nice smooth finish.

Good stuff.
I am intrigued that they claim this is a combination of 3 styles.
I bought a "Tackle Box" sampler/variety case that Dogfish puts out and it's probably my favorite of all 4 in there.
I love Scotch ales, IPA and APA's so this is a logical fit .
The ABV is nice, don't have to drink a bunch to get your buzz on.
Brown for sure in color with a gentle lacey head and tease of alcohol vapor in the bouquet .
I'll buy more of this one i'm sure .

I was surprised at the reserved nature of this beer. Don't get me wrong, it's an excellent brown ale, but I was expecting something over the top from Dogfish Head. Actually, I guess a 7.2% brown ale is over the top, but you can't taste it. Alcohol is nowhere to be found in the aroma or flavor. The body is a nice clear rubied leather. The cream-colored head is thick and slow to subside. Nice texture. The aroma has a bit of chocolate and toffee, really malty with a slight hop bite underneath. The flavor is the same way, smooth creamy malts, a bit sweet, but the hops are present just enough to cut through the sweetness and leave this a very drinkable but still flavorful brown. The body is surprisingly thin given the alcohol content and huge maltiness of the flavor. Must be the brown sugar.

Pours a very dark brown with a hint red woven in. Distinct coffee and caramel in the nose along with some subtle fruitness. Quite complex
aroma. Medium body. This beer is more like a cross between an imperial stout, a brown and an american pale. Very long lasting coffee finish. Not really my style. If your a stout fan this one you'll probably like.

Last week I drank this beer along with a 90 Minute IPA at the Dogfish Head brew pub down in Rehobeth Beach. I am not a big fan of brown ales but I really enjoyed this one. Or maybe I enjoyed it more because I was sitting at the bar in the Dogfish Head pub? I live about an hour and 20 minutes from the place and it was the first time I had been there. It's a great place. More like I had died and gone to heaven.
I thought this was a better-than-average brown ale, but my bottle was explosively frothy so sometime soon I would like to try another sample.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 Bottle..  This beer came across like a mutt, not an IPA, not a brown ale, somewhere in between.  Forget that though, this is a tasty beer.  I was not expecting 7.2% alcohol, the flavors are rich and balanced.  Excuse me for not writing more, but Im heading to the store to buy a 6-pak of this stuff.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2005 Very good.  Great flavor, like an IPA mixed with a brown, some strong hops.  Lots of brown sugar.
Dark brown color medium tan head. Hoppy aroma. Sweet fruity malt taste with a little carbonation. Finishes hoppy with a little bitterness. nice brown

Beautiful garnet-brown, tan head and decent lacing. Sweet roasted malts, coffe and a little earthiness.  Sweet and tart, malty backbone, hops and a fascinating bitter floral finish.  Medium body, nicely carbonated.
Nice deep brown color with a tan head. Plenty of hops and malt. Very impressed with this. Had at Barley's in Knoxville, TN.
The commercial description is right on. Lots of hops, lots of malt as well. Nice looking dark brown, decent head. Malty flavor with a bitter finish. Quite good

Nice amber\brownish color with a thin head that disappears quickly.  Chocolatey, slightly fruity malt nose.  The taste is well above what I expect from a brown ale, with hints of chocolate, a good malt profile, and a nice bit of hoppiness at the end.  A damn niced beer.

Aroma is restrained but has notes of citrus, malt and chocolate. Pours a ruby brown, slight head. Very smooth. Hops linger at the end. Alcohol is nicely delivered. Awfully close to tasting like a porter. A solid brown ale, enjoyable.
More like a brown IPA than a strongly hopped brown.  Hops are strong.  Body is thin.  Dark copper.  Nice head.  Warm malty nose.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Nicely hopped.
A very dark brown ale, lots of things going on in this one. It is sweet, malty, and finished with carmel for me. Nice kick too. This is a good brew, I'll go back for more.

A good but heavy brown ale. A little to sweet for my taste, but they have done a great job creating a unique brew. Darker than a brown. Winey notes due to alcohol. These guys really make strong brews.

Bottled.  Poured a dark brown/black with barely any head.  The nose was like chocolate smoke.  The taste was like a hoppy carbonated coffee.  It was pleasant, but definately not a session beer.  Because of the thickness and alcohol content (7.2%), this beer is much better suited for the cold winter months.  I'll be sure to have some more this coming winter.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2012 Pours a dark mahognay with a decent 2cm tan head which fizzles into some nice lace after a couple minutes.  Nose is sort carmelly.  Start is kinda of malty and theres some alcohol present too, while the finish smooths out into a more caramel flavor.  The carbonation is good, and the palate is medium.  This is an interesting brew, allthough I can honestly say that I dont taste any IPA in this, like the brewers said...(6/4/7/4/15 3.6)~~~~~RE-RATE~~~~~Only took me 9 years to re-visit this beer.  16 ounce sample on tap at The Davis Beer Shoppe.  The aroma is a bit roasty with some herbal hop character.  Lightly metallic.  Decent.  Transparent cola-colored body with a medium cream-colored head with good lacing present.  Starts a little sweet with some mild chocolate hints.  Becomes toasted, lightly burnt and chewy in the middle.  More burnt tannins come in the finish later on.  A little heavy on the body, but decent.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2005 Smells roasty/malty/caramel/coffe/chocolate.Pours out a deep ruby,w/ a quick brown tinted head(yum)some lace that held on long after the beer was drank.Tastes like it smells roasty/malty/w/ some hops in there.Roasted coffe/chocolate-malt/hop balance.Very smooth on the palate(easy to drink). Another great brew from this wonderful brewery.The hops are very well intregrated.Damn good stuff!

Beautiful pour with head to match. The initial taste was a bit different, resembling a wine or fortified wine like sherry. The aftertaste was smoky and pretty good. Not bad but still not that good for a brown ale. The Samuel Smith Nut brown was much better.

This is an odd one but I liked it quite a bit. Hops and malt are quite evident in the aromas. Taste is sugary-malty hints of roasted and chocolate flavors. There  are plenty of hop flavors in there also. IMHO does not belong in the "Brown Ale" category.
I very heavy Brown Ale. Probably a little too complex of a flavor in my book.  The alcohol tends to overwhelm the hops-malts battle. Otherwise, I think it would show more promise.

Finally a brown ale with character!  I've always felt that a typical brown ale is very mild in flavor, non-descript, harmless etc.  This one sets a new standard for brown ales - finally some flavor and personality!

Big toasty head.  Aroma is toasted malt and nuts.  Color is deep brown.  Flavor is big malts with a light hoppy finish.  Not as hopy as some beers i.e. victory old horizontal or storm king.  A dam good brown ale.

very fun to drink and like most brown ales really nice and versatile.  spicy, complex, and wonderfully nalty, i've loved everything by this brewer.  well, that world wide stout is kinda out of my league

Tap.  Nearly-oqaque brown with a quickly dying head.  Somewhat flat taste and texture.  Roasted coffee, dark malts, I didn't get as much hops as I had expected.  A bit of a disappointment for me considering it came from such a well-respected brewer.

One day I had a great idea:  to combine a brown ale and an IPA . . . but Dogfish Head beat me to the punch.    Dark brown, almost black, in color with a brown head.  Luscious aroma of big malts and hops.  Flavor is of rich, chewy malts, with the hops not coming through as much as I expected.  Still, this is an excellent brown ale.
This is serious beer.  Nice malt and hop aroma as well as flavor.  Pretty big beer for a brown ale.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a dark black liquid when held up to light can be seen through showing a dark brown-red that gives little head unless agitated.  When agitated, beer gives a great off-white creamy head that quickly disapates to nothing.  Aroma is a rich, rich dark coffee-chocolate, molasses, caramel.  Flavor is a medium to strong hops giving way to a dark, rich, burned coffee finish.  Very nice.  Almost as easy to drink as it is to enjoy.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2010 Rerate Tons of chocolate, coffee, licorice in both the aroma and flavor - must have gotten a bad bottle 6.5 years ago! Excellent brown ale Original 3.4Found this to be a solid brown ale - it just did not bowl me over. Would make a good session ale. No discernible aroma; thin mouthfeel; dark copper colored appearance. Thin, tight off-white head with a bit of lacing. Decent balance of hops and malt.
Very deep brown.  Malty aroma, lots of roast and caramel. Good hopping and well balanced. I wish I could write more intelligently about this, but I'm in the middle of an argument...

Deep reddish pour, thick head formation. Strong chocolaty and roasted aromas, along with some bubble gum or gluey notes. Sweet nutty, roasted coffee and chocolate on the palate, a little sticky with a cleansing hoppiness. Pretty hearty and warming.
UPDATED: JUL 20, 2003 This is a unique and creative beer. Decent and balanced dose of both hops and malt. Taste of residual sweetness present. Good and interesting, but not spectacular.
Dark brown.  Big malty nose full of cake and nuts.  Mild coffee flavor with almond flavor.

Reddish brown hue with very little head or lacing. Roasted malt, caramel, mild coffee, smoky and perfume aroma. Grapefruit like sourness mixed with very sweet malt and brown sugar taste, nutty undertones, smokey and dry aftertaste. Dry and fizzy mouthfeel with a chalky feel. Interesting brew not really fitting any style, but still quite drinkable, grows on you.

Pretty deep brown color, rapidly diminishing head fades into almost nothing by the end of the beer.  Smells initially of brown sugar, but then the bitter malts kick in.  The taste reminds me in an odd way of Schmaltz's Alt.  There is a touch of sweetness, but then the bitter malts kick in, giving it an almost chocolate flavor.  Hops weave through this in an interesting manner.  There is also a tang in the aftertaste that is reminiscent of Guinness.  The thing that keeps this beer from getting a higher rating is that the aftertaste is completely dominated by this sour acidity.  My mouth now tastes like I did a shot of A1 steak sauce.

When first tasting this, I was rather surprised at the hoppy zing prickling my tongue. Looking at the bottle I noticed that this has a bit of IPA in it...interesting for a "brown"...but fair enough. This however grew a bit annoying as the Scotch aspect worked its way into the mix, providing a very musky malt that didn't compliment the hops as well as I would have hoped, in fact it made the hops appear as much more of a stark citrus intrusion then a complimentary addition. I must give my compliments on a reasonably decent attempt at combining all three of these very powerful flavors, it could just use a little tweaking that's all.

Dark brown, reddish almost black color.  Only a tad bit of head.  Aroma is strong of sweet malt, with the carmel scent much like a scottish ale.  Flavor is nicely hopped, yet has a good balace of hops.  Nothing to distinctive about this, but damn good tho.

Opaque dark brown w/ light brown head. Burnt, caramelized sugar aroma w/ nuts & grapefruit coming through. Firm, full body. Very roasty, burnt toffee & nougat-like flavours. Some nuttiness & leafy hoppiness as well. Unique beer.

Dark brown/black color with a slight tint of purple.  Big white head.  The aroma is of smoked malts and coffee.  The flavor follows the aroma with a little sweetness.  The finish is kind of funky.  Strong caramel, coffee, chocolate flavors.  A delicious and very good offering.

Bottle:  I was suprised that I didn't rate this, as I have had it in the fridge for awhile now.  Brown in color with a tinge of red to it.  Fairly decent head on it.  The aroma is a wonderful mix of hops and the malts.  Taste has a bit of chocolate to it.  A very interesting brown ale, but a most welcome one!

Pours a nice deep brown with a hint of red. Nice malty sweet nose with a hint of coca and spice. The body seemed like a richer Newcastle. Very smooth and sweet and malty. Finishes well and is definitely trying.

Pours a nice ruby brown with surprisingly good head retention for a bottled ale. The flavor is very well balanced with the Liberty & Goldings hops giving just the right bitterness around the edges of the sweetness provided by the brown sugar and malt. I drove for two hours to buy this and it was well worth the trip.

bottle:  aroma was that of carmal, smoke, ginger and spices.  Appearance was bold brown with lots of carbonation.  flavor was very robust-full of carmal,chocolate, and roasted malts-very thick/full bodied.  one of the better brown ales i have had(not much of a brown ale fan)

Looked great. Smelled great. Started off with great hop flavors then my tongue got wrapped in caramel syrup. Its disappointing that these Dogfish Head brown ale's look so promising in the glass and smell so fantastic, then once in the mouth, they nauseate you with sweetness. Back off the caramel guys!

(bottled).  Bright mahogany with frothy white head.  Vinuous, malty aroma.  Medium-full bodied with strong malt and caramel overtones.  Assertive bitterness balances the maltiness perfectly and persists long into the finish with a spiciness that's either alcohol or hops.  Strongly recommended!
Great tasting Ale! Not the best Dogfish beer I've had but a tasty treat indeed. Good nutty taste with the right amount of bitterness.
Indian brown has a malt/raisin aroma and a big chocolate malt flavor. Another great beer from Dogfish Head.

a great beer (especially to get the crappy taste of that Stone IPA out of my mouth).  nice malty coffey-ee, chocolately aroma that was a good precursor to the actual taste.  now i don't like coffey (i love the smell but hate the taste), but i like this beer.  wicked gwood stuff.

coffe color with good head. coco coffee malty aroma. chocolate, citrus, nutty, malty taste. tingley, bitter and acoholic palate. this is a great tasting beer that doesn't have too many different flavors going on at once. Highly recomended.

Medium to dark amber in color. Pours a thick light tan head. Pleasantly malty and bitter at the same time, but the flavor is short lived. Finish is almost clean, but with a lingering bitterness at the back of my throat
A very nice darker ale. I did not feel the alcohol either.  Definitely worth trying.

Pours out very dark brown with a nice long lasting tan head. The nose is full of roasted malt. More roasted malt taste than I expected from a brown ale, but there is also a nice sweetness coming through from the brown sugar. The ABV is surprisingly high on this, because the alcohol is not noticed at all. A nice unique brown ale

Pours very dark brown, with a full tan head(it looks like a porter).  Exhibits a rich smell of both hops and malt.  Starts out hoppy(slightly bitter), goes down smooth and leaves a dry roasted malt(subtley nutty) aftertaste with a touch of lingering hops.  Exactly the unique spin that I have come to expect from Dogfish.
Dark as a porter.  Roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate nose.  Medium-bodied, with a well rounded hoppy taste and a nutty aftertaste.  7.2 abv?  You won't notice it.

Rich clear mahogony color with a tan head. Somewhat sweet nutty and hoppy aroma. Smooth, rich, and roasted, the flavor is of caramel and some nuts. Initial malty sweetness tapers to a pleasantly bitter roasted nutty finish.

This beer pours very dark brown with moderate head that quickly disappears.  The aroma is of hops with slightly malty undertones and hints of alcohol.  Extremely smooth taste and very easy to drink.  Hints of nuts in the flavor.  Very good brown ale.
A very unique beer, dark brown in color hoppy with moderate bitterness and a hint of chocolate, well done and worth drinking!
As usual another very good Dogfish Head brew.  So far haven't found one i didn't like.  Wonderful sweet aroma, nice roasted nut and chocolate flavor.  This is so smooth and enjoyable!

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2003 This is really a mix.
All the flavours collecting together. A smoky aftertaste is really dominating, and this is a fine allround ale.

Not quite a brown ale as advertised. Aroma is malty and slightly smokey. Appeareance is brown, are you surprised? Flavor has a hint of malt and chocolate with a sour and slightly hoppy flavor. A good beer but not quite as flavorful as the Raison D'Etre.
Nicely hopped, smoked flavor. An interesting brew. I liked it. It was a mix of an IPA, Brown ale, and a pale ale.
very rich,thick dark brown ale with a robust flavor with hints of roasted nuts. a great beer for a cold rainy day
Roasted malts and chocolate, although this beer had a strange sour astringency to it.  Some good brown ale characteristics but not many.  On the same level as their pale ale.
Mahogany color with a small tan fizzy head. Smells like sweet fruit and alcohol. Taste carmel, alcohol and earthy.
Poured a dark brown with a light tan frothy head. A nutty and malty aroma. A little metallic that is not at all enjoyable. A nuttiness with rich malts and little sour grape flavor.
Dark brown, not much of a head.  Roasted malt with a little alcohol in the nose.  Well hopped with a little bit of smoke and bitter chocolate.  Good body.  Dry coffee aftertaste.
Dark brown with just a tinge of red, light tan head.  Mostly coffee in the nose.  Body is quite bitter with coffee notes.  Nice hops at the finish.  Long.  Good beer, nice brown.
A nice, smooth brown ale that hides the alcohol very well. Be careful with this one! it creeps up on you.
Heavy malts in the front and end, and fairly representative of DFH.  More balance and less malts would have smoothed this ale out.
(bottle) Strong, rich, and yummy. It looked like a red ale to me, and was very nice to taste.

Dark reddish brown, like an old brick.  Nose is all malt, some raosted chocolate, some burnt woody caramel-like, and some sweet as mollasses.  The smoky flavor was first to be noticed, quickly followed by  chocolater and coffee bean. Even though this was very sweet, there was still a very harsh flavor that detracted from my enjoyment.  Light dryness at the end.
Different from what I expected (but then what should I expect from DFH) Very deep brown. Roasted malt flavors, hints of sweetness along with a definate hops kick.
Deep mahogany to black body, miniscule tan head that quickly dissipates.  Sweet aroma of caramel and coffee.  It initially tastes of malt and coffee, then the hops kick in at the finish.  Enjoyable.

As far as appearance goes, you could easily confuse this for a stout. Nearly black but a deep garnet red shows through when held to a light. Off-white, creamy head. Intricate lacing. Roasted coffee aroma and maybe a hint of citrusy sourness. Velvety smooth mouthfeel. Delicate but vigorous carbonation. Brown-sugary malts up front with a rising hint of dark chocolate. Alcohol is ever-so-slightly apparent. The hops assert themselves quite well in the finish.

By the name, I anticipated a little more hops than I found here.  Definitely different.  Lots more carbonation and roasted tones than found in most brown ales.  The hops merely counterbalance the maltiness.  This is a very queching beer, and well worth a try.
This is a unique and, IMHO, most excellent brew. It is, indeed, different. I've never had anything quite like it and that may put some off...but I find it delicious and quite drinkable. Very good.

This is an interesting taste, but not surprising coming from dogfish head. There is a chocolate taste and a little java hint. The sweet bitter taste was very welcome. It was a good topper to the evening of good eats and better beer.
Dark brown color, thick head, and a sweet caramel aroma.  Sweet roasted malts and bitter hops flavor make this beer unique.

Cocoa, caramel, faint roastiness and darkly sweet malt in the aroma.  Dark red-brown in color, filtered.  Roasty, toasty malt, breadiness, slightly burnt brown sugar, earthy coffee grounds and a healthy dosage of hop bitterness and spice all enter the picture at once.  Finish is bittersweet and body is medium-full, surprisingly light and carbonated on the palate.  Different and tasty.

Stunning clarity in this copper body.  Aroma is spicy hops.  The malt is rich and complex: lots of Scottish peat, smoke, hop spice and a little fruit.  This is excellent beer.  The problem is that it should be compared to Scottish Ale rather than Brown Ale--it's so damned rich, other browns wouldn't have a chance.  Wow.  Funny, but this reminds me of a really good Doppelbock.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2005 When I think "dogfish head", I think IPA, and this brown definately has roots of an IPA, very hoppy, but unique... it kinda grows on you! The brown sugar / molasses aroma is very nice!

Wow, a great deal of complxity.  Goregeous lace, a tan tight head, very deep mahogany color.  Well roasted and nutty nose with hints of toffee.  Very nutty flavor, followed by a well balanced, long drawn out finish.  Hints of sweet milk chocolate and plenty of caramel.  Only hints of the 7.2 %.  Velvety soft, nice and roastey palate among the well hopped finish.  Great balance, lots of complexity, awesome brew.
This beer has great color and a very nice flavor. It's similar to a nut brown ale but you can also detect the Scotch Ale, IPA and APA styles. Good quality beer.

I think that this could still be considered a true brown ale- it still has lots of characteristics ofo a brown.  Dark brown color with a off white/beige head.  Great aroma of hops and nutty malts.  Loaded with flavor.

Beautiful caramel colored beer with a thick and creamy head.  A very sweet beer.  Almost tasted like a light version of the Dogfish World Wide Stout.  A good beer to share with a friend but not the type that you would have 3 in one sitting.

Mellow, but with a hoppy bite. Very full mouthfeel and nice color. Head does not apply to this review since I had it at the Real Ale Festival in Chicago. Does not come as alive as well as some other ales do at cellar temp.

Dark brown color with a creamy off white head.  Appetizing roasted, sweet, caramel malts.  There is a layer of hops underneath the sweetness as this warms.  The first sip is sweet then the bitterness comes forward and stays there.  A dry finish. Very strong alcohol aroma last 1/4 of the beer. A good brown.  Of my mix six of Dogfish(RaisonD'etre, Pale ale, and this brown) the brown is the best, but none of them are worth the $10/six.

Beautiful brown colour with a nice beige head and decent lacing. Very good sweetish aroma with caramel and hints of coffee. Flavour is initially quite sweet and malty. Smooth, but maybe not perfectly balanced palate. The mix of styles results in an interesting, medium bitter finish.

Deep ruby red body with a thin tan head. Nice lacing.
Smells malty with lots of coffee notes. Very grainy smell.
Malty taste. Slight hop astrigency with a nice, warm finish. Hops do become apparent in the aftertaste. Noble variety?
Smooth, full-bodied ale. Reminds me of the body of a porter.

The roasted malt and coffee overtones hit me pretty strong in the nose. The brownish off white head lasts quite awhile and laces down the glass. Color comes in dark brown with a bit of thinning around the edges. This has a very mellow taste...a hint of roasted dark malt, backed up by a tease of orange citrus. The hops are hardly there. This is a nicely balanced beer that goes down pretty easy.

2/14/03:  bottle.  nice rocky, tan head.  good amount of lacing.  deep dark brown color- full bodied.  malty nose with notes of hops.  wonderful, dark malt flavor with aftertastes of hops.  tones of caramel and coffee also come through.  a tiny bit bitter.  remarkably designed brew which includes a superb presentation (excellent label.)  i will definitely drink this one again.
Good god was this a amazing brew.  A brown IPA tast that was underscored with appropriate levels of intense hops and caramel notes.  OVerevall a phenomenal brew.

This was a refreshing surprise in many ways.  It is a very drinkable beer from Dogfish Head.  Not a single bottle that packs the kick of a six-pack, like Raison d'extra, nor a beer that you could right a masters thesis about, like World Wide Stout.  Just a really good, really drinkable beer.  Also, an American India Ale that is not so hopped that it coats your gums, or hopped to the max with orange, pine, and grapefruit with pacific north west varieties.  It  greats you with a dark reddish brown pour, almost clear, little head.  The nose says sweet malt and hops.  The mouth is a little thin.  The taste is nicely balanced between sweetness, malt, and classic floral European hops in moderation.  If the ABV were lower this would be an easy drinking session beer.  As it is, it is a really plesant brew.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2003 WOw. Dogfish in Dan Siego, I never could have guessed or imagined, great though,  Very hoppy, but mostly towards the end.  Great  mixture of the carmel and Choco. great beer, great beer.

a fine brew as expected from DoggyFishy. I am yet again pleased. Prefer Raison or Immort, but its hard to beat a stout. Pours easy and sips well. a good smoking drink. a nice sweet stout taste with a bit of hops in the background an ingenious design yet again

Deep ruby brown color with a big mocha head. Sweet caramel and light coffee nose. Complex flavors: a little chocolate, a hint of coffee and a touch of burnt sugar. A nice bitter sweet aftertaste. An awesome brew, but kinda pricey.

Great deep brown color with red accents topped with a medium thick to thick creamy lasting head with lots of lace.  Slightly sweet malty aroma with a slight coffee aroma and hoppy accents.  Strong malty flavor with coffee accents and a touch of alcohol.  Good coffee flavored finish.  Slightly warming, full bodied with a slight dryness.

Hmmmmm. Poured a clear ruby brown with a tannish white head. Left some nice lacing and had good head retention. Chocolate and malty aroma. Too many oddly paired flavors for me - sweetness, chocolate, malt, bubble gum, hops, and nuttiness. Bitter and chocolate aftertaste. Slightly chalky mouthfeel.
Deep brown colour with a tan head.  Mellow chocolate aroma.  Healthy hop bitterness with nice nutty toasty malt notes.  Great balance, complexity, and mouthfeel.

Pours a dark reddish color with a small but long-lasting head. Aroma is hoppy and slightly sweet. Flavor is unusually hoppy for a brown ale (at least in my humble opinion), but good, with a decent amount of malt and brown sugar in the flavor as well. Overall a very good brown ale. Would definitely have it again.

The aroma first gave off a bubblegum (Belgian yeast maybe) tone, and then a hops bitterness one. The flavor was slightly acidic, and malty sweet...different. Some kind of spice is present...similar to cinnamon!? Dark brown color with a very small, tight head.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2004 wow... my second beer from this brewery and I think I like their style.  This brew, like the other I tried, is something out the ordinary, but is reminiscent of a few styles as the description states.  Tasty goodness

This beer is dark brown (almost black) with flecks of ruby and has perfect clarity. The head is thin, cappuccino-colored and quickly dissipating. The nose is somewhat aggressive with strong hints of citrusy hops and coffee with a slight nuance of burnt grains. The medium-bodied palate also carries the strong nuance of coffee, subtle hop astringency and wonderful sweet malt, finishing well with a lovely bitter/sweet balance.
Good Strong Ale!

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, nutty, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.  Decent, but I dont like acidity of this level in a brown ale.

SMACK!!!! A roasty caramel awakening seeps from my glass...i could squeeze out the nut, caramel, malt, and floral/Golding hops out of my glass with a sponge. Distinct dark brown appearance which is magenta red in the light. Heavy head..beige in color, but lacing heavily and remaining quite creamy..probably one of my favorite things about this beer. The taste itself is pretty complex. You have something to the effect of a caramelized roasted barley effect right on the tongue...my favorite part of this...nice malty finish. Something of a nut and wood flavor dance around too..and during the drinking is when the aroma of those Goldings really become apparent. A very smooth drink, a good smack of a bite..some roastiness and chocolate hidden in there, a nice dry, but not horribly dry finish. I love the way it feels as those little bubbles and caramel base go over my tongue...Dogfish i love you!!!!! Thanks goes to akinm for donating a bottle to my drunken cause...thanks matt!

What!!!  the alcohol cant possibly be that high!  I cant taste it at all oh man this rating just went up even more.  the aroma is a little bland but it has some malty almost chocolatey notes.  this beer looks great.  rich brown color, very clear, well filtered.  a light tan and very tight head that lasts all the way to the bottom of the pint glass.  very pretty beer.  very smooth body.  flavor is a little sweet, a little toasty and rosty and as it warms up some bitterness sneaks out too.  finishes very smooth, a hint of slightly roasted grain and a little friendly bitterness leave me wanting more.  I am glad i got a six pack of this one.
A solid beer. Strong flavor, almost similar to a black and tan. The rather high alcohol content (7.2%) is well hidden. Bitter aftertaste.

Deep brown color with a rapidly diminishing head. Powerful aroma of brown sugar and burnt caramel, with a faint hop lingering in the end.
The description says well hopped but I didnt seem to notice in the flavor. Giant sugary sweet malt with a bit of spice, clean warming finish. This is one that I could drink all night long.
Has a deep amber color and a hops smell.  Taste is mildly roasted/hoppy and it finishes refreshingly bitter.  Overall I thought this was a very good beer.
UPDATED: DEC 31, 2003 Deep brown color, quickly fading head.  Huge malt flavor with a sweet flavor and aroma.  Very unique.  Ends bitter with a toffee caramel thing.

It might call itself a brown, but its not my kind of one - really weird accents of fruit candies and odd, exotic spices in addition to more usual brown ale flavors.  Too sophisticated?  Is that possible?
Re rate: 12/11/03: Even better than I remembered. Yummy. Nicely malty sweet and not overly hopped. This is a great beer and second only to Immort Ale as the best that Dogfish Head has to offer.
This is a great brown ale.  Possibly my favorite of the style.  Dark brown in color.  Tan head.  Tasted like brown sugar and malt.  Try this brew from a great brewery.

Cask.  Awesome cask pour leaves a beautiful dark red/brown colored beer with an ample off-white head.  An interesting combination of styles.  Smooth as all hell.  Nuts, caramel, soft fruit, sweet malts typical of the Scotch Ale.  However, suddenly things change and there are plenty of hops.  An interesting IPA/APA finish which comes as a shock.  Interesting and amazing.  A very nice drinking beer.
A rich brown ale with a great hop kick at the finish.   I could drink many of these and it would be my new session beer if not for the price ($9.99/six pack in OH).

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2003 This is definitely a candidate for the new American Strong catagory, certainly a cross between several styles, nutty flavors as in a nut brown, slight hoppiess in the flavors & aftertaste like an IPA, and a very strong malty tone in the nose & flavors as well, definitely a fantastic brew

Sweet smelling beer with a hoppy malt mix.  Tasting of carmel and a small sort of fruity flavor, backed with the hoppiness and malt quality I look for in a good beer.  Not really a brown ale, but oh well a good beer anyway.

ummmm, well, err, hmmmm, uh, oh! ahhhh.  (What I mean to say is, this started off interesting with a nut brown ale kind of flavor, all malty, sweet, carmel and everything, and then - ping! - hops, man, hops!  A very interesting blend!)

A well balanced beer. The malty sugary sweetness is offset by the bitter finish. Hard to detect any alcohol at all. Great deep brown color with an almost nonexistent head. Tasty and worth trying again.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2003 Re-rate:  Excellent.  It's chocolate malts have grown on me, and I think this beer is absolutely great.  Dark brown body, full-flavored with malts and cocoa.  I don't know what I was thinking earlier.  November: Very dry, like a fine champagne.  Fruity, malty and Full bodied.  Nice.

Im not very familiar with american strong ales, but this tastes very similar to the better english strongs that Fullers makes.  You can really taste the caramelized brown sugar.  This has a very nice dry hop and roasted malt finish.  Very tasty.

Deep mahogany color when held up to the light with a thin tan head that left nice lace all the way down.  Very malty with strong roasted grain/burnt caramel flavors.  Very flavorful bitterness in the finish.  I struggled to place this in a style and am glad that the commercial description does also.
Nice malty brew.  Great color.  I really like the combo of sweetness with hoppiness.

I usually find that brown ales are more aroma than flavor, and this one is no exception. Nowhere near the quality of the Rogue Nectar Brown, but not bad. Has a bit more hop to it than other Brown Ales Ive had.

Mmmm!  This stuff is very tasty.  A pleasant blend of IPA and scotch ale.  Sounds wierd, considering the opposite ends of the spectrum both beers represent.  What came together was a rich, hoppy, generally all around big beer.  A good drink worth making a staple in the fridge.  My second favorite from the brewery.
This could be my new 1 session beer.  Amazing combination of flavors.  Sweet yet hoppy, but unlike any barley wine.  A really unique brew.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 nice reddish brown with a big light tan and gleaming head that lasts throughout.. Aroma was superbly superb carmel covered nuts..brown sugar clumps..and there aint no denying it chumps!..Damn fine aroma..Good carmelly roasts turning nuttier than Squirrel turds on a autumn afternoon..malty goodness..its actually not really all that hoppy..but whateva..call it what you want..its mighty fine!! and a damn smooth and unnoticeable 7.2%..if youve ever had Rogue mogul ale..its kinda like that..shows a little hazelnut flavors at time..but definitely not as hoppy as the mogul

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2003 Alcohol in the nose, light grain.  Ruby brown hue.  Light brown head, edge lace.  Caramel, coffee mocha, medium bodied, mildly hopped, very well rounded and hard to classify.  Kinda sweet, not cloying, very drinkable and decent.
A happy hoppy beer, somewhat cloudy. Very flavorful--taste sorta like french toast.  Beer just isnt for breakfast anymore.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: This is a dank brown ale is I say so!  7.2% abv is nice. The roasted carmel flavors were nice.  This was a strange approach to a brown ale.
Does not work for me. Brown ales are not my favorite style and this spin, edging towards porter, didnt help. Color is too dark, flavor too roasty/malty. mouthfeel a bit thin.

Chestnut brown in color with a head that is too thick--yet of a nice creamy, small bubbled consistency. The aroma is subtle, carmel and malt-like. The alcohol in this beer is not detectable--great balance overall.The flavor is certainly reminiscent of a a brown ale--with an offkey malty/nuttiness and a finish that is quite bitter.
This is a great beer.  Commercial description says its a cross of beers, but the tastes of a Brown Ale with molasses would simply do.  Well hopped and not too sweet.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2004 2/11/04 Sep. 03' version: Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin light tan head.  Dry mostly Scottish peat malty aroma has some earthy notes and a touch of dried fruit.  Body is lightly sweet and becomes more musty and dry toward the finish.  Sugary caramel grapefruit flavor is prominent.  Not as good as I remembered from the first time, but still a unique and powerful brown ale.

11/6/02: Raisiny sweet aroma erupts from the deep dark brown body.  Lots of roasted coffee character in the palate.  Starts sweet on the tip of the tounge then turns sour toward the finish.  Reminds me a bit of the Calumet Dark, but just a step behind.
big nose, chocolatey and nutty.  Dark, dark burgundy with a thin swirl of white for a head.  Hop crispness at the end, definetly one of the best brown ales available.
the perfect mix of a brown ale and an IPA.  Hoppy, but dark and full of a enough flavor where the hops was the overriding feature.  Id definatly have this beer again.
An interesting "Brown Ale".  Very hoppy.  Dark color, and nice aroma.  A fine brew.
Thickhead.  Very dark brown color(obviously).  I think this is Delawares answer to very famous English Brown Ale.  Slightly sweet

interesting - has the looks of a brown ale - doesnt taste like one much though.  medium to thick body - backbone seems more brown sugary than malty though.  well hopped - but not really quite to "indian" levels... not terribly complex in flavor.  comes across like a scotch ale with a bit more bitterness too it.  enjoyable.

Fine creamy head atop a darker-than-usual nearly opaque brown surface.  Nose hints of hops, lots of caramel and nuts.  Flavor rich and I thought fairly typical of the style; like Shelter this is more restrained than most DFH products.  More hoppy than usual for the style; body seems a little light.  Good, but does not compare favorably to McNeills Slopbucket Double Brown, my favorite "strong" brown from the USA.
deep brown with thin head. malty sweet with chocolate flavors..dont detect a huge hop presence out of this one..but still quite tasty
A brown ale with a scotch ale twist and hoppy bite.  Nice, rich caramel flavor, but the alcohol was overly apparent.

Dark brown/black color, medium head. Heavily hopped, medium malts. Roasted malts with “caramelized brown sugars”. Heavily hopped, intense malt flavor. A cross between an IPA and a brown ale (Scotch Ale). It has the maltyness of a scotch ale with the hop kick of an IPA. Interesting beer. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is bitter, somewhat malty.
Brown w/ a tan head, slightly sweet and malty w/ a slight cocoa aroma. An enjoyable beer.

Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head that doesnt last long. Very sweet tasting, but the hops, malts and carbonation of this brew are in perfect balance. Very smooth and highly drinkable, the high ABV may sneak up on you.
Sweet chocolate chip muffin this morning my dear?...And how about a dash of clean hops to give some little kick...A quiet nutty smoke on your coffee?...

Big roasted malt nose very reminiscent of a porter. Dark brown pour with a nice tan head. Big malt flavor at first cut through by a nice hop bite in the middle with the roasted malt flavor lingering at the end. Very nice beer. Thanks to jayme_9874 for this one.
Carmel and very slight hoppy aroma and sweet begining. Nice hoppy finish. Very nice beer.
Excellent.  Nice big mouthfeel, but clean tasting because of the hops.  A keeper.
A delicous hybrid beer with an alcohol content that really sneaks up on you. Sweet, but not over the top.
Nice aroma, a little sweet. The high abv helps.
The first theing you smell on the beer is a slight hint of caramel.  Smooth tasting beer with no aftertaste,  good beer

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2003 (draft) Clear mahogany with tan head.  Aroma is sweet, raisin, caramel, roasty.  Taste is medium sweet, malty, light caramel, roasty.  Wet, light/medium body.  (bottle) Very dark brown body with minimal head.  Rich caramel and chocolate malty sweet aroma, a bit of bitterness at the edges.  The taste is sweet but hoppy.  Assertive maltiness (caramel/chocolate/coffee), the brown sugar is evident as well.  The sweetness diminishes at mid-taste, and some spiciness and the English hops begin to assert themselves.  Alcohol is always at the periphery and finally makes itself known in the aftertaste.  Good beer, though taste- and strength-wise it's much more a doppelbock than a brown ale.

Pitch black,nice thick foamy tan head,looks like a stout.Aroma of roasted malts,coffee,nuts.Bitter all the way through with a tangy malt and hop presence.The 7.2% ABV is quite well hidden and could be dangerous.
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2003 Weird. The nose is full of tropical fruit and metal. The palate is soft and sweet with out being cloying. Overall the beer is a bit out of wack.

8/29/02:  Root beer brown---thin head, light spotted lace...Aroma has vanilla, caramel, and some other etheral sweetness--some light roastiness appears as well...The flavor is complex--quite rich with a slight molasses tang, balanced with some malt roastiness...This has outstanding balance and a deceiving buoyancy with healthy carbonation that provides an effervescent quality to this substantial ale...A very flavorful, very interesting offering...

The 7.2% of alcohol in this beer is a hidden treasure.  A bonus of exceptional flavor is offered by this brown ale.  The head is a pillowy light brown foam that slowly dissapates into the robust caramel flavored froth.  The aroma immediately reminded me of nuts and caramel.  The taste is a very malty flavored creamy brown ale with no harsh aftertaste.  The appearance is a very rich brownish red favoring a traditional british bitter/brown ale. Smooth and creamy.  This beer would be great on a cool winters night with a hot bowl of oyster stew after an exhausting day of skiing and kicking back at the lodge.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2006 (re-rate)Deep, dark garnet. So-so head. Decent nose of sweet caramel, hint of chocolate, resin and brown sugar. The caramel and sugar mix nicely with the roasted malt. The blast of goldings balance nicely and give the beer a very clean taste. ALthough its a bit sweet, its an unique and tasty concoction. These guys rock!

Malty sweet aroma, like an English strong ale, later smelling like candy and root beer.  Dark color with golden hues around the edge, fluffy beige head, dissipating a bit too quickly.  Balanced carbonation, smooth and good texture.  The flavor was more subdued than the aroma.  Hoppy bitterness in the finish, but only mildly and very pleasant.  Some coffee and caramel hints, event a taste of smoke at the first sip.  This hides its alcohol extremely well, with only a hint of it in the aroma (reference my comment about English strong ales, which tend to wear their alcohol on their sleeve).  Enjoyable and easy drinking.
A very unique and interesting combination.  A nice malty brown ale, with an abundance of hops.  very good
It definitely has a caramel hoppy taste to it.  Its not my favorite type of ale. But its not bad either.
Deep brown color, sweet malty aroma, malty caremel flavor, I dont care for brown ale, but I love this one.

This beer has the right components, but just doesnt add up to the sum of its parts.  Maltiness is distinctly brown in character some chocolate.  Hops are assertive but sort of prevent any malt subtlety from shining through, kind of like someone ringing a bell constantly during some sort of event--distracting is the word Im looking for.  My first Dogfish Head experience.  It shows promise, but is not more than slightly above average.
UPDATED: AUG 18, 2003 A delicious, hopped-up brown ale.

American strong ale?  Yeah, ok, if there is such a thing, then this is it.  American ales of any type are not among my favorites, this one tastes about the same as most decent ones but gets points for the ABV.  As with all of DFH beers, it is a nice looking one.  Not up to Immort Ale or Raison D Etre standards.
Black color. Medium head. Funky winey aroma. Hoppy brown ale flavor. Some chocolate and bread-like notes. Like a cross between an IPA and a brown ale. Some off flavors in the finish.

I havent rated something this high in years. Slightly metallic flavor but like true love it draws you in with its good looks and intoxicating smell then you find out its whats inside that really counts.

I think this is a great brown ale. Not as filtered as some of the other more dominate browns out there. Fortunately, that means a deeper more malted body, which is fine by me. The beer begins and finishes with a nice hopped bite that is reminiscent of an ESB. This is my second Dogfish brew, and I am looking forward to the third.
A strong brown ale with a somewhat mapley taste. Pretty good overall, but not as good as the Raison D Etre.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2003 Rerate: 10/08/03 On tap at the Moan and Dove DFH festival. Starts with a Guinnes, smoother, nutty and smokier. Originaly I had this a 3.5. Great aroma that is a good mix of hops and fruit. The taste is odd, has a weird smokey, fruity, bubblegum taste that is slightly bitter. At first taste I wasnt sure what to think, but it wasnt very positive. As I finished it grew on me, and as others have alluded to I think that if I have more my opinion will continue to grow.
Very dark brew. Had a smokiness to it as some others have said. Not bad but may have to grow on me.
Nice flavor - roasty & slightly smoky.  Good complex maltiness with a moderate hop bite at the end.
Re-rate.  Now that I am working my way through a sixer of this stuff, it is really growing on me.  I think that this is definitely one of the most distinctive beers I have ever had.

Hunh.  This is funny.  No sooner does the American Strong Ale category arrive onsite, than I receive two of them via trades.  I admired the good hop action of this beer, but was not a big fan of the rest of it.  The malt is busy, more sweetly muddy than complex, though.  Very good stuff went into this beer - its just the combination thats a bit weird.  Glad I had a chance to try it though (thanks John!) - this is one interesting style category!
This is quite a good  beer if ya ask me. a strong flavor mix of hops and roasted malts and alcohol

The Goldings hops really show through in this lamentable effort from DFH.  Its seems unbalanced and I think I can see why some raters talk about bubblegum.  For a brown ale, this is not up to the usual high Dogfish standards.
Had the smell of Twizzlers. Medium-full body with soft carbonation - low head retention. Molasses, malt, and alcohol flavor.

Very unique beer, unlike anything Ive ever experienced.  Strong aroma of bubblegum, some molasses and carmalized malts.  Slightly burnt taste to it.  I was uncertain after the first few sips, but it really grew on me.
Is that bubblegum I smell?  Dark brown color.  taste is initially very sweet, with flavors of dark roasted malt, and the finish is nice with a hint of caramel.  Unique flavor, gotta hand it to em.

Large initial head, very dark for a brown ale, and an aroma which is also not fitting for a traditional brown. The palate is is thick and creamy, the middle is fruity, and the finish is very nice. I like this better than the barley wine.
Coca-Cola brown, a bit bitter, more than a bit sweet, pretty heavy. Sort of a less potent version of Victorys Storm King, perhaps?
Nice dark color, bitter flavor, nice finish.
Nice dark brown color, great taste with a excellent finish. I think it is a great beer.

This heavy (7.2% alcohol by volume) ale pours with a very dark brown color and a thin, beige head. This ale is low in carbonates and does contain some sedimentary brewing byproducts. The nose is sweet, but not as sweet Hair of the Dogs Adam beer or the Aventinus Wheat Doppelbock. Flavor is complex, with hints of coffee, licorice and even eucalyptus. This beer is most flavorful at a temperature within a few degrees below room temperature.
Nice smooth taste.  Veyr slight hint of carmel
Nice roastiness in the aroma.  Nice balnace with the hops with a slight caramel taste.  A very smooth beer.

My tastes really seem to be moving more to the dark beers.  This one was excellent.  Pleasant aroma, went down smooth, and definitly didnt taste like a 7.2% beer. From what I have seen of the Dogfish Head folks, they make good stuff.

Nice hoppy aroma. Virtually no head. Very smooth medium body that is very nice on the palate. Mildly hoppy at the start with a mildy bitter and hint of sweetness on the finish.  I dont like hoppy beers so I was suprised at how smooth this was despite the semi strong hop aroma. No hint whatsoever of the 7.2%. How do these guys manage to hide the alcohol content so well in all their beers??? Nicely balanced beer, but it lacks a distinctive flavor or rating would be higher.

A bi brown ale.  dark brown with red highlights.
very smooth, has a sweet caramel and chocolate taste.  more alcohol  than most browns . well hopped and gives off  a soft floral aroma and bittering aftertaste. however the suary nature of the brew detracts from its overall quality.

The first hoppy/spicy aromas -  I thought this would be too bitter for me. Dark porter-like color, caramel head, almost like a dark Christmas ale, but w/o the spices. Well balanced , hops do not dominate as much as Id first thought. Hints of molasses, licorice...sweet finish. Everything has already been said about this beer in prior reviews... a good flavorful brew hard to compare.
Brown, big maltiness, somewhat sweet and very round. Defies any attempt of classification. Very interesting brewery.

As others have noted, color is almost as dark as some of your lighter stouts. Very nice. Suffers a bit in the aroma...it smells, well, clean. Perhaps this is because of the high ABV for the style? The sweetness was a bit over the top for me, although it was nearly countered by the hop presence. Still, Im pretty sure Im nitpicking...in the world of browns, which some apparently do not go for, this is a more full-bodied, nearly creamy addition that satisfies. Different for the style, by a little bit, but isnt is the old sage Arbys that said that Different is good?
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Strong flavor, pretty well balanced.  A nice brown ale.
It has the sweetness of a brown ale, but packs the hop flavor and aroma I like in a IPA.  Great on draft, and a good amber color head, with a dark brown color.  A fine beer that is worth a try.

Good sweet maltiness in the flavor, reminscent of brown sugar and candy.  Nice brown color, though the most noticeable aspect is the almost complete lack of a head on this one.  Also lacks a bit in the creaminess department.  A good brown, but nothing phenomenal.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2003 Deep, I mean deep brown color, nice full beige head and sheets of lace, sweet malt nose with hints of caramel. The front sweet, maybe a bit to sweet, mild carbonation, the middle fresh, the finish a bit hop spicy. A real nice beer, but just a tad to sweet? thanks Venom.
Very good brown ale. More like strong american brown than anything else. I love the carmelized flavor and the hop presence.
Rerated - Brown sugar, sweet finish. I found it to be a bit too sweet to the point of feeling heavy.
Its beer.

Black-stout like color; Rocky head that didnt stick around to say hello; No notes for aroma?
Sweet, brown sugar to start, nice hops and very subtle nuts thankfully. The alcohol was present and warming. Again, thin palate. Damn it!
Thanks as always to the greatness of VENOM!

Re-rating after another try.  Boy have I come a long way.  Fairly well hopped.  Dark ruby color with little head.  Good hop aroma with maltiness apparent.  Burnt toffee flavors abundant.  Quite sweet with hop flavor in the background.  Quite heavy on the palate.  A good beer, but nothing incredible.
Lovely hopping on this one with the characteristic toasted barley of the other Dogfish Heads Ive had. Dry finish, very hearty. And that colour, deep red brown. A very unique product.

A dark brown going toward black color and a light head graced this ale.    The bouquet was slightly alcoholic and very fruity.   Indian Brown Ale hovered between slick and syrupy in mouthfeel.   This beer was somewhat flat on the palate and lacking signifigant flavor.     A somewhat sweet malty taste was apparent along with hints ranging from maple to caramel.
Red/brown with a light lacey head. Malty and roasty, very smooth with a hint of hops. Enjoyable, but there is better out ther.

An incredibly odd alcohol/fruity aroma started me off on the wrong foot. A moderate caramel malt flavor followed by moderate hops, but too thin and poorly balanced. Definitely an interesting experience.
A sub-par beer, even for the lame brown ale style.  Even worse when you consider its from Dogfish Head.

Deep, karo-syrup red color, with a sharp, vinuous aroma and roasted barley accents.  The taste is quite edgy, a mixture of roasted barley, brown sugar, and hops.  Quite rich with a burnt finish. A disappointment by their standards, but good nonetheless.
Rich and zingy with a warming sensation. Fairly big and somewhat strong, compared to your typical Brown Ale. Burnt-caramel sweetness exudes; almost candy-like.

Rich licorice nose with no head.Burnt is the key word here. Burnt barley. Burnt caramel. Burnt hopps? While very complex it goes a little overboared with a little bit excessive use of the Goldings.Finish is warm but with edgey bitterness.
While it is totally unique, I just couldnt get into this for some reason.  I think it was those bubblegum notes.  Where the hell did they come from?
Pretty good, with a dry bitter touch.

Wow - a great beer.  Wonderful sweet
chocolate aroma.  Malty sweet flavor, with
mod high alcohol - not unlike a doppelbock - 
but with a definite hop presence.  Very dark brown
color with reddish tint.
